webTitle: Hendry escapes police action over elbowing incident

fields.headline: Hendry escapes police action over elbowing incident
fields.trailText: Colin Hendry will not face police action over his seeming elbow assault on San Marino player Nicola Albani.
fields.body:
One of the most torrid 24 hours in the life of Scotland's captain Colin Hendry ended last night with news that police will not take action for his seeming assault on an opponent during the final seconds of the World Cup qualifier against San Marino.

Scotland's 4-0 win at Hampden Park on Wednesday, with Hendry twice on the scoresheet, was overshadowed by the captain lashing out with his elbow at the San Marino defender Nicola Albani and the player appearing to lose consciousness before being taken to hospital. The referee did not see the incident but it was caught by television cameras.

Yesterday, as Scotland's coach Craig Brown publicly supported his player and Hendry expressed his concern for his victim's welfare, San Marino officials tried to smooth troubled waters, saying they would not lodge a complaint.

A San Marino spokesperson said: "They [the players] were angry at the time. But when we came back to the hotel we were not angry any more." Albani himself said: "These things happen."

But the biggest weight off Hendry's shoulders was the decision by Strathclyde police. Asked by the Glasgow procurator fiscal if they intended to submit a report on the incident, they said: "At this time, Strathclyde Police has received no complaint from the player who was involved in the incident, nor from the Sammarinese football officials."

The procurator fiscal made the inquiry entirely on its own initiative. A spokesperson for Glasgow's Victoria Infirmary, where Albani was detained overnight, could neither confirm nor deny whether the player had lost consciousness after the incident with Hendry.

Hendry, who had scored two goals, was being manhandled seconds from the final whistle from behind in a congested San Marino penalty area as he was preparing to win the ball in the air. He lashed out with an arm, a part of which - not necessarily the elbow - made contact with Albani's throat. Within seconds, players were urging medical staff on to the pitch, fearing Albani had swallowed his tongue.

Scotland's captain was looking away from Albani, in direction of the ball, when he threw out his arm. How great the contact, and how premeditated the act, is open to question.

Albani was carried off and, by the time he reached the touchline, was sufficiently conscious to lift his head.

Hendry, back training with his club Bolton yesterday, on Wednesday night admitted it had taken four attempts to free himself of what he considered holding by Albani and San Marino's captain Luca Gobbi.

Yesterday, after a barrage of outraged headlines, most taking issue with his unrepentant attitude, Hendry issued his own statement: "There was no intent to injure the player who held on to me. I am deeply sorry if he suffered any injury, and there was no malice on my part. I was focusing on the ball, he was holding on to my shirt and I was trying to get free ... He was behind me and at the time I did not know which part of him I hit."

Brown, having seen a recording of the match - which he had not when he backed Hendry late on Wednesday - reiterated his support.

The coach said yesterday: "It was wrong, we know that, but it was not a heinous crime. He didn't take a knife out of his shorts, and didn't forearm-smash the player. I have got to stand up for my player and I think he has been vilified far too much. It's really over the top."

There are no plans to drop Hendry, strip him of the captaincy or fine him.

Because the Finnish referee Petter Kari did not see the incident, taking no action, it will presumably not appear in his match report.

The incident will be taken further only if brought up by the Fifa observer, watching from the stand, or if San Marino have a change of heart and do lodge an official complaint with Fifa.

fields.headline: Pole's sounds of technology on the blink
fields.standfirst:
Pole
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Pole
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
This is the fourth in a series of concerts put on by that champion of all things avant-garde and electronic, the magazine the Wire. There are four sets tonight: digital jazzer Burnt Friedman teams up with krautrock's polyrhythmic hero, Jaki Liebezeit of Can; bassist Jah Wobble performs with saxophonist Evan Parker; Pole offers processed dub; and all the players return for a sort of electronica superjam.

It is Pole - 34-year-old Berliner Stefan Betke - who intrigues most. A DJ-musician with three albums to his credit, he is also a producer and remixer, owns the excellent ~Scape record label, stages the ~Scape night at Berlin's WMF club, runs a music publishing company and works as a CD-mastering engineer in his own recording studio.

It was while engineering that Betke acquired his performing name and discovered an alternative approach to music-making, when he heard the sounds made by a faulty piece of analogue equipment called the Waldorf 4-Pole filter - the spits, crackles, hisses and hums of technology on the blink. And so Pole became one of a new wave of artists on the fringes of dance making rhythmically interesting music out of machine glitches. Errors and malfunctions are amplified and organised to become an integral part of the experience.

Although in his open-neck shirt he isn't visually arresting, Pole commands attention. He moves busily between his Powerbook, MiniDisc player, keyboards and mixing desk, triggering programmed effects, playing a plaintive melody with one hand while arranging the sounds live with the other. What separates Pole from his peers is his devotion to King Tubby-style dub: the way he phases between right and left speakers is an old dub trick, as is the use of reverb, sustain, echo and delay.

As the giant bass pulse thuds relentlessly, the space around it is filled with and emptied of whorls and eddies, drones and detonations. Various noise particles fly in and out of the mix, bringing to mind all manner of intergalactic weather metaphors, images of meteorite showers or dustbowls on Mars. At one point, the clang of metal against metal reverberates around the sold-out hall, and it's like we're all wearing the most advanced headphones on this or any other planet, lost together in deep dub space, picking up the distress signals of a dying star.

webTitle: Boeing pulls out of race to build superjumbo

fields.headline: Airbus wins clear skies
fields.standfirst: Boeing pulls out of race to build a superjumbo
fields.trailText: Boeing pulls out of race to build a superjumbo.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and David Gow
fields.body:
Airbus, the European aircraft maker, last night pulled off a stunning victory when Boeing, its bitter rival, threw in the towel and pulled out of the race to build new double-decker superjumbos.

The US group said it was cancelling plans for a stretch version of its 747 jet, leaving the Airbus A380 as the only superjumbo in a growing market that Boeing once derided as non-existent.

The Seattle company said that it was shelving the 747X after several years of development in favour of a new, faster mid-sized plane. The company admitted that it had found no support among its customers for the super jumbo.

Craig Martin, a company spokesman, said: "We could not find a current market, nor do we believe that there is a long-term market, for many aeroplanes bigger than the current 747."

The announcement comes as a huge fillip to Airbus, a partnership of Britain's BAe Systems and the European Aeronautic Defence and Space company. The European group has already received several orders for its new superjumbo, which will be available in 2006.

Airbus has captured 62 firm orders for the A380, a $11bn (£7.7bn) project, partly funded by European government loans, with options for a further 40. Senior executives say they are on course to have more than 100 firm orders by the end of this year, with options for up to a further 70. Boeing has won no orders for its 747X in nine contests.

The Airbus group, in which BAE Systems has a 20% stake, says it will break even on the project with orders for 250 aircraft and sees a potential market for 1,500 planes of its kind over the next 20 years. It had planned to take half of that. Now insiders expect the US planemaker to accelerate design work on the rival airliner.

"We've had nine head-to-head competitions and the score is 9-0 for us," one Airbus adviser said. "No matter how hard Boeing tried to talk up the 747X it never made economic sense," another insider said.

The A380 will create 22,000 jobs in Britain, with the wings designed, built and assembled in factories in Filton, near Bristol, and Broughton, near Chester, while Rolls-Royce in Derby will build engines.

Boeing's new plane is expected to fly at just below supersonic speeds, cutting between 15% and 20% off flight times. Mr Martin said yesterday: "This aeroplane will fly faster, higher and further than any currently available. We foresee it essentially changing the market as dramatically as introducing jets did back in the 1950s."

A feature of the prototype will be a "delta wing", which will make the plane look more like Concorde than usual commercial aircraft. Boeing said costs for the new aircraft would be much lower than those of Concorde. The engine size would allow it to fly non-stop between London and Sydney.

Wall Street analysts expected the new plane, which will be available "within the decade", to cost about $9bn to develop, much more than the $4bn 747X superjumbo.

About 10 Boeing customers have been briefed on the new plane, which could hold between 100 and 300 passengers.

In a note to investors last week, Byron Callan, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, welcomed the new plane. "It could have range of 9,000 nautical miles and would fly at higher altitudes, meaning it could avoid slower-flying aircraft in air traffic routes," he said.

Boeing's move will spell the end to a potential trade war between Europe and the US over development loans for the A380 given by the Britain and Germany. Boeing last week announced plans to move its corporate headquarters out of Seattle, home for 85 years.

fields.headline: A Doll's House
fields.standfirst:
Warehouse, Croydon
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Warehouse, Croydon
Rating: ***
fields.body:
How far does Nora collude in her own imprisonment in Ibsen's play? This interesting question is raised in Juliet Forster's thoughtful production for the Custard Factory theatre company. Forster has an approach to the play that sounds gimmicky but works very well. Ilona Macdonald and Kelvin Goodspeed play Nora and Torvald Helmer, the young couple whose relationship is built on play and fantasy, not reality or a genuine partnership. The rest of the cast are puppets. Nora's school friend, Kristen, is a doll that Nora finds in an old trunk; the money- lender is a looming shadow; most cleverly of all, the Helmers' friend Dr Rank is a comic little figure manipulated by Torvald. To him the couple say the things that they cannot say directly to each other.

The interaction between live actors and puppets is so seamless that you pretty quickly cease to make the distinction between the two. And the puppetry has an interesting psychological effect, further isolating Nora and Torvald from the real world as they retreat from their problems into play-acting.

The production made me realise just how infantile Nora and Torvald are, and how significant is the absence of their children. As the design makes clear, these are people who have not yet left the nursery and dressing-up box behind them. They hold each other back, both reluctant to take on the emotional maturity of the adult world.

The insights of the production, which is particularly good on the couple's see-sawing balance of power, are not always matched by the performances, which lack both sharpness and, in the case of Macdonald's Nora, variation. The attempt to make the play relevant to modern audiences by taking it out of its Victorian context and having Nora wear short skirts is also a mistake. The play, and Nora's crisis, arise out of the fact that 100 years ago a woman could not borrow money without the loan being guaranteed by either her husband or her father. Times change, but the play's psychological acuity holds true. All us latter-day Noras in the audience may be able to pay off our debts with plastic but we sometimes need reminding when it is time to slam the doll's house door behind us.

Until April 8. Box office: 020-8680 4060.

fields.headline: Tram
fields.standfirst:
Mean Fiddler, London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Mean Fiddler, London
Rating: **
fields.body:
"Hello there. We're Tram and we don't like football either." Not the most inspiring of introductions, but as Paul Anderson, the band's voice and swaying hips, peers at the audience, it's an apt one. Tonight Tram are up against England versus Albania and being unhappy is what they're good at. Anderson, along with drumming cohort Nick Avery, knows that heartbreak isn't glamorous, but is made more poignant by its bleak mundanity.

Here joy turns into fear and it's what's not said that's powerful, silence explored through increasingly grand soundscapes. While their debut album adhered to lo-fi sensibilities, Tram's new offering, Frequently Asked Questions, uses a larger range of instruments to express a wider set of emotions. The violin is an integral part of this vision, and it's the pretty violinist on stage who grabs the crowd's attention, as she moves to the melancholic sound, her T-shirt rising to expose some flesh.

Tram need more of this kind of appeal. As the dying waltz of Underneath the Ceiling drones on, its lyrics full of sighing resignation, the graceful moaning of the violin enlivens the suffocating sadness. Anderson hunches over his microphone and Avery, hitting the cymbal, keeps his head bent low; they're both so unassuming as to be almost invisible.

Throughout the set, Tram are as anonymous as their songs, which melt slowly into each other. There's no interaction between the band and the audience; all communication is restricted to the music. Which is fine, except these are the kind of songs best listened to at dawn, after a hedonistic night out leaves you confused and emotional. Fragile and intricate, Tram's musings make you think, not concentrate on the delicate things happening on stage.

So it takes a slight change of mood to capture the attention. The keyboards and drums come together to make a sound like rain, a closed cymbal providing a tinny sound against the sweeping melody. Then it stops, leaving only the gentle strumming of an acoustic guitar, before beginning again, a would-be soundtrack to a chase scene across some windswept moor, anxious and unrelenting. If only Tram showed such passion more often, we wouldn't be left to our own imaginations.

fields.headline: The electric sound of Hood
fields.standfirst:
Hood
Brudenell Social Club, Leeds
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Hood

Brudenell Social Club, Leeds
Rating: ****
fields.body:
The Yorkshire town of Wetherby is in the middle of nowhere, so remote that the under-the-microscope Leeds United are able to train there. The settlement is surrounded by miles of fields, woodlands and ancient railway tracks; if you stop in the fields you'll hear birds singing and the electric pylons buzzing. On a good day, when they've left their windows open, you'll hear the sounds of Hood.

Hood are, as far as I'm aware, the only band ever to come out of Wetherby. Their location underpins their music, which is impressive, sometimes breathtakingly atmospheric, and has an eerie emotional power and vast electrical charge - if the pylons formed a pop group, this would be it. Instead the big music is made by four young men in T-shirts and jeans. But Hood's nondescript appearance matters not a jot. Strategically placed bulbs project the players' shadows onto a backdrop of the Wetherby sky. It's cheap but visually stunning. Thus primed, Hood craft their spell.

They're rooted in the best leftfield music of the past 20-odd years - from Joy Division and PiL to Warp electronica - but manage to sound both timeless and individual. Sometimes it feels as though there are several bands onstage at once, such is the collage of dance grooves, jazz layers and sonic dubs. Guitarist/vocalist Chris Adams's whispered words are more a texture than a commanding voice, but the best of their rhythms and melodies are as catchy as Atomic Kitten's.

With Adams's bassist brother Richard pounding his foot into the floor, their intensity certainly sets them apart. However, they're not without sly humour. One of their songs considers sabotage of the Great North Eastern Railway so a partner can't leave. Confronted by a technical problem, Adams self-effacingly jokes that it's hardly surprising their new single, Home Is Where It Hurts, only costs a pound.

They do themselves down. Their final number mutates into an unearthly primal scream of extraordinary, priceless power. Of course, Hood pose no threat to Westlife, but they do offer a brilliant alternative to a tired mainstream. This is music of the spheres, far above the madding crowd.

Hood play the Arts Cafe, London E1 (020-7247 5681), tonight, and the Lift, Brighton (01273 776961), tomorrow.

Of course, Hood pose no threat to Westlife, but they do offer a brilliant alternative to a tired mainstream. This is music of the spheres, far above the madding crowd. Hood play the Arts Cafe, London E1 (020-7247 5681), tonight, and the Lift, Brighton (01273 776961), tomorrow.

fields.headline: RLPO/ Hirokami
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
Rating: *****
fields.body:
If Vaughan Williams ever heard Mahler's Sixth Symphony it would have been as an old man, probably in his 70s. What he might have made of it is a matter for speculation. For decades Mahler's symphonies were frowned upon in British conservatories (forcing the young Britten to study them in secret), and the Sixth went unperformed here until 1950. And yet the two composers were near-contemporaries: Vaughan Williams's early Walt Whitman setting Towards the Unknown Region was composed just one year after Mahler's Sixth.

Whitman's portrayal of the soul at the threshold of the afterlife is visionary, tingling with anticipation. The hushed expectancy of its opening in Vaughan Williams's choral setting prefaces a gradual unveiling of ecstatic spiritual liberation, exultantly performed by the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Choir. At just 12 minutes it made for a short first half, but such bold programming is welcome.

There is no such thing as a straightforward performance of Mahler's Sixth. Ambiguities remain as to the ordering of the scherzo and slow movement, and the choice of whether to include the third hammer blow in the finale rests entirely with the conductor, since Mahler only omitted it for superstitious reasons. Added to that are the broader interpretative questions: whether or not to streamline, smoothing over the painful fissures and demonic grotesqueries; and what to make of the slow movement, so often played with a luxuriant warmth that can place it light years away from the agonised tone of the rest of the symphony.

Junichi Hirokami's Mahler was a heady combination of viscerality and grace; caricatures paraded triumphantly through moods of solemnity and wistful beauty alike. His strikingly fast account of the andante moderato - played at the borders of allegretto - was revelatory. Deprived of the chance to bask in its own warmth, it became consumed with doubt, inflected with pain. Even at this brisk tempo, not a single moment was sacrificed, and the final climax has rarely sounded so heartrending.

The performance of the finale was among the most theatrical ever. Soberly ascending the stairs and lifting the gigantic hammer for the third time, the percussionist dramatically stopped short of striking the blow. It did not feel like empty melodrama; in the context of a shattering performance, this strange gesture was unexpectedly powerful.

webTitle: How to ensure pension funds are safe from fraud

fields.headline: How to make sure you're not Maxwelled
fields.standfirst:
The official report into the pension fraud committed by the late Robert Maxwell is suitably damning, but how do we make sure it doesn't happen again?
30.03.2001: Maxwell son blamed over pensions
fields.trailText: Publication of the long-awaited official report into the frauds committed by the late Robert Maxwell will have left many members of company pension schemes wondering: "Could this sort of thing ever happen again?"
fields.body:
Publication of the long-awaited official report into the frauds committed by the late Robert Maxwell will have left many members of company pension schemes wondering: "Could this sort of thing ever happen again?"

The report was commissioned in 1992 after administrators called in following the media tycoon's death discovered that more than £400m was missing from Maxwell company pension funds. It was discovered the money had been used to prop up his collapsing business empire.

It was only after a long battle that a multi-million pound deal was reached in 1995 which meant the vast majority of the 32,000 victims did not lose out financially.

TUC general secretary John Monks called today's publication "a shocking report into how workers were robbed of their pensions". It contains a number of recommendations concerning the conduct of businesses aimed at stamping out fraud.

However, those hoping for a declaration that there could never be a repeat of the debacle will be disappointed. John Hayes, chairman of pensions watchdog Opra (Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority) said today: "As the report says, no system of regulation can positively guarantee things like this will not happen again."

It would be naive to think that merely because there is greater regulation, a determined fraudster couldn't find a way to abuse the system. "But we also strongly support the view that members of pension schemes asking questions and becoming involved can help to reduce that risk," added Mr Hayes.

In the wake of the Maxwell affair, the government brought in a raft of new legislation aimed at improving people's confidence that the money they are putting aside for their retirement is being looked after properly.

The Pensions Act 1995 took something of a two-pronged approach with company pension schemes - it set up Opra to police the nation's 130,000 occupational pension schemes and make sure they are safe and well run, and it also set up a official safety net scheme to make sure that if the worst happened, people would be properly compensated and wouldn't have to wait years for payouts as happened with the Maxwell affair.

Opra, which opened for business in April 1997, investigates and takes action where there is "carelessness or negligence" that could put occupational pension schemes at risk. It has a wide range of powers including the ability to impose fines of up to £50,000 on a company and up to £5,000 on an individual; prohibit and disqualify pension scheme trustees, and appoint new trustees where necessary; referring cases to the police; and authorising criminal prosecutions.

Mr Hayes says there have been "relatively few" cases - less than 50 - where it appears fraud has been committed, and most related to events before the Pensions Act came into force. He believes the general level of corporate governance and other standards of behaviour have improved in the last few years.

But, interestingly, he takes the view that there are still a small minority of small and medium sized businesses where the employer believes, as Maxwell apparently did, that pension scheme cash "is his money". Eradicating this attitude is one of Opra's main tasks.

Sitting alongside Opra is the Pensions Compensation Board, which was explicitly described at the time of its 1997 launch as a back-up insurance for pension funds "in case there is another Maxwell".

It is funded by a levy paid by all occupational pension schemes, and to trigger a compensation payout the employer has to be insolvent and there has to have been a loss. However, it is not necessary for someone to have been convicted or even prosecuted - all it has to have is "reasonable grounds for believing there has been loss attributable to an offence involving dishonesty".

In the four years it has been going the Board has only paid out on two claims, one of which involves a Birmingham company currently at the centre of a police investigation over the alleged disappearance of pension fund cash. The Board has made a payment of around £60,000 in order to enable pensions to be paid for a period of six months, and expects to hand over more emergency cash to the scheme's trustees.

Eariler this month further measures to tighten up pension scheme security were proposed by Paul Myners, the chairman of the Gartmore fund management group and chairman of the Guardian Media Group, in his Treasury-commissioned review of institutional investment.

He recommended that pension scheme trustees should receive better training and better support from their sponsoring companies, and says that more of them should be paid for their services - something which should boost the numbers of people who put themselves forward to carry out this fairly onerous task.

He also recommended that trustees become more expert in investment rather than leaving it all to consultants. The government accepted there should be a statutory basis for the skills required by trustees involved in investment decisions. In addition, Mr Myners called for a voluntary code of practice for trustees and investment managers.

However, his government-backed recommendation that the so-called minimum funding requirement - a solvency test for pensions introduced to protect pensioners after the Maxwell debacle - be abolished in order to encourage pension funds to invest in a wider range of companies proved controversial.

The scrapping of the MFR - which Mr Myners did not believe protected pension fund members - was met with concern in parts of the City about how pension fund schemes would be protected.

fields.headline: Women macho about their jobs
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Women are adopting macho working patterns and sacrificing family lives in order to get ahead despite moves to make the workplace more family-friendly, psychologists said yesterday.
fields.body:
Women are adopting macho working patterns and sacrificing family lives in order to get ahead despite moves to make the workplace more family-friendly, psychologists said yesterday.

Although the government is increasing statutory maternity leave and many employers have polices which should allow women to achieve a better work-life balance, many women still feel they must conform to the "male" way of working. Across the corporate spectrum, successful women are working long hours and taking short maternity leaves.

Researchers Janet Smithson, of Manchester Metropolitan University, Elizabeth Stokoe, of University College Worcester, and Chris Coupland, of Birmingham University, looked at women working in banking, retail and accountancy.

"Women managers tend to talk about themselves in male terms - 'I'm still my own man' etc - and they feel they have to keep up with the hours men work, network alongside them and take as little leave. There were some women who took only two weeks off after having a baby," said Ms Smithson.

The researchers found that the concept of flexible hours was a myth. Women were expected to arrive early, leave late and go for a drink after work with their colleagues or face slipping down the career ladder.

Other research unveiled at the British Psychological Society's conference revealed that women were generally disadvantaged in interviews but still managed to perform better than men.

Jo Silvester, of City University, London, looked at the graduate recruitment programme of a petrochemical company. She discovered that men were generally allowed to talk for longer in interviews and were asked open-ended questions, which allow for lengthy responses.

Women, on the other hand, were asked closed questions and were not given so long too talk. Despite this, they performed better in face-to-face interviews than men.

"Although women were being asked more closed questions than men, they were presenting themselves better and they were more in control," said Dr Silvester.

webTitle: Beenz means signs of a downturn

fields.headline: Beenz means signs of a downturn
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The company that created a currency for the internet, Beenz.com, yesterday admitted that it had sacked 180 staff and could be sold.
fields.body:
The company that created a currency for the internet, Beenz.com, yesterday admitted that it had sacked 180 staff and could be sold.

Beenz, which raised $89m (£61m) from investors including Oracle chief Larry Ellison, said that it would cut a further 20 jobs at its British operations after a strategic review.

It would leave a company that had employed 260 people in 13 offices worldwide at the height of the dot.com boom with just 60 staff spread across five international offices.

The company rewards net users with "beenz", redeemable for goods at participating websites. Like many other online loyalty schemes it has failed to generate the revenues it hoped for, however.

A link-up with or takeover by a bricks and mortar player looks like the most likely route ahead.

"The company is in discussions with several potential strategic partners, the goal of which is to enable the long-term future and value of the beenz business," a statement said.

Beenz declined to say how much cash it had left or what revenues it is generating. There are 5.4m beenz accounts.

Charles Cohen, Beenz's founder and chief executive, warned in December that volatile stock markets had sent many of his customers out of business and he would have to scale back Beenz's international network, which stretched from London and New York to China and Japan.

At the time he denied that Beenz was going bust. "We still have tens of millions of dollars in the bank, but we don't want to be one of these dot.coms that rockets along like a train, crashes into a wall and everybody dies," he said.

Other backers include Apax, Softbank, Vivendi, Jellyworks and Monaco-based businessman Andrew Regan.

webTitle: DrKW cry freedom in face of alliance

fields.headline: DrKW cry freedom in face of alliance
fields.trailText: Senior executives at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein are to press for greater autonomy if the investment bank's Germany parent, Dresdner Bank, merges with the major insurer Allianz.
fields.body:
Senior executives at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein are to press for greater autonomy if the investment bank's Germany parent, Dresdner Bank, merges with the major insurer Allianz.

Reports from Germany suggest that Allianz will be keen to hang on to the investment bank, not least because of the benefits of its mergers and acquisitions expertise as corporate Germany restructures in the back of forthcoming tax reforms.

There are strong suggestions that DrKW - which employs some 3,500 people in London - could be established as a separate legal entity and then partially floated if the merger, now in the final stages of negotiation, goes ahead.

"For people at the bank it would be a plausible and desireable route, particularly for those at the top of the bank," according to one source. "It's probably not too far fetched," said another.

Though Allianz, which owns more than 21% of Dresdner shares, is keen to acquire the bank to gain access to its retail network through which it could distribute its range of insurance products to Germany's growing retirement savings market, it does not lack knowledge of investment banking and the opportunities on offer. Its chief financial officer Paul Achleitner joined the Munich insurer from investment bank Goldman Sachs.

Last year negotiations between Dresdner and Deutsche Bank foundered over what would happen to DrKW and after a second round of merger talks, this time between Dresdner and Commerzbank, came to nothing, the investment bank's senior managers are understood to have pressed for a greater say in the bank's future.

Industry sources say there is little comparison between a merger with Deutsche Bank and one with Allianz. There is little overlap between the bank and the insurer while over the past year Dresdner has invested almost €2bn (£1.2bn) in the investment bank - €1.5bn on buying Wasserstein Perella and €489m on retention bonuses as it sought to hang on to key staff.

Yesterday's confirmation that talks between Allianz and Dresdner over the creation of "an integrated financial services group" with a market capitalisation of £65bn has prompted a rash of speculation that other mergers or alliances could be on the way. Deutsche Bank chief executive Rolf Breur did little to dampen expectations when he acknowledged that his bank was holding exploratory talks with French insurer Axa.

"The talks with Axa are far from any concrete result. However Axa is a highly significant negotiating partner and in any Europe-wide cooperation, Axa would be a partner of considerable weight."

A Dresdner-Allianz alliance is likely to clear the way for another German "bancassurance" merger. As part of the Dresdner deal Allianz is expected to sell its stake in HypoVereinsbank to fellow insurer, Munich-Re, clearing the way for a link up between the two.

But dealers believe the action will not stop there. "There are a lot of cross [share]holdings around and that will bring new takeover speculation in the market," according to one Frankfurt share dealer.

"It is a smart move from Allianz, acquiring Dresdner, this will really change the financial environment in Germany and also in Europe," Boris Böhm, a fund manager at Nordinvest in Hamburg, said.

The spotlight has fallen on Commerzbank which has built a series of links with other European banks through equity stakes but which has been criticised for failing to build on those positions commercially.

webTitle: Bedouin style fails to help Po Na Na

fields.headline: Bedouin style fails to help Po Na Na
fields.trailText: Hammersmith Palais - immortalised in the Clash song but now under a new name - was the subject of a profits warning from the bar and nightclub group Po Na Na yesterday. In a statement to the stock exchange, the group said trading at the west London venue had been disappointing over the last four weeks.
fields.body:
Hammersmith Palais - immortalised in the Clash song but now under a new name - was the subject of a profits warning from the bar and nightclub group Po Na Na yesterday. In a statement to the stock exchange, the group said trading at the west London venue had been disappointing over the last four weeks.

Po Na Na bought the Palais last year and relaunched it as a Moroccan themed venue with a "Bedouin-style lay out" under the name Po Na Na Hammersmith last month. The group said that sales reached £100,000 a week early on, but had fallen to £45,000 - a loss making level.

Yesterday, shares in Po Na Na fell 23.5p to close at 91.5p.

Finance director Tim Andrews said he had hoped the Palais would be making more than £60,000 a week. He suggested the venue was struggling to attract people in part because of its history. "That history has gone now - some people in their 30s and 40s think that is a shame, but they are not the people walking through the doors," he said.

"We are targeting young aspirational clubbers at the weekend and corporate events and live music during the week." Mr Andrews said aspirational clubbers were those who "like to feel part of an exclusive crowd".

Douglas Jack, of house broker WestLB Panmure, revised his pretax profits for the year to April from £2.7m to £2.5m.

webTitle: MPs blame regulators following Equitable failure

fields.headline: MPs blame regulators following Equitable failure
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: A powerful committee of MPs yesterday effectively accused Equitable Life of misleading policyholders and questioned the judgment of the Department of Trade and Industry and the Financial Services Authority, which both regulated the insurer.
fields.body:
A powerful committee of MPs yesterday effectively accused Equitable Life of misleading policyholders and questioned the judgment of the Department of Trade and Industry and the Financial Services Authority, which both regulated the insurer.

The influential Treasury select committee said that in the light of the Equitable affair there must be a review of the relationship between insurers' appointed actuaries and their managements.

The appointed actuary has a statutory responsibility to look after the interests of policyholders, and MPs noted that between August 1997 and December 2000, Equitable's appointed actuary, Chris Headdon, was also the company's finance director.

Following the publication of the committee's interim report into the affair, chairman Giles Radice said Equitable's management made a "misjudgment" in deciding in 1993 not to build up a reserve to cover the cost of meeting annuity guarantees it had issued as part of pension policies.

He added: "On the face of it, the DTI [which regulated Equitable until 1998] ought to have been more aware of this burgeoning problem."

Equitable reached crisis point last July when the law lords ruled it had treated 90,000 policyholders unfairly and left the world's oldest mutual insurer facing a bill of at least £1.5bn.

The insurer had tried to renege on promises it made to policyholders with so-called guaranteed annuity rates (GARs) by cutting the final bonus payments for those who chose to exercise the guarantee.

Last month the business, apart from the with-profits fund, was sold to the Halifax for £1bn.

The report criticises the way the information provided to policyholders before the crisis took hold "differed substantially" from that provided to the regulators.

The company's accounts intended for policyholders made no mention of the estimated £1.5bn GAR liability and instead said it had made a provision of £200m to cover a cost estimated at £50m.

"As a result, policyholders were not able easily to establish the true position of the company," said the MPs.

They added: "It is unclear to us why the issue of GAR liabilities and reserving was not considered by the prudential insurance regulator [the DTI] at least by 1993, rather than only in 1998. We believe the current inquiries should pursue this closely."

 Late 1993

Annuity rates fall below "guaranteed annuity rates" (GARs) Equitable had sold as part of pension policies. Crucially, it did not start to build up a reserve to meet future liabilities.

 November 5, 1998

Memo from Treasury to Financial Services Authority (FSA) states there are "serious questions about company's solvency".

 July 1999

Equitable Life goes to the High Court to defend decision to cut bonuses to those with GARs.

 September 9, 1999

High Court upholds Equitable's policy.

 January 21, 2000

Court of Appeal rules against Equitable.

 July 20, 2000

House of Lords dismisses Equitable's appeal. Company puts itself up for sale.

 December 8, 2000

Equitable closes to new business.

 December 22, 2000

FSA says it will open an inquiry.

 February 5, 2001

Equitable announces sale of its business, other than with-profits fund, to the Halifax for up to £1bn.

 February 15, 2001

Select committee hears evidence from leading players in the saga.

fields.headline: New York swagger comes to Edinburgh
fields.standfirst:
Guys and Dolls
Royal Lyceum Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Guys and Dolls
Royal Lyceum Theatre, Edinburgh
Rating: ***
fields.body:
When the best-known version of a Broadway musical is a 1955 film starring Marlon Brando and Frank Sinatra, stage productions that follow have an unenviable task: no Sinatra to sing Luck Be a Lady, few extras, and stage sets only as convincing as small budgets can make them.

Given this, the Royal Lyceum's first production of a Broadway musical for more than a decade does well to succeed. There are moments of convincing New York swagger from the gangsters, gamblers and molls on the streets after midnight, some genuine comedy and a smoothly handled love affair between Sky Masterton and do-gooder Miss Sarah Brown. The stage might be too small to bring Broadway to life, but with lead performances ranging from impressively slick (Alasdair Harvey as Masterton and Fiona Steele as Brown) to affectionately engaging (Elaine C Smith's Adelaide, all Betty Boop meets pantomime dame), there is some escapist magic to the proceedings - which is what musicals are all about.

In the second act, where the big ensemble numbers take over, you forget all about rainy old Edinburgh outside as Sit Down, You're Rocking the Boat, Luck Be a Lady and the Crap Game Dance all soar atmospherically, just as they should. Tom McGovern shines as the commitment-phobic Nathan Detroit, engaged to Miss Adelaide for 14 years. All he wants is to find a venue for the next crap game; all she wants is to have a "house and wallpaper and bookends".

The limits of the magic are to do with the production's physical scale and scope - the set presents a rather woeful New York - and some problems with sound. The microphones are set high to make all the voices powerful enough to root you to the spot, but they give out a maddening buzz between musical numbers and there are several audio clonks and clangs too. You forget these momentarily during numbers like A Bushel and a Peck, but the dream is dispelled when the singing stops. Without the dream, these are just ordinary men and women, not guys and dolls, bad boys and dreamy broads at play and in love.

Until April 21. Box office: 0131-248 4848.

webTitle: £7m shock knocks the wheels off Redbus

fields.headline: £7m shock knocks the wheels off Redbus
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Redbus Interhouse, the internet hotels group, saw its share price hammered yesterday after reporting wider than expected losses, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
Redbus Interhouse, the internet hotels group founded by technology entrepreneurs Cliff Stanford and John Porter, saw its share price hammered yesterday after reporting wider than expected losses.

The company, which provides facilities for hosting internet servers for big companies, had 17% knocked off the value of its shares after reporting an operating loss of £6.8m on revenues of £3.5m and a further £47.2m write-off due to expansion in the six months ending December 2000.

Comments from managing director Kevin Neal that Redbus "remained alert to the potential impact on our business of the slow down in the technology markets" also unnerved investors.

Redbus's first internet hotel in Docklands, London, is already profitable and it plans to lease a further 650,000 square feet at facilities across Europe by the end of this year.

Mr Porter, the son of Dame Shirley Porter, and Mr Stanford, who netted £50m from the sale of Demon Internet to Scottish Telecom, reversed Redbus into Horace Small Apparel last year. It has raised £102m since then but its shares have fallen from a peak of 330p to 85p.

Mr Stanford plans to build a business empire around the Redbus brand and has a film business called Redbus Film Distribution. In his spare time he sponsors Charlton Athletic football club and flies by private jet.

fields.headline: £240m loss for Europe's largest ISP
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Europe's largest internet service provider, T-Online, yesterday underlined the difficulties for access providers by revealing that it had lost 390m euros (£240m) last year. By Julia Snoddy and John Cassy.
fields.body:
Europe's largest internet service provider, T-Online, yesterday underlined the difficulties for access providers by revealing that it had lost 390m euros (£240m) last year.

It blamed the shift towards flat-rate internet access and the write-off costs relating to a series of acquisitions.

The takeovers of Club Internet and Ya.com account for 203m euros of the write-offs, following the fall in value of ISPs since last year's technology stock boom.

Last year it recorded pretax losses before write-offs of only 17.6m euros.

Sales for 2000 almost doubled to 797.2m euros, largely off the back of acquisitions.

T-Online, which is 81.7% owned by Deutsche Telekom, last month tried to reduce its losses by pulling an unlimited internet access package which was sold for $35 (£24) per month. Customers now have to pay that amount to get 90 hours' access a month.

Like many internet service providers T-Online has been able to grow fast and attract millions of users but it has had difficulty making money out of them. It currently has 8.5m customers.

Chief executive Thomas Holtrop has said he aims to generate 30% of revenues from e-commerce and advertising. At the moment only 22% of income comes from sources other than the charges users are levied for logging on.

"After a period of growth, profitability and professionalism are now our focus," he said.

Last year T-Online held takeover talks with Britain's leading ISP, Freeserve, which broke down after the two companies failed to agree on price. Freeserve has since been bought by Wanadoo of France.

Shares in T-Online have suffered in line with the wider internet sector and last week touched an all-time low. Many analysts believe that European ISPs remain overvalued compared to their longer established US competitors.

webTitle: Euro sinks as ECB sits on its hands

fields.headline: Euro sinks as ECB sits on its hands
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Europe's battered single currency yesterday plunged to its lowest level this year as traders expressed their disappointment at the European Central Bank's failure to deliver a hoped for cut in interest rates.
fields.body:
Europe's battered single currency yesterday plunged to its lowest level this year as traders expressed their disappointment at the European Central Bank's failure to deliver a hoped for cut in interest rates.

Dealers had been expecting the ECB to join the world's other big central banks in reducing borrowing costs to prevent the onset of recession. But after the ECB's governing council announced its decision to keep rates unchanged at 4.75%, the euro fell to 88.20 cents, its lowest level since December 13 last year.

"Things may have been moving a little too fast for a number of council members, especially after the dramatic change in rhetoric last week," Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein economist Eckhard Schulte said.

"The ECB likes to have broad consensus in its monetary policy decisions. They clearly did not have it this time. But the bank does appear to be leaning towards a rate cut and I think we'll see one next time round."

Analysts said that yesterday's inaction will increase pressure on the ECB for a steeper rate cut at its pre-Easter meeting on April 11.

"With US data likely to get worse in coming weeks, the pressure for a cut, perhaps even by 50 basis points, will mount," investment bank ING Barings said in a research note published yesterday.

Many analysts have slashed their forecasts for European growth since the beginning of the year, as the fallout from the US slowdown has spread. The US government revised down its estimate of fourth quarter growth from a previously published 1.1% annual rate to 1%.

Yesterday's decision "will leave the ECB open to market criticism that it is in denial about the risks from the US and behind the curve in not cutting interest rates, leaving the euro vulnerable," according to ING Barings.

The US Federal Reserve has cut rates three times since the beginning of the year in an attempt to halt the slide into recession.

In recent days, there have been hints from the ECB that it is more concerned about slowing growth than about the fact that inflation in the eurozone is above its 2% ceiling. That had been seen as a move to prepare the markets for a borrowing cut.

Noting that the euro had fallen to its lowest level for three and half months, David Brown at Bear Stearns said: "Had they actually cut rates today the euro would be trading stronger. It really beggars belief that they sat on their hands again. They had built up expectations so much and the market is going to have a very severe sense of being let down."

Though the ECB statement gave few clues about its thinking, analysts believe that it is still concerned about the inflation risk and stronger than expected growth in the money supply.

Though eurozone rates are on hold for the time being, British borrowing costs could be lowered next week, after inflation doves on the Bank of England's key rate setting committee received more ammunition. A new survey showed that consumer confidence has collapsed to its lowest level for more than two years.

Equity markets were unmoved by both the ECB's decision and the latest US news. The FTSE 100 closed down 25.6 points at 5588.4, while the Dow Jones industrial average was up 66 points by lunchtime at 9582. The technology rich Nasdaq index was little changed on the day.

fields.headline: Katie Mitchell devastates with Euripides
fields.standfirst:
Iphigenia at Aulis
Abbey Theatre, Dublin
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
Iphigenia at Aulis
Abbey Theatre, Dublin
Rating: *****
fields.body:
The echoes of Deborah Warner and Fiona Shaw's Medea are still rattling around the Abbey's main stage, but this Euripides tragedy is equally appalling. Directed by Katie Mitchell, the production views human horror through a charged medium of deranged gods, offstage gore, farcical civic power and inhuman sacrilege.

The scene is set by an old manservant, who rearranges the chairs in a vast, ruined 1930s hall, like deckchairs on the Titanic. Helen, wife of Menelaus, has been stolen away to Troy. But the vengeful Grecian fleet is stalled at Aulis, thanks to the doldrum winds of the goddess Artemis, who will only be appeased by the sacrifice of Agamemnon's daughter Iphigenia. Agamemnon's acquiescence in this slaughter involves much indecision, even in his cuckolded brother Menelaus.

The chorus, five women in scarves, hourglass dresses and handbags, cluck onstage, representing the populace as a flock of fickle, gaggling, fashionable geese. Agamemnon's wife Clytemnestra arrives with baby Orestes in a pram, falsely summoned to the marriage of Iphigenia and the unwitting hero, Achilles. She is followed by the sacrificial lamb, the shockingly goofy child Iphigenia, her scarlet baby-dress hiked high. She lovingly faces her father, Agamemnon, now wearing an SS uniform.

Agamemnon's plot is sprung by Achilles, a preposterous, swashbuckling figure who, on discovering the lie, swears to Clytemnestra that he will avenge her - and his - wounded honour. Clytemnestra appeals to Agamemnon; Kate Duchene's momentous performance as the former curiously dwarfs Chris McHallem as the latter. But the wheels of tragedy have turned. Agamemnon commands his hysteric daughter in her outrageous wedding dress. Immediately she is disrobed, erotically drenched and garlanded by the chorus for the blood-altar of Artemis. As her death howls blast through the great hall, the chorus rally like Nazi women heiling to Hitler and waving little flags. Clytemnestra weaves desperately through them, howling, "Vermin, vermin!"

Sustaining the pitch is a tall order but, sandwiching the piece into an uninterrupted two hours, Mitchell delivers a mind-bending intensity. The link to Nazi Germany is unsettling but apposite: women and children are the first casualties of masculine warfare.

Many aspects of the text (translated by Don Taylor) are problematic, such as Clytemnestra's outburst to Achilles, "God bless you for your courage", as though monotheism were the issue. Agamemnon's naked reference to the Fatherland also honks loudly. Despite these square pegs encountering round holes, Mitchell has delivered Euripides in all his humanist, immortal power. This is an astonishing, uncomfortable, unrelenting production.

Until April 21. Box office: 00 353 1 878 7222.

fields.headline: King John
fields.standfirst:
Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon
Rating: ****
fields.body:
With this production following hard on the heels of Northern Broadsides', King John has suddenly moved from unloved orphan to teacher's pet. Gregory Doran kicks off the Royal Shakespeare Company's Stratford season with a wittily intelligent revival that highlights Shakespeare's corrosively ironic view of power politics - although the production leans a bit too far in the direction of black comedy.

The very casting of Guy Henry as John makes a statement. Henry is an attenuated actor whose very presence ignites laughter. So here, following endless Duck Soup-type brass fanfares, he misses his first entrance, forgets the name of the French ambassador and instinctively flinches when confronted by a noble appellant. Sid Field used to do a King John sketch and there is more than a touch of that great, fairy-footed comic in Henry's whimsically petulant performance.

But, although this king is a wavering usurper, there are echoes of Richard III and intimations of Macbeth that here go undetected. One of the great passages in all Shakespeare is John's cryptic instruction to Hubert to kill the boy Arthur. It runs "Death - My lord? - A grave - He shall not live - Enough." It cries out for Pinteresque phrasing but is here comically rattled off as though they were wrapping up any other business. Henry is always magnetically watchable but, by making him a kingly klutz, the production undercuts his role as anti-papist spokesman and pre-empts much of Shakespeare's own political cynicism.

It comes back to the old rule about playing a character from his own point of view. In that sense, the performance of the evening comes from David Collings as the Papal legate, Pandulph, who presumptuously intervenes in the battle for the English throne. Collings makes him a figure of self-delighting intellectual sophistry who impatiently rolls his eyes at the Dauphin's failure to realise that defeat can be classed as victory. If Collings's Pandulph is an ecclesiastical spin-master, Jo Stone-Fewings's bumptious Bastard is his secular equivalent. The scene where he convinces the French that "warlike John" is champing at the bit would take even Alastair Campbell's breath away.

Doran's alert production allows you to see the play's modern political parallels without cramping its traditional theatricality. Battles are evoked through swirling banners. The putative blinding of Josh McGuire's Arthur by Trevor Cooper's Hubert has exactly that mix of pathos and cruelty that so thrilled the Victorians; Arthur's later death-fall is also sensationally well done. And the production's dual focus is nowhere better seen than in the treatment of Arthur's mother, Constance, who is betrayed by the big powers. Kelly Hunter makes her a figure of justifiable maternal rage; yet when Geoffrey Freshwater's French king tells her "You are as fond of grief as of your child", the line cuts like a knife through butter. For heart-stopping moments like that I can easily forgive the production its occasional hints of Woody Allen in medieval England.

Until October 13. Box office: 01789 403403.

It cries out for Pinteresque phrasing but is here comically rattled off as though they were wrapping up any other business. Henry is always magnetically watchable but, by making him a kingly klutz, the production undercuts his role as anti-papist spokesman and pre-empts much of Shakespeare's own political cynicism. It comes back to the old rule about playing a character from his own point of view. In that sense, the performance of the evening comes from David Collings as the Papal legate, Pandulph, who presumptuously intervenes in the battle for the English throne. Collings makes him a figure of self-delighting intellectual sophistry who impatiently rolls his eyes at the Dauphin's failure to realise that defeat can be classed as victory. If Collings's Pandulph is an ecclesiastical spin-master, Jo Stone-Fewings's bumptious Bastard is his secular equivalent. The scene where he convinces the French that "warlike John" is champing at the bit would take even Alastair Campbell's breath away. Doran's alert production allows you to see the play's modern political parallels without cramping its traditional theatricality. Battles are evoked through swirling banners. The putative blinding of Josh McGuire's Arthur by Trevor Cooper's Hubert has exactly that mix of pathos and cruelty that so thrilled the Victorians; Arthur's later death-fall is also sensationally well done. And the production's dual focus is nowhere better seen than in the treatment of Arthur's mother, Constance, who is betrayed by the big powers. Kelly Hunter makes her a figure of justifiable maternal rage; yet when Geoffrey Freshwater's French king tells her "You are as fond of grief as of your child", the line cuts like a knife through butter. For heart-stopping moments like that I can easily forgive the production its occasional hints of Woody Allen in medieval England. Until October 13. Box office: 01789 403403.

fields.headline: The story of 'o', and a night in the pub
fields.standfirst: Your football questions answered every week. Email the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to help
fields.trailText: OH NO FOUR O
fields.body:
OH NO FOUR O

"Last week I drunkenly challenged my mates in the pub to name five players that have played for England whose surname ends in 'o'. However, in my inebriated state I had forgotten the answer and to this day cannot remember. If I can counter my friends claims that I am a useless alcoholic oaf by providing the answer, I will probably look dead clever. Can you help me?" writes Matthew Szabo.

You're very nearly right, Matto, although whether the following information will help you counter claims of being a useless alcoholic oaf is another matter. You did get all pissed up and forgot the point you were trying to make, after all.

But if we can help you repair some of the damage, we will. Bristol City striker John Atyeo was the first player with a surname ending in 'o' to pull an England shirt on: he did so six times between 1956 and 1957. Chelsea's Ken Shellito was next, although he only got one cap in 1963.

John Salako fared little better: he was capped five times during those glory, glory Graham Taylor years. But the most successful of the lot was Tony Dorigo, who collected a mammoth 15 caps between 1990 and 1994.

Four players, none of whom achieved a great deal on the international stage. The moral? If you want to play for England, Matthew, we suggest lopping the end of your surname off. And cutting down on the booze, obviously.

WHERE DID THE TERM HAT-TRICK COME FROM?

"Which sport originated the term hat-trick?" asks Harry Gottlieb.

"The term hat-trick originated within the sport of ice hockey, or just plain "hockey" as the Canuks know it," insists Neil MacKnish. "A Toronto hat shop owner had the brainwave of publicising his business by offering a free hat to any member of his favourite team, the Toronto Maple Leafs, who scored three goals in a game. The media cottoned onto the offer, and the expression 'hat-trick' was born."

But John Whiting is sure that the term comes from cricket. "In the early days, those taking three successive wickets were awarded a complimentary hat," he says. "Maybe two wickets was a brace and got you a pair of braces, but that's just speculation on my part."

WHY DON'T MORE TEAMS PLAY IN WEIRD COLOURS?

"Why don't more teams play in either black, green, maroon or purple? What is the history behind most teams playing in either blue, red or white?" asks Paul Kilgour.

"I remember reading somewhere that in the 1800s the only colours widely available for kits were black, red, white and blue," says Lee Calvert. "That is why England play in white and navy, because Scotland took navy shirts and Wales took red, and the ref already had black"

Meanwhile Phil Baiden says the reason why more clubs don't play in green is because it is considered unlucky. "One famous example of this was at Peterborough in 1937," he says. "The team's fans were complaining that the green shirts being worn were bringing the team bad luck. As a result the board declared, 'Pay for blue shirts and we'll wear blue shirts.' The rest is history."

"I assume that teams don't wear black because of the clash with referees, but Bristol Rovers began life as the Black Arabs wearing a dashing black shirt with a yellow sash," he adds. "The blue and white quarters now worn were brought in by manager Albert Prince-Cox in the early thirties for no other reason than to make the team stand out."

"Also there are plenty of colour schemes that have vanished such as Brentford's pink, claret and sky and Watford's turquoise (again thought of as unlucky)."

THE FIRST AUSSIE TO PLAY IN THE UK

"Who was the first Australian to play in the top flight in Britain?" asks Robert Lawton.

The man you're looking for is Joe Marston, who played 185 games for Preston North End between 1950 and 1956. Marston, who captained the Australian national side for much of the 1950s, was also the first Aussie to play at Wembley, turning out for Preston in their 3-2 FA Cup Final defeat against WBA in 1954.

Recently Marston was acclaimed as the fourth most outstanding footballer of the century in the Oceania region - behind Wynton Rufer, Frank Farina and Christian Karembeu - and according to Bill Pennington is still going strong. "Joe is still alive and living in Sydney, and his wife can still be found complaining about post-war rationing!" he says.

For more information see the book 'Aussies Abroad' which was published last year.

PHIL NEVILLE? PAH!

"Does anyone know who has the highest ratio of international caps to league appearances? Surely Phil 'overachiever' Neville is a prime candidate?" asked Chris Field.

Yeah, but he's joined by Northern Ireland's David Healy and Pat McGibbon, who while never playing a first team game for their club, Manchester United, still represented their country. Thanks to Iain Wright, Mickenna and Richard Evans for the spot.

TEAMS WITH ONE SEASON IN THE SUN

Last time out, we asked for teams who had one season in the sun amid years and years of darkness. You haven't let us down.

"A good non-British example of a stellar year surrounded by mediocrity was the 1970 Cagliari team, which won the Italian championship, thanks to the incomparable Gigi Riva, and never won anything else before or since," writes John Alvey.

"And what about the Ipswich team of 1962?" he continues, with a nod to Alf Ramsey's championship-winning side. "They won the Second Division championship the year before but, after Alf Ramsey left, dropped back into the Second by 1964 and did not get back to the First till 1968 and didn't win anything again till they won the Cup in 1978."

"I am tempted to say England post 1966 but that's probably not too accurate," he concludes. Ah but it is, John.

Meanwhile, Neil McKenzie writes: "Not quite the answer to the question, but what about Huddersfield Town in the mid-Twenties? A few years of superlative dominance, and bugger all else EVER!"

Fair point. Do you have anything to add, Ben Hendy?

"To add to your list of overacheiving clubs," he nods," I believe that the Southampton team of around 1984 somehow (God knows how) managed to finish second in the league to a certain Liverpudlian team. This was followed by a glorious dropping out of Europe in the second round."

There must be more. Keep sending them in.

Can you help?

"Who received the first red card in the Premiership/old 1st division?" asks Andy Fouracre.

"When did shirt numbers first start getting used and who wore the first shirt with the number one on it?" asks Mins.

"Does anyone know which non-league side has made the most appearances - including the preliminary stages - in European competition over the years?" asks Mick Stead.

"Which foreign (non-British) player has scored the most goals in top-flight England?" asks Simon Rogerson.

Trawl through The Knowledge archive.

webTitle: Hoddle signs up to Spurs' vision

fields.headline: Hoddle signs up to Spurs' vision
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle will be unveiled as Tottenham's manager today after the club's owner Enic revealed that he had needed little persuading to leave his post at Southampton. Kevin Keegan is the favourite to replace him.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle will be unveiled as Tottenham's manager today after the club's owner Enic revealed that he had needed little persuading to leave his post at Southampton and succeed George Graham.

Enic denied claims that it had made an illegal approach for Hoddle while he was contracted to Southampton. The Spurs chairman David Buchler said yesterday that he first contacted his opposite number Rupert Lowe on Monday and asked for permission to speak to Hoddle, who was on his way back from a holiday in South Africa at the time.

With permission granted, Buchler and Enic's chief executive Daniel Levy arranged to meet Hoddle and his agent Dennis Roach in London on Tuesday afternoon. They spoke for almost 12 hours, the meeting ending at about 3am yesterday.

Midway through the meeting Hoddle informed Lowe by telephone of his decision to join Tottenham, but no formal announcement was made by Spurs. Lawyers representing both sides spent most of yesterday finalising contracts.

Buchler said: "It was a long, long meeting but Glenn did not need much convincing because we had the same interests at heart and our minds were thinking alike. It was really just a matter of dotting the i's and crossing the t's.

"It really was not difficult convincing Glenn to come to Spurs. We spoke about a number of issues and we outlined our vision for Tottenham. We share the same vision."

Buchler said the appointment was an attempt to bring stability and unity to Spurs after the divisions and anger caused by the appointment of Graham and the ownership of Alan Sugar, during which time there were disagreements over the running of the club, the direction Spurs should go and the relative lack of success.

"My aim is really to get Spurs back to its roots and to heal the divisions that existed within the club," Buchler said. "This appointment is one of the most important ways of achieving this. All Spurs fans will understand this. All Spurs fans will understand why we have appointed Glenn Hoddle."

Hoddle will not be in charge of the Tottenham team who face Arsenal at Highbury on Saturday. The director of football David Pleat will be in con trol but Hoddle will pick the team when the two sides meet again in the FA Cup semi-final on Sunday week.

Hoddle will take charge on Monday, when he will hold his first training session with the squad. He will be joined by John Gorman, his assistant at Swindon, England and Southampton, who also announced his resignation from the south coast club yesterday.

The departure of one former England coach from Southampton has led to speculation about another, with Kevin Keegan emerging as the favourite to take over from Hoddle.

Keegan is popular with Southampton fans and, with the club moving to a new stadium next season, a big-name manager is viewed as crucial to ensuring large attendances and placating those angry at Hoddle's departure. Keegan, who recently expressed an interest in returning to management, is viewed as the No1 choice and still owns a house in Hampshire.

But Southampton are unlikely to make a formal appointment until the end of the season, and the coach Stuart Gray has taken charge for now. Given that the team are eighth in the Premiership, club officials feel that they should take their time in securing the right man, one who can build upon the relative successes of this season.

Lowe yesterday addressed the Southampton players and expressed his sadness at Hoddle's departure. "I am sure that our fans will share my regret at what has happened as they too have given Glenn every support and been an important component in his success," he said later in a statement.

"I am also saddened that Glenn has chosen to leave the team with a European place in sight and a new stadium only five months from completion. Whilst Glenn has 15 months of his contract outstanding, he has no doubt considered all these factors in the short space of time available to him and I do not propose to hold him against his will to move elsewhere."

Buchler said that a compensation package was being worked out with Saints' lawyers but Tottenham had not broken any rules in their attempts to land Hoddle.

"It has been very difficult for Southampton because their loss is our gain," he said. "We have no problem with Southampton and of course they will receive compensation. No illegal approaches were made to Glenn at any time. Everything has been done properly and within the rules of the game."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: World Cup round-up
fields.trailText: Germany maintained their five-point lead over England at the top of Group Nine with a 4-2 win over Greece in Athens.
fields.body:
Germany maintained their five-point lead over England at the top of Group Nine with a 4-2 win over Greece in Athens.

Rudi Voller's men had to see out the last 30 minutes with just ten men after the striker Sebastian Deisler was sent off for two bookable offences. Marko Rehmer put them ahead in the sixth minute before Angelos Haristeas equalised.

Michael Ballack restored the lead with a penalty on 25 minutes but Giorgos Georgiadis then equalised just before half-time. It looked to be heading for a draw before Miroslav Klose put the German's ahead with nine minutes left and Marco Bode wrapped it up a minute from time.

Italy, the runaway leaders in Group Eight, took advantage of Hungary's night off to extend their lead at the top of the table to eight points. Filippo Inzaghi and Alessandro Del Piero each scored twice in a 4-0 win over Lithuania.

Cyprus, fresh from Saturday's 4-0 drubbing at home to Republic of Ireland, threw away a two-goal lead to draw 2-2 with Estonia in Group Two. Michalis Constantinou gave the hosts the lead and Yiannakis Okkas doubled it with a close-range effort with 25 minutes left. Estonia bounced back to wipe out the deficit inside three minutes, with goals from Marko Kristal and Raio Piiroja.

Czech Republic and Denmark drew 0-0 in Group Three, the same group as Northern Ireland, and ensured the Czechs stayed on top of the table, one point ahead of Bulgaria.

Undefeated Poland stayed clear at the top of Group Five after hitting four goals without reply against Armenia, who had held Wales to a 2-2 draw in Yerevan at the weekend. Michal Zewlakow's penalty and Emannuel Olisadebe put them two ahead before half-time and Marcin Zewlakow and Bartosz Karwan wrapped up the win in the final ten minutes. Poland's next match is in Cardiff on June 2.

In the group's other match, Norway's rotten run continued when they went down 2-1 in Belarus. Manchester United's Ole Gunnar Solskjaer cancelled out Alexander Khatskevich's goal for the hosts, but Roman Vasilyuk popped up with a 90th-minute strike to keep Norway rooted to the foot of the table.

Turkey are one of three teams locked at the top of Group Four. Despite Toni Micevski's early goal for Macedonia, Turkey battled back after the break. Igor Mitrevski's 68th-minute own goal and Umit Davala's sealed victory a minute later.

Slovakia also kept up the pace with a 3-1 victory over Azerbaijan. Szilard Nemeth put them ahead after just 18 seconds but Vadim Vasilyev levelled from the spot two minutes later. Nemeth and Lubomir Meszaros made the match safe. In the same group, two goals in the last two minutes from Markus Allback gave Sweden a 2-0 win over Moldova.

Alexander Mostovoi ensured Russia stayed at the top of Group One, scoring the winner in an unconvincing 1-0 victory over the Faroe Islands in Moscow.

Moscow, Mostovoi struck in the 18th minute, scooping the ball up in the penalty area and drilling it past goalkeeper Jakup Mikkelsen.

Second-half goals by Dorinel Munteanu and Cosmin Contra gave Romania a 2-0 win over Georgia in their Group Eight encounter.

fields.headline: A taste of paradise
fields.standfirst: This week Sam arrives in Malawi, is reunited with his girlfriend, and stays in an island paradise.
fields.trailText: Week 17: Harare to Malawi Sam arrives in Malawi, is reunited with his girlfriend, and stays in an island paradise
fields.body:
Flying out of Zimbabwe, I almost left my rucksack behind in Harare. They had an unusual security system at the airport. When walking out to the plane you have to identify your luggage before it's put on board. Unfortunately I didn't realise this until I got into my seat and just happened to look out the window.

There was my rucksack sitting forlornly by itself on the runway. I managed to fight my way to the front of the plane and salvage all my worldly possessions with seconds to spare before the steward closed the door.

Arriving at Lilongwe, Malawi's capital, I spent a tedious hour queuing at immigration. Travelling in Africa takes 10 times as long as you expect. Planes never turn up. Trains get delayed by elephants crossing the tracks. And buses don't have a schedule - they just leave when they are full.

I spent a night in Lilongwe and the next morning met up with H, my girlfriend, who had flown in from London. We travelled down to Cape Maclear on the southern shore of Lake Malawi. To get H in the holiday mood we had booked ourselves a two-day stay on a nearby island with a South African-based company called Kayak Africa.

Cape Maclear lies off the main road at the end of a long and bumpy track. The effects of the recent heavy rain that has hit this part of Africa over the last month was clearly evident. Fields were flooded and large chunks of the road had been washed away.

At Kayak Africa's base we were kitted out with a double kayak and introduced to our guide for the trip, Edward. Then it was straight into the water and we were paddling the eight kilometres to Mumbo Island. On the way Edward pointed out fish eagles swooping low over the water and local fisherman trailing their nets from carved wooden canoes.

Mumbo Island was truly idyllic. The camp was perched on a rocky outcrop with a low wooden footbridge to the beach. Our tent looked out across the lake. When I say tent, this wasn't one of your tiny, canvas jobs that I had when I was a boy scout. This was a luxury, walk-in number, with two beds and a chest of drawers, covered by a thatched shelter and with its own veranda and hammock.

There were five tents on the island, but as it is the low season we were the only ones there. This meant we had the undivided attention of the three guys who looked after the camp: Dennis, Adamson and the amazing cook, Francis. Francis had previously worked for pretty much every foreign embassy in Malawi so the food was excellent.

We spent long, happy days snorkelling in the clear, blue waters and exploring the island with the kayak. We learnt how to play 'baur' (an addictive game using a carved wooden board and seeds for pieces and played a bit like solitaire for two). At night we sat out on the veranda and watched huge electrical storms lighting up the lake.

It certainly wasn't cheap, but we were enjoying it so much that we decided to treat ourselves and booked to stay for an extra night.

Unfortunately I can't show you just how wonderful it all was as Malawi's email facilities are very limited (I'm writing this on a borrowed computer and I'm not sure it's going to reach you), but I will try and send some photos soon.

Back at Cape Maclear we spent a couple of days hanging round the beach. There were very few tourists but plenty of beach boys trying to sell you everything from trips to the islands to copious quantities of marijuana. Some of these guys have picked up mock cockney accents from somewhere. I had the following conversation with one of them:

Beach boy: "Aw'right mate, how ya doing?"
Me: "Er, I'm good thanks. How are you?"
Beach boy: "Blinding mate. What can I do ya for? Some ganja maybe?"
Me: "No, no, I'm fine thanks".
Beach Boy: "Ah, you're sorted then. Lovely jubbly. Catch ya later."

This made my head hurt.

Next week: On safari in Liwonde National Park.
