webTitle: Swiss teaching method to be adopted

fields.headline: Lesson from Swiss in reading skills
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A "long tail of under-achievement" in literacy among school leavers in England compared with the continent could be eradicated by switching to a teaching method proven in Switzerland, researchers claim today.
fields.body:
A "long tail of under-achievement" in literacy among school leavers in England compared with the continent could be eradicated by switching to a teaching method proven in Switzerland, researchers claim today.

The method could help primary pupils master the basics of reading in two terms, compared with three years under the government's national literacy strategy, according to a report by the independent National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

In the longer term, improved literacy led to lower teenage pregnancy and crime rates. Last week, the head of inspections at Ofsted, David Taylor, told MPs on the education select committee that low literacy among boys was "a national scandal".

In Swiss schools, pupils start by combining letters into simple words (synthetic phonetics), said Sig Prais of the institute. In England, children use analytic phonics, breaking words down into sounds and then identifying the corresponding letters.

In Switzerland, pupils started primary school at six or seven, up to two years later than in England, by which time progress was faster because of a "better foundation" established in kindergarten - where there was "less emphasis on early mastery of academic skills of reading, writing and arithmetic, more on lengthening attention span and memory, and developing 'social skills' of learning together in a classroom setting". In Swiss primaries generally there is a greater emphasis on whole-class teaching in literacy, with every child encouraged to make a contribution.

The teaching meant children progressed more evenly, without the "long tail of under-achievement" in England, said Professor Prais.

The report is based on visits to 20 schools in Zurich by researchers from the institute and school inspectors. In east London, Barking and Dagenham is to introduce the methods, having successfully applied Swiss methods to maths teaching.

fields.headline: John Peake
fields.standfirst: Eton housemaster who set out to reform a South African school in apartheid's heyday
fields.trailText: Eton housemaster who set out to reform a South African school in apartheid's heyday.
fields.body:
John Peake, who has died aged 68, left a hugely successful and comfortable career as a housemaster at Eton to become principal of "Bishop's", the Diocesan College in Cape Town, possibly South Africa's most famous school. When he arrived in 1983, the situation in South Africa was at its ugliest, with the Botha government cracking down in the face of growing opposition on all fronts - internal resistance, ANC guerrilla warfare, wars in the frontline states and the condemnation of the world outside: there was no hint of the settlement that was to come.

Heedless of opposition and, indeed, of personal risk, Peake proposed a revolutionary series of reforms for the school, not least to enlarge its racial mix - out of 930 pupils, only 45 were non-whites, of whom only seven were black. Bishop's was at that time in a timewarp. Though maintaining high academic and sporting standards, the school had no orchestra, no theatre (only one play a year in the gymnasium), no woodwork or design and only the most basic facilities for art. The director of music also ran the tennis, while the art master doubled, most unwillingly, as head of the cadet corps.

Peake lost no time in trying to implement changes. An appeal was launched with the enthusiastic backing and support of the school council, and this proved so successful that a spectacular building programme was completed over the next four years. A new theatre, art school, sports hall, day house, sixth form centre, mathematics and computer block, squash court, climbing wall, woodwork centre and six staff houses were all constructed in this period, and the school site was quite literally transformed.

At the same time, Peake sought out sponsors for scholarships for black boys, and largely through personal contacts succeeded in bringing to Bishop's a number of Xhosa boys from the local townships, virtually all from deprived backgrounds. By 1988, there were 150 non-white boys in the school, of whom 41 were black.

Among the more liberal-thinking parents and old boys these changes were welcomed, but they were to prove very unpopular both with the traditionalists, who were still predominantly concerned with image and sporting success, especially in rugby, and with the right-wingers.

John Wiley, an old boy and member of PW Botha's government, had written to the chairman of council on Peake's appointment, demanding that a time limit should be set within which Peake would have to learn Afrikaans. Another old boy wrote: "Let us rather stick to the tried and tested formula with plenty of maths, rugger and penal gardening. Let's cut out the frills and the sculpture. If boys are not talented at games, they can still play or at least support their teams."

By 1988, despite the fact that the school was fuller than it had ever been and was flourishing in almost every sphere, the level of opposition was formidable and a concerted campaign was launched to get rid of Peake. At the old boy AGM, a very large crowd was brought together to hear Peake's review of the preceding year. This was ignored, and a series of speakers then rose to denounce his policies in the most virulent terms. In the light of this the council felt that he had become altogether too controversial a figure and asked for his resignation. A financial settlement was agreed and Peake finally left in July 1988.

In 1999, a wholly different council invited Peake and his wife back to Cape Town to attend the school's 150th anniversary celebrations. It was made clear on both sides that the reconciliation was complete.

Peake had been imbued from an early age with a sense of injustice about the system in South Africa. He was educated in England but spent his holidays abroad - his father was a diplomat, becoming ambassador to Yugoslavia and Greece. After Eton and King's College, Cambridge, where he read history, he did national service and then briefly worked for Shell in Brazil.

But then he was recruited by Sir Robert Birley, the anti-apartheid Eton headmaster, to teach, and he returned to his old school. There, with zest, energy and generosity of spirit, his history teaching was characterised by his ability to bringthe subject to life and to get the best out of his pupils; he set up a class on Africa at Eton which, although outside the curriculum, was invariably packed. As a rowing coach, he also took Eton to some of the school's greatest rowing victories.

On his return from South Africa, he became principal of Queen Elizabeth training college, Leatherhead, for the disabled. He retired in 1996 and went to live in his home in Dorchester.

He is survived by his wife, Susan, and son and daughter.

 John Sebastian Brinsley Peake, teacher, born February 11 1933; died March 11 2001

By 1988, despite the fact that the school was fuller than it had ever been and was flourishing in almost every sphere, the level of opposition was formidable and a concerted campaign was launched to get rid of Peake. At the old boy AGM, a very large crowd was brought together to hear Peake's review of the preceding year. This was ignored, and a series of speakers then rose to denounce his policies in the most virulent terms. In the light of this the council felt that he had become altogether too controversial a figure and asked for his resignation. A financial settlement was agreed and Peake finally left in July 1988. In 1999, a wholly different council invited Peake and his wife back to Cape Town to attend the school's 150th anniversary celebrations. It was made clear on both sides that the reconciliation was complete. Peake had been imbued from an early age with a sense of injustice about the system in South Africa. He was educated in England but spent his holidays abroad - his father was a diplomat, becoming ambassador to Yugoslavia and Greece. After Eton and King's College, Cambridge, where he read history, he did national service and then briefly worked for Shell in Brazil. But then he was recruited by Sir Robert Birley, the anti-apartheid Eton headmaster, to teach, and he returned to his old school. There, with zest, energy and generosity of spirit, his history teaching was characterised by his ability to bringthe subject to life and to get the best out of his pupils; he set up a class on Africa at Eton which, although outside the curriculum, was invariably packed. As a rowing coach, he also took Eton to some of the school's greatest rowing victories. On his return from South Africa, he became principal of Queen Elizabeth training college, Leatherhead, for the disabled. He retired in 1996 and went to live in his home in Dorchester. He is survived by his wife, Susan, and son and daughter.  John Sebastian Brinsley Peake, teacher, born February 11 1933; died March 11 2001

webTitle: Britain near bottom for adult literacy

fields.headline: Britain near bottom for adult literacy
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Britain has one of the lowest levels of adult literacy in the industrialised world, according to a report.
fields.body:
Britain has one of the lowest levels of adult literacy in the industrialised world, according to a report.

One in three people who leave school at 16 have inadequate basic skills - a greater percentage than is the case for 12 countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Those with better literacy rates include Finland (the best), Denmark, Sweden, Germany, the Czech Republic and Australia. Among OECD countries only Poland (the worst), the US, Hungary, Ireland and New Zealand have higher levels of illiteracy, according to the organisation's latest education analysis.

The report also shows that earning inequalities between women and men with fewer than five good GCSEs or the equivalent are greater in Britain than elsewhere in the OECD. In 1998, women in this category earned on average only 45% of men's salaries.

The OECD put the UK in the third of four tiers in rankings to measure performance in lifelong learning. In the UK, US and Australia, adults were "well presented in formal education systems", but did "less well on measures of literacy".

Yesterday, ministers reacted furiously to a Daily Mail story which claimed that the report showed Britain's schools were the worst in Europe. They showed a statement from Barry McGaw, the OECD's deputy director of education, saying the report did not suggest that. "The reforms of the last few years are directed at raising standards and the results so far look good," he said.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, said: "We don't say we were the worst in Europe because the report doesn't say it and nobody else has. Their report does say that we have a legacy of adult illiteracy and numeracy which we are now putting right."

Other measures in the report show that the average number of pupils per computer is quite small in UK schools.

The UK has a better than average number of three-year-olds in early years provision, and a high level of participation in continuing education and adult training.

Theresa May, the shadow education spokesperson, said: "This report is a stark warning to the government that the bureaucracy they are piling on teachers is crippling education in this country." But most of the OECD information relates to the years of the previous Conservative government.

The OECD warned that many countries will face problems staffing schools. "The teaching force is ageing and recruitment has become more difficult as the relative status of teaching has declined."

The education department issued its fourth annual report yesterday showing the percentage of children reaching level four in English at key stage two, age 11, had risen to 75%, 10 points up since the start of the literacy strategy in 1998.

At the official launch yesterday of the Learning and Skills Council, the body responsible for post-16 education and training, Mr Blunkett unveiled plans for "bite-sized" computer, literacy and numeracy courses for 50,000 adults. He said he wanted the courses to be held in pubs, shops, gyms, workplaces and colleges.

Mr Blunkett also announced £150m extra for performance-related pay for further education and sixth form college lecturers, £15m this year and £135m in 2003-4.

fields.headline: Eyre says digital is pipedream
fields.trailText: Richard Eyre, the outgoing chief executive of Pearson TV, has warned Britain's top advertisers that there will be no digital TV revolution, writes Claire Cozens .
fields.body:
Richard Eyre, the outgoing chief executive of Pearson TV, has warned Britain's top advertisers that there will be no digital TV revolution.

Speaking at the annual conference of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, Mr Eyre said the take-up of digital TV had not been driven by consumer demand but by broadcasters giving away the set top boxes. "In the UK, where digital television is further advanced than anywhere else in the world, the locomotive of change is not consumer demand but the business models of the suppliers and the desire of government to get its hands on lucrative spectrum currently jammed up with inefficient analogue television," said Mr Eyre.

"Unless or until consumer demand - the desire of real people, backed by their wallets - that drives the process, it will remain less a revolution than a giant marketing campaign."

Mr Eyre said his personal 'room 101' would be filled with the new media pundits who predicted the digital age would mean an end to the media as we know it.

He described their assumption that where technology leads, human behaviour will follow as the "Negroponte snare" after the internet guru Nicholas Negroponte.

"We've all heard the saying that nobody ever went bust under-estimating the taste of the American public, and here's another," he said.

"A lot of people went bust over-estimating the pace of the American public. And the European public. And the Chinese public. People are habitual creatures."

fields.headline: Tips for charity rebranding
fields.trailText: Roger Taylor is a corporate strategist with Addison Corporate Marketing, a brand identity consultancy which managed the review of the corporate identity for the charity Understanding Industry, which changed its name this week to Business Dynamics.
fields.body:
Roger Taylor is a corporate strategist with Addison Corporate Marketing, a brand identity consultancy which managed the review of the corporate identity for the charity Understanding Industry, which changed its name this week to Business Dynamics.

His top tips for anyone thinking of rebranding a charity are:

 Talk to all your stakeholders - users, beneficiaries, trustees etc.

 Find out whether their expectations of the charity fit with what you are doing.

 If there is a mismatch decide how you want to position yourself.

 Do further research among stakeholders about repositioning.

 Once you have agreed on your values and purpose start the creative work to rebrand your image.

 Make sure the new logo and name underpin your values, don't have a meaningless name.

 Make sure you can register the name on the internet.

 Use the rebranding to revitalise the staff and charity.

webTitle: Local branches to break away from leading charity

fields.headline: Local branches to break away from leading charity
fields.trailText: The disability charity Mencap is facing a grassroots rebellion after two of its local branches announced they are to pull out of the organisation in protest at its "outdated" approach. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
The disability charity Mencap is facing a grassroots rebellion after two of its local branches announced they are to pull out of the organisation in protest at its "outdated" approach.

Two London Mencap groups have decided to change their name to dissociate themselves from the national charity, whose president is comic actor Lord Brian Rix.

Islington and Kensington & Chelsea local branches say they no longer want a name linked to mental handicap, which they say is derogatory and outdated.

They are also angry at having to compete with the national organisation for grants and funds, and claim that little of the cash raised centrally trickles down to local level.

The decision bucks the trend towards mergers and enhanced corporate identity branding within the voluntary sector.

Director of Islington Mencap, Debbie Pippard, said: "I hope this sends a strong message to the national charity especially as last week's government white paper on learning disability emphasised respect for people with learning difficulties."

She said many other local societies of the charity had talked about the need to change the name.

However, a national Mencap spokesperson said the charity had no plans to change its name, and believed its brand was "based on a positive image".

The spokesperson added: "The local groups are independent charities and are entitled to change their name."

The two rebel branches said they are in competition with the national charity for funds. The local societies of Mencap are all registered as separate charities and many funders such as trusts or local boroughs will only give to one charity with the same name.

The national charity of Mencap has a team of fundraisers who usually win grants and funding much more easily than local societies.

Islington local society receives no funding from national Mencap and Kensington & Chelsea has only received £1,200 in the last two-and-a-half years.

Kensington & Chelsea director Simon Tyler said: "Even the London borough grants committee, one of the major funders in our area, had no perception of the difference between the national charity and the local branch until we explained it."

Kensington & Chelsea branch is to be renamed Equal People from next month. It has a turnover of £500,000 and runs services for local people including a residential home and leisure clubs.

Mr Tyler admitted he was worried about having to raise the profile of the local charity without the branding of the national charity.

"It will be a problem for people who suddenly need our services so we will have to make sure we are getting the message across but the people we work with now are very happy about the decision."

The move was greeted with surprise by others in the voluntary sector. Sean Triner, marketing manager of mental health charity Mind, said: "If any one of our branches wanted to change its name, I would strongly advise against it."

Brand strategist Roger Taylor said: "I'm all in favour of political correctness but I'm very surprised that these branches are deserting a parent charity."

webTitle: Straw and minister clash on youth jails

fields.headline: Straw and minister clash on youth jails
fields.standfirst: Boateng's objections to early release of teenagers are overruled
fields.trailText: Boateng's objections to early release of teenagers are overruled.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has overruled the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, in a Home Office clash over how to keep discipline inside youth jails, according to Whitehall papers leaked to the Guardian.

Mr Boateng objected to a more liberal approach now being introduced of releasing early those juveniles who behaved well, saying it would lead to suggestions that the prison service was rewarding them with reduced sentences as the only way to get them to behave.

The approach also brought a warning from the director-general of prisons, Martin Narey, about whether he could make it work.

But Mr Straw rejected Mr Boateng's criticism and backed demands from Lord Warner, head of the youth justice board, for a more liberal use of the carrot rather than the stick.

The options under the incentive scheme to enforce discipline among the more troublesome teenagers include rewarding good behaviour with early release, in-cell television and allowing them more trips home during their sentence.

The clash between liberal and hardline approaches at the highest levels of the Home Office took place after prison governors complained that the new juvenile detention and training orders did not give them the power to add extra days to a sentence for bad behaviour.

A leaked letter from Mr Narey to Mr Straw of February 12 makes clear that the home secretary rejected the option of new legislation to restore the punishment power of governors for juveniles under 18.

"In consideration of this I wanted to be open about how I will be encouraging governors to use the incentive of early release to encourage good order. You will remember that at a recent bilateral Paul Boateng expressed some concern about that," Mr Narey wrote, going on to make clear that he recognised some of the prison minister's concerns.

He said most young offenders' institutions were coping well, but there was a problem in three jails where the over 18s, who could be punished with extra days, were held alongside the under 18s, who could not.

Mr Narey also said the scheme was in danger of undermining the anti-drugs policy, which has so far proved successful because a positive drug test inevitably led to extra days on the sentence. "But a juvenile who tests positive for drugs can have no such sanction imposed."

He said nothing could be done about teenage offenders who smashed up their cells. If governors reported the matter to police, the courts had no custodial sanction because "the maximum available sentence for criminal damage under £5,000 is a three month period in custody, and the detention and training order [DTO] is a minimum of four months.

"We are doing everything we can to manage this and trying to make the system work. I think we can. But you need to know that to do so I am encouraging governors to exploit the ability of governors to release juveniles early from the custodial part of the DTO if they have made good progress with their sentence plan.

"In other words I am saying that I think we can manage without the stick if we can make reasonably liberal use of the carrot.

"We have no intention of making early release routine. But I recognise Paul's concern that its frequent use might lead to suggestions that we were having to reward young hooligans with reduced sentences as the only means of getting them to behave."

The chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, warned this month that the ban on governors adding extra punishment days on the end of the new sentences had seen some teenage offenders assaulting staff and smashing their cells with impunity, and violence was a growing problem in the youth jails.

webTitle: Tory leaflets inflame race issue after MP's attack

fields.headline: Tory leaflets inflame race issue after MP's attack
fields.standfirst:
Hague repudiates veteran rightwinger's 'unacceptable' praise for Powell but stops short of further action

Leader: Anglo-Saxon attitudes
fields.trailText: Hague repudiates veteran rightwinger's 'unacceptable' praise for Powell but stops short of further action.
fields.body:
William Hague suffered a damaging blow last night when it emerged that Tory associations throughout Britain are publishing openly racist general election leaflets in the wake of his hardline speeches on asylum seekers. As Mr Hague attempted to distance himself from a veteran Tory MP who praised Enoch Powell's infamous attack on immigrants, Conservative election leaflets seen by the Guardian show that general election candidates are exploiting the asylum issue in highly emotive language.

Tories in Dagenham complain that local residents are "disgusted" by Labour's "soft" approach to asylum which has led to "floods of bogus asylum seekers coming into Britain". The leaflet also rounds on the government for "importing foreign nurses with HIV". It adds: "Is this Labour's way of cutting the waiting list, by scaring people not to go to hospital?"

The election leaflets dealt a blow to the attempts by the Tory leadership to distance itself from the rightwing MP John Townend after he lavished praise on Powell's infamous 1968 "rivers of blood" warning. Mr Townend, 66, who is standing down as MP for Yorkshire East at the general election, sparked a storm of protest when he blamed "coloured immigrants" for changing British society.

In a speech to his local association, Mr Townend said: "Our homogeneous Anglo-Saxon society has been seriously undermined by the massive immigration, particularly coloured immigration, that has taken place since the war. We should certainly have acted sooner and I believe Enoch Powell was right in his pessimistic forecast."

Mr Townend, who stood by his remarks yesterday, then turned his fire on today's asylum seekers. "Illegal immigrants now have a new ploy," he said. "They call themselves asylum seekers. In my view the only way to deal with the problem is to send them back quickly. Many come from violent societies and inevitably crime is already beginning to rise."

His outburst was condemned by MPs across the political spectrum. Tony Blair told MPs: "Many, many people, including many members of this house, have backgrounds that come from other countries. In this modern day and age, surely it is not merely a principle that is morally right, but a principle in our self interests that anyone, irrespective of their race or ethnic background, is a full and proper member of our society."

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, who raised the issue at prime minister's questions, accused Mr Hague of fostering racism in his party. "Mr Townend's remarks confirm the inevitable result of William Hague's leadership. Mr Hague has set an uncomfortable tone within his own party over the last few months. His comments on Britain being a 'foreign land' and his obsession with 'bogus asylum seekers' have given credence to offensive opinions within his ranks."

Mr Kennedy was congratulated by the former prime minister Sir Edward Heath who told the Lib Dem leader: "I had to sack Enoch, you know." Sir Edward's reference to the late Enoch Powell, who was sacked from the shadow cabinet after his explosive speech, was seen as a rebuke to Mr Hague, who refused to remove the Tory whip from Mr Townend.

Mr Hague issued a strong statement rebuking the retiring MP, but pointedly stopped short of taking any action. The Tory leader, who recently joined Britain's other main political leaders to sign an anti-racist declaration which was boycotted by Mr Townend, described the remarks as "totally unacceptable and I wholly repudiate them".

A Tory spokesman said that Mr Townend had been "severely rebuked" by the party's whips at Westminster. Tory sources insisted that they would have no truck with racists. One shadow cabinet minister said: "John Townend is standing down at the election - I say good riddance to him. He is a sour-faced rightwinger who has no place in today's party." However, the leadership's attempts to portray the Tory party as anti-racist were undermined by the racist election leaflets seen by the Guardian. In Dagenham, voters are told that Labour will not fly the union flag in the constituency "because it would upset ethnic minorities".

Tories in the marginal seat of Medway claim that Labour is hoping to admit increasing numbers of asylum seekers, adding that the £915m spent on asylum seekers was 100 times the amount needed for a local hospital. In a question and answer section on the back of the leaflets, the Tories ask: "Do you think it is right to accept a moderate number of immigrants so long as they are skilled and do not claim welfare benefits?"

Central office will shrug off the leaflets, saying they are the work of an unrepresentative minority. However, there is a fear among some Tories that Mr Hague gave the green light to such dangerous language when he warned earlier this month that a second Labour term would turn Britain into a "foreign land". One shadow minister said: "That speech was definitely a mistake. I have no problem in saying that Blair will change Britain beyond recognition. But it was wrong to use such an emotive term in a speech which also mentioned asylum seekers."

Despite Mr Hague's questionable speech, there is no doubt that the Tory party at Westminster has changed since the 1980s when activists and some MPs were members of the racist Monday Club.

As a member of the Monday Club in the 1980s, the young rightwinger John Bercow called for the voluntary repatriation of black and Asian people, repeal of the Race Relations Act and abolition of the commission for racial equality. Mr Bercow, now a member of the Tory frontbench, has impressed MPs with the way in which he has abandoned his racist views. "I believe that in a fair society if you start identifying volunteers to leave that can turn nasty," he said recently.

Mr Kennedy was congratulated by the former prime minister Sir Edward Heath who told the Lib Dem leader: "I had to sack Enoch, you know." Sir Edward's reference to the late Enoch Powell, who was sacked from the shadow cabinet after his explosive speech, was seen as a rebuke to Mr Hague, who refused to remove the Tory whip from Mr Townend. Mr Hague issued a strong statement rebuking the retiring MP, but pointedly stopped short of taking any action. The Tory leader, who recently joined Britain's other main political leaders to sign an anti-racist declaration which was boycotted by Mr Townend, described the remarks as "totally unacceptable and I wholly repudiate them". A Tory spokesman said that Mr Townend had been "severely rebuked" by the party's whips at Westminster. Tory sources insisted that they would have no truck with racists. One shadow cabinet minister said: "John Townend is standing down at the election - I say good riddance to him. He is a sour-faced rightwinger who has no place in today's party." However, the leadership's attempts to portray the Tory party as anti-racist were undermined by the racist election leaflets seen by the Guardian. In Dagenham, voters are told that Labour will not fly the union flag in the constituency "because it would upset ethnic minorities". Tories in the marginal seat of Medway claim that Labour is hoping to admit increasing numbers of asylum seekers, adding that the £915m spent on asylum seekers was 100 times the amount needed for a local hospital. In a question and answer section on the back of the leaflets, the Tories ask: "Do you think it is right to accept a moderate number of immigrants so long as they are skilled and do not claim welfare benefits?" Central office will shrug off the leaflets, saying they are the work of an unrepresentative minority. However, there is a fear among some Tories that Mr Hague gave the green light to such dangerous language when he warned earlier this month that a second Labour term would turn Britain into a "foreign land". One shadow minister said: "That speech was definitely a mistake. I have no problem in saying that Blair will change Britain beyond recognition. But it was wrong to use such an emotive term in a speech which also mentioned asylum seekers." Despite Mr Hague's questionable speech, there is no doubt that the Tory party at Westminster has changed since the 1980s when activists and some MPs were members of the racist Monday Club. As a member of the Monday Club in the 1980s, the young rightwinger John Bercow called for the voluntary repatriation of black and Asian people, repeal of the Race Relations Act and abolition of the commission for racial equality. Mr Bercow, now a member of the Tory frontbench, has impressed MPs with the way in which he has abandoned his racist views. "I believe that in a fair society if you start identifying volunteers to leave that can turn nasty," he said recently. fields.trailText: How admirable of William Hague to condemn so rapidly the words of his outspoken backbench colleague, John Townend.
fields.body:
How admirable of William Hague to condemn so rapidly the words of his outspoken backbench colleague, John Townend. Barely had Mr Townend delivered his message to his Yorkshire East constituents - lamenting the "commonwealth immigration" which has undermined "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society" - than his leader had slapped him down, branding his remarks "totally unacceptable."

Surely only a pedant would point out that Mr Hague had a far stiffer penalty at his disposal: he could instantly have denied Mr Townend the Conservative whip, forcing him to spend his remaining weeks in the Commons as a partyless loner. Still, never mind. We should probably overlook that - just as Mr Hague wisely turned a blind eye to the MP's admission that his first draft referred to "coloured immigration". Dirt like that is probably best swept under the carpet. Same goes for Mr Townend's wistful observation that Enoch Powell's predictions of race war were right all along and that, if they knew then what they know now, the British people would have wanted Powell as their prime minister. Sound move, Mr Hague: best to ignore it.

After all, those who point to the Tory leader's recent signature on a Commission for Racial Equality pledge, committing all the party leaders to racism-free politics, are being unfair. For they are surely thinking of the previous Mr Hague - the man of 1997 who went to the Notting Hill Carnival and told his first party conference as leader that he believed in "patriotism without bigotry" and wanted "more black people, more Asians" in his party. How unfair to hold today's Mr Hague to account for the actions of that quite different chap. The 2001 model speaks of "bogus asylum seekers" and warns of Britain being a "foreign land". No sense in blaming this Mr Hague for failing to punish Mr Townend: after all, he helped create the climate in which racist language can flourish.

webTitle: Blair invites religious groups to deliver public services

fields.headline: Blair invites religious groups to deliver public services
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today promised faith-based voluntary organisations a bigger role in the delivery of public services - but insisted that they would not wholly replace state provision. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today promised faith-based voluntary organisations a bigger role in the delivery of public services - but insisted that they would not wholly replace state provision.

In a speech to the Christian Socialist Movement in London, Mr Blair praised the "unique contribution" of churches and faith groups in helping deliver "speedily and effectively" a range of services from health to regeneration.

But he emphasised that the state would not jettison its "obligations" to provide public services, nor would it allow the transfer provision of services to the voluntary sector without the support of local communities.

The prime minister's approach was noticeably less enthusiastic than that of Conservative leader William Hague's who last year proposed to "denationalise compassion" and give charities a bigger role in the provision of public services.

Mr Blair told the conference that the role of faith groups working in partnership with central and local government was "legitimate and important", and that ministers were keen to take forward such partnerships "wherever we can".

He added: "Where you have the desire and ability to play a greater role, with the support of your communities, we want to see you do so. But I emphasize, we want you as partners, not substitutes."

He said it was "misguided and outdated" to suggest that there was a straight choice between voluntary activity and state activity because the two should go together.

"And where the two do go together - the government fully recognising its obligations, looking to the voluntary sector as partner not substitute - the impact is far greater than government acting on its own.

"We see this in countless charities, schools, health projects, youth work, provision for the elderly, the homeless, work with offenders and ex-offenders, local regeneration schemes and many other social activities."

Mr Blair launched Experience Corps, a national organisation which will work in partnership with public and voluntary sector bodies to promoting volunteering by the over-50s at local level. Experience Corps will be chaired by Sally Greengross, the former chief executive of Age Concern.

He promised to test drive projects with local regeneration partnerships to see how obstacles to faith community involvement can be overcome in practice.

Mr Hague told the Charities Aid Foundation in October 2000 that "We must role back the frontiers of the state and allow independent groups and charities the scope to play a bigger role in tackling our social ills.

"It is time to denationalise compassion and create a genuine partnership between government and charities.

webTitle: Conflict looms over rapid reaction force

fields.headline: Conflict looms over rapid reaction force
fields.standfirst: The arguments over the nature of an independent European army have begun in earnest, writes foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: The arguments over the nature of an independent European army have begun in earnest, writes foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall.
fields.body:
No sooner has Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, assured the US president, George Bush, that EU plans to form a defence force pose no threat to Nato than along comes France's top soldier suggesting exactly the opposite.

That it is how it looks, at any rate, after General Jean-Pierre Kelche, chief of the French defence staff, loosed off a powerful salvo in a British newspaper interview, leaving Britain's defence secretary, Geoffrey Hoon, running for cover.

Mr Kelche reportedly insisted that the EU's proposed 60,000-strong rapid reaction force (RRF) would become operational by the end of the year with or without Nato's agreement - and could in future conduct operations independently of the Americans and without necessarily obtaining their okay.

Contrary to what Mr Blair said during a visit to Mr Bush at Camp David last month, Mr Kelche seemed to suggest that the RRF would have to have its own, separate operational planning staff. Furthermore, it would not give Nato a "right of first refusal" over the use of European member countries' troops, Mr Kelche said.

And in a defiantly political statement, unusual for a military man, he told London's Daily Telegraph that the advent of the RRF would be the conscious beginning of an effort by France and the EU to shift the balance of power within Nato away from America.

Mr Hoon said that Mr Kelche's remarks had been misrepresented and distorted as a government attempt at damage limitation got under way. However, it is unlikely that the general would have spoken out on such a controversial issue had he not known that he was reflecting the views of his political masters.

In this case, we are talking specifically about the French president, Jacques Chirac, who has never made any secret of his hope to reduce US influence in Europe.

But Mr Chirac is hardly alone in holding this view in France, or in many other European capitals. Tired of being told by Washington that Europeans do not carry their fair burden of defence expenditures and responsibilities, leading EU countries see the RRF as a constructive and logical response.

If the Americans are now worrying that the RRF will weaken Nato, they are trying to have it both ways - trying to make Europe do more, while retaining control as before. That, at least, is the argument.

The political thinking underlying this is obvious as Mr Chirac, for instance, prepares to fight a presidential election next year. Cutting the Americans down to size is a recurring, popular Gaullist election theme - and if he can show that he has done that through the RRF, there may be votes in it.

But what may seem logical and rational in Paris looks like a big political problem in Britain. The transatlantic alliance has long been regarded as a sacrosanct cornerstone of Britain's defence and a key element in the supposed "special relationship" with Washington.

Tony Blair signed on to the RRF at a meeting with Mr Chirac at St Malo in 1999. As the two biggest European countries in terms of defence capabilities, the project could not sensibly proceed without their joint agreement.

But many critics in Britain, including the Conservative opposition, now say the British prime minister was duped by Mr Chirac in a typical piece of French chicanery. Mr Chirac's insistence at last December's EU summit in Nice on viewing the RRF as an independent entity only strengthened those suspicions.

The Tory opposition spokesman on defence, Ian Duncan Smith, openly accuses the Blair government of conniving in the break up of Nato and thus betraying Britain's vital defence interests. Mr Duncan Smith even went to Washington to warn the Pentagon, as it were, of what he fears is really going on.

Mr Blair and Mr Hoon insist that the RRF, which will be led by a general from neutral, non-Nato Finland, will be compatible with, and indeed subordinate to, Nato.

"The new EU arrangements will complement and strengthen Nato," Mr Hoon said. "The EU will not divert resources from Nato, duplicate its arrangements, create separate military structures or conduct operational planning."

Such British statements are directly at odds with those made by Mr Kelche this week. And they are unlikely to reassure the US, which remains deeply suspicious, despite Mr Blair's Camp David blandishments.

Donald Rumsfeld, the US defence secretary, pointedly declined to endorse the RRF plan at a recent Pentagon press conference with Mr Hoon. He merely noted what the British had said and remarked that "the devil is in the details".

His deputy, Paul Wolfowitz, has also indicated scepticism while suggesting that the more positive welcome given to the RRF plan by the secretary of state, Colin Powell, did not represent the Bush administration's final view on the issue.

All this manoeuvring raises a number of questions. Even if they decide they really cannot tolerate the RRF as envisaged by France, how will the Americans stop it? Will Blair and Hoon be the salami trapped in the resulting sandwich? If Britain and France cannot agree on the RRF's organisation and remit, are we heading for an enormous EU row with immensely damaging implications for those who favour greater European cooperation and integration?

Or, alternatively, are we looking, prospectively, at the break up of the Nato alliance?

Contrary to the conventional wisdom in Britain, there are good reasons for arguing that Nato, essentially a 20th-century cold-war creation, has largely outlived its usefulness.

In Macedonia and Kosovo, for example, European troops have taken the lead in anti-insurgency operations after the Americans largely held back. Given the Bush administration's broad dislike of overseas military entanglements where US interests are not directly at stake, such Europe-only operations, in Europe itself, but also in former spheres of colonial influence like Africa, may be the future.

Membership of Nato also tends to lock European countries into a US world view that they do not necessarily share. Current American antagonism towards Russia, for example, is the cause of considerable unease in Europe, where Russia is a neighbour with whom good relations are desirable.

And, if an increasingly militarily independent Europe is less inclined to back US-led policies such as the bombing of Serbia, then many on the European Left - and even within Blair's Labour party - would probably be all the happier.

fields.headline: Minister slams Celebrity Bodies
fields.standfirst: Decide for yourself: click here
fields.trailText:
3pm: Emap's new women's magazine Celebrity Bodies has been condemned by a government minister as 'grim' reading, writes Julia Day.
Mar 29: Women's mag in crash diet storm
Decide for yourself: click here
fields.body:
Minister for women Tessa Jowell has condemned Emap's new magazine Celebrity Bodies as "grim" reading.

Ms Jowell, who is also minister for employment, said she was depressed by the sight of the women's magazine, which glorifies the diets of celebrities and encourages readers to copy them.

"It's grim. It will add to the torment that 15-year-old girls already feel [about their weight]," said Ms Jowell.

She said her opinion was "personal" not a government line.

In one feature about Friends star Jennifer Aniston, readers are given a diet to help them get from size 12 to size 6.

Last year Ms Jowell chaired a "body image summit" with magazine editors to discuss whether images of skinny superwaifs in the media fuel anorexia.

A Guide Association study found one-fifth of girls aged between 11 and 17 were on diets, while the Eating Disorders Association estimates that one in 100 young women suffers bulimia nervosa.

But Celebrity Bodies editor Alison Hall vehemently denied the magazine will make women, and girls, starve themselves.

"It is not a teen mag. It's aimed at 25 to 35-year-olds," said Ms Hall. "If teenagers do read the magazine, they will not find information telling them to starve themselves, but nutritionally sound diets and healthy exercising routines."

Although the magazine details how readers can copy the diet that took Jennifer Aniston from size 12 to size six, Ms Hall was adamant the title was aimed at health.

"The magazine does not promote skinny women," she said. "It aims to take celebrity diet, exercise and beauty regimes and make them accessible to the reader."

Ms Hall said Emap launched the magazine to cash in on public interest in celebrities and dieting.

She said sales of celebrity magazines increased by 142% last year and that, at any one time, 48% of 25 to 35-year-old women are on a diet.

A date for the next issue of the quarterly magazine has not been finalised.

fields.headline: British reporter killed in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Macedonia
fields.trailText:
A British journalist was killed today near the Kosovo-Macedonia border
as he arrived to cover the deployment of Nato-led peacekeepers monitoring fighting between Macedonian troops and ethnic Albanian rebels.
fields.body:
A British journalist was killed today near the Kosovo-Macedonia border as he arrived to cover the deployment of Nato-led peacekeepers monitoring fighting between Macedonian troops and ethnic Albanian rebels.

Kerem Lawton, 30, a news producer working for Associated Press Television News (APTN), died of shrapnel wounds he suffered when a shell hit his vehicle.

His car was shelled as he arrived this morning in the village of Krivenik, 1,200 yards (1,100m ) inside the Kosovo border. At least two other civilians were killed and 10 others wounded in the assault. Their identities were not immediately known.

Syllejman Klokoqi, an APTN cameraman who was working with Mr Lawton but had left the car moments before it was struck, was uninjured.

Mr Klokoqi said he had left the car to photograph refugees fleeing the area, and Mr Lawton was parking it, when he heard an explosion and saw a plume of smoke. "I saw people lying on the ground. I started shouting, 'Kerem! Kerem!' Then I saw Kerem in the car," he said.

Nato medics treated Mr Lawton at the scene, then took him by road to Camp Bondsteel, a US military base in Kosovo. He was dead on arrival at the base hospital, said US captain Alayne Cramer. She said the medics were unable to fly him out of the area because of sustained fire.

"We are all grief stricken at this loss," said Louis D Boccardi, the president and chief operating officer of the Associated Press. "Kerem's courage and devotion to gathering the story reached beyond any words we can say. We weep with his family and his friends."

Major James Marshall, a spokesman for US forces in Kosovo, said no peacekeepers were reported injured in the assault. American soldiers later sealed off the village.

Both the Macedonian army and the rebels denied that they were responsible for the Krivenik attack. Commander Sokoli, a regional rebel commander, said the insurgents lacked the military capability to strike the village from their positions in Macedonia.

A Macedonian military spokesman, Blagoja Markovski, said the shell that killed Lawton "was not fired from the Macedonian side" but that the army was conducting an investigation to be certain.

UN officials said 10 shells landed in the village. Captain Cramer said a crater analysis was being conducted to try to determine where the shells came from.

Mr Lawton had been based for the past several months in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo province, and earlier had been assigned to Istanbul, Turkey. He is the 26th AP journalist to die in the line of duty since the news co-operative was founded in 1848.

fields.headline: Blairites accused of silencing opponents
fields.standfirst:
Liz Davies on Labour pains
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour's leadership is accused today of creating a "cult-like atmosphere" by a former member of the party's national executive committee.
fields.body:
Labour's leadership is accused today of creating a "cult-like atmosphere" by a former member of the party's national executive committee.

Liz Davies, a leftwing lawyer, claims that Tony Blair and the Labour hierarchy ruthlessly silence internal opposition and treat members with contempt.

The accusations are levelled in her new book, Through the Looking Glass: A Dissenter Inside New Labour. Extracts are published in the Guardian today and tomorrow.

Ms Davies has now left the party but sat on the NEC between 1998 and 2000 after being elected as a member of the Grassroots Alliance group disaffected with the party's Millbank machine. She complains of repeated dirty tricks including late distribution of long reports so they could not be read.

"I was to find over two years that NEC meetings were easily the least democratic, most stitched-up and most unpleasant meetings I have ever attended," she says.

Much of her criticism is directed at Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, but other NEC members, too, come under fire for failing to challenge the leadership.

fields.headline: Talking of war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli and Palestinian leaders are talking today of open, unrestrained war.
fields.body:
Israeli and Palestinian leaders are talking today of open, unrestrained war.

This week has already seen an explosive increase in violence. All Israel was enraged when a Palestinian gunman shot dead a Jewish infant in the occupied West Bank. That atrocity was followed by a clutch of deadly bomb explosions within Israel, in the latest of which an Islamist suicide bomber killed himself and two Israeli teenagers.

The response has been no less savage. On Wednesday night Israeli helicopter gunships blasted Palestinian positions in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, including the home of the Palestinian National Authority president, Yasser Arafat. And this morning three more Palestinians have been shot dead in running battles with Israeli occupation troops.

The new hardline Israeli government led by Ariel Sharon is clearly in belligerent mood. Environment minister Tzahi Hanegbi spoke today of a coming "very lengthy" battle.

"This could likely lead to war, but with the disposition of forces facing each other, this would not be a war in the classic sense," he said.

Indeed, Israel has an overwhelming military advantage over Yasser Arafat ragbag forces. But the Palestinians are in do-or-die mood, with their fragile economy close to collapse after nearly six months of Israeli blockade.

Arafat himself is talking of the start of a "100 day war", and has warned the Palestinians of the occupied territories to prepare for a prolonged military assault.

His warning appeared to be backed up by one of the leading hawks in the Israeli cabinet, Avigdor Lieberman. "As the prime minister has said, this is not a reaction, this is not a one-time operation. This is the opening phase of an overall policy whose aim is putting an end to terror. The difference must be that the political echelon gives full backing to the security forces to do everything they can and know how to do, full freedom of operation," he said.

One of the few rays of light in the encircling gloom of bloodshed and aggression has been the marked change of tack by Washington. Under President Bill Clinton, American policy was based on virtually unqualified support of Israel. That support remains, as witnessed by the US veto in the United Nations of a proposal to send an observer force to the region - a long-held Palestinian objective.

But President George Bush shows little inclination to back Israel all the way. Both the White House and the State Department have sharply criticised the latest bombardments in the occupied territories, while calling for an end to Palestinian militant attacks.

fields.headline: Bedside stories
fields.standfirst: Why the consultant is always right - but it might be necessary to hide the patients from him
fields.trailText: Why the consultant is always right - but it might be necessary to hide the patients from him.
fields.body:
I have been reduced to hiding patients from my consultant. You try telling him that the little old lady whose gall bladder he has whipped out can't go home, just because some occupational therapist says she can't make a cup of tea safely in the practice kitchen. "Out!" he shouts (and he does really shout it) waving his arms around at head height, and moves on to the next patient.

Now, naturally I assumed that this was no more than rather camp affectation on his part: but the same afternoon, the sister on ward 6B bleeps to let me know she has "sorted out" Mrs Henderson. "You know how upset John can get," she says, referring to our consultant surgeon (whose name is Mr Cobb, and definitely not John) as if she were his devoted and long-suffering wife.

The next morning the patient has indeed disappeared. Until the nurses on 3C, an orthopaedic ward, bleep me after lunchtime. "When are you coming to see your patient, then?" (I don't know if you could hear the silent "you bastard" on the end of that sentence). Sitting in the corner is dear old Mrs Henderson, and she still doesn't have a clue where she is. Neither does my consultant: as far as he is concerned, she's back festering in sheltered accommodation. After the mess he made of her insides, I was amazed she even woke up, but there it is. Don't tell anyone, for God's sake.

The patients who have been around for a while think this is all very entertaining. Mr Parkett has been moored to the ward by his ropey waterworks since before I arrived. He has been having secret rendezvous with Mrs Henderson in the smoking room, and now knows that I too have secret liaisons with her, at the end of every ward round.

Unfortunately, I'm not allowed to chat with him like I used to, because he has offended sister. Deluded, perhaps, by the sheer volume of attention that has been lavished on his penis, and the central role it has come to play in his life, he has taken to wearing it outside his trousers (sometimes he just wears anti-blood clot stockings up to his thighs and a rather louche open dressing gown). "I'm not going to talk to you until you put your penis away, Mr Parkett." I say with a broad smile, on sister's instructions, and he rolls his eyes.

So, as you can see, I'm on the wards all day and I'm bored. All the action in surgery happens in out-patients (which is fairly boring) or theatre (which is very boring). All day all I do is paperwork and drip lines. I'm bored of being boring by boring on about it, nobody ever teaches me anything, and even bum jokes aren't funny any more.

I spent the whole of yesterday morning with my eye on a lens attached to a pipe up someone's bum, inflating their colon with air from a pump to get a good view, and replenishing it as it blew out of the margins of their anus, occasionally with such force that I could feel its cool wind against my nose. It wasn't funny. It wasn't even gross. I can have tea and cake in an atmosphere misty with bowel gas without even a twitch. But it is very, very boring.

The only interesting thing about my job is when I get to bear witness to the ball-breaking insensitivity of surgeons. "Your toes," they start to shout, as we walk up to the foot of a bed. "Yes doctor?" replies a little old lady in a floral nightie who, as far as she was concerned, had only popped in to show her GP her cold painful feet out of passing interest. "They'll probably drop off by themselves in the next week or so." And then we rush away to finish the ward round by nine, so that everyone can get to theatre.

But let's go back to that little old lady, because those 14 words were literally all he said to her. "Did I catch that right?" she must surely be thinking. "Did that bloke just tell me my feet are going to fall off? He didn't seem to be making much of an issue out of it. Perhaps I misunderstood."

And worse of all, that brashness, that hurried "I've got something terribly important to do with a big knife over there" stride, is starting to rub off on me. The other day I was a little bit rude to a nurse, albeit a nurse who bleeped me three times in half an hour to write up some non-urgent fluids that she then didn't even bother to put up.

But in medicine you must never forget your place. In medicine the hierarchy is worse even than the military, and the nurses love it: they love having a doctor they can bully, and they think it's so cute when the little baby house officers try and get angry. "I'm not going to talk to you until you put your penis away, Dr Foxton." And that's that.

webTitle: Dea Birkett on her maternity ward hell

fields.headline: My maternity ward hell
fields.standfirst: When  Dea Birkett  went into hospital to have twins, she was shocked by the conveyor-belt experience that turned giving birth into a 'cold, clinical encounter'
fields.trailText: When Dea Birkett went into hospital to have twins, she was shocked by the conveyor-belt experience that turned giving birth into a 'cold, clinical encounter'.
fields.body:
I remember everything about my midwife - her name, her face, the things she told me. She saw me at my GP's practice throughout my pregnancy and visited every day for 10 days after I returned home with my new daughter. She made my first days with my first born a joy.

That was eight years ago and the midwife has moved on. Three weeks ago, I gave birth to twins in the same London teaching hospital, under the same practice. But this second tale of maternity care is not so happy. In less than a decade, the service I took for granted for my first born had collapsed. There is a severe shortage of midwives; two out of three maternity units are understaffed and London hospitals in particular have problems with recruitment.

Last week, a survey of 2,000 recent mothers by the online magazine motherandbaby revealed that most were dissatisfied with the care they received, less than half would be happy to return to the same hospital due to lack of support, and half said they received poor post-natal care at home. Only 4% had the same midwife for antenatal appointments and the birth. "Chronically overstretched maternity staff simply don't have the time to provide the sort of quality care pregnant women expect," says Sarah Stone, editor of motherandbaby. "Many women feel as if they have gone through a conveyor-belt birth experience."

My experience in the labour ward was exemplary. But the moment I was wheeled out of the delivery room and into the packed post-natal ward, it was as if I was being taken from a place where I was the centre of attention to a place where I had to be processed and moved on. The conveyor belt had begun to roll.

It began with my inability to get breakfast. I had been in the ward for less than two hours and my legs were still dead from the epidural. I was awake (I had no choice - the fluorescent lights were on and the curtains around my bed drawn back) and very, very hungry. I had not eaten since breakfast the previous day.

Breakfast was self-service. I watched as the trolley of catering- sized cereal boxes, sliced white bread and mini packets of Flora was wheeled up the centre of the ward. Legless, I called out from my metal-barred bed, "Can I have some cornflakes please?" My cries were drowned out by the baby opposite, who had an infection which wouldn't let him (or us) sleep. The trolley wheeled on past. My thirst was terrible. When a cleaner with a giant mop started wiping under my bed, I asked her if she could kindly get me some water. She took the empty plastic jug from my bedside cabinet, and trotted off to fill it. I never saw her or the jug again.

I was later told it was all to do with the shift change, which coincided with breakfast in the morning and a busy visiting time in the evening. I learned to dread the shift change. If both babies started crying uncontrollably, if I developed a raging thirst while trying to breastfeed, if I needed to go to the toilet, and it happened to coincide with the shift change, then there was no help at hand. The midwives were swapping notes about us somewhere but could not be found on the ward.

The continual change of staff was confusing. When one of my babies wouldn't breastfeed, I was told to feed him from a cup. The next day, a different midwife recommended a bottle or he would lose too much weight. The next day, another midwife said if I gave him a bottle he would never take the breast, so I had to starve him into submission. The following day, that decision was overturned by the next change of staff.

Midwives themselves are not to blame (80% of those surveyed found them "sympathetic and kind"). They are given an unenviable number of roles to play in the postnatal ward. As well as carrying out rigorous medical checks of mother and child, they are expected to inform and educate.

During my three days in hospital, I accumulated no less than six copies of the same full-colour glossy brochure on breastfeeding. Midwives are instructed to promote this method of feeding above all others. The only problem was, through no choice of my own, one of the twins was being bottlefed. It wasn't until two weeks later, when the health visitor (a former midwife who left because of the horrendous hours) came to my home, that I received my first bottle-feeding brochure.

In black and white, it looked like something from the 50s, dated and unattractive. Yet it contained vital information on sterilisation of feeding equipment - information that I should have surely received far earlier. And not only me; despite the emphasis on "breast is best", the vast majority of women in my ward pulled out their ready-made bottles, handing their new-born over to a visiting grandmother. Half of the women in the survey said that, despite trying, breast-feeding didn't work out for them either.

But perhaps, lying behind the disillusionment with maternity care, is a relationship that is inevitably and unavoidably one sided. You never forget the face or name of the woman who helped to deliver your child. Yet, within hours, she will have forgotten yours. It is, therefore, a relationship in which the mother is bound to feel abandoned. For us, it's a time of overpowering importance, when our emotions are at their most raw. For the midwife, it's just a job.

In my ward, the conflict between the expectations of the women in the beds and those pacing the wards was acute. One midwife kept complaining about being tired from working 12-hour shifts. This is not an unreasonable complaint. But we mothers showed no sympathy. What was this midwife moaning on about, when we had been up all night, and would count three hours sleep at a time as a luxury? When the ward manager unplugged the patients' phone, saying staff didn't have time to keep answering it, mutters rippled through the mothers, stranded in bed by caesarean sections and catheters. Calls from family and friends were vital to us. It was as if we were being punished for not rising sooner from our post-natal rest.

At home, the care was no less cursory. My GP practice's midwife no longer makes post-natal home visits; she has too many other clinics to cover. I saw three different midwives over two weeks. They came every four to five days, and it was only so frequently because the baby girl was a bit jaundiced. One weighed the babies with their clothes on; a week later, another weighed them naked, so comparing the weights became meaningless. Another asked me if I had been back for my hospital appointment yet, confusing me with someone else. It is hardly surprising. She had never met me before, and never would again. I was just another mother and baby to visit that day.

"Pressures on the health service mean there is little consistency in antenatal, birth and postnatal care, and some mums-to-be are lucky to see the same midwife twice," says Stone. "The majority of pregnant women do not have the opportunity to build a trusting relationship with a midwife. Instead, most are filtered through a sea of different faces."

Midwives are no happier than mothers with the system. On my post natal ward, they complained of impossibly long and erratic hours, making parenting impossible. Ironically, many midwives change profession when they have children. The government is promising to address this haemorrhaging with a recruitment drive. By 2004, the NHS plans to have 20,000 more nursing staff, although it is not clear how many of those will be midwives.

If I did not have such strong, fond memories of my first child's birth, perhaps this time around would not seem such a cold, cynical encounter. But it does. I did not feel cared for; I felt as if having a baby was burden too much for the health service to bear. I know it can and has been otherwise. To restore a service to what it was almost a decade ago does not seem an exorbitant demand. After all, where better to get it right than from birth.

Calls from family and friends were vital to us. It was as if we were being punished for not rising sooner from our post-natal rest. At home, the care was no less cursory. My GP practice's midwife no longer makes post-natal home visits; she has too many other clinics to cover. I saw three different midwives over two weeks. They came every four to five days, and it was only so frequently because the baby girl was a bit jaundiced. One weighed the babies with their clothes on; a week later, another weighed them naked, so comparing the weights became meaningless. Another asked me if I had been back for my hospital appointment yet, confusing me with someone else. It is hardly surprising. She had never met me before, and never would again. I was just another mother and baby to visit that day. "Pressures on the health service mean there is little consistency in antenatal, birth and postnatal care, and some mums-to-be are lucky to see the same midwife twice," says Stone. "The majority of pregnant women do not have the opportunity to build a trusting relationship with a midwife. Instead, most are filtered through a sea of different faces." Midwives are no happier than mothers with the system. On my post natal ward, they complained of impossibly long and erratic hours, making parenting impossible. Ironically, many midwives change profession when they have children. The government is promising to address this haemorrhaging with a recruitment drive. By 2004, the NHS plans to have 20,000 more nursing staff, although it is not clear how many of those will be midwives. If I did not have such strong, fond memories of my first child's birth, perhaps this time around would not seem such a cold, cynical encounter. But it does. I did not feel cared for; I felt as if having a baby was burden too much for the health service to bear. I know it can and has been otherwise. To restore a service to what it was almost a decade ago does not seem an exorbitant demand. After all, where better to get it right than from birth.

webTitle: Why going to the toilet is important

fields.headline: King in the throne room
fields.standfirst: For many men the loo is a sanctuary - a quiet place to read and think. But, says  Sean Stone, it could also save your life
fields.trailText: For many men the loo is a sanctuary - a quiet place to read and think. But, says Sean Stone, it could also save your life.
fields.body:
The toilet. Perfect sanctuary. Lock the door, park your bum, and leave the world behind. Sit on the throne, master of your universe. Fag in hand, paper on knee, louchely graffiti'd door ahead of you, buttocks squeezed - what could be better?

Toilet time, my favourite time of the day. I always tell my colleagues when it's time to go. I used to get weird looks - disapproving grunts and murmurs. But now they understand. I just wanted to know there was always a little room where you could lock yourself away and contemplate, reinvigorate yourself. The toilet has long been my inspiration. Most of the great headlines are dreamed up in the loo, many life-changing strategies are devised in there. When Blair and Bush talk about thinking out of the box, they mean the thunderbox.

So I'm off to the loo. It's like packing for a holiday. And I always have to return for things I've forgotten. Cigarettes (a must in the non-smoking office), a flow chart so you can get on with a bit of work, a jumper in case the weather changes while you are away. And a book, a newspaper, a magazine. I like reading women's mags on the khazi - stories about how bad I am in bed are a particular favourite; somehow if you do it in public you have to apologise for it. There should always be a stack of magazines to the side of the bowl, and Cosmopolitan should definitely be among them.

I know I'm not alone. We love to read on the bog, especially men. A survey last week by the Imperial Cancer Research Fund (ICRF) found that 49% of men read on the toilet, compared to a slightly disappointing 26% of women. Most men read newspapers, 14% catch up on current afairs, 4% even scan their bills for inspiration.

But if you confine your toilet trips to this season's new lipstick colours, a splash and a wipe, you could be missing something important. The same study found that only 44% of us bother to cast a quick look behind before we pull up and zip up. Which is rather silly. If we paid a little more attention to our crap, according to Dr Wendy Atkins, deputy director of the colo-rectal cancer unit at St Mark's hospital in London, we might just save our lives.

Bowel cancer is the second biggest cancer killer in the UK, next only to lung cancer. In 1998, 17,000 people died of it. Yet it is one of the most treatable forms of the disease - 90% of cases can be stopped in their tracks if caught at the right stage.

The most important thing is noticing the symptoms early. "If you just leap off the loo without having a quick look behind, you might miss it," says Atkins. What you're looking for is blood. Red blood, or clotted blood, not the little spots of blood you might get if you have piles after spending too much time reading on the bog in the first place. Your number twos are also likely to be "more loose", and you might find, says Atkins, that your toilet habits change. By which she means, if you get through the Brothers Karamazov in a week due to the number of times you need to visit the little room, it might also be a sign of something wrong downstairs.

If you have both symptoms - blood in your stools and a touch of the runs - it's time to take it seriously, says Atkins, particularly if you are over 50. And particularly if you have a family history of the disease. And particularly - rather unfortunate, this - if you smoke. "The chance of having a polyp (early stage tumour) is much more likely if you are a smoker," says Atkins. Which makes eminent sense, but rather pisses on one of life's great pleasures.

Needless to say it is men who are especially useless at dealing with their crap. We are, according to Atkins, particularly bad at taking note of something murky in the bowl, hoping instead that it will just go away. It is that great British disease again: embarrassment. But if you see blood more than once, and don't know of anything else that might be causing it, get along to the GP. Better than dying for a crap, so to speak.

Better still, once you have turned round to check that healthy little turd, why not throw the packet of fags down the loo as well. Less chance of cancer, more reading time.

fields.headline: Marathon man
fields.trailText: David Munk: The marathon is still more than three weeks away but already I'm thinking about the afterglow, the pleasant feeling of satisfaction I have been promised once it's all over.
fields.body:
The marathon is still more than three weeks away but already I'm thinking about the afterglow, the pleasant feeling of satisfaction I have been promised once it's all over. Perhaps it will be the warm heavy clunk of a cheese sandwich as it lodges itself in my stomach, the icy fingertip chill of the cold beer in my hand and the thought of not a single race to be run for the rest of my life. No more nights of anguish, cancelled pub appointments, staying late at work to avoid the run I know I need to do. And then there's the sense of achievement ...

But before that there is more pain. Having briefly drifted on a legal high following my sound trouncing of Britain's most successful athlete (Sir Steven Redgrave) in the Murcia half marathon last week, I have come down to earth. I am back on the treadmill, the only memory of my victory, a fading photo in my shorts pocket.

Meanwhile I have been bombarded with reports on what I should be doing to make my body more of a temple, less of a takeaway. This ranges from what shoes I should be using for my training to what shampoo will make my hair right for running. I've also been told my favourite isotonic drink will not be available on the day. Instead there will be a rival brand handed out every five miles. Apparently I need to try this out before the big day, otherwise I could be sick.

But it isn't all bad news. I have discovered a free way of relieving my body of bruises, aches and pains: the cold bath. After a long run, slip into the invigorating comfort of a completely chilled bath for 15 minutes. If you can manage not to grind your teeth into paste, good things will happen to your body.

I am told the logic is this: when you run you get hot and blood rises to the skin surface in order to cool you down. That's why we all go red when exercising. But after a long run you need your blood to be in your muscles, breaking down lactic acid build-ups and helping to mend those minor tears. So to drive the blood there ultra quick and ensure it gets to work, immerse yourself in a cold bath. Blood is no longer needed on the surface and retreats. Another top tip. Who said running wasn't fun?
