webTitle: Three people recently died of pneumonia. Wasn't it supposed to be a disease of the past?

fields.headline: Three people recently died of pneumonia. Wasn't it supposed to be a disease of the past?
fields.standfirst: Laura Barton on the true impact of a devastating illness
fields.trailText: Laura Barton on the true impact of a devastating illness.
fields.body:
It starts with a cough. Nagging away for a couple of weeks. Almost overlooked, really, what with the cold weather and all this flu doing the rounds. The journey to work becomes a steady hack, hack, hack, a red-nosed and weary-boned bus-ride across town. It is only once the coughing gets louder, angrier, when the phlegm becomes blood-spattered, that the worry sets in.

The diagnosis, when it comes, can be a surprising one: pneumonia. A disease - like diphtheria and consumption - that we tend to assume is a thing of the past; an illness of tragic Dickensian heroines. But pneumonia is very much still with us, and can be a devastating illness. Last week, the political journalist Tony Bevins died suddenly of viral pneumonia. A highly respected Fleet Street figure who had been working until recently at the Daily Express, Bevins was only 58.

His death followed those of Frances Lincoln, a successful independent publisher, who succumbed to the illness last month aged 55, and of the artist Sarah Raphael, who died in January at the startlingly early age of 40, having also contracted pneumonia. Raphael's death was particularly shocking: she is reported to have felt ill in the morning, taken her children to school and died by the evening.

"It is still a common disease, and still a serious disease," says Dr John Macfarlane, a respiratory consultant at Nottingham city hospital and chair of the British Thoracic Society's pneumonia guidelines committee. There were 500 cases admitted to Nottinghams's two hospitals last year, he says, 5-10% of which were fatal.

Pneumonia is a disease of the lungs, in which the alveoli (the air-containing spaces in the lungs) and the smaller bronchial tubes become filled with fluid. Symptoms are typically a high fever, lethargy and a difficulty in breathing, as breaths become shallow and painful. Sufferers may sweat profusely, lose their appetite or feel sick, they may appear confused or disorientated. And of course there is a cough - whooping up mucus, which is yellow, green, rust-coloured or bloody. The effects can be sudden - "I fell like a small elm," said one sufferer - and the cough can be immensely painful. "It was like scraping my lungs away," according to another.

Two-thirds of pneumonia cases occur in the winter months. In January 1997, 11,000 people died from the disease in the UK - approximately double the usual number for that month, and the worst bout since 1965. The deaths in that year came on the back of a particularly severe winter flu epidemic, which provided ideal conditions for the infection to spread.

That is because while anyone can fall ill to pneumonia, it is usually only life-threatening if the patient has been weakened or run down by another infection or condition. The disease strikes the elderly two or three times more often than the young. Patients enfeebled by lingering illness or a low immune system, or who have suffered a fall in the cold weather, are particularly at risk. A combination of the body's lowered defences to disease and the enclosed hospital environment, with its inhabitant bugs, allows the infection to flourish. Smokers and those with addictions such as alcoholism are also vulnerable, as are those with serious illnesses affecting the immune system, such as HIV, Hodgkin's disease, cancer, or leukaemia.

Part of the problem is that there is more than one type of pneumonia. The most common is bacterial, which can be treated relatively easily with antibiotics. Viral pneumonia is generally less severe, but has no known cure. The fungal strain of the illness mainly affects those with long-term illnesses such as leukaemia. Macfarlane stresses that the illness, in one of its forms, can attack anyone: 40% of those admitted to hospital in Nottingham were of pre-retirement age.

But a diagnosis of pneumonia need not be a cause for panic. Fatalities tend to be among elderly patients who might have suffered a stroke or have diabetes, says Macfarlane, and cases have fallen since the introduction of the influenza vaccine and the pneumococcal pneumonia vaccine, which is recommended for anyone with lung or heart problems. "Of all the cases of pneumonia which occur annually, about 80% can be treated adequately in the community by a GP, with antibiotics. Only about one in five cases requires hospitalisation."

The important thing to remember, he says, is to try to get regular exercise. Elderly patients often find that their lungs become congested from constant bed rest, as pneumonia bacteria continue to multiply. High fluid intake is essential, and painkillers can ease a chest that has been weakened by endless bouts of coughing. Those deemed particularly at risk may consider having the pneumonia and flu vaccines, but, advises Macfarlane, it never hurts to reduce alcohol consumption, stop smoking, take it easy if you get run down and make sure you get enough sleep and exercise.

webTitle: Dr Ann Robinson answers your queries

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.standfirst: Dr Ann Robinson on preparations for pregnancy and aspirin concerns
fields.trailText: On preparations for pregnancy and aspirin concerns.
fields.body:
Maybe baby

I want to come off the pill and get pregnant, but I've read that you should wait several months before trying to conceive. Is that true? If so, how long should I leave before getting pregnant? And why? Also, how long before should I be taking folic acid?

It is a myth that you need to "wash out" the contraceptive pill from your system before trying to conceive. It is a good idea for you and your partner to have a health check with your GP before throwing away your contraception. It is wise to include a blood test to check that you are immune to rubella (vaccination in adolescence doesn't necessarily mean you are immune; if you're not, it is better to be revaccinated before pregnancy).

Any pre-existing medical conditions should be stabilised. If you or you partner take any prescription drugs, you can check they're safe in pregnancy. Quit smoking, dump any drugs or excess alcohol intake and aim for a balanced diet with moderate chunks of exercise in the run-up to conception. Once you're ready, finish the packet of pills rather than abandoning it in the middle to avoid erratic vaginal bleeding.

Start taking folic acid as soon as you come off the pill. Then you can go for it; your body returns to normal each pill-free week that you have between packets. Some women find their periods don't return immediately but they usually had irregular cycles prior to being on the pill. Fertility often takes time. The average couple takes up to a year to conceive. If you're over 35 and never been pregnant or have reason to think your fertility might need a helping hand, you may want to get medical advice after six months of trying. Good luck!

Ulcer prevention

Twenty-five years ago I had a duodenal ulcer which was cured with a course of ranitidine (Zantac). At that time the treatment was so new that I was recruited to a clinical trial which lasted for a year. Since then I have assumed that I should never take aspirin, as my consultant then advised. However, I believe that it is now established that ulcers of the digestive tract are caused by a bacterium, the treatment for which is antibiotics. I have been prescribed one or two short courses since I had the treatment. Should I continue to avoid aspirin, even though it is now widely used to prevent strokes?

It is true that the bacterium helicobacter pylori has been implicated as a possible cause of stomach ulcers, but not everyone who has an ulcer has helicobacter, and vice versa. Also, the short courses of single antibiotics that you have been given are unlikely to have eradicated helicobacter if you have it. So it is not safe to assume that you are no longer at risk of ulcers, and I should imagine most doctors would advise you to steer clear of aspirin unless there is a pressing reason to take it.

My eight-year-old son has been diagnosed as dyspraxic. What exactly is dyspraxia, how can I get help and is evening primrose oil, mentioned by a friend, any use?

Dyspraxia is now a well-recognised cause of problems that affect kids, especially boys. It is thought to be due to an immaturity of the brain resulting in messages not being properly transmitted to the body. It can account for slowness of toddlers to feed or dress themselves, poor posture, an awkward gait, confusion about which hand to use, difficulties throwing or catching a ball, dislike of being touched, discomfort in certain clothes and materials such as wool, poor short-term memory, difficulty riding a bike and hopping and skipping, reading and writing difficulties and a poor sense of direction.

Speech may be delayed or hard to understand and obsessive behaviour can make the child with dyspraxia hard to cope with. Your son may hate having his nails cut, hair brushed or teeth cleaned, so getting to school in the mornings can be a battle. Kids with dyspraxia don't always fit in in the playground and teachers need to be on guard against bullying. They can be of average or above-average intelligence but are often behaviourally immature.

You are fortunate that your son has been diagnosed because early intervention will improve his outlook. Occupational therapists, physiotherapists and extra help at school can all help him to learn the skills he needs.

Evening primrose oil and cod liver oil are sources of a fatty acid (EPA) known to be involved in the development and functioning of our nervous system. Given in the recommended doses, they won't cause any harm, though firm evidence of their benefits in dyspraxia is awaited. If my child were dyspraxic, I'd be tempted to try some.

Contact the Dyspraxia Foundation helpline on 01462 454986.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

Kids with dyspraxia don't always fit in in the playground and teachers need to be on guard against bullying. They can be of average or above-average intelligence but are often behaviourally immature. You are fortunate that your son has been diagnosed because early intervention will improve his outlook. Occupational therapists, physiotherapists and extra help at school can all help him to learn the skills he needs. Evening primrose oil and cod liver oil are sources of a fatty acid (EPA) known to be involved in the development and functioning of our nervous system. Given in the recommended doses, they won't cause any harm, though firm evidence of their benefits in dyspraxia is awaited. If my child were dyspraxic, I'd be tempted to try some. fields.headline: ASA chief calls for regulation overhaul
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Lord Borrie has called for a single advertising regulator covering all media, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Lord Borrie, the new chairman of the Advertising Standards Authority, has called for a drastic overhaul of advertising regulation to cover newspapers, television and the internet.

He called on the government to create a new watchdog to police all advertising as the boundaries between media become increasingly blurred.

Speaking at the annual conference of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, Lord Borrie pointed to the absurdity of a system whereby the latest FCUK campaign is banned from being aired on TV but is run on French Connection's website and trailed on giant posters.

"Convergence makes the current system distinctly problematic," he said.

"We now have outdoor adverts that carry video advertising that looks just like what we used to call TV advertising. Consumers may soon see no distinction.

"We have shouldn't need to wait for another communications white paper in another 10 years for a common self-regulatory regime that recognises what advertisers actually do."

But Lord Borrie warned the industry that self-regulation would only be allowed to survive if it continued to be effective.

He criticised advertisers for spending too much time focusing on their competitors' advertising and not enough on their own.

Almost 10% of the complaints received by the ASA are now from the advertisers' commercial rivals, he said.

"The self-regulatory system is being hijacked by industry rivalry," he warned.

webTitle: High court to rule on cull of healthy cattle

fields.headline: High court to rule on cull of healthy cattle
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Organic farmer Peter Kindersley today won permission to seek high court orders blocking the government's policy of slaughtering healthy animals to combat the foot-and-mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Organic farmer Peter Kindersley today won permission to seek high court orders blocking the government's policy of slaughtering healthy animals to combat the foot-and-mouth crisis.

In the first legal action of its kind, a judge ruled that Mr Kindersley, 59, a publishing entrepreneur, had "an arguable case" which should be heard as a matter of extreme urgency.

Mr Justice Richards said the challenge should come in a full hearing set for Monday at 2pm.

The multi-millionaire farmer's lawyers had argued that the policy adopted by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food of slaughtering animals which were "only suspected of being infected" or might have been exposed to the foot-and-mouth virus went too far and was unlawful under both European Community and domestic law.

fields.headline: Slaughter is working, says NFU
fields.standfirst:
 Farmers' leader backs Blair's policy
 Hague urges PM to delay election
 Huge Labour poll lead despite crisis

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 Farmers' leader backs Blair's policy
 Hague urges PM to delay election
 Huge Labour poll lead despite crisis
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.body:
The president of the National Farmers' Union today told Tony Blair that there are "positive signs" that the policy of mass slaughter to combat foot and mouth disease is working.

Ben Gill met the prime minister at Downing Street for 90 minutes. Afterwards he told reporters: "It is important to realise that yesterday, for the first time, more animals from infected farms were slaughtered than were actually reported. That's the first time that has been achieved and that is an important development.

"What we need to look at and will continue to look at in the next 24 hours is whether that policy needs augmenting with supplementary measures in Cumbria or any of the other regions. Those supplementary measures might include an element of vaccination."

Meanwhile the Tory leader, William Hague, today accused the prime minister of putting the interests of the Labour party ahead of the country as British tourism and farming industries were being ravaged by foot and mouth disease.

Speaking in North Yorkshire, which today suffered a further case of the disease, Mr Hague made his first public statement on the possible May 3 general election.

He said: "I would be concentrating on fighting this disease and not the election." Mr Hague accused the government of being "behind the game" in tackling the epidemic. "For a long time the government have lacked the urgency and conviction they have needed on this," he said.

The Tory leader was in North Yorkshire to see at first hand the massive impact the disease has had on rural businesses and tourism.

Mr Hague spoke out after an opinion poll was published in the Times showing that the foot and mouth crisis has failed to significantly dent Labour's lead over the Conservatives. That might encourage Mr Blair to opt for his preferred date for a general election - May 3.

The Mori survey showed Labour on 50% - unchanged since late February and the early days of the outbreak. The poll found that support for the Conservatives had firmed slightly - up one point, at 31%. The Liberal Democrats were unchanged on 14%.

The ratings were in spite of the fact that 69% of those polled said they were dissatisfied with the government's handling of the crisis. Only 18% said they were satisfied.

webTitle: Army called in to dig graves for mass cull

fields.headline: Army called in to dig graves for mass cull
fields.trailText: As leading scientists warned that the foot and mouth crisis was spiralling out of control, the Government stepped up its efforts to combat the epidemic with two new policies. This week it began to bury up to 500,000 sheep in mass graves, and has introduced a policy of slaughter on suspicion of the disease without waiting for laboratory tests.
fields.body:
As leading scientists warned that the foot and mouth crisis was spiralling out of control, the Government stepped up its efforts to combat the epidemic with two new policies. This week it began to bury up to 500,000 sheep in mass graves, and has introduced a policy of slaughter on suspicion of the disease without waiting for laboratory tests.

The army is digging about 20 huge trenches, each 4m deep, 15m wide and 150m long, at a disused airstrip at Great Orton, near Penrith in Cumbria. The site is licensed to take the carcasses of half a million sheep that the authorities have not yet been able to burn.

Brigadier Alex Birtwistle, head of the army operation, said the pits were first taking the backlog of rotting carcasses of slaughtered animals that have lain on farms across Cumbria for days. The carcasses are being taken from the farms and sealed in trucks to stop them from spreading disease on their way to Great Orton. The airfield is being scattered with lime to alter the soil's acidity to destroy the virus. Live sheep from areas surrounding infected farms will then be brought in by lorry, slaughtered and buried at the rate of 20,000 a day. "It is an apocalyptic task," Brig Birtwistle said.

Vets have been authorised to slaughter on suspicion, to speed up the killing once farmers have reported a possible outbreak. This is in response to criticism about delays between farmers reporting potential cases, vets visiting the farm, and the subsequent order to destroy the animals. Previously if there was a doubt that livestock had foot and mouth, samples were taken and sent to the laboratory, and a vet would return the next day. Now the animals will be killed at once, and any doubts cleared up later when tests are through.

Government advisers said the single most important factor in controlling the outbreak was to shorten the time between a farmer reporting the disease and the animal being slaughtered. Delays of 26 hours in Devon and much longer in Cumbria have been recorded. The Deputy Chief Veterinary Officer, Martin Atkinson, said the ideal was to get to a farm within two to three hours of the report, and to have slaughtering begin immediately after diagnosis.

Three teams of scientists monitoring the epidemic agreed this week that existing measures were failing to cope. One team forecast an eventual total of 4,400 cases - almost twice as many as in the 1967 outbreak - and another warned that the whole country could be affected.

As the government's chief scientist, Professor David King, admitted that the epidemic was out of control, Tony Blair entered the week that will decide whether he can call a general election for May 3. The Government announced its new measuresin an effort to convince voters that ministers have sufficient control over the crisis to justify pressing ahead with a May 3 poll rather than postponing it until June 7. Though October has been ruled out, June is becoming a serious option despite reluctance in Downing Street and Labour headquarters to abandon their plans.

The Government is also considering an alternative policy of vaccinating cattle near infected areas and pedigree flocks, to buy time and check the immediate spread of the virus. The animals would be slaughtered later to ensure Britain can resume meat exports.

But the crisis shows no sign of easing. By Tuesday the number of cases had reached 649, and the disease had spread to new areas that are important for tourism: East Lothian, near Edinburgh, nearly 160km from the nearest other outbreak in Scotland, and Broughton-in-Furness, on the edge of the Lake District national park. Foot and mouth is also edging into an increasing number of cities. Along with the whole of Bradford, most of Preston and Wolverhampton, all of Blackburn, Gloucester and Worcester, and the outskirts of Stoke and Birmingham, the northwest of Leeds has joined the urban areas officially classified as infected.

An official account of the likely source of the outbreak points to contaminated meat smuggled into Britain. Pigs on a farm in Northumberland were apparently fed meat that was illegally imported for possible use in Chinese restaurants.

It is understood that prosecutions are planned. Unconfirmed reports suggested that officials in the northeast of England had been alerted after a container of illegal meat, labelled for a Chinese restaurant, was found concealed inside a load of household goods.

 The first confirmed cases of foot and mouth were reported in the Republic of Ireland, among sheep in Co Louth, and in the Netherlands, among cows on a small family farm.

fields.headline: Advertising slump hits SRH results
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Scottish Radio Holdings has admitted a difficult start to the year due to a fall in advertising revenues, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings, the media group which is being stalked by several regional rivals, has admitted a difficult start to the year due to a fall in advertising revenues.

SRH said in a trading statement that declining radio advertising revenues would hit first-half figures.

Advertising income from its radio stations for the six months to March this year will be down 4% compared with the same period last year.

Radio advertising makes up around half of the group's revenues, but SRH remained bullish about the market's long-term prospects.

"While the board is somewhat cautious regarding current trends in the UK advertising market, it believes the longer-term prospects for advertising, and radio advertising in particular, remain positive," the company said.

Capital Radio, the UK's largest commercial radio operator, underlined the scale of the downturn last week when it cut full-year profit forecasts by 10% due to do.tcom and telecoms companies reining in their marketing budgets.

The company's first-half revenues climbed 19% to £40m, thanks to SRH's acquisition of Irish newspapers the Kilkenny People and Ireland on Sunday.

SRH is under attack from Virgin Radio owner SMG, which has built a 27.7% stake in preparation for a hostile takeover bid.

SRH executives are seeking alternative bidders and have appointed financial advisers to find the best deal.

SMG is unable to launch a full bid for its rival under current cross-media ownership rules are relaxed, increasing speculation that DC Thomson, owner of the Beano and 10% shareholder, will make an offer.

SRH hinted in its statement that the ongoing speculation over the company's future will be settled before its first-half results in two months' time.

"It is expected that a further announcement on this subject will be made in advance of publication of the group's interim results on 18 May 2001," the company said.

SRH is under attack from Virgin Radio owner SMG, which has built a 27.7% stake in preparation for a hostile takeover bid. SRH executives are seeking alternative bidders and have appointed financial advisers to find the best deal. SMG is unable to launch a full bid for its rival under current cross-media ownership rules are relaxed, increasing speculation that DC Thomson, owner of the Beano and 10% shareholder, will make an offer. SRH hinted in its statement that the ongoing speculation over the company's future will be settled before its first-half results in two months' time. "It is expected that a further announcement on this subject will be made in advance of publication of the group's interim results on 18 May 2001," the company said.

webTitle: Turkey puts rape victims in the dock

fields.headline: Turkey puts rape victims in the dock
fields.trailText: Fatima Polattas says she was 19 when Turkish police raped her while she was in custody. She filed charges, and her four alleged tormenters are now on trial. But so is Ms Polattas. She faces up to six years in prison for insulting Turkey's security forces and the moral integrity of her country by speaking publicly about her ordeal.
fields.body:
Fatima Polattas says she was 19 when Turkish police raped her while she was in custody. She filed charges, and her four alleged tormenters are now on trial. But so is Ms Polattas. She faces up to six years in prison for insulting Turkey's security forces and the moral integrity of her country by speaking publicly about her ordeal.

Ms Polattas is one of 11 women and one man who went on trial in Istanbul last week for describing sexual torture at a conference on sexual abuse and rape organised in Istanbul last year by the Women Workers' Union. Most of the defendants were among 21 people detained by police as they left the conference. They face jail terms of up to 30 years. The court adjourned the trial until June 21, ordering police to find videos of the conference.

Ms Polattas was not at the conference. She is already in jail, serving 18 years for allegedly belonging to the Kurdistan Workers' party (PKK), the outlawed Kurdish rebel group that waged a 16-year war in southeast Turkey for greater autonomy for the country's estimated 12m Kurds. She denies being a member.

Polattas's father is the one male defendant on trial, accused of slander for reading a message from his daughter to the conference.

Polattas, arrested in 1999, says that she and her friend, Ceren Salmanoglu, then aged 16, confessed to being PKK members only after they were beaten, sprayed with freezing water and raped with a truncheon during eight days of interrogation. Salmanoglu was sentenced to 21 years. Polattas and the other defendants at the conference were the first women to speak out about police rape. Women rarely talk of their ordeal, afraid they will worsen their situation by violating laws that restrict freedom of expression when it comes to the honour and reputation of Turkey's security forces.

Ms Polattas's trial highlights Turkey's difficult struggle to clean up its human rights record as it prepares for European Union membership. Two days before the trial began, Ankara published a report promising reforms to end torture. The document also commits Turkey to review laws that restrict freedom of expression.

"Two days ago [Turkey] promised human rights for all. Don't I have that right?" Sultan Secik, one of Ms Polattas's co-defendants, asked the court. The eight police officers Secik accuses of raping her are currently on trial.

International human rights groups have condemned the trial. Amnesty International said it had "called on the Turkish authorities to drop the charges against these women's rights activists who are guilty only of peacefully expressing their views".

Turkey admits that torture occurs, but says it is not systematic. It has promised to crack down on offenders. But, while members of the security forces are being prosecuted, they are often acquitted in court. The five officers accused of raping Nazli Top, another of Ms Polattas's co-defendants, were cleared. The Observer

fields.headline: Graham Taylor factfile
fields.trailText: 1944: Born Worksop, September 15.
fields.body:
1944: Born Worksop, September 15.

1961: Joins Grimsby as apprentice.

1962: Makes first of 189 League appearances for Mariners.

1965: At 21, becomes youngest person to attain full FA coaching badge.

1968: Joins Lincoln, making a further 150 League appearances.

1972: Playing career ended at 28 by a hip injury. Made manager.

1976: Guides Imps to Fourth Division championship.

1977: Quits to take over as manager of Watford, linking up with pop star chairman Elton John to take Hornets from Fourth to First Division in five seasons.

1978: Watford win Fourth Division title, scoring 111 goals and securing then-record 74 points.

1979: Hornets promoted again, this time as Third Division runners-up.

1982: Watford reach top flight for first time as Second Division runners-up.

1983: Taylor guides club to final second place in First Division as they qualify for Europe for first time.

1984: Hornets reach first FA Cup final only to slump 2-0 to Everton.

1987: Quits to take up manager's job at Aston Villa.

1988: Takes Villa back to top flight as runners-up in Division Two.

1990: Guides club to second place in Division One. Appointed manager of England as successor to Bobby Robson. In first game Hungary are beaten 1-0 at Wembley.

1991: Late equaliser by Gary Lineker against Poland in Poznan books passage to 1992 European Championship finals in Sweden.

1992: England go out at first stage following goalless draws with Denmark and France and a 2-1 defeat by home nation, with Taylor substituting Lineker in his final international.

1993: England's hopes of qualifying for 1994 World Cup finals in America dealt devastating blow by controversial 2-0 defeat by Holland in Rotterdam. England beat San Marino 7-1 in final qualifying tie in Bologna, but fail to make finals. Taylor's reign ends when he resigns with a record of 18 wins, seven defeats, 13 draws and seven defeats from his 38 internationals.

1994: Documentary of Taylor during England World Cup campaign shown on television and his phrase 'Do I not like that' becomes national saying. Appointed manager of First Division Wolves.

1995: Molineux club miss out on promotion to Premiership when they are beaten by Bolton in play-off semi-finals. Taylor resigns after a disappointing start to 1995-96 season, as Wolves slump to 18th in table with four wins in 16 games.

1996: Returns to Watford as general manager with task of lifting the rock-bottom Vicarage Road club away from First Division danger zone.

1997: Watford are relegated to the Second Division.

1998: Leads the Hornets back to the First Division at the first attempt.

1999: Watford sneak into the play-offs and reach Wembley, where they beat Bolton 2-0 to claim Premiership status.

2000: Hornets are relegated back to Division One, winning just six matches all season and finishing bottom with 24 points.

2001: March 29: With Watford on the fringes of the play-offs, Taylor announces his decision to retire from club management at the end of the season, after more than 1,000 league games.

webTitle: Final part of investigation into British farming

fields.headline: The big squeeze
fields.standfirst:
Why are supermarkets booming when so many of the people who supply them are close to going under? Andrew O'Hagan concludes his remarkable investigation

Special report: what's wrong with our food?
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Why are supermarkets booming when so many of the people who supply them are close to going under? Andrew O'Hagan concludes his remarkable investigation.
fields.body:
The most comprehensive guide to British farming performance is provided by Deloitte & Touche's Farming Results. "Despite cutting costs and tightening their belts," the report for autumn 2000 concludes, "farmers have suffered the lowest average incomes since our survey began 11 years ago." Several facts stand out, so unreasonable do they seem, and so shocking. "In the last five years the net farm income of a 200-hectare family farm has plunged from around £80,000 to just £8,000 ... Those farmers who have expanded their operations dramatically in recent times ... cannot sustain profitability in the face of tumbling commodity prices."

"The bad news," says Mark Hill, the firm's partner in charge of the food and agriculture group, "is that we predict small profits becoming losses in the coming year. This is due to a further fall in output prices and yield, plus rising costs of £25 per hectare in fuel alone."

Meanwhile the supermarkets are happy enough. Since 1995 Tesco's pre-tax profits have grown from £551m to £842m. Asda's have increased from £258m to £410m. Safeway's were £176m and are now £341m. In 1996 Somerfield made £92m and in 1999 £208.5m. And Sainsbury's has gone from a 1995 profit of £809m to a 1999 figure of £888m.

According to a recent three-volume report from the competition commission, the supermarkets share certain practices that are likely to accelerate their own profits at the expense of farmers and producers. This situation has been too little remarked on: despite complaints of a downturn in profits over the past five years, British supermarkets have enjoyed massive profits at a time when many of the people who produce the goods they sell have been living close to bankruptcy.

There are three common perceptions about British supermarkets. The first is that the food sold in them is much more expensive than it is in their EU counterparts or in the US. Second, there's thought to be a great disparity between what is called the farm-gate price (what the farmer sells a product for) and the price of the item on the supermarket shelf. According to the competition commission, this "was seen as evidence by some that grocery multiples were profiting from the crisis in the farming industry". Third, many people believe that the growth of giant out-of-town supermarkets has been a major factor in the shrinking of town centres and the disappearance of small shops.

There is some truth in each of these accusations. Food prices are on average 12-16% higher in the UK than in France, Germany and the Netherlands. (This trend is exaggerated by the strong pound.) "In a competitive environment," the commission reports, "we would expect most or all of the impact of various shocks to the farming industry to have fallen on farmers rather than on retailers; but the existence of buying power among some of the main parties has meant that the burden of cost increases in the supply chain has fallen disproportionately heavily on small suppliers such as farmers." Yet farmers' troubles are seen to be farmers' troubles.

In market-speak the customer is God. Questions of environmental balance, social welfare, healthy farming culture and common fairness, are not the concern of the competition commission: it is interested only in the extent to which the main supermarkets infringe the customer's right to a good price. Between the lines of their assessments, however, a picture emerges of large-scale indifference to the wellbeing of the agriculture industry on the part of some supermarket chains.

Again and again evidence is presented which makes clear the extent to which the suppliers are squeezed by the retailers. For example, supermarkets usually require suppliers to agree to "various non-cost-related payments or discounts, sometimes retrospectively"; impose charges and make changes to contractual agreements "without adequate notice"; and transfer risks "unreasonably" to the supplier.

In other words, if a supermarket shows an interest in taking on a given product for its shelves, it will, by several routes, require payments from the producer in return for the favour. The overall UK market for groceries was worth around £90bn in 1998. Between them, Asda, Morrisons, Safeway, Sainsbury's, Somerfield and Tesco account for 84% of the total. All the main supermarkets admit to "requesting payments from suppliers as a condition of stocking and displaying their products". All of them admitted requesting suppliers "to make a payment for better positioning of products' in the stores. Many suppliers are familiar with what is known as the "pay to play" system, which requires them to pay fees to the supermarket chains for the privilege of having their products promoted within the store.

The buying power of the British stores puts them in an unassailable position. Some suppliers, such as Peter and Carol Duncan whose Devon farm I visited, speak of a good working relationship with their main buyer. But most of the suppliers I spoke to expressed dismay at the tactics of the multiples. When I asked Tesco if it believed an unfair burden of costs was being passed back to its suppliers, it refused to comment.

A very English drizzle was making a blur of Otford in Kent the day I visited. Hedges were loaded like wet sponges, the short grass squeaked underfoot, there was mud in the road and mud at the farm gate, with a cold whiteness in the sky that darkened quickly in the afternoon. Ian and Anne Carter were sitting in the drawing-room of their farmhouse. She is a JP, groomed to a fine point of civic order, wearing a blue suit with a poppy pinned to its lapel. She is well-spoken, opening up her world in good clear southern English, the language of the prep school and the Shipping Forecast, and her generosity seems to go perfectly with the rationale of the teacups. Ian stretched out his long legs like a teenager: he is likably comfortable with everything he knows and everything he doesn't know; he is right as rain and habitually nice. They both shake their heads.

"You need to have 2,500 acres to make farming work nowadays," he says. "Not so long ago you could have 600 acres and second-hand equipment and send your kids to a good school and holiday in the South of France. That's all gone now."

"Absolutely," agrees Anne, "there has been pressure from fertiliser companies to use certain fertilisers. There are too many sheep owing to these awful subsidies. The whole countryside has changed almost beyond recognition."

Over the fireplace hangs a Constable painting: a portrait of one of Anne's ancestors. There is something darkly lively about the picture. For a while we all sat and stared into it. "It's not at all famous," Anne says. "All the famous ones are out there being admired."

A British Legion-type couple came to lunch. "It's funny the way things go," the man says, "when you think of all those British companies that went to the wall. British manufacturing took such a hammering and now you see a whole way of living and working has disappeared."

"Do you think the land will eventually be nationalised and given to the National Trust?' his wife asks.

"You mean heritaged?" someone else asks.

"Very interesting what's happened to The Archers," Anne says. "This year Nigel, who has the big house, Lower Loxley, is involved in some sort of shooting gallery. They didn't have that before. The Archers has become less and less farming and more sex."

We walked several miles over the fields. Anne spoke about a spiritual connection she felt with the countryside and a hope she retained in the balance of nature. When I walked with Ian he tried to give an account of why things had gone the way they had, a story of overproduction and subsidy distortion and diseased animals and the threat of bad seeds. It seemed less imposing that the land belonged to the Carters, and much more interesting, in an easy, uncomplicated way, that they belonged to the land thereabouts. They seemed to walk it knowingly.

We stopped at the family chapel, dedicated to St Jude, in a building which dates from 1650. A book inside the chapel tells the story of the ownership of this piece of land - the lay ownership from 1066 to 1521, the removal of the house and the farm from a nobleman to one of the wives of Henry VIII. Across from the chapel is a disused cowshed that Anne's father built in 1946. Water dripped from the lintel, and an inscription is carved above. "To the glory of agriculture," it says, "and the working man."

fields.headline: Campaign
fields.trailText: March 30: M&C Saatchi has won NatWest's £30m above-the-line account.
fields.body:
M&C Saatchi has won NatWest's £30m above-the-line account, ending months of speculation.

Nokia is holding a global media pitch for a range of next generation services it is planning to launch through a new division.

Mother has resigned the £3.5m Typhoo Tea account following differences in opinion over future direction of the business.

Political advertising campaigns are in chaos because of the foot and mouth crisis.

HPT Brand Response is to merge with the London office of Impiric.

Nick Moore, the former creative director of BHWG Proximity, is joining TBWA GGT as creative director.

WWAV Rapp Collins is to replace Lesley Mair as chief executive of its London agency with the appointment of Adam Cole from the agency's Scottish shop.

Fallon is to launch the first brand campaign for coffee chain Starbucks.

Marie Claire editor Liz Jones has resigned to be replaced by Marie O'Riordan.

fields.headline: Taylor to retire from football
fields.trailText: Former England manager Graham Taylor is to retire from club management at the end of the season.
fields.body:
Former England manager Graham Taylor is to retire from club management at the end of the season.

The Watford manager, 56, has decided to bring down the curtain on a 28-year career which began with Lincoln in 1972.

"After much consideration and after over 1,000 league games, I have decided it is time for me to retire from club management at the end of this season," he said.

"When I returned to Watford in 1996, I set out a five-year plan for the future of the club, on and off the field.

"With the help of the many people, all of those targets have been achieved, with our year in the Premiership being an added bonus."

"My thanks and appreciation go to all Watford supporters for the wonderful times we have had during my two spells at Vicarage Road - in all a total of 15 years.

"Some of the achievements for a club our size will continually live in my memory."

Following the announcement, Taylor says he will not making any further comment on his retirement because "all of my energies will be focused on our final run of matches as we try to gain promotion to the Premiership once more."

Watford's vice-chairman Haig Oundjian said: " This football club - and indeed the town of Watford - owes Graham Taylor a great debt.

"With the help of those around him, he has put Watford on the football map. Of course, we are deeply saddened to see him depart at the end of the current campaign, but fully respect his decision.

"There is so much more we could say about Graham's contribution, and right now there simply isn't space.

"The short-term objective now is to give Graham and his players every support as the team makes its push for promotion - and then to start looking ahead to appoint a successor."

Taylor enjoyed his best years with the Hornets when he guided them from the Fourth Division to second place in the top flight in 1983, and the FA Cup final the following season.

After taking Aston Villa to the runners-up spot in 1990, he endured a torrid time in charge of the England team, crashing out in the group stages at Euro 92 in Sweden and failing to qualify for the 1994 World Cup in the United States.

The Watford manager, 56, has decided to bring down the curtain on a 28-year career which began with Lincoln in 1972. "After much consideration and after over 1,000 league games, I have decided it is time for me to retire from club management at the end of this season," he said. "When I returned to Watford in 1996, I set out a five-year plan for the future of the club, on and off the field. "With the help of the many people, all of those targets have been achieved, with our year in the Premiership being an added bonus." "My thanks and appreciation go to all Watford supporters for the wonderful times we have had during my two spells at Vicarage Road - in all a total of 15 years. "Some of the achievements for a club our size will continually live in my memory." Following the announcement, Taylor says he will not making any further comment on his retirement because "all of my energies will be focused on our final run of matches as we try to gain promotion to the Premiership once more." fields.headline: Poptones postpones web plans
fields.trailText: Alan McGee's record label Poptones is putting its internet plans on ice, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Poptones, the record company run by music mogul Alan McGee, is putting its internet plans on ice until the industry finds a method of paying for web downloads.

The company was launched with a fanfare last year.

At the time, Mr McGee, the man who discovered Britpop icons Oasis, said: "The future of the record industry is now in the distribution of music content over the internet".

But a Poptones spokeswoman today admitted the label will have to wait until the record industry finds a reliable means of securing payment for internet downloads.

"We are waiting for the model to be established and the standard to be set," said the spokeswoman.

"It is one thing buying a CD over the net but it is another thing to pay for downloading the music."

The record industry is inching towards establishing a standard for downloading and paying for music over the web.

However, the major labels appear more intent on shackling rogue websites such as Napster through multimillion-pound court cases.

Meanwhile, Poptones today revealed it lost just over £1m between June and December last year in its first results since floating in August.

The label registered a turnover of just £175,000 and has £1.4m left of the £2.2m it raised from the flotation.

It was revealed last year the Queen had bought a 2.2% share in the company through her investment adviser.

Poptones has signed 22 bands since its flotation - including Elvis impersonator El Vez and Cosmic Rough Riders - and has sealed 15 international distribution deals.

webTitle: Blair clears way for May 3 poll

fields.headline: Blair clears way for May 3 poll
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday paved the way for a general election on May 3 by agreeing to start a vaccination programme of 200,000 cattle as early as this week and by demanding that local councils reopen swaths of the countryside closed at the start of the foot and mouth epidemic.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Michael White  and Paul Brown
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday paved the way for a general election on May 3 by agreeing to start a vaccination programme of 200,000 cattle as early as this week and by demanding that local councils reopen swaths of the countryside closed at the start of the foot and mouth epidemic.

Mr Blair, determined to give the impression that the government will soon have the crisis under control, hopes to see more than 700,000 animals slaughtered by the weekend, with 50 burial sites identified.

Labour MPs expect him to go to Buckingham Palace next week after officials told them at a private meeting that the party's polling showed it had a 16-point lead over the Tories. Labour's poll, taken at the weekend, showed it ahead on every policy except immigration and asylum. The party's already rock-solid lead on economic competence had risen.

Election strategists who met in Downing Street yesterday believe that Mr Blair will face charges of insensitivity for the first two or three days of the campaign, but can ride out the charge.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, also gave the first public clue of how Labour will simultaneously fight an election and the spread of foot and mouth. He told MPs the 26-strong rural task force would continue to meet during the election and promised that any largesse to farmers would "not be done in a political way".

The main block to the election juggernaut was advice from some senior Labour MPs that William Hague now privately favours a May 3 election in the belief that the crisis has knocked the sheen off Mr Blair.

Despite the Tories' formal opposition to a May 3 poll, shadow cabinet members now believe that it provides the best chance to trim Labour's Commons majority to well below 100. One Tory MP said: "At last we've got an issue to hang our hat on: competence and opportunism."

The move to inoculate cattle, inititally in Devon and Cumbria, is expected to be announced today.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, who has in effect been sidelined by the prime minister this week, last night met the National Farmers Union leader, Ben Gill, to tell him that the vaccination programme must go ahead. Government sources said farmers' leaders increasingly recognised there was now no alternative to what was once described as the last resort.

A European Union veterinary surgeons' meeting in Brussels yesterday gave approval for the vaccinations to start. No fresh domestic legislation is required. Adequate supplies of vaccination are said already to be available in Britain. Once vaccinated the cattle will eventually be slaughtered, but the move buys ministers time and helps create firebreaks.

General Sir Mike Jackson, commander of British land forces and a Kosovo war veteran, personally oversaw the start of the mass slaughter in Cumbria. The animals were being buried in a mass grave. But the backlog of sheep waiting to be slaughtered in the county had risen to 140,000, leaving the government far off its target of reducing the wait from identification to slaughter to 24 hours. A total of 41 new cases were announced yesterday, taking the total nationwide to at least 716.

The Ministry of Agriculture has now authorised 764,319 animals for slaughter, including 552,550 sheep. So far 481,909 of the total have been slaughtered with 282,410 animals still be culled.

The prime minister admitted that it could not be said with certainty when the disease would end. Pressed by Mr Hague in the Commons, he conceded: "When you say how can we be sure when the disease is going to end, the answer is we cannot be sure at the present time."

In an attempt to reopen the countryside and save the ravaged rural tourist industry, ministers yesterday agreed revised guidelines for the opening of footpaths. Organisations such as the National Trust were pressed to reopen.

webTitle: Leave the Balkans to the big boys and forget about Vaz

fields.headline: Leave the Balkans to the big boys and forget about Vaz
fields.standfirst: It's time to clear up some misconceptions about Labour's foreign policy
fields.trailText: It's time to clear up some misconceptions about Labour's foreign policy.
fields.body:
Protecting Keith Vaz is Robin Cook. Not just protecting, eclipsing. That is the point about Mr Vaz, a man of many guises. The smarmy politician, like the wheeler-dealer at the centre of squalor in the Labour party in Leicester East, momentarily becomes less significant than the junior minister at the Foreign Office, whose performance in his job is termed "deeply regrettable" by the Commons select committee on foreign affairs. But this time the charge is not justified. The Tories are calling it the most devastating attack ever made by a committee on a serving minister. It helpfully guides us, instead, towards three misperceptions about Labour's conduct of foreign policy. Let us get them out of the way, in ascending order of importance, before the election.

First, there does not need to be a junior minister with responsibility for the Balkans, and he does not need to go there. The job is as absurd as the committee's judgment is ritualistic. The MPs seared Vaz for his ignorance and his absence, as if there was anything he could do to affect a policy that is entirely out of his hands. The Balkans is big stuff, which Mr Cook has rightly taken under his personal control, with the prime minister close alongside. The whole of policy, moreover, is done collectively inside the European Union. For the committee to remark that the EU commissioner, Chris Patten, has been to the Balkans seven times while minister Vaz hasn't gone near the place is a reproach based on the premise that empty ceremonial remains at the heart of political accountability.

Which perhaps is a mirror of the committee's own role. To the over-stretched officials and military people trying to make a useful difference in Kosovo and the rest of the region, the only thing more irritating than a visit from a token British minister was surely the collective descent upon them, requiring to be watered and chaperoned, of a parliamentary committee whose subsequent report throws little more light on Balkans policy than many journalists have done before. The luckless Vaz, with his meaningless Balkan label, got caught up in the committee's own empty vanities.

Second, though, his proper role as minister for Europe has been misconceived in a different way. This is not his fault, nor parliament's, but the government's. Most countries have ministers with that title, and many of these make serious contributions to thinking about the EU. They are often politicians to be reckoned with. In both Germany and France, the Europe ministers have a standing that entitles them to be heard, with opinions that sometimes disagree with their superiors'.

Mr Blair has got through Europe ministers at the rate of one a year. Literally no job in the whole of government has come closer to being treated as a trash-can. The one occupant with the qualifications to fill it, Joyce Quin, was quickly moved on. The government thus accumulates little collective memory, or cultural affinity, for the kind of networking that is second nature to European politicians. Even harder than getting ministers to go to the Balkans is interesting them in the much more useful function of attending informal European get-togethers. Not long ago, at the annual Bertelsmann Foundation conference in Berlin, attended by Chancellor Schröder and President Prodi, and several foreign ministers, as well as a number of presidents from central Europe, the best Britain could field was a Conservative baroness. The government voice for the British interest simply wasn't heard.

This is a habitual British pattern, probably worse under Labour than the Tories. Since Peter Mandelson left office, there hasn't been a single leading Labour figure willing to do anything abroad which his department doesn't tell him he has to do. We need a Europe minister liberated to take the task of intelligent networking seriously, something Blair and Cook, in thrall to hierarchies of control, do not encourage. That person Keith Vaz will never be.

Third, though, Cook has become on the whole an excellent foreign secretary. His low reputation with his political enemies and several newspapers is the biggest misperception at the end of these four years, owing a lot to the kind of vicious, personalised triviality which can endure so much longer here than in more mature societies.

Apart from the major misfortune in his private life, Cook made one calamitous error at the start of his term, which was to promise an ethical dimension to his foreign policy in terms that have led to him being ethically faulted ever since. It was an honourable but half-baked claim, hoisting to prominence the false assumption that his predecessors had always been unethical and carrying the implication that he, a principled foreign secretary, would address the harshness of the world from a more elevated position. With the exception of a slight improvement in the European rules for arms sales, this he has naturally failed to do.

But he is now admired in quarters we seldom hear about. The Foreign Office itself, many of whose top people detested his posturing at the start, has succumbed to his intellectual swiftness. Some officials still reflect bitterly on the responsibility which, as they see it, he failed to take for the Sandline affair in Sierra Leone, instead dumping them in the dirt. But his thorough grasp of many issues now overshadows his notorious reluctance to carry half-a-dozen red boxes home at night.

He has likewise made friends in the European Union. For two years, he took no interest in the EU and made little impact on British policy there. Now he is an important player. When Mr Blair had to leave last week's Stockholm summit early, he could rely not only on Cook playing the British hand as he would have done but - a privilege not granted to many foreign ministers - on the Schröders and Chiracs accepting him at the table without demur. The friends of Mr Blair now say the leader cannot do without his foreign secretary. Of all top ministers, he has the closest, least troubled working relationship of any with the prime minister.

Though he, too, was tritely criticised by the select committee for not visiting the Balkans, it is there, in his own eyes, that he has earned the greatest credit. His role was less spectacular than Joschka Fischer's. He didn't, like the German foreign minister, put his political life on the line to persuade his party of the case for defending Kosovo against ethnic purging by the Serbs. But alongside Blair, from a different wing of old Labour, he can take some credit for the removal of Slobodan Milosevic from power. In the scales that measure ethical foreign policy with a political purpose, this weighs in as a not inconsiderable item.

After the election, I think Keith Vaz will no longer be minister for Europe, or the Balkans. A good thing too. But Robin Cook will still be foreign secretary, because nobody would do a better job.

fields.headline: Committee meanings
fields.trailText: The House of Lords voted this week against a ban on hunting, against any system of outside supervision, and in favour of self-regulation: a system widely disparaged in society nowadays, especially by the press. But perhaps that is unfair to the hunting lobby.
fields.body:
The House of Lords voted this week against a ban on hunting, against any system of outside supervision, and in favour of self-regulation: a system widely disparaged in society nowadays, especially by the press (except, of course, in the case of the press, where they're for it). But perhaps that is unfair to the hunting lobby. For as the hunting baroness, Lady Mallalieu, explained on the radio, what in fact they favour - what in fact they've already got - is independent self-regulation. So that's all right, then. Everything is under control and we people who don't like hunting can go back to sleep.

So why is it that as I contemplate this assurance, there suddenly swims before me the gaunt and haggard face of one of my greatest heroes, George Orwell? Perhaps because he wrote a novel, 1984, one of whose themes is the way politicians misuse and corrupt our language, the way in their mouths words come to mean not what they used to mean, but what they want them to mean. Also because he published an essay called Politics and the English Language which ought to be learned by heart by everyone who goes into political journalism. Here he warns against what he calls a "catalogue of swindles and perversions": words used in variable meanings, "in most cases more or less dishonestly": class, totalitarian, science, progressive, reactionary, bourgeois, equality....

But surely that noble concept, independence, has nothing to do with any of these? Look how anxious people have been to claim it, from the Declaration of Independence on. When three Daily Telegraph journalists decided to leave their old paper and set up on their own, what better title could they have found than the Independent, signalling that their new venture was not beholden to anyone? Or look at the institutions which cluster under the name Independent in the phone book - from suppliers of cars and corporate membership to the Independent Talent Company and the Independent Women's Protection Association. Not to mention those that have aimed slightly off and are listed as Independant.

But the ghost of George Orwell has started to mutter impatiently. "When you see the word 'independent'," he orders, "ask yourself: independent of whom? Independent of what?" Independent of whom? Of Big Brother government, certainly. But of the hunting lobby? George Orwell's ghost is not too sure about that.

When this list was read out by Lord Phillips of Sudbury in the debate there were protests from pro-hunting peers, with Lady Mallalieu to the fore. Only one member of the commission which runs ISAH's affairs, she said, had any connection with hunting. Well, maybe. But if I catch him correctly, George Orwell is saying: always, when you see the report of some committee or commission, ask: who recruited these people? Why are they there?

Sometimes, as with the one which Margaret Thatcher appointed to look at the future of broadcasting, the facts make a hole in the dogma and the politicians do not get the outcome they want. But quite often they do. I know nothing of the commissioners who serve at ISAH and of course accept the organisation's assurance that none comes from a hunting body. You bet.

webTitle: Foot and mouth is a  good thing

fields.headline: Foot and mouth is a  good thing
fields.standfirst: If our herds are infected it can only be of benefit in the long run
fields.trailText: If our herds are infected it can only be of benefit in the long run.
fields.body:
Last week a friend working in Kenya explained Britain's foot and mouth policy to a Maasai cattle herder. The nomad found our approach horrifying and hilarious in equal measure. His first objection was that all cattle belong to the Maasai, and no one had asked their permission. Then he wanted to know why Britain found it so hard to suppress a disease which the Maasai had learnt to control generations ago. When my friend explained that we were hoping to start selling our meat abroad once more, he was mystified: "Why on earth would you want to do that?" he asked. This is a good question, which we in Britain have so far failed to ask, let alone to answer.

Yesterday, the Times suggested that our meat exports are worth "up to £1bn a year". As usual, the paper of record seems to be making it up as it goes along. The Ministry of Agriculture's figures for last year show that we exported £310m worth of cattle, pigs and sheep to the European Union, and next to nothing elsewhere. Interestingly, this figure represents a decline of 39% from 1999. If this trend continues, our exports will dwindle to zero in three years' time. But it won't continue. Foot and mouth, for most foreign buyers, is the final straw, confirming their well-founded suspicion that our farming is unsafe. There is no guarantee that exports will resume at all when the UK is declared free from disease.

Most of our livestock sales, moreover, are subsidised, by both headage and export payments. The truckers who drive them around are also state assisted, as their fuel and road taxes now pay only some 80% of the costs they impose on the Exchequer. Livestock sales, in other words, are likely to cost the country more than they make.

So parts of the countryside have been declared off limits, the tourist industry has been all but obliterated, rare breeds have been slaughtered and hundreds of businesses have been closed to protect an industry which is worth not £1bn a year, not £570m as ministers have claimed, not even the £310m that Maff figures show, but, in all probability, less than nothing.

Surely then, there must be other reasons for the government's declaration of war with Britain's sheep? One compelling argument is that Europe insists we stamp out the disease. But the European rules - which arose, anyway, from the British insistence on curtailing foot and mouth through mass slaughter - are designed to protect trade between member states. Were we to abandon our fantasy animal exports, then the requirement would become obsolete.

Foot and mouth disease does have implications for animal welfare. In extreme cases, livestock suffer gravely from the lesions on their mouths and feet. But we can put down animals in this condition without having to slaughter the entire herd, let alone the healthy stock on surrounding farms. Indeed, one of the many idiocies of the mass slaughter programme is that animals in distress are reached no faster than animals which aren't suffering at all: it prolongs pain, rather than relieving it. The selective culling of badly infected stock, moreover, is likely to lead to an improvement in disease resistance, which many of our over-developed new breeds are now woefully lacking. Any suffering caused by foot and mouth would surely be offset by terminating the cruel and unnecessary live transport of animals to other countries.

There is no doubt that foot and mouth will also lead to reduced yields of milk and meat, but it's hard to understand why this should be considered a problem. Thanks to overproduction, the EU has introduced a quota system which ensures that every time we buy a pint of milk, we have to pay two pence over the market price.

The benefits of endemic foot and mouth, by contrast, must surely be obvious. It would encourage farmers to develop local markets for their produce, which is the only strategy which makes both economic and environmental sense. It would reduce the number of lorries on the roads. It would persuade breeders to phase out strains with poor resistance to disease and inherent welfare problems, and return to hardier types which don't require such intensive management.

So the government's decision to start vaccinating livestock should be opposed, on the grounds that it might eliminate foot and mouth from Britain. The ministry should continue to spread the disease around as rapidly as possible, by pursuing a slaughter programme it doesn't have the capacity to implement, leaving piles of rotting animals strewn around the countryside, then setting fire to them so that the virus is lifted into the jetstream and widely dispersed. If the vaccination programme is successful, then, as an urgent strategic priority, the government should reinfect the country forthwith.

fields.headline: Anglo-Saxon attitudes
fields.standfirst: Mr Townend is not alone in giving offence
fields.trailText: Mr Townend is not alone in giving offence.
fields.body:
How admirable of William Hague to condemn so rapidly the words of his outspoken backbench colleague, John Townend. Barely had Mr Townend delivered his message to his Yorkshire East constituents - lamenting the "commonwealth immigration" which has undermined "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society" - than his leader had slapped him down, branding his remarks "totally unacceptable."

Surely only a pedant would point out that Mr Hague had a far stiffer penalty at his disposal: he could instantly have denied Mr Townend the Conservative whip, forcing him to spend his remaining weeks in the Commons as a partyless loner. Still, never mind. We should probably overlook that - just as Mr Hague wisely turned a blind eye to the MP's admission that his first draft referred to "coloured immigration". Dirt like that is probably best swept under the carpet. Same goes for Mr Townend's wistful observation that Enoch Powell's predictions of race war were right all along and that, if they knew then what they know now, the British people would have wanted Powell as their prime minister. Sound move, Mr Hague: best to ignore it.

After all, those who point to the Tory leader's recent signature on a Commission for Racial Equality pledge, committing all the party leaders to racism-free politics, are being unfair. For they are surely thinking of the previous Mr Hague - the man of 1997 who went to the Notting Hill Carnival and told his first party conference as leader that he believed in "patriotism without bigotry" and wanted "more black people, more Asians" in his party. How unfair to hold today's Mr Hague to account for the actions of that quite different chap. The 2001 model speaks of "bogus asylum seekers" and warns of Britain being a "foreign land". No sense in blaming this Mr Hague for failing to punish Mr Townend: after all, he helped create the climate in which racist language can flourish.

webTitle: A baldy with a funny accent, speaking in code

fields.headline: A baldy with a funny accent, speaking in code
fields.trailText: Nobody wanted to mention the "E" word during prime minister's questions. In particular, William Hague can't appear to be running from an election.
fields.body:
Nobody wanted to mention the "E" word during prime minister's questions. In particular, William Hague can't appear to be running from an election.

Tony Blair wants it to seem that his choice of date will be made exclusively to benefit the national weal, and will have nothing whatever to do with cutting and running before the recession gets worse and before every animal in the country, including cute pet kittens and frolicsome puppies, has been shot, oh dear me, definitely not.

So Mr Hague had to employ a kind of code. After dancing around the prime minister, so to speak, trying to imply that the rampaging plague was in some way Mr Blair's fault without actually accusing him of feeding poisonous leftover number 37 with pak choi and egg fried rice to the pigs of Northumberland, he reached the point.

"The prime minister has promised to strain every sinew," he said. The present crisis required the use of all military resources "and every ounce of the prime minister's care and attention". In other words, this is no time for such frivolities as an election. Actually, "strain every sinew" is one of those dead metaphors you only ever hear politicians use. Brought back to life by a linguistic Frankenstein, it sounds to modern ears more like a cookery recipe. "Plunge the sinews into boiling salted water and simmer for five minutes. Then drain, being careful to strain every one."

Mr Blair, of course, was having none of it. "We are doing everything we can to bring it under control," and he was wise to say that, since if he had appeared to give way on the election, almost the entire parliamentary Labour party would have called for his removal to the nearest abattoir. They really want that election, now.

But nobody mentioned it. The tension in the chamber was almost unbearable. Most MPs are ready to snap. If they don't know about the poll, one way or the other, within 24 hours, some of them will be found naked under Westminster bridge, painted bright green, and claiming to hear messages from giant talking pigs.

So there was a happy moment of relief half way through. Tim Loughton, the Tory MP for Worthing East, had a question on the order paper. Unfortunately for him, it came the day after he had described his leader as "a baldy with a funny accent".

The public loves politicians who tell the truth, but politicians hate it. So even though Mr Loughton had gone on to say, "in spite of these drawbacks, he is a miracle worker who could cure foot and mouth if he only had time to lay hands on five million sheep" (or words to that effect), he was in big trouble.

Labour MPs had passed the word around, and greeted his question with cheers and cries of "more, more!", before he even started.

Mr Loughton had a choice. He could grin winsomely, chuckle, and make some self-deprecating remark, such as "...speaking as someone with far too much hair and a stuck-up accent..." Or he could be pompous.

He chose pompous.

"While Labour members cheer..." he said magnificently, rather like Sir Peter Tapsell waiting for the Hansard reporters to get out their stone and chisels so as to immortalise his words.

The cheering redoubled. The Speaker called for order. Mr Loughton sat down. The cheering ebbed. Then he rose again, pomposity coursing in his veins like steroids through an Olympic athlete.

"While Labour members cheer..." he went on, before reminding us of the state of play in the countryside.

A Labour MP I know was sitting diagonally opposite the Tory leader, and reported that, ever so slightly, he blushed.

webTitle: Blair in row over job for aide

fields.headline: Blair in row over job for aide
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, are at loggerheads over a proposal to offer a top political aide a new job as political secretary at £120,000 a year, if Labour wins the next election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, are at loggerheads over a proposal to offer a top political aide a new job as political secretary at £120,000 a year, if Labour wins the next election.

Sir Richard has threatened to block the appointment of Anji Hunter because the prime minister wants to use £70,000 of taxpayers' cash to fund the post. The Labour party would pay the other £50,000.

The offer would make Ms Hunter, 45, now Mr Blair's social secretary, the highest paid political adviser in the government. She would earn £20,000 a year more than his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, and chief of staff, Jonathan Powell.

Mr Blair has known Ms Hunter since she was 15. She has worked for him since 1983 and has been described as his "fixer, charmer and tactician".

The Guardian has learnt that Sir Richard is against further use of taxpayers' funds for people in a political role, and objects to a proposal that Ms Hunter should have executive powers over civil servants.

Mr Blair's present political secretary is Sally Morgan. Her post has no executive power and she gets half the salary proposed for the revised post. She would have to become an assistant to Ms Hunter or leave.

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman said: "We cannot comment on speculation, especially about individuals." Ms Hunter said last night: "I am not speaking to you. As you know, I do not speak to journalists."

fields.headline: Peer apologises to MPs for contempt
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: A hereditary peer and a chief executive of a private regulator yesterday "unreservedly apologised" to MPs in the first parliamentary contempt hearing for nearly a decade.
fields.body:
A hereditary peer and a chief executive of a private regulator yesterday "unreservedly apologised" to MPs in the first parliamentary contempt hearing for nearly a decade.

The Earl of Cranbrook, chairman of Entrust, and Richard Sills, its chief executive, are the first people to be admonished by MPs since Ian and Kevin Maxwell were dragged before a parliamentary committee in 1992 and made to apologise for refusing to answer questions about their disgraced father, Robert Maxwell.

Lord Cranbrook and Mr Sills were accused under the 1892 Witnesses (Public Inquiries) Protection Act of "threats and molestation" of a key witness to an investigation by the Commons environment sub-committee into the government's waste policy. MPs yesterday accused them of "behaving like petulant schoolgirls" after they sacked a "distinguished environmentalist", Malcolm Aickin, from an Entrust job paying up to £40,000 a year.

This followed evidence given to MPs by Mr Aickin attacking the organisation's ability to supervise a £350m funding programme (money from waste operators' donations to environmental groups).

Mr Aickin had been ordered to give evidence after the Guardian passed to MPs a memorandum he had written for the committee which had been altered out of all recognition before it reached parliament. In his original memorandum, Mr Aickin said that the regulations Entrust administered were "inadequate and inconsistent to the point of incompetence". He accused the regulatory body of "a potential abuse of power" by changing its constitution to dispose of its assets in secret if it faced being wound up. This point was removed from the official evidence from his advisory body, which instead praised Entrust.

After the hearing Mr Sills withdrew a job offer to Mr Aickin, which he had already accepted, accusing him of "damaging Entrust's reputation and inflicting severe injury on the [landfill tax] credit scheme and all of those participating in it".

Mr Sills wrote: "In view of your correspondence with the select committee and public utterances, both written and oral, some of which I understand are soon to be published officially by the committee, Entrust can no longer rely on your advice or your ability to maintain a reasonable degree of confidentiality about our relationship."

Andrew Bennett, Labour chairman of the sub-committee, asked Lord Cranbrook and Mr Sills to appear before MPs for contempt of parliament.

Yesterday, Lord Cranbrook said: "Entrust recognises ... the letter should not have been written in [those] terms. It accepts that the letter constitutes a contempt of the rights and privileges of the House of Commons and its committees. Entrust unreservedly apologises for that contempt."

However, MPs were infuriated yesterday when the peer refused to discuss Mr Aicken's wider criticisms while praising him as "independent minded and distinguished".

Gwyneth Dunwoody, Labour chairwoman of the environment committee, said: "You are behaving like petulant schoolgirls by sacking a man who provides you with unwelcome criticism you won't even consider."

MPs advised that Entrust be scrapped and replaced with a publicly run watchdog.

fields.headline: C5 celebrates England win
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: Channel 5 got its biggest ever audience for its coverage of England's World Cup qualifier, write Lisa O'Carroll and Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's audiences plunged last night as viewers switched in droves to Channel 5 for England's World Cup qualifier.

The channel struggled to pull in viewers from the moment C5's match against Albania kicked off at 7.30pm.

Channel 5 hit its biggest ever audience with an average of 5.5m viewers, although at one point - around 9pm - up to 8m viewers were tuning in.

ITV managed to limit the damage with Coronation Street surviving on 10m viewers and a 46% share of the audience.

At kick off the network had just 3m viewers who had tuned in to see Greg Rusedski and Tara Palmer Tomkinson on Celebrity Steady Cook. And its audience share dropped to 13%.

Mean Streets, the first of a six-part series on driving, got 3.2m viewers - a 14% share of the audience.

Channel 5's coverage of the tense World Cup qualifying clash in Tirana, which ended in a 3-1 England victory after a late goal rush, had a 24% audience share - more than four times the Channel 5 average.

The live football was followed by a repeat showing of cult Michael Caine gangster movie Get Carter between 10pm and 12.10pm.

Get Carter had 2.1m and a 16% share.

Overall yesterday, Channel 5 had a 13.6% share of viewing - more than double its average.
