fields.headline: Gebt Gas - auf eigene Gefahr
fields.standfirst: Young drivers cause a quarter of all road accidents in Germany so traffic experts want every newly qualified driver to go through a four-year trial period. Break the law and they lose their licence. Nicole Prestle sounds out young people's opinion
fields.trailText: Young drivers cause a quarter of all road accidents in Germany so traffic experts want every newly qualified driver to go through a four-year trial period. Break the law and they lose their licence. Nicole Prestle sounds out young people's opinion
fields.body:
"Ich will Spass, ich geb' Gas." Mit diesem Text besang einst ein deutscher Musiker das Lebensgefühl der jungen Generation. Wer richtig gut drauf ist, drückt im Auto auf die Tube. Je schneller, desto besser. Je riskanter, desto beeindruckender.

Die Wirklichkeit sieht ein wenig anders aus. Und trotzdem: Autofahrer zwischen 18 und 25 Jahren verursachen laut Statistik jährlich ein Viertel aller Unfälle, bei denen Menschen verletzt werden. Sie sind zu schnell unterwegs, fahren dem Vordermann zu nahe auf, nehmen anderen die Vorfahrt oder biegen falsch ab.

Jetzt wollen Experten vorbeugen: Für vier Jahre soll es den Führerschein künftig "auf Probe" geben. Wer sich in dieser Zeit nicht an die Verkehrsregeln hält, muss die Fahrerlaubnis abgeben. Bekommt er sie zurück, beginnt die Probezeit (die es bereits gibt, allerdings nur für zwei Jahre) von Neuem. Wir haben uns bei jungen Menschen erkundigt, was sie von strengeren Regeln für Führerschein-Neulinge halten.

Frage: Sind junge Leute die schlechteren Autofahrer?

Marita (19): Das kann man so sicherlich nicht sagen. Viele junge Menschen fahren ja gerade vorsichtig und ganz genau nach den Regeln, weil sie noch ein wenig unsicher sind. Das nervt zwar meistens die anderen Autofahrer, aber das ist ja egal.

Peter (20): Ich muss ehrlich zugeben: Als ich meinen Führerschein neu hatte, bin ich manchmal schon etwas schneller gefahren als erlaubt. Schon allein, um die Mädchen zu beeindrucken. Ich bilde mir aber ein, nie riskant unterwegs gewesen zu sein.

Philipp (18): Ich mache den Führerschein gerade. Und bei den Fahrstunden ist mir aufgefallen, dass viele Menschen, die erst etwas später Auto fahren lernen, genauso unsicher sind. Ich glaube also nicht, dass es am Alter eines Autofahrers liegt, wenn er sich im Straßenverkehr falsch verhält.

Frage: Experten hatten vorgeschlagen, dass Fahranfänger künftig nicht mehr nachts unterwegs sein sollen. Auch an eine PS-Grenze für Neulinge war gedacht. Ein Gericht hat all diese Ideen verworfen. Was sagt ihr dazu?

Claudia (16): Ich habe ja noch keinen Führerschein, aber zum Teil halte ich diese Vorschläge für falsch. Gerade das Nachtfahrverbot. Selbst wer einen Führerschein hat, müsste dann abends von der Disko mit älteren Freunden mitfahren oder vielleicht sogar per Anhalter unterwegs sein. Mir wäre es da immer noch lieber, mich auf mein eigenes Können zu verlassen und selbst zu fahren. Außerdem ist nachts doch ohnehin weniger los auf den Straßen. Da können auch junge Leute fahren.

Marita: Den Ansatzpunkt kann ich verstehen. Damit wollen Experten wohl den vielen Unfällen vorbeugen, die zum Beispiel nach dem Besuch einer Disko passieren. Ich frage mich nur, was dann jemand macht, der bei Tag an einen Ort gefahren ist und nachts wieder zurück will. Dürfte der dann gar nicht mehr nach Hause fahren? Oder gar nicht erst losfahren? Ich glaube, eine solche Regel wäre schwer durchzusetzen.

Philipp: Eine PS-Obergrenze könnte nicht schaden. Das macht man ja jetzt auch bei Motorrädern schon so. Warum also nicht auch beim Auto? Meine Eltern zum Beispiel wollen mir einen Wagen kaufen, der nur um die 60 PS hat. Und mich strt das nicht. Auch damit komme ich überall hin.

Frage: Wie denkt ihr über ein absolutes Alkoholverbot für Leute, die noch Auto fahren müssen?

Angelika (17): Das halte ich für absolut richtig. Ich setze mich nie in das Auto eines Freundes, von dem ich weiß, dass er etwas getrunken hat. Und wenn die Grenze bei 0,0 Promille liegt, ist die Hemmschwelle für viele doch noch viel größer, weil keiner seinen Führerschein verlieren will.

Peter: Das ist völlig ok. Oft kann man ja gar nicht einschätzen, welche Wirkung schon ein Glas Bier auf einen haben kann. Das hängt ja auch vom Tageszustand des Körpers ab. Also ist es am besten, gar keinen Alk zu trinken, wenn man im Auto unterwegs ist. Ich mache das schon jetzt so.

Frage: In anderen Ländern sind die Autos von Führerschein-Neulingen oft gekennzeichnet . . .

Philipp: Das finde ich ganz gut. Die anderen Fahrer nehmen dann vielleicht etwas mehr Rücksicht.

Peter: Das ist meiner Meinung nach sinnlos. Im Gegenteil: Das verleitet die anderen Verkehrsteilnehmer eher dazu, solche Autos rasant zu überholen, weil sie glauben, der Fahranfänger vor ihnen wird sowieso viel zu langsam fahren.

der Alk (coll) alcohol

per Anhalter hitchhiking

der Ansatzpunkt starting point (for a discussion)

gut drauf sein (coll) to be in a good mood

die Hemmschwelle barrier (mental)

fields.headline: Labour's grim spring
fields.standfirst: To we Conservatives, Labour looks as if it's heading back to the old horrors of the winter of discontent
fields.trailText: To we Conservatives, Labour looks as if it's heading back to the old horrors of the winter of discontent.
fields.body:
What a difference a month makes. Before the outbreak of foot and mouth, before the stock market crash, the government kept reciting, "No more boom and bust". Many believed it. Now people are not so sure.

This government of soothing soundbites is discovering that asinine spin when a crisis hits does not reassure. Farmers did not believe the government when they were told that the foot and mouth outbreak was under control. They were worried to death as the disease stalked ever closer to their farms. Steel workers at Llanwern do not believe that the government has created economic stability, as they line up to collect their P45s. Lorry drivers are not convinced that the government is on their side, seeing their businesses taxed and regulated to death.

This cold, hard, wet, sometimes snow ridden, grey, miserable spring is proving to be Labour's spring of discontent. You could see it in the faces of the Cumbrian protesters when Tony Blair swept in by Jaguar four weeks after the foot and mouth disaster struck. You can see it in the faces of the hoteliers and leisure operators looking at blank booking diaries, ringing their bank managers anxiously to see how long they will tide them over. You can see it in the crushed looks of the dot.com brigade, whose year of fun is well and truly over.

The government still tells us that the economy is fine. It has after all abolished boom and bust. When I warned that it could not abolish the trade cycle, I was told I was wrong. Now the trade cycle, like an unfriendly boomerang, is coming back to haunt them. Soon the government will solemnly tell us that Britain is fine, but unfortunately the US under Mr Clinton (they will probably blame Mr Bush) did not succeed in abolishing boom and bust, so there will be some collateral damage over here.

The truth is that this government has ensured that the bust will be bigger for more people in Britain than it need have been. It will be worse in the countryside. As we watch the funeral pyres mount on our TV screens, we are sickened and saddened by the slaughter. We see a way of life going up in smoke. No one can say how much animal husbandry there will be after this. No one in authority wants to tell us how many sheep and cattle will have to die before it is all over. People might be able to accept the slaughter if it was working, but so far it isn't. What we do know is that many farming businesses will go under.

We also see that the government's unsuccessful attempts to contain the disease are threatening countless other rural businesses with bankruptcy. The message has got out that much of the countryside is closed to tourists.

No amount of expensive advertising can restore the position, if footpaths are closed, if all contact with animals of any kind is banned, if the government gives out a message that you can go to the countryside but cannot walk on the grass. Pity the poor hotelier, tour operator or employee at a rural attraction.

Meanwhile, back in the City there has been a dramatic collapse in confidence. This week's rally has not restored the fortunes of investment banks and brokers. Wall Street started it, but now home grown problems are making it worse. Telecoms stocks have fallen around the world. One of the main reasons is the greed of the British government in designing an auction to charge them £22bn to stay in the business - followed by a similar auction in Germany, which charged them another £50bn. European governments decided to smash the telecoms industry, and they succeeded. They should not be surprised if such a massive hit causes cash problems and leads to redundancies and cancelled investment programmes. What did they expect?

Much of British manufacturing is suffering from high taxes and regulations at home, and a weak euro abroad. The government turns a deaf ear to them, as the factory closures and sackings mount. The dot.coms are largely history. Many middle of the road businesses are tearing up their plans for 2001 based on rosy government forecasts and battening down the hatches to prepare for the economic storm.

The government now faces not one crisis, but a series of intersecting ones. Its efforts to save farming will bring down much of the rural tourist industry. Its efforts to tax success will help bring down the dot.com and telecom sectors which led the growth of the 1990s. Its belief that business can pay more and accept more regulation will destroy jobs in manufacturing. Its belief that motoring is evil leaves us dependent on a railway system which has got worse.

Governments need to control events, or tell the public honestly they cannot and keep out. This government has said it can control the foot and mouth epidemic, but failed so far. It has said it can control the transport system and make it better, and has failed so far. It has said it has abolished boom and bust. What is it going to say and do now, when so many are staring bankruptcy or job loss in the face? Now is truly our spring of discontent. It is back to the 1970s with a vengeance.

 John Redwood is Conservative member of parliament for Wokingham

webTitle: Tory leaflets inflame race issue after MP's attack

fields.headline: Tory leaflets inflame race issue after MP's attack
fields.standfirst: Hague repudiates veteran rightwinger's 'unacceptable' praise for Powell but stops short of further action
fields.trailText: Hague repudiates veteran rightwinger's 'unacceptable' praise for Powell but stops short of further action.
fields.body:
William Hague suffered a damaging blow last night when it emerged that Tory associations throughout Britain are publishing openly racist general election leaflets in the wake of his hardline speeches on asylum seekers. As Mr Hague attempted to distance himself from a veteran Tory MP who praised Enoch Powell's infamous attack on immigrants, Conservative election leaflets seen by the Guardian show that general election candidates are exploiting the asylum issue in highly emotive language.

Tories in Dagenham complain that local residents are "disgusted" by Labour's "soft" approach to asylum which has led to "floods of bogus asylum seekers coming into Britain". The leaflet also rounds on the government for "importing foreign nurses with HIV". It adds: "Is this Labour's way of cutting the waiting list, by scaring people not to go to hospital?"

The election leaflets dealt a blow to the attempts by the Tory leadership to distance itself from the rightwing MP John Townend after he lavished praise on Powell's infamous 1968 "rivers of blood" warning. Mr Townend, 66, who is standing down as MP for Yorkshire East at the general election, sparked a storm of protest when he blamed "coloured immigrants" for changing British society.

In a speech to his local association, Mr Townend said: "Our homogeneous Anglo-Saxon society has been seriously undermined by the massive immigration, particularly coloured immigration, that has taken place since the war. We should certainly have acted sooner and I believe Enoch Powell was right in his pessimistic forecast."

Mr Townend, who stood by his remarks yesterday, then turned his fire on today's asylum seekers. "Illegal immigrants now have a new ploy," he said. "They call themselves asylum seekers. In my view the only way to deal with the problem is to send them back quickly. Many come from violent societies and inevitably crime is already beginning to rise."

His outburst was condemned by MPs across the political spectrum. Tony Blair told MPs: "Many, many people, including many members of this house, have backgrounds that come from other countries. In this modern day and age, surely it is not merely a principle that is morally right, but a principle in our self interests that anyone, irrespective of their race or ethnic background, is a full and proper member of our society."

Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, who raised the issue at prime minister's questions, accused Mr Hague of fostering racism in his party. "Mr Townend's remarks confirm the inevitable result of William Hague's leadership. Mr Hague has set an uncomfortable tone within his own party over the last few months. His comments on Britain being a 'foreign land' and his obsession with 'bogus asylum seekers' have given credence to offensive opinions within his ranks."

Mr Kennedy was congratulated by the former prime minister Sir Edward Heath who told the Lib Dem leader: "I had to sack Enoch, you know." Sir Edward's reference to the late Enoch Powell, who was sacked from the shadow cabinet after his explosive speech, was seen as a rebuke to Mr Hague, who refused to remove the Tory whip from Mr Townend.

Mr Hague issued a strong statement rebuking the retiring MP, but pointedly stopped short of taking any action. The Tory leader, who recently joined Britain's other main political leaders to sign an anti-racist declaration which was boycotted by Mr Townend, described the remarks as "totally unacceptable and I wholly repudiate them".

A Tory spokesman said that Mr Townend had been "severely rebuked" by the party's whips at Westminster. Tory sources insisted that they would have no truck with racists. One shadow cabinet minister said: "John Townend is standing down at the election - I say good riddance to him. He is a sour-faced rightwinger who has no place in today's party." However, the leadership's attempts to portray the Tory party as anti-racist were undermined by the racist election leaflets seen by the Guardian. In Dagenham, voters are told that Labour will not fly the union flag in the constituency "because it would upset ethnic minorities".

Tories in the marginal seat of Medway claim that Labour is hoping to admit increasing numbers of asylum seekers, adding that the £915m spent on asylum seekers was 100 times the amount needed for a local hospital. In a question and answer section on the back of the leaflets, the Tories ask: "Do you think it is right to accept a moderate number of immigrants so long as they are skilled and do not claim welfare benefits?"

Central office will shrug off the leaflets, saying they are the work of an unrepresentative minority. However, there is a fear among some Tories that Mr Hague gave the green light to such dangerous language when he warned earlier this month that a second Labour term would turn Britain into a "foreign land". One shadow minister said: "That speech was definitely a mistake. I have no problem in saying that Blair will change Britain beyond recognition. But it was wrong to use such an emotive term in a speech which also mentioned asylum seekers."

Despite Mr Hague's questionable speech, there is no doubt that the Tory party at Westminster has changed since the 1980s when activists and some MPs were members of the racist Monday Club.

As a member of the Monday Club in the 1980s, the young rightwinger John Bercow called for the voluntary repatriation of black and Asian people, repeal of the Race Relations Act and abolition of the commission for racial equality. Mr Bercow, now a member of the Tory frontbench, has impressed MPs with the way in which he has abandoned his racist views. "I believe that in a fair society if you start identifying volunteers to leave that can turn nasty," he said recently.

webTitle: Kelly McGillis talks to  Emma Brockes

fields.headline: 'I didn't want to do Top Gun. It wasn't about acting, it was about being a cartoon character'
fields.standfirst: Kelly McGillis talks to  Emma Brockes
fields.trailText: The star of Top Gun, Witness and The Accused talks to Emma Brockes about her new movie, The Monkey's Mask, and the problems that she faced, as a mother of two, with the film's explicit sex scenes
fields.body:
The most frequently asked question at Kelly's Bar and Grill is, "Where's Tom?" A Caribbean restaurant in Key West, Florida, it serves buffalo wings, crab cakes, grilled lobster and a homely number called Kelly's shrimp fettucini. Customers take photos of it and post them on the internet because the Kelly of the shrimp dish is Kelly McGillis, while Tom is Tom Cruise. The pair's collaboration on the 1986 movie Top Gun impressed teenagers enough to send them shuffling into the actor's joint, 15 years later, in search of an ending.

"They come in asking, 'Where's Tom?'" says McGillis wearily. "And I say, 'I don't know. I guess he's somewhere else.' And they say, 'Well, aren't you married?' I mean, these are adults, for Christ's sake. I have to say to them, 'That was a movie - it was fake.' People come in and go, 'You cut your hair.' And I go, 'Yuh, I've cut my hair in the last 15 years. I hope you have too.' It drives me a little nutty."

There are two reasons for the enduring fascination with McGillis's role as flight instructor Charlie Blackwood: Top Gun's status as a symbol of the glossy 1980s and McGillis's subsequent withdrawal from blockbuster movie-making. She is more famous as the subject of "where are they now?" enquiries than for the roles she created to provoke them.

After Top Gun, McGillis freaked out, moved to Florida and put most of her energy into catering. Witness, the Amish country thriller in which she starred with Harrison Ford, was not seen widely enough to unseat her public image as a springy-haired siren riding pillion to the strains of Take My Breath Away.

This week she has taken a break from the restaurant to be in London for the opening of The Monkey's Mask, a low-budget Australian flick directed by Samantha Lang. Based on "a novel in poetry" by Dorothy Porter, it is the story of Jill, a private detective investigating the death of a young girl while falling in love with the girl's poetry lecturer (played by McGillis).

The movie, which has had its premiere as part of the London Lesbian and Gay film festival, is powerfully shot and has a dream-like quality to it, although of the kind used by young directors to mitigate structural problems. The sex scenes are explicit, the performances strong and the end result is a chaotic but interesting film. The kind description is "experimental", the honest one "pretentious gubbins". It appealed to McGillis, she says, because of its juxtaposition of beautiful poetic language and dark, ugly subject matter. "I read the book and thought, it's in verse, it's interesting, it's challenging. I thought it was a courageous move."

Even in an empty London restaurant it takes a few moments to recognise McGillis. She's Florida-tanned, with the pinched look of someone who's spent too many hours in the gym. She's also in the slightly crabby stages of jet lag. "Listen. At 43, I don't give a shit what people's expectations of me are. It took me a long time to learn that. If other people are disappointed, that's not my fault. It's a stupid way to live your life, to make other people happy. You can't."

The expectations in this case are that The Monkey's Mask is some kind of coming-out statement for McGillis, the denouement of a rumour that took off after she shot the rape drama The Accused with Jodie Foster. It is pathetic, she says, but she is accustomed to it. "I knew that making this film would start all that up again. And it doesn't bother me. Next week I'm coming out as an Amish, the week after that as a navy pilot. This is a role, not a statement about my life. It isn't about me 'coming out', but if people want to think that - fine. I don't care."

Florida - especially the Keys - has a large gay population and if McGillis's choice of film reveals anything, she says, it is the core liberal belief that people should live their lives the way they want to, preferably with backing from the state. "If two people are in love, I have a hard time saying they shouldn't get married. If that's what you choose to do with your life, that's wonderful. Love and happiness are so hard to find in this world that if you can find them, God bless you."

McGillis treads a weird line between flinty belligerence and self-deprecation. She says she cried during the filming of The Monkey's Mask because she had to do sex scenes with a woman 20 years her junior. "Every night I was on the phone to my husband, crying, 'Am I pretty?' I was scared to death. It's hard exposing yourself physically in front of millions of people when you've had two kids."

At the same time, she thinks that actors who kick up a fuss to anyone but their partners are completely pitiful. One of the reasons she stopped doing big-budget films was the hours wasted while the star threw a tantrum. "I've worked with actors who, when the director says, 'You have to sit down and cry,' say, 'I don't know how to do that.' Well - hello? - that's your job. I've been in situations where actors will lock themselves in their trailers for hours and say, 'I'm not coming out, I'm not taking my clothes off.' And it's like, 'You know what, honey? You read the script, you knew you were gonna be naked, so get out here and do the shot, 'cause I want to go home and have lunch with my kids. OK?'"

If McGillis displays the zeal of a convert, it's because for a while she was in danger of being sucked into the celebrity whirlpool she had despised since high school. Despite growing up in LA, she always wanted to work in theatre and as a teenager ran away to New York to train at the Juilliard drama school. She stood before the mirror and ruled out a career in movies. "My whole image of myself was a tall, fat, geeky, ugly girl that nobody liked. I thought I was too tall for the movies - I'm still taller than anyone I work with. It never crossed my mind that someone might want to hire me for a movie."

But in 1983, after four years of heavy-duty method work, she landed a role in Reuben Reuben, a comedy with Tom Conti, and made a big enough impression to win the lead role as an Amish woman in Witness in 1985. Then came Top Gun. McGillis pauses, reluctant to slag it off even at this late stage, then laughs and says what she thinks. "I didn't want to do it - there. But because I'd done Witness, I owed Paramount another film, and my agent said, 'You have to do this.' I took one look at it and said, 'This is like a western in the sky - I don't wanna do this.'

"It wasn't about acting, it was about being a cartoon character. You know what I mean? I could have done it blindfolded. I was grateful for the fact that it gave me opportunities I wouldn't otherwise have had. But I showed up for work, did my bit, hung out with a bunch of boys, played baseball, and went home. It was like being at camp. Why they hired me I'll never know."

She was tempted by the crazy offers that followed the film's release and spent months "terribly depressed" with indecision. "I didn't know how to deal with it. I didn't know how to be a household name, because it's never what I aspired to. I didn't want to live up to these huge expectations. I wanted to be able to go the store and buy Tampax without being asked for my autograph. I wanted to be a mom to my kids."

So she flew to Washington DC, did a theatre production of Chekhov's The Seagull, got married to a yachting millionaire, Fred Tillman, and had two children, now 10 and seven. She bought a restaurant in Florida, waited tables, and deflected the astonishment of customers who recognised her as one of the most famous actresses of the 1980s. In between, she satisfied her creative instinct by doing low-budget films and a lot of theatre.

"I want to be acting when I'm 92," she says. "I want to die acting, and that wasn't going to happen if I carried on doing films like Top Gun. So I decided I would always try to do something unexpected, not to shake up other people's ideas of me, but for myself." And she invites those who don't like it to kiss her "big, fat ass".

The pair's collaboration on the 1986 movie Top Gun impressed teenagers enough to send them shuffling into the actor's joint, 15 years later, in search of an ending. "They come in asking, 'Where's Tom?'" says McGillis wearily. "And I say, 'I don't know. I guess he's somewhere else.' And they say, 'Well, aren't you married?' I mean, these are adults, for Christ's sake. I have to say to them, 'That was a movie - it was fake.' People come in and go, 'You cut your hair.' And I go, 'Yuh, I've cut my hair in the last 15 years. I hope you have too.' It drives me a little nutty." There are two reasons for the enduring fascination with McGillis's role as flight instructor Charlie Blackwood: Top Gun's status as a symbol of the glossy 1980s and McGillis's subsequent withdrawal from blockbuster movie-making. She is more famous as the subject of "where are they now?" enquiries than for the roles she created to provoke them. After Top Gun, McGillis freaked out, moved to Florida and put most of her energy into catering. Witness, the Amish country thriller in which she starred with Harrison Ford, was not seen widely enough to unseat her public image as a springy-haired siren riding pillion to the strains of Take My Breath Away. This week she has taken a break from the restaurant to be in London for the opening of The Monkey's Mask, a low-budget Australian flick directed by Samantha Lang. Based on "a novel in poetry" by Dorothy Porter, it is the story of Jill, a private detective investigating the death of a young girl while falling in love with the girl's poetry lecturer (played by McGillis). The movie, which has had its premiere as part of the London Lesbian and Gay film festival, is powerfully shot and has a dream-like quality to it, although of the kind used by young directors to mitigate structural problems. The sex scenes are explicit, the performances strong and the end result is a chaotic but interesting film. The kind description is "experimental", the honest one "pretentious gubbins". It appealed to McGillis, she says, because of its juxtaposition of beautiful poetic language and dark, ugly subject matter. "I read the book and thought, it's in verse, it's interesting, it's challenging. I thought it was a courageous move." Even in an empty London restaurant it takes a few moments to recognise McGillis. She's Florida-tanned, with the pinched look of someone who's spent too many hours in the gym. She's also in the slightly crabby stages of jet lag. "Listen. At 43, I don't give a shit what people's expectations of me are. It took me a long time to learn that. If other people are disappointed, that's not my fault. It's a stupid way to live your life, to make other people happy. You can't." The expectations in this case are that The Monkey's Mask is some kind of coming-out statement for McGillis, the denouement of a rumour that took off after she shot the rape drama The Accused with Jodie Foster. It is pathetic, she says, but she is accustomed to it. "I knew that making this film would start all that up again. And it doesn't bother me. Next week I'm coming out as an Amish, the week after that as a navy pilot. This is a role, not a statement about my life. It isn't about me 'coming out', but if people want to think that - fine. I don't care." Florida - especially the Keys - has a large gay population and if McGillis's choice of film reveals anything, she says, it is the core liberal belief that people should live their lives the way they want to, preferably with backing from the state. "If two people are in love, I have a hard time saying they shouldn't get married. If that's what you choose to do with your life, that's wonderful. Love and happiness are so hard to find in this world that if you can find them, God bless you." McGillis treads a weird line between flinty belligerence and self-deprecation. She says she cried during the filming of The Monkey's Mask because she had to do sex scenes with a woman 20 years her junior. "Every night I was on the phone to my husband, crying, 'Am I pretty?' I was scared to death. It's hard exposing yourself physically in front of millions of people when you've had two kids." At the same time, she thinks that actors who kick up a fuss to anyone but their partners are completely pitiful. One of the reasons she stopped doing big-budget films was the hours wasted while the star threw a tantrum. "I've worked with actors who, when the director says, 'You have to sit down and cry,' say, 'I don't know how to do that.' Well - hello? - that's your job. I've been in situations where actors will lock themselves in their trailers for hours and say, 'I'm not coming out, I'm not taking my clothes off.' And it's like, 'You know what, honey? You read the script, you knew you were gonna be naked, so get out here and do the shot, 'cause I want to go home and have lunch with my kids. OK?'" If McGillis displays the zeal of a convert, it's because for a while she was in danger of being sucked into the celebrity whirlpool she had despised since high school. Despite growing up in LA, she always wanted to work in theatre and as a teenager ran away to New York to train at the Juilliard drama school. She stood before the mirror and ruled out a career in movies. "My whole image of myself was a tall, fat, geeky, ugly girl that nobody liked. I thought I was too tall for the movies - I'm still taller than anyone I work with. It never crossed my mind that someone might want to hire me for a movie." But in 1983, after four years of heavy-duty method work, she landed a role in Reuben Reuben, a comedy with Tom Conti, and made a big enough impression to win the lead role as an Amish woman in Witness in 1985. Then came Top Gun. McGillis pauses, reluctant to slag it off even at this late stage, then laughs and says what she thinks. "I didn't want to do it - there. But because I'd done Witness, I owed Paramount another film, and my agent said, 'You have to do this.' I took one look at it and said, 'This is like a western in the sky - I don't wanna do this.' "It wasn't about acting, it was about being a cartoon character. You know what I mean? I could have done it blindfolded. I was grateful for the fact that it gave me opportunities I wouldn't otherwise have had. But I showed up for work, did my bit, hung out with a bunch of boys, played baseball, and went home. It was like being at camp. Why they hired me I'll never know." She was tempted by the crazy offers that followed the film's release and spent months "terribly depressed" with indecision. "I didn't know how to deal with it. I didn't know how to be a household name, because it's never what I aspired to. I didn't want to live up to these huge expectations. I wanted to be able to go the store and buy Tampax without being asked for my autograph. I wanted to be a mom to my kids." So she flew to Washington DC, did a theatre production of Chekhov's The Seagull, got married to a yachting millionaire, Fred Tillman, and had two children, now 10 and seven. She bought a restaurant in Florida, waited tables, and deflected the astonishment of customers who recognised her as one of the most famous actresses of the 1980s. In between, she satisfied her creative instinct by doing low-budget films and a lot of theatre. "I want to be acting when I'm 92," she says. "I want to die acting, and that wasn't going to happen if I carried on doing films like Top Gun. So I decided I would always try to do something unexpected, not to shake up other people's ideas of me, but for myself." And she invites those who don't like it to kiss her "big, fat ass".

webTitle: How M&S fell from high street supremacy

fields.headline: How M&S fell from high street supremacy
fields.standfirst: Marks & Spencer lays off 4,390 staff
fields.trailText: Managers at troubled retailer Marks & Spencer have been attempting to turn the tide on their slumping clothes sales.
fields.body:
Managers at troubled retailer Marks & Spencer have been attempting to turn the tide on their slumping clothes sales.

Following disappointing reports at Christmas, business guru George Davies, the founder of Next and Asda's George clothing range, was appointed to turn around the ailing chain's womenswear collection.

However, there has been speculation that the injection of new blood may have come too late to save the high street stores.

M&S became the country's most profitable retailer in May 1998, reporting profits of £2bn. The tide, however, began to turn a year later, as the group issued its first profits warning.

Sir Richard Greenbury resigned as non-executive chairman a month later in June 1999 - a year before his planned retirement date.

The chief executive, Peter Salsbury, issued the second profits warning in September. The Belgian Luc Vandevelde, 48, took over as executive chairman on January 24 2000, moving from the French retailer, Promodes.

He said: "M&S is one of the great retail names in the world." He set himself a two-year deadline to achieve the much-needed turnaround.

In a bid to throw off its frumpy image, M&S unveiled a range of designer wear by catwalk stars Katharine Hamnett, Betty Jackson and Julien Macdonald - The Autograph Collection - in February last year.

The chain reported a slump in full-year pre-tax profits and cut its dividend for the first time in its history in July. Profits for the year to April 1 dropped to £417.5m, against £546.1m the year before, while the dividend was slashed from 14.4p to 9p. Like-for-like sales in the UK tumbled 7.2%.

Mr Vandevelde said the chain was pumping money into restructuring its supply chain and modernising its brand. A new concept store programme was unveiled.

It also introduced a new staff uniform after deeming the old navy and green skirts too frumpy - but this was recalled in August after female staff complained their bras were visible through the new cream blouses. Replacement blouses of thicker material were issued.

In the same month, the retailer spent £100,000 on a 30-second commercial showing a naked size 16 woman shouting: "I'm normal."

In September the firm paid £1.2m to three directors who were leaving. Among them was Peter Salsbury, who stepped down as chief executive, taking a year's salary of £560,000.

Mr Vandevelde announced that he had snatched Roger Holmes, chief executive of Kingfisher's electrical division, as Mr Salsbury's replacement.

In November, Mr Vandevelde said that there was no quick fix, as the retailer reported a drop in first-half profits, and unveiled plans to axe six stores.

Pre-tax profits for the interim fell to £183.4m from £192.8m, with group like-for-like sales down 1.2%.

Mr Vandevelde predicted a rosy Christmas, and stuck by his claim that it would take two years to turn the ailing retailer around. Admitting the job was "a bit more difficult than I thought", he added: "We are going back to some basics in retailing and hope that will deliver some results. I think there is nothing in the way of improving our trading over Christmas."

fields.headline: About No-One Likes Us
fields.trailText: No-One Likes Us was the first fanzine to sponsor a league game when we sponsored the (old) Second Division game against Plymouth in 1991.
fields.body:
No-One Likes Us was the first fanzine to sponsor a league game when we sponsored the (old) Second Division game against Plymouth in 1991.

We repeated this a couple of years later and to date have contributed over £18,000 to the club's meagre funds.

For twelve seasons NOLU has been a hobby for us - we basically take the piss out of everyone (including ourselves), something that drives our current Chairman to threats and bluster. Which, of course, makes us do it all the more.

Get the picture? NOLU is £5 for 4 issues or £10 for 9 - cheap at twice the price Guv.

Available from: 30 Wendover Road, Bromley Kent BR2 9JX

fields.headline: Poems by Andrew Wilson
fields.trailText: ALEX
fields.body:
ALEX

Id seen
the short film before,
so i watched it
across
the darkened bar
thru u:
your face,
caught,
edged
in reflected silver,
a smile
opening your profile.

TRAIN TRAIN

The countryside
outside's
as black as oil,
as next to me
my face - eyes
colour of my eyes
- keeps pace.

BULLIED

Half the
school followed
down
the snowy back lane,
hardest first.
He already knew
they'd help me.
I hit his face.
He crumpled,
said to me
that's enough.

webTitle: Do men think differently from women?

fields.headline: Mind reading
fields.standfirst: Should men judge a women's book prize? Should women be on a panel of rape judges? It all depends on whether men and women think the same
fields.trailText: Should men judge a women's book prize? Should women be on a panel of rape judges? It all depends on whether men and women think the same, argues Katharine Whitehorn.
fields.body:
The Orange Prize for women's fiction, traditionally judged by an all-woman panel, is this year to have an all-male panel, too, to see if they choose different books. This suggests that men and women do have a different viewpoint - a notion rejected by the Law Lords, who last week refused the campaigning Fawcett Society's request that a female be included in the final panel of judges that will decide the balance between the rights of a male accused of rape and the victim's right to privacy.

Both cases raise the question of whether women's and men's viewpoints inevitably differ, or whether their brains actually do function in the same way. They certainly don't, in the physical sense: we now know that a man and a woman can come up with the same solution to a problem, but that the woman will have used two bits of her brain where a man will have used one. Women's brains are on average smaller, too, but the idea that size matters (a male obsession) has not stood up for a long time. Remember that elephants have the biggest brains of all (presumably entirely devoted to Never Forgetting).

Women have often, though, spat at any idea of the sexes thinking in different ways, simply because blokes have always assumed that different means inferior. We've said that insisting you have to be male to think like Plato was as daft as saying you have to be Greek. But nearly 20 years ago, Carol Gilligan's In a Different Voice made it plain that a woman's thinking could be both different and better. In the classic case of the boy who had to choose between stealing or letting his mother go without medicine, women were deemed deficient because they wouldn't come up with an either/or answer - they insisted on trying to find an actual practical solution. But this, far from meaning they were deficient, showed they were after something subtler and more useful.

But do men and women read the same things? Virago made its name and its money in the 70s by realising that what women readers (perhaps middle-aged and suburban) wanted to read bore no relation to what male London publishers thought was the latest trend. But the better the books, I suspect, the less difference there is - women do read Hornblower, men do read Jane Austen. It's which kind of lousy books Mars and Venus cuddle up with - space battles or love-ever-after? - that really shows the difference. Which is not, we hope, what the Orange judges will be chewing over.

As for the law, you would think that after Helena Kennedy's searing Eve Was Framed, no one could deny that the law, however unconsciously, has been biased in favour of the gender making it. To take just one example, look at our conviction that we all have an immemorial right to be tried by a jury of our peers - no woman was tried by a jury of her peers until 1919, when they allowed women on juries for the first time. Yet still there is this assumption that the male viewpoint is the viewpoint and it is only when the wimmin try to suggest something different that gender comes into it.

The case for having a woman advising on anything connected with rape trials is not only that a woman would Understand How It Might Feel but also that she might actually be a lot better placed than a man to tell when another woman is lying - in which case her presence would serve the best interests of a man wrongly accused as well. There is a basic inequality, anyway, in a man being allowed to bring up a woman's past sexual history - and a woman's view ought surely to be represented on any panel trying to decide how these things in equity should go.

Some women may be wonderful at cars - the late, great Baroness Denton was a round-the-world rally driver; some women are intrigued by military stratgey - TV producer Cate Haste is a whizz on Clausewitz; Muriel Seibert, the first woman on Wall Street, sucks in financial pages the way some of us read agony columns. But you wouldn't say a woman had been given equal access to reading if all that was on offer was Motor Sport, Battle Formations of the Napoleonic Era and the Wall Street Journal. Equality, as in "the same", is not the whole story: we must be allowed to read different things.

I am reminded of the jape in one of those greeting cards. A harridan on the front saying: "What's all this I hear about young women wanting to be equal to men?" And inside it says: "Have they no ambition?"

fields.headline: Poems by Ian McMillan
fields.trailText:
DOMAIN names.
All day it's fish:
bluefish.com
redfish.com
smilefish.com.
It used 2 b
car names.
Zephyr, Orion.
At night I stare
at my fish in the bowl.
Name em.
fields.body:
DOMAIN names.
All day it's fish:
bluefish.com
redfish.com
smilefish.com.
It used 2 b
car names.
Zephyr, Orion.
At night I stare
at my fish in the bowl.
Name em.

SPRING trees
like the trees
I used to draw
in Mrs Yelland's class
all browns
and greens.
And that yellow star
I got
could be the sun.

DEAR diary,
it's march and I'm
bored with you.
I tell you everything.
You only tell me the date.
And how the moon looks.

fields.headline: Meet Halfway Harry
fields.standfirst: He's angry, he's waving a rolled-up copy of the Sun, and he's Millwall through and through
fields.trailText: He's angry, he's waving a rolled-up copy of the Sun, and he's Millwall through and through.
fields.body: "Top in the New Year who woulda thought it - but it's a false position ain't it, what's McGhee really done - ain't bought no-one, ain't changed the team still picks the wrong players, STILL A JOCK - I mean we may have beaten Walsall but they were the better footballing side and as for Reading WARNER HAS SOMEONE TIED YOU TO THEM POSTS? well any side that damn near throws away a four-goal lead will have problems against a defence as good as Wigan's, Rioch has got them well organised, don't give nuffink away, still a bloody good crowd ain't it HAVEN'T SEEN YOU SINCE WEMBERLEY all come out the woodwork again ain't you - you'll be disappointed we always bomb out in the crunch games, where were you Tuesday night for the Swindon game - sat at home watching EastEnders in the warm while the half a dozen of us that made the effort got bleedin' frostbite COR LOOK AT ALL THAT SMOKE looks like Theo's torched the Lions Centre for the insurance money COME ON HARRIS - LOOK LIVELY over rated he is, apart from score goals and make them - what else does he do - lazier than Sherington he is, as for that big donkey Moody he must be due his bus pass by now, Nah this lot will see us off again no messing, shut up shop and hit us on the break GOOD CROSS MONKEY no-one there though OH! GREAT FINISH, MOODS won't be able to hold on though, need that all important second goal BLOODY HELL! HE'S ONLY DONE IT AGAIN! fields.headline: No 11. Millwall
fields.standfirst: Keith Pegg - aka The Albatross from Millwall fanzine No-One Likes Us - introduces us to the Lions
fields.trailText: What makes you so different?
fields.body:
What makes you so different?

To the neutral who base their opinions largely on a rabid tabloid press who believe if a Millwall supporter sneezes, pneumonia has broken out, we are probably as welcome as a turd in a punch bowl. Combined with the attitudes of local plod, we have, it has to be admitted, adopted something of a siege mentality. No-One Likes Us, we don't care. We actually do care, but have long since given up trying to get a fair deal.

The high point

It has to be going top of the old First Division against QPR. Little old Millwall top of the English game - who would have thought it? A close second would be taking 47,000 supporters to Wembley for the wing mirror shield. Wembley a sea of Millwall blue - unforgettable.

The low point

Plunging from the top of the First Division to relegation on the last day of the season takes some beating, but being a Millwall supporter means none of us are in it for the glory. Having almost gone out of business, rebuilding has been a slow process but, based on an excellent youth policy, we've been getting there. If only the board had shown some ambition and relaxed the purse strings to build from strength instead of waiting for it to all go wobbly and still not putting their hands in their pockets.

What's going on at the moment?

Once the so-called pundits had Millwall crowned as champions we knew we were in for a bumpy ride. A seven-point lead with games in hand, our closest rivals Wigan and Walsall going into freefall, it was all over. Who was going to finish second?

A month later and doom and gloom descends. The lead has evaporated, Reading and Rotherham can't seem to lose and for the first time in months we're off the top. Following our worst spell of the season, our precious darlings were packed off to Spain for a spot of R&R for four days, leaving manager Mark McGhee to swoop on transfer deadline day and rebuild our stumbling promotion bid

Sore point

and as our success this season was built on youth, McGhee continued this policy by making his first signings since his appointment: Steve Claridge and Tony Cottee. McGhee has doubled the average age of the side and immediately moved himself into the firing line if it all goes Pete Tong.

Manager

McGhee inherited probably the best squad in the division and, without actually doing much, got us to the top. Promotion will tell if he's accepted or not.

What's your chairman like?

The chairman is Theo Paphitis, paper clip and knicker salesman. Loved by some who see him as a saviour, he's loathed by others (well, all right, us) as a bit of a spiv. Neutrals who saw his performance on the BBC programme Back to the Floor will have made their own minds up. Massive ego, short arms, deep pockets.

Who are your rivals?

Crippled Palarse and West Ham are the traditional rivals. We had a brief flirtation with Gillingham and Wigan, but nothing quite compares with the thrill of a local derby with the hamsters. All police leave in the metropolitan area cancelled, local pubs "redecorated" you get the picture. It really means something!

Kit

The most controversial thing our chairman did was to change our traditional blue and white kit to all white and revert to a more traditional badge to be more "user friendly". Re-introducing the blue kit for away games was purely a means of extracting more dosh from the punters. The Lions play in blue and white: end of.

Most ridiculous piece of merchandise

A £200 crystal replica of the Den (although the incinerator adjacent to the ground is not included). Anyone considering this sort of overpriced crap really should seek medical help.

Mascot

Zampa the Lion, some sad YTS kid who hasn't got the nerve to tell the club to bog off. Having said that, the current wearer of the smelly suit does seem up for it, although a recent run in with Cyril the Swan which resulted in Zampa losing his head may well calm him down.

Player rated

Neil Harris, the league's top scorer. The most popular ever depends on your age: Teddy Sheringham, Terry Hurlock, Barry Kitchener or the legendary Harry Cripps are heroes all.

Player hated

Oddly enough for us, we don't have any real villains since Bobby Bowry and Jamie Stuart were banished to the reserves to see out their contracts. The least popular player ever would take about five pages - we have had rather a lot! We don't care that much about other teams players, although we did have the satisfaction of driving Paul Birch out of the game. He had floppy blond hair. Nuff said?

What's your ground like?

The "New" Den nearly finished us off, so feelings are mixed. When it's full, the atmosphere is quite lively. Most intellectuals can be found in the south lower having a "free and frank exchange of views" with the visiting keeper, or giving advice, most of which is physically impossible.

What to do when you get there

Visiting northerners may care to sample the delights that the many car-breaker's yards in the area offer. Alternatively, a cold Den Burger and chips with a couple of pints of recycled piss laughingly called "Lager" will sustain them on the long journey home. Links

There are a great variety of Millwall websites: some good, some poor and some plain boring. For sheer excellence, though, we suggest a visit to Tits, Fanny and Millwall (http://www.titsfannyandmillwall.co.uk/). Alternatively, The Lion Roars fanzine has been around for even longer than us, it's a good read even if they do tend to take themselves rather seriously.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Amazingly, yesterday's item concerning the Diary's acquisition of papers relating to DTI secretary Stephen Byers's libel action against the Daily Mail has taken a turn that could be described as interesting.
fields.body:
 Amazingly, yesterday's item concerning the Diary's acquisition of papers relating to DTI secretary Stephen Byers's libel action against the Daily Mail has taken a turn that could be described as interesting, with a call from Associated Newspapers' lawyer, Ed Young. "I'm just wondering," he begins cosily, "how on earth you managed to get hold of them?"

Ed, I'd love to tell you that the last fortnight has been spent working on hunches, conducting furtive meetings in underground car parks, and that I'd rather die than reveal my sources, but somehow "it just came on an anonymous fax" has the ring of truth so woefully absent from the any of the above. "I see," says Ed. "Only our letter from Byers's solicitors was sent and yet never arrived, which is very unusual. We have it now, but via a circuitous route, and I'd have thought the Mail and the Guardian Diary were quite difficult to confuse."

We'd like to hope so, though Ed is reluctant to swallow the explanation that the Diary's reputation for breaking big stories made us the natural choice for a strategic rerouting of the documents. He rings off promising to "stay in touch". Whoever you believe in this sticky web, strange forces are at work. Why they have chosen to involve the Diary in their machinations, perhaps we shall discover soon.

 Remarkably again, we have something resembling a sort of story on which to consult George Brock, tank-top wearing managing editor of the delightfully republican Times (you will recall how George despises being drafted into the "junk journalism" to which this Diary is such a martyr). But when we call, an unfamiliar voice breaks the news that Brocky is away until next Wednesday.

This is maddening, as it means we are unable to discuss the issue of grace-and-favour accommodation with him. If his wife were at her Buckingham Palace workstation (she is assistant private secretary to Her Majesty) we could perhaps have taken her views, but they must be away together. Still, plenty of time, unless Jasper Gerard's recent Times piece ("It can't be long now before the royals are written out of the script") bears fruit before Wednesday.

 Surveillance: Cypriot wine waiter Taki-George, on the BBC1 show about gambling on Tuesday night, talking arrant rot about casinos and slot machines in sporadic 20-second bursts. Due to some confusion in the editing room, the resultant 20 minute disclaimers of everything he said from Conrad Black were omitted, and will now be shown at a later date.

 Turncoat of Turncoats voting surges with the contest's debut on Oofy Wegg-Prosser's political arm of our website. And though Steptoe fancies she'll tire early, an assumption reflected in his 100-30 price, Bomber Short, secretary of state for international development, has flown out of the traps. Current trends would indicate that Bomber's about-turn is a particular affront to two religious groups, whose representatives have placed early flutters on her. Still everything to play for at Turncoats contest

 It is always heartening to hear news of Telegraph cricket hack and renaissance man Michael Henderson, whose conversational gambits are the envy of the Duke of Edinburgh. We join him on radio station TalkSport, during a break in Tuesday's one-day international in Sri Lanka, as commentator Jack Bannister asks him what has been the most memorable moment of England's tour of the country. "For me," Hendo muses, "it was a party on the beach yesterday, where I got thoroughly pissed." Many thanks.

 "If I have 10 or 11 email addresses," writes reader James McBride on Turncoat polling, "can I vote once for each email address? Or can I just vote 10 or 11 times from any one (or more) of my collection?" Let your conscience be your guide James. I simply haven't the strength for it today.

fields.headline: Camelot rethinks lottery logo
fields.trailText:
10.45am: The National Lottery's lucky crossed fingers could be dropped in favour of a new logo, writes Julia Day.
Feb 28: 'Musical lottery tickets' unveiled
fields.body:
The National Lottery's lucky crossed fingers could be dropped in favour of a new logo.

Camelot is conducting a widescale review of its image, which will scrutinise the National Lottery logo, the five sub-brands including logos, and the materials used to promote the games in shops.

The National Lottery operator is to ask a dozen design and branding consultancies to come up with new ideas for the games.

However, it is not thought Camelot intends to change the name of the National Lottery or those of sub-brands Thunderball, National Lottery Instants, Lottery Extra, The Big Draw 2001 and National Lottery Game.

The work is being carried out in advance of Camelot taking up its new licence to run the lottery, which is due to start in February 2002.

Related story

webTitle: Unprincipled times: the current crop of political biographies

fields.headline: Unprincipled times
fields.standfirst: Sleazy, vacuous and unprincipled. RW Johnson offers a resounding critique of politics today as he rounds up the current crop of political biographies in this exclusive online essay from the London Review of Books
fields.trailText: RW Johnson offers a resounding critique of politics today
fields.body:
Servants of the People: The Inside Story of New Labour by Andrew Rawnsley. Hamish Hamilton, 434 pp., £17.99, 25 September 2000, 0 241 14029 3
Buy it at a discount from BOL

Mandelson and the Making of New Labour by Donald Macintyre. HarperCollins, 638 pp., £6.99, 18 September 2000, 0 00 653062 1 mm
Buy it at a discount from BOL

Mo Mowlam: The Biography by Julia Langdon. Little, Brown, 324 pp., £16.99, 28 September 2000, 0 316 85304 6
Buy it at a discount from BOL

Ann Widdecombe: Right from the Beginning by Nicholas Kochan. Politico's, 302 pp., £17.99, 2 October 2000, 1 902301 55 2
Buy it at a discount from BOL

The Paymaster: Geoffrey Robinson, Maxwell and New Labour by Tom Bower. Simon and Schuster, 272 pp., £17.99, 22 March, 0 74320 689 4

The Future of Politics by Charles Kennedy. HarperCollins, 235 pp., £17.99, 21 September 2000, 0 00 710131 7
Buy it at a discount from BOL

Throughout the time that he was prime minister Clement Attlee read only the Times. He was, he said, too busy to bother with other newspapers. The fact that the Times was firmly Tory and, after a few years of Labour government, almost hysterically anti-socialist, didn't worry him at all. "That's what one expects," he said. "It's quite reliable in that, which is, in its way, rather restful. And the cricket reports are good." Under New Labour, by contrast, every day in Downing Street starts with a careful sifting of the press; there are strong responses to any stories which might have been 'inspired' or leaked. Enormous care is taken to try to manage the news not just in the obvious sense of trying to put a positive spin on whatever the Government is doing but, more fundamentally, in blocking off whole policy areas because they might result in a damaging headline in the Sun or the Mail.

This ultra-sensitivity has inevitably increased the importance of the media managers. When the Northern Ireland negotiations got serious Tony Blair took Alistair Campbell into the room with him and insisted that Mo Mowlam remain outside. David Trimble was astonished but that's how it always is with New Labour. Andrew Rawnsley records how the momentous decision that Britain would not join the euro during the current parliament was taken. Aware of the increase in Euroscepticism from Philip Gould's focus groups and daily readings of the Sun and the Mail, Gordon Brown's press secretary, Charlie Whelan, and his economic adviser, Ed Balls, sent the Times a fax hinting at a major policy change while Whelan tried to persuade the Sun to go with the headline 'Brown Saves Pound'. Whelan, operating from his mobile phone on the pavement outside a pub, confirmed to the BBC and ITN: "Yes, Gordon is ruling out British membership." Word rapidly spread that this massive policy shift on what Brown had called "the most important question the country is likely to face in a generation" was being announced to the world from a mobile phone against a background of general inebriation.

When the story came out not as a hint but as an emphatic rejection of Europe, there was consternation: Britain's relations with the EU were on the line. Peter Mandelson, horrified at the implications - he styled himself Minister for Looking Ahead - was sure that this all resulted from leaving him out of the loop. Blair was alerted and asked Whelan what had happened. Whelan told him that the report merely echoed Government policy. "Who says it's our policy?" the prime minister asked - he had not been consulted - and ordered Whelan to "row back". "Sorry, Tony, it's too late," he was told. A conference call between Blair, Campbell, Brown, Balls, Mandelson and Whelan dealt with the crisis. No one thought it odd that the real inner cabinet not only did not include the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, but comprised four spinners and only two responsible ministers.

As Rawnsley points out, the curious thing about Blair is that, however much he wants to reject ideology, he is also endlessly eager to explain himself, to insist that there is a big idea, that there are principles, that there is, indeed, an ideology of the Third Way. The result of all these attempted explanations is utter vacuity. The nearest thing to a big idea - and it is the fundament to which Blair always returns under pressure - is that most Labour governments of the 20th century were failures, that Labour never managed to become 'the natural party of government' as Harold Wilson wished, and that this was reflected in its failure ever to get elected for two full terms. Traumatised by four successive defeats, Blair wanted above all to make Labour electable and then to secure those two full terms. This would demonstrate that Blairism had overcome Labour's congenital weakness. The problem was that there was no New Labour project to rival that of Attlee or Thatcher, no real idea of what those two full terms were to be about.

Blair sought to make up for this by leaning on the venerable sage Lord Jenkins for advice. (Rawnsley appears to accept this estimate, repeatedly referring to Jenkins as "the great historian", apparently unaware that serious historians regard Jenkins as a coffee-table lightweight.) What Jenkins had to offer was a passionate Europeanism and a belief that it was Labour's split from the Liberals early in the century that had allowed the Tories to dominate government down the years. The remarriage of Lib and Lab should, he argued, be cemented by a change from first-past-the-post to proportional representation, which would not only make parliament a much truer reflection of the popular will but would result in an alliance resembling the broader formation of the Democratic Party in the US.

This all sounded plausible enough, although a moment's reflection would have suggested a number of difficulties. The basic problem with Europeanism in Britain has, after all, been its fear of the popular will. This was why the champions of Europe like Jenkins, knowing full well that British voters would not swallow what they regarded as the sacrifice of national sovereignty, never liked to tell them the truth - which was that its continental founders were, from the outset, determined to build a federal Europe. This was why, when Heath took Britain into Europe, he pretended to have "the full-hearted consent of the people" but carefully avoided letting them have any say in the matter. It is also why, when Labour committed itself to a referendum, Jenkins was so horrified that he resigned the Party's deputy leadership. And it is also why Blair, having committed himself to a referendum on entry into the euro has failed to call one in his first term (he's promised a decision within two years of a second - as long as economic conditions are met, of course).

The trouble with Lib-Labbery was that this was Jenkins's third stab at the problem. For most of his career he had been firmly Labour and had repeatedly sworn that he would never, but never, launch a centre party. Then he left Labour to do just that. That initiative having come to grief, here he was arguing for a British version of the Democratic party. Given New Labour's love affair with Clintonism, this was attractive to Blair: inconveniently, after a few years of listening to such advice he found himself impaled on the unpopularity of the euro, on the one hand, while having, on the other, allowed the Welsh and Scottish assemblies to be elected on a PR basis, only to end up with Labour losing its majority in both cases. To make matters worse, the Welsh assembly soon fell to a Labour leader Blair had done everything to stop. It wasn't long before something similar happened in London, though this hasn't stopped Blair, in generous pre-election mood, again promising the Lib-Dems a referendum on PR, to be held in 2003-4.

When Mitterrand introduced elected regional assemblies throughout France, for the first time fundamentally reforming the rule from the prefecture which had been bequeathed by Napoleon, he announced that regionalisation would be "la grande affaire du septennat". Using power with deliberation to make large strategic choices is precisely what New Labour doesn't do. The Upper House has been 'reformed' to reduce the number of hereditary peers - but the qualification for belonging is still to be a peer. The European Convention on Human Rights has been incorporated into British law, but the whole point about such fundamental rights is that they ought to be entrenched. Thus the greater the distance the Labour party puts between its old role and its new one, the more one should expect turnout to fall. The Third Way, it turns out, was shorthand for a bland and manipulative short-termism. Blair just doesn't seem to be the man for the big idea, for grand strategy, for, if you like, 'the vision thing'. Now who does that remind you of?

Thus the greater the distance the Labour party puts between its old role and its new one, the more one should expect turnout to fall. Nothing will make that fall more permanent than the sort of Lib-Lab deal Jenkins wants, for in that new political environment the older, better educated and richer Tory voters will have an increasing participation advantage. So before Blair tries to build a British version of the American Democrats he might reflect that despite the 20-year supremacy of the New Deal coalition, 20th century America had Republican Presidents for 52 years, Democratic ones for 48 and that since the 1965 Act - which should have given the Democrats a huge new advantage - Republicans have won the presidency six times to the Democrats' three. But in any case one rather doubts that Blair is the man to fashion New Labour into anything other than what it already is. The Third Way, it turns out, was shorthand for a bland and manipulative short-termism. Blair just doesn't seem to be the man for the big idea, for grand strategy, for, if you like, 'the vision thing'. Now who does that remind you of?  To read more online essays from the current edition of the London Review of Books visit the LRB. fields.headline: New job for 'Nasty' Nigel
fields.trailText:
10am: Popstars's 'Nasty' Nigel Lythgoe has got a new job, heading former Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller's TV production company. By Jason Deans.
Mar 23: ITV unveils Popstars follow-up
Nov 15: Lythgoe goes to Carlton
fields.body:
Popstars's "Nasty" Nigel Lythgoe has got a new job, heading former Spice Girls manager Simon Fuller's TV production company.

Mr Lythgoe is currently on secondment from LWT to Planet 24, working on ITV's next big reality show, Survivor.

He will join Mr Fuller's outfit, 19 TV, when he finishes work in the summer.

His brief will include overseeing Popstars follow-up Pop Idol, which is to be co-produced for ITV with Pearson TV.

Mr Lythgoe will not be returning to his LWT job as controller of entertainment.

During six years at LWT he established a reputation as an old-style ITV entertainment baron, overseeing a slate of shows, including Blind Date and Gladiators, regarded as unfashionable by the critics, no matter how popular.

But Mr Lythgoe reinvented himself with his role as Popstars's Nasty Nigel, carving out a place at the forefront of the high-concept, reality entertainment format boom.

He cemented this position by landing the job executive producing Survivor, the Planet 24 reality format that proved such a hit in the US last summer.

Mr Lythgoe is currently on location in Borneo working on Survivor, which pits a group of contestants against each other in a Big Brother-style battle for a cash prize.

LWT is understood to have demanded up to £200,000 in compensation from Planet 24 parent company Carlton to cover Mr Lythgoe's salary for the six-month secondment.

His LWT responsibilities will be shared between head of entertainment Bob Massie and head of production Jane Honeycombe.

fields.headline: A bad, bad move
fields.standfirst: When Glenn Hoddle upped sticks and left Southampton for Spurs in March 2001, Scott Murray wondered whether it was such a smart move...
fields.trailText: In football, it's easy to spot someone making a decision you know they'll end up regretting. It usually happens when the heart has been allowed to rule the head.
fields.body:
In football, it's easy to spot someone making a decision you know they'll end up regretting. It usually happens when the heart has been allowed to rule the head.

Think Graeme Souness, moving from Rangers to his dream job at Liverpool, taking his untarnished managerial reputation with him. Think Kevin Keegan, leaving upwardly mobile Fulham for the England job he was powerless to resist and incapable of doing. Think Kenny Dalglish, returning as a hero to Celtic and leaving a pariah. Think ... well, there are a hundred other examples, but now isn't the time or the place.

Ah, just one more, though. In 1985, Lawrie McMenemy, then considered one of the brightest managerial talents in the country, left brave little Southampton - where he'd enjoyed some success - to join a club close to his heart which had seen better times.

He promised to bring the glory days back, and was given a big budget to do so. But unlike his adverts for alcohol-free lager, his efforts were not "great, man". Within a couple of years, all the money and everyone's patience had been frittered away, and Big Lawrie was soon bouncing down the road on his big arse, while Sunderland - the love of his life - faced up to their first-ever season in the (old) Third Division.

Does this remind you of anything? Or anyone?

Glenn Hoddle's decision to take the job at his spiritual home is a bad move. No, scrub that: it's a bad, bad, bad move.

It's bad for Saints, obviously, who, after years of Ian Branfoots, Alan Balls, Dave Merringtons and Dave Joneses, finally found someone who knew what they were talking about. OK, so the Dell wasn't exactly enjoying progressive football, but you've got to run before you can walk, and it takes a while for an attritional 1-0 home win to become tedious when you've been battling relegation for years.

Which quickly brings me on to why it's bad for Tottenham fans. The White Hart Lane regulars already had a manager who could deliver solid home results. Why did they need another? If Gunner George had fashioned a team who pushed it around like Real Madrid, you wouldn't have heard anyone complaining. You see, the average Spurs fan desires a return to the glory, glory game more than anything else.

But this desire is confusing the glassy-eyed Spurs faithful, who seem to think the man who played a beautiful game can organise one as well. He can't, you know. When has he ever? We keep hearing about those heady nights against Italy and Argentina, but scrapping with your back to the wall is hardly something Danny Blanchflower would have been proud of. So after a couple of seasons, when Spurs fans suddenly realise they've got another pragmatist on their hands, expect the trouble to start.

No real need to explain why it was a bad move for Hoddle, then. All he'll get at Spurs is pressure and grief - unless, of course, he brings European action to the Lane, and perhaps a title. (That's slightly harder to deliver than mid-table safety or a second-round hard-luck story, as we know.)

The man hardly cuts the most cheerful of figures as it is, and we've already seen how badly he sours when the pressure is on. Of course, like Lawrie and the Titanic, if he stayed at Southampton it could have been so different. Team moving in the right direction, new ground, a little bit of money to spend? That wouldn't have been so bad, would it?

So how will it all end? Well, maybe the only party to come out of this without too much to worry about is Southampton - which is fair enough when you think about it. Kevin Keegan is rumoured to be taking over, and with memories fresh of his England disaster, it's important to remember how inspirational he can be at club level.

Perhaps, in a couple of years, when Tottenham are looking for another new manager, Hoddle will cast a rueful glance towards the Hampshire coast. Perhaps he'll see Keegan waving a cup about, although he probably won't. But you can guarantee he'll see everyone smiling, something he won't have seen too much of in the interim around N17.

webTitle: US airline waives fee to cancel UK flights

fields.headline: US airline waives fee to cancel UK flights
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Americans flying to Britain are being warned of foot and mouth, and one airline has dropped the normal $100 fee to cancel a flight.
fields.body:
Americans flying to Britain are being warned of foot and mouth, and one airline has dropped the normal $100 fee to cancel a flight.

The warning is being issued on most flights. Norwest is waiving its cancellation or postponement fee for those booked for travel on or before May 21.

Northwest links with on-going flights from the US to London. It said yesterday its sales to Britain were not down, but it had decided its policy following inquiries by customers about foot and mouth.

Another airline, one of the biggest carriers flying direct to Heathrow from several hubs, said March figures to Britain were up, and it was assessing the situation all the time. United, American Airlines and Delta have not changed their cancellation policy but have the situation under review. Their March figures show no fall-off in passenger demand.

US reaction is being closely watched by the travel business, because Easter is the first point in the year when Americans flock to the UK. Hotels in UK cities said they had not noticed any drop in bookings, but the next weeks would be crucial.

 A national park near Hungary's famous tourist spot, Lake Balaton, has closed to visitors for fear of foot and mouth. It is home to hundreds of indigenous Hungarian animals from its people's nomadic past in the first millennium - buffalos, cattle and sheep. The closure is in effect until Easter, said the park's spokeswoman.

Hungarian authorities have also introduced measures to protect livestock.

fields.headline: My maternity ward hell
fields.standfirst: When  Dea Birkett  went into hospital to have twins, she was shocked by the conveyor-belt experience that turned giving birth into a 'cold, clinical encounter'
fields.trailText: When Dea Birkett went into hospital to have twins, she was shocked by the conveyor-belt experience that turned giving birth into a 'cold, clinical encounter'.
fields.body:
I remember everything about my midwife - her name, her face, the things she told me. She saw me at my GP's practice throughout my pregnancy and visited every day for 10 days after I returned home with my new daughter. She made my first days with my first born a joy.

That was eight years ago and the midwife has moved on. Three weeks ago, I gave birth to twins in the same London teaching hospital, under the same practice. But this second tale of maternity care is not so happy. In less than a decade, the service I took for granted for my first born had collapsed. There is a severe shortage of midwives; two out of three maternity units are understaffed and London hospitals in particular have problems with recruitment.

Last week, a survey of 2,000 recent mothers by the online magazine Mother & Baby revealed that most were dissatisfied with the care they received, less than half would be happy to return to the same hospital due to lack of support, and half said they received poor post-natal care at home. Only 4% had the same midwife for antenatal appointments and the birth. "Chronically overstretched maternity staff simply don't have the time to provide the sort of quality care pregnant women expect," says Sarah Stone, editor of Mother & Baby. "Many women feel as if they have gone through a conveyor-belt birth experience."

My experience in the labour ward was exemplary. But the moment I was wheeled out of the delivery room and into the packed post-natal ward, it was as if I was being taken from a place where I was the centre of attention to a place where I had to be processed and moved on. The conveyor belt had begun to roll.

It began with my inability to get breakfast. I had been in the ward for less than two hours and my legs were still dead from the epidural. I was awake (I had no choice - the fluorescent lights were on and the curtains around my bed drawn back) and very, very hungry. I had not eaten since breakfast the previous day.

Breakfast was self-service. I watched as the trolley of catering- sized cereal boxes, sliced white bread and mini packets of Flora was wheeled up the centre of the ward. Legless, I called out from my metal-barred bed, "Can I have some cornflakes please?" My cries were drowned out by the baby opposite, who had an infection which wouldn't let him (or us) sleep. The trolley wheeled on past. My thirst was terrible. When a cleaner with a giant mop started wiping under my bed, I asked her if she could kindly get me some water. She took the empty plastic jug from my bedside cabinet, and trotted off to fill it. I never saw her or the jug again.

I was later told it was all to do with the shift change, which coincided with breakfast in the morning and a busy visiting time in the evening. I learned to dread the shift change. If both babies started crying uncontrollably, if I developed a raging thirst while trying to breastfeed, if I needed to go to the toilet, and it happened to coincide with the shift change, then there was no help at hand. The midwives were swapping notes about us somewhere but could not be found on the ward.

The continual change of staff was confusing. When one of my babies wouldn't breastfeed, I was told to feed him from a cup. The next day, a different midwife recommended a bottle or he would lose too much weight. The next day, another midwife said if I gave him a bottle he would never take the breast, so I had to starve him into submission. The following day, that decision was overturned by the next change of staff.

Midwives themselves are not to blame (80% of those surveyed found them "sympathetic and kind"). They are given an unenviable number of roles to play in the postnatal ward. As well as carrying out rigorous medical checks of mother and child, they are expected to inform and educate.

During my three days in hospital, I accumulated no less than six copies of the same full-colour glossy brochure on breastfeeding. Midwives are instructed to promote this method of feeding above all others. The only problem was, through no choice of my own, one of the twins was being bottlefed. It wasn't until two weeks later, when the health visitor (a former midwife who left because of the horrendous hours) came to my home, that I received my first bottle-feeding brochure.

In black and white, it looked like something from the 50s, dated and unattractive. Yet it contained vital information on sterilisation of feeding equipment - information that I should have surely received far earlier. And not only me; despite the emphasis on "breast is best", the vast majority of women in my ward pulled out their ready-made bottles, handing their new-born over to a visiting grandmother. Half of the women in the survey said that, despite trying, breast-feeding didn't work out for them either.

You never forget the face or name of the woman who helped to deliver your child. Yet, within hours, she will have forgotten yours. It is, therefore, a relationship in which the mother is bound to feel abandoned. For us, it's a time of overpowering importance, when our emotions are at their most raw. What was this midwife moaning on about, when we had been up all night, and would count three hours sleep at a time as a luxury? They came every four to five days, and it was only so frequently because the baby girl was a bit jaundiced. One weighed the babies with their clothes on; a week later, another weighed them naked, so comparing the weights became meaningless. Another asked me if I had been back for my hospital appointment yet, confusing me with someone else. It is hardly surprising. She had never met me before, and never would again.
