By 2004, the NHS plans to have 20,000 more nursing staff, although it is not clear how many of those will be midwives.

I did not feel cared for; I felt as if having a baby was burden too much for the health service to bear. I know it can and has been otherwise. To restore a service to what it was almost a decade ago does not seem an exorbitant demand. After all, where better to get it right than from birth.

fields.headline: M&S to share flagship store with Selfridges
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is to share its new Manchester flagship store with Selfridges in a desperate bid to attract customers, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is to share its new Manchester flagship store with Selfridges, the department store, in a desperate bid to attract customers.

The move comes as M&S announces a radical new strategy and structure in an attempt to turn around the company's flagging sales and transform its outdated image.

The store is to close its Direct catalogue business, affecting 690 jobs, and a return to selling only own-brand products and brands exclusive to M&S.

It will also close its European subsidiaries with the loss of 3,500 jobs, divest its US businesses and franchise those businesses in Hong Kong.

The total number of jobs axed is 4,390, with 1,000 of these in the UK.

In the tie-up with Selfridges, the two retailers will share M&S's Manchester store, which is due to open in autumn 2002.

Each retailer will have 120,000sqft of space with an internal mall linking them.

M&S also intends to cut the price of its clothing and stock more low cost items. The company has already announced George Davies is to design a younger, fashion range.

The company is seeking opportunities to sell its food ranges through other outlets. It already sells a snack line through WH Smith.

The home ranges will be expanded as will beauty lines to be sold through in-store "Beauty Shops".

M&S's store card is central to the company's plans to increase sales and loyalty and its financial services will take on a bigger presence in-store.

fields.headline: 54-hour wait tops casualty survey
fields.trailText: A spot check of hospitals by community health watchdogs this week found at least 20 patients who were experiencing "unacceptable" waits of more than 24 hours in casualty departments.
fields.body:
A spot check of hospitals by community health watchdogs this week found at least 20 patients who were experiencing "unacceptable" waits of more than 24 hours in casualty departments.

They included a 93-year-old woman with hypothermia and leg ulcers who was kept for more than 30 hours in the accident and emergency unit at Maidstone hospital in Kent before being admitted to a ward.

The longest wait was by a 41-year-old woman with abdominal pains who spent more than 54 hours in casualty at Kent and Canterbury hospital in Canterbury where she was detained for investigation. Nine other patients at these hospitals had been waiting more than 24 hours at the time of the spot check on Monday.

The findings sparked anger between the Department of Health and the association of community health councils for England and Wales which organised the survey - the last annual exercise of this type before the councils are abolished by legislation going through parliament.

Donna Covey, director of the association, said: "For many people even a two-hour wait in accident and emergency can seem an eternity. Waits of over 24 hours are clearly unacceptable. Casualty waits of this length show that the system is now under year-round pressure."

But the department said 19 of the longest waits recorded were patients being cared for in beds in accident and emergency departments. Only one was on a trolley. "Many were not waiting," a department spokesman said. "They were under observation by doctors and nurses, or undergoing tests so they could diagnose what's wrong. This is a key part of what A&E departments have always done."

The government has set a target that by 2004 nobody is to wait more than four hours between arrival and admission, transfer or discharge. But ministers are considering how to define the goal to permit people to remain under observation in admission wards in accident and emergency if conditions are appropriate.

The annual casualty watch survey was carried out at 200 hospitals throughout the UK. Preliminary results showing the 20 longest waits were published yesterday.

Six were at Kent and Canterbury hospital, which came under fire last week when a report by independent experts said the accident and emergency department was "fundamentally unsafe".

Rupert Williamson, chief officer of Canterbury and Thanet CHC, said there was no serious incident at the time of the survey to explain the lengthy waits. The problem seemed to be that 74 beds in hospital wards were filled by patients ready for discharge who were unable to leave.

"As a result there were patients in A&E who should not have been there," he said. "It is not a ward. It does not have toilets or washing facilities. It is not ideal for feeding and patients do not have call bells."

David Astley, chief executive of the East Kent Hospitals NHS trust, said all the patients had been admitted to the hospital and were being nursed in beds, under the care of a named consultant, with a proper treatment plan. "Although they were not in ideal conditions .. their dignity and privacy was protected by screens."

The spot check also found a 30-year-old woman who had taken an overdose who waited 26 hours to be admitted to a ward at Newham general hospital, east London, and an 84-year-old man with stomach pains who waited in casualty at St Helier hospital in Surrey for 29 hours.

webTitle: Express faces exodus from City desk

fields.headline: Express faces exodus from City desk
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The Express titles are facing a mass exodus from their City desks with senior staff taking voluntary redundancy, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 29: Express addresses 'interference' claims
Special report: Express takeover
fields.body:
The Express and Sunday Express are facing a mass exodus from their City desks with the news that a number of senior staff have taken voluntary redundancy.

Sunday Express business editor Patrick Tooher, who edits the title's business section, is in negotiations to take voluntary redundancy.

And Daily Express City editor Patrick Hosking is also believed to be in negotiations to leave.

Meanwhile, the Express's long-time picture editor, Chris Djukanovic and deputy showbusiness editor Neil Michael have also taken fast-track voluntary redundancy.

Mr Djukanovic, who is believed to be the longest-serving picture editor on Fleet Street, has been at the Express for 28 years.

Mr Hosking was one of the journalists who received a £40,000 pay-off from the former proprietor, Lord Hollick, after the paper was sold to Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell group.

webTitle: Comment: Foot and mouth is a good thing

fields.headline: Foot and mouth is a  good thing
fields.standfirst:
If our herds are infected it can only be of benefit in the long run

Special report: Foot and mouth disease

Email update
Sign up for our free daily foot and mouth roundup
fields.trailText: If our herds are infected it can only be of benefit in the long run.
fields.body:
Last week a friend working in Kenya explained Britain's foot and mouth policy to a Maasai cattle herder. The nomad found our approach horrifying and hilarious in equal measure. His first objection was that all cattle belong to the Maasai, and no one had asked their permission. Then he wanted to know why Britain found it so hard to suppress a disease which the Maasai had learnt to control generations ago. When my friend explained that we were hoping to start selling our meat abroad once more, he was mystified: "Why on earth would you want to do that?" he asked. This is a good question, which we in Britain have so far failed to ask, let alone to answer.

Yesterday, the Times suggested that our meat exports are worth "up to £1bn a year". As usual, the paper of record seems to be making it up as it goes along. The Ministry of Agriculture's figures for last year show that we exported £310m worth of cattle, pigs and sheep to the European Union, and next to nothing elsewhere. Interestingly, this figure represents a decline of 39% from 1999. If this trend continues, our exports will dwindle to zero in three years' time. But it won't continue. Foot and mouth, for most foreign buyers, is the final straw, confirming their well-founded suspicion that our farming is unsafe. There is no guarantee that exports will resume at all when the UK is declared free from disease.

Most of our livestock sales, moreover, are subsidised, by both headage and export payments. The truckers who drive them around are also state assisted, as their fuel and road taxes now pay only some 80% of the costs they impose on the Exchequer. Livestock sales, in other words, are likely to cost the country more than they make.

So parts of the countryside have been declared off limits, the tourist industry has been all but obliterated, rare breeds have been slaughtered and hundreds of businesses have been closed to protect an industry which is worth not £1bn a year, not £570m as ministers have claimed, not even the £310m that Maff figures show, but, in all probability, less than nothing.

Surely then, there must be other reasons for the government's declaration of war with Britain's sheep? One compelling argument is that Europe insists we stamp out the disease. But the European rules - which arose, anyway, from the British insistence on curtailing foot and mouth through mass slaughter - are designed to protect trade between member states. Were we to abandon our fantasy animal exports, then the requirement would become obsolete.

Foot and mouth disease does have implications for animal welfare. In extreme cases, livestock suffer gravely from the lesions on their mouths and feet. But we can put down animals in this condition without having to slaughter the entire herd, let alone the healthy stock on surrounding farms. Indeed, one of the many idiocies of the mass slaughter programme is that animals in distress are reached no faster than animals which aren't suffering at all: it prolongs pain, rather than relieving it. The selective culling of badly infected stock, moreover, is likely to lead to an improvement in disease resistance, which many of our over-developed new breeds are now woefully lacking. Any suffering caused by foot and mouth would surely be offset by terminating the cruel and unnecessary live transport of animals to other countries.

There is no doubt that foot and mouth will also lead to reduced yields of milk and meat, but it's hard to understand why this should be considered a problem. Thanks to overproduction, the EU has introduced a quota system which ensures that every time we buy a pint of milk, we have to pay two pence over the market price.

The benefits of endemic foot and mouth, by contrast, must surely be obvious. It would encourage farmers to develop local markets for their produce, which is the only strategy which makes both economic and environmental sense. It would reduce the number of lorries on the roads. It would persuade breeders to phase out strains with poor resistance to disease and inherent welfare problems, and return to hardier types which don't require such intensive management.

So the government's decision to start vaccinating livestock should be opposed, on the grounds that it might eliminate foot and mouth from Britain. The ministry should continue to spread the disease around as rapidly as possible, by pursuing a slaughter programme it doesn't have the capacity to implement, leaving piles of rotting animals strewn around the countryside, then setting fire to them so that the virus is lifted into the jetstream and widely dispersed. If the vaccination programme is successful, then, as an urgent strategic priority, the government should reinfect the country forthwith.

It would persuade breeders to phase out strains with poor resistance to disease and inherent welfare problems, and return to hardier types which don't require such intensive management. The ministry should continue to spread the disease around as rapidly as possible, by pursuing a slaughter programme it doesn't have the capacity to implement, leaving piles of rotting animals strewn around the countryside, then setting fire to them so that the virus is lifted into the jetstream and widely dispersed. webTitle: Foot and mouth: Cumbria scene of mass sheep slaughter

fields.headline: Hoon sees sheep arrive for slaughter
fields.standfirst:
Army butchers go to work in Cumbria

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, yesterday visited Cumbria's mass sheep grave near Carlisle and watched the first lorryloads of healthy farm stock arrive to be shot in the head by army personnel.
fields.body:
The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, yesterday visited Cumbria's mass sheep grave near Carlisle and watched the first lorryloads of healthy farm stock arrive to be shot in the head by army personnel.

As the soldiers started the cull of apparently healthy sheep from the three-kilometre zone around the foot and mouth outbreaks, Mr Hoon accompanied the commander in chief of the land forces, Sir Mike Jackson, to the mass burial site at Great Orton airfield, the abandoned Royal Air Force base. They watched sheep being slaughtered with stun guns, then bulldozed into trenches beside hundreds of diseased carcasses.

As General Jackson was last seen heading the forces in Kosovo, fears were sparked that the crisis was now beginning to escalate out of control. But Mr Hoon said he was pleased with the army's work, and that resources were not an issue. "It is not an easy job, it is not a pleasant job," he added, saying General Jackson was in Cumbria as the head of the land forces, not as a crisis call.

General Jackson said: "It is a rather different sort of conflict. It is not one involving human beings who cannot get on with each other, it is a very tragic disease in our own country. Nobody likes to see death and it is just an awful waste. Seeing the utter waste is very sad."

Up to 2,000 healthy animals were slaughtered at the burial pit yesterday, alongside 8,000 or so decomposing carcasses that were pushed from dumper trucks into the graves.

The first load of healthy animals arrived just before 10am. Whimpering sheep poked their noses out of slits in the packed trailers as they were driven over disinfected straw bales. Supervised by two Ministry of Agriculture vets, the sheep were herded, around 40 at a time, into metal pens on the edge of the graves.

The animals were then herded to a patch of concrete covered by a plastic tarpaulin where they each received an electric bolt through the head. The diggers scooped up the carcasses and then dumped them into the pits.

The army calmed fears by the RSPCA that animals were not being killed properly and that some were even being buried alive. Brigadier Alex Birtwhistle, head of the military operation in Cumbria, said that the RSPCA could enter the site at any time without giving prior warning.

At least 4,000 apparently healthy livestock were culled at Carlisle abattoir yesterday and, faced with growing numbers of dead cows littering Cumbrian fields, the army said that it was preparing the biggest pyre that the country had seen.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: compensation could cost £300m

fields.headline: Farmers jam helpline asking for 700,000 animals to be killed
fields.standfirst:
Cost of compensation could reach £300m

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farmers are so desperate after five weeks of being unable to move their stock they have asked for an extra 700,000 animals to be slaughtered, overwhelming the government's ability to deal with the demand.
fields.body:
Farmers are so desperate after five weeks of being unable to move their stock they have asked for an extra 700,000 animals to be slaughtered, overwhelming the government's ability to deal with the demand.

From the moment the Intervention Board opened its 30 phone lines on Friday the switchboard has been jammed. Yesterday 1,900 farmers had managed to register asking for sheep, pigs and cattle to be slaughtered because they are stranded in fields or on farms where they can no longer be properly cared for.

The take-up has been so great that the Intervention Board in Newcastle said last night it could not find enough rendering plants to destroy them all and is looking for landfill sites on the same scale as the giant mass grave on the airfield at Great Orton, in Cumbria.

Farmers get 90% of the pre-foot and mouth price for their animals. Cattle are priced at £900 a head and breeding ewes at £81 a head. Pigs can be as much as £165.

Farmers with 2,000 sheep could expect £100,000 from the scheme. The government has already raised its estimated cost of the scheme from £150m to £200m, but that may not be enough.

John Thorley, chief executive of the National Sheep Association, said: "We are inundated with calls from desperate farmers who cannot even get through on the 30 helplines at the Intervention Board. It is not surprising, this is coming to the peak of the lambing season and farmers have been unable to move their stock."

A second problem is in the pig herd where specialist units normally move piglets on to fattening units but have been unable to do so. Thousands of animals are now in overcrowded conditions.

The Intervention Board said in a statement: "We acknowledge we are experiencing problems with making rendering capacity available. As a consequence there is a backlog of animals." A spokeswoman said they were hoping to make rendering capacity available for the highest priority cases.

Compensation for animals in the compulsory slaughter scheme for infected flocks and herds is also mounting. Yesterday £21.8m had already been paid out and another £6.8m has been allocated on a total of 244 claims. This represents less than a third of the animals already earmarked for slaughter.

Prices vary enormously for animals because of quality but to speed up the process of valuation the Ministry of Agriculture has produced a standard price list. If farmers do not think it is enough they can ask for an individual valuation.

Under this scheme slaughtered breeding ewes are worth £90 each, lambs £60 and rams £150. Breeding sows get £190 and boars £520 as a standard rate although there is less for piglets and cull sows. Breeding cows are valued at £1,100, and beef cattle £600. Bulls are worth £1,000 each.

With 148,000 cattle, 530,000 sheep and 50,000 pigs already earmarked for slaughter the bill is already more than £150m. With the number of animals expected to be slaughtered as part of precautionary culls this is bound to double to more than £300m.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has repeatedly said that money is no object in dealing with the crisis. However, the astonishing take-up of the welfare scheme has shocked officials, who fear that the numbers will exceed a million animals by the end of the week. Each welfare case has to be verified by a vet so some may be disqualified.

The National Sheep Association has appealed to members to hold off to give time for the scheme to get up and running.

webTitle: Leader: Part-privatisation plans are being botched

fields.headline: That uncertain feeling
fields.standfirst:
Part-privatisation plans are being botched

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The chief benefit of the government's PPPs is supposed to be that they transfer the financial risks of major public projects to the private sector. If that were true, there would be a strong case for giving them a go.
fields.body:
The chief benefit of the government's PPPs (public-private partnerships) is supposed to be that they transfer the financial risks of major public projects to the private sector, thereby preventing the taxpayer from being taken for a ride. If that were true, there would be a strong case for giving them a go. But the evidence so far is the opposite. The high-speed rail link from the Channel tunnel to Ebbsfleet was supposed to be the flagship. But early on the contractors managed to secure a government guarantee on £1.1bn of the bonds they raised, making a mockery of it all from the start. This week the national audit office (NAO) warned that taxpayers could be faced with a further bill of up to £1.2bn if passenger targets for Eurostar trains are not reached. Once again, the private sector has insured itself against risk by negotiating escape clauses in the small print.

It is the same with London Transport, even before a deal has been agreed. Even if the Treasury gets its way and - foolishly - goes for the original PPP option, there will have to be an injection of billions of public money to make the project viable. And that is before private sector lawyers have negotiated escape clauses in the small print to cover special situations, the consequences of which will only be unearthed by another NAO investigation years into the future.

This week's hurried compromise over ownership of Britain's air traffic control system does not inspire confidence. It is good that it has not been sold to a private company seeking to make profits out of a system where safety must be paramount. Encouragingly, the new company is a "not for profit" one. But the fact that a group of airlines, including BA, has 46% of the shares - with the possibility that it may one day gain majority control - raises a potential conflict of interest. It is not just that overseas airlines feel they may be discriminated against. The problem is that in future the board of the new company may want to do something (like cutting down the number of flights or upping capital investment) that goes against the interests of the member companies that control it. What happens then? Situations like this and the cost increases of the tube and the rail link are the predictable result of ill-thought out schemes that constantly change as they come up against tough private sector negotiators. The Treasury's plans for the London tube will need a miracle to work properly.

webTitle: Comment: Who exactly are the House of Lords?

fields.headline: Committee meanings
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: The House of Lords voted this week against a ban on hunting, against any system of outside supervision, and in favour of self-regulation: a system widely disparaged in society nowadays, especially by the press. But perhaps that is unfair to the hunting lobby.
fields.body:
The House of Lords voted this week against a ban on hunting, against any system of outside supervision, and in favour of self-regulation: a system widely disparaged in society nowadays, especially by the press (except, of course, in the case of the press, where they're for it). But perhaps that is unfair to the hunting lobby. For as the hunting baroness, Lady Mallalieu, explained on the radio, what in fact they favour - what in fact they've already got - is independent self-regulation. So that's all right, then. Everything is under control and we people who don't like hunting can go back to sleep.

So why is it that as I contemplate this assurance, there suddenly swims before me the gaunt and haggard face of one of my greatest heroes, George Orwell? Perhaps because he wrote a novel, 1984, one of whose themes is the way politicians misuse and corrupt our language, the way in their mouths words come to mean not what they used to mean, but what they want them to mean. Also because he published an essay called Politics and the English Language which ought to be learned by heart by everyone who goes into political journalism. Here he warns against what he calls a "catalogue of swindles and perversions": words used in variable meanings, "in most cases more or less dishonestly": class, totalitarian, science, progressive, reactionary, bourgeois, equality....

But surely that noble concept, independence, has nothing to do with any of these? Look how anxious people have been to claim it, from the Declaration of Independence on. When three Daily Telegraph journalists decided to leave their old paper and set up on their own, what better title could they have found than the Independent, signalling that their new venture was not beholden to anyone? Or look at the institutions which cluster under the name Independent in the phone book - from suppliers of cars and corporate membership to the Independent Talent Company and the Independent Women's Protection Association. Not to mention those that have aimed slightly off and are listed as Independant.

But the ghost of George Orwell has started to mutter impatiently. "When you see the word 'independent'," he orders, "ask yourself: independent of whom? Independent of what?" Obedient to his advice, I consult the briefing notes for this week's debate, which tells me that the Independent Supervisory Authority for Hunting (ISAH), in which Lady M invests so much faith, was established at the end of 1999, and that the members of the authority are its chairman (who is Sir Ronald Waterhouse QC), the chairman of the Countryside Alliance's hunting committee and the chairmen of the various hunting associations. These are: the Masters of Foxhounds Association, Central Committee of Fell Packs, Federation of Welsh Packs, Association of Masters of Harriers and Beagles, Masters of Basset Hounds Association, National Coursing Club, Association of Lurcher Clubs, Master of Deer Hounds Association, Masters of Mink Hounds Associations and National Working Terrier Federation. Independent of whom? Of Big Brother government, certainly. But of the hunting lobby? George Orwell's ghost is not too sure about that.

When this list was read out by Lord Phillips of Sudbury in the debate there were protests from pro-hunting peers, with Lady Mallalieu to the fore. Only one member of the commission which runs ISAH's affairs, she said, had any connection with hunting. Well, maybe. But if I catch him correctly, George Orwell is saying: always, when you see the report of some committee or commission, ask: who recruited these people? Why are they there?

There are many well-documented instances of governments appointing committees with a view to producing the answer they first thought of. Sometimes, as with the one which Margaret Thatcher appointed to look at the future of broadcasting, the facts make a hole in the dogma and the politicians do not get the outcome they want. But quite often they do. I know nothing of the commissioners who serve at ISAH and of course accept the organisation's assurance that none comes from a hunting body. Even so, I think the list of the organisations which make up the ISAH underline the wise words of the Daily Telegraph's environment correspondent when this organisation was set up. The commissioners, he wrote, would be chosen by a panel consisting of five people connected to land management and veterinary and welfare organisations - but these were "unlikely to include the League Against Cruel Sports, the RSPCA, or the International Fund for Animal Welfare". You bet.

Here he warns against what he calls a "catalogue of swindles and perversions": words used in variable meanings, "in most cases more or less dishonestly": class, totalitarian, science, progressive, reactionary, bourgeois, equality.... But surely that noble concept, independence, has nothing to do with any of these? Look how anxious people have been to claim it, from the Declaration of Independence on. When three Daily Telegraph journalists decided to leave their old paper and set up on their own, what better title could they have found than the Independent, signalling that their new venture was not beholden to anyone? Or look at the institutions which cluster under the name Independent in the phone book - from suppliers of cars and corporate membership to the Independent Talent Company and the Independent Women's Protection Association. Not to mention those that have aimed slightly off and are listed as Independant. But the ghost of George Orwell has started to mutter impatiently. "When you see the word 'independent'," he orders, "ask yourself: independent of whom? Independent of what?" Obedient to his advice, I consult the briefing notes for this week's debate, which tells me that the Independent Supervisory Authority for Hunting (ISAH), in which Lady M invests so much faith, was established at the end of 1999, and that the members of the authority are its chairman (who is Sir Ronald Waterhouse QC), the chairman of the Countryside Alliance's hunting committee and the chairmen of the various hunting associations. These are: the Masters of Foxhounds Association, Central Committee of Fell Packs, Federation of Welsh Packs, Association of Masters of Harriers and Beagles, Masters of Basset Hounds Association, National Coursing Club, Association of Lurcher Clubs, Master of Deer Hounds Association, Masters of Mink Hounds Associations and National Working Terrier Federation. Independent of whom? Of Big Brother government, certainly. But of the hunting lobby? George Orwell's ghost is not too sure about that. When this list was read out by Lord Phillips of Sudbury in the debate there were protests from pro-hunting peers, with Lady Mallalieu to the fore. Only one member of the commission which runs ISAH's affairs, she said, had any connection with hunting. Well, maybe. But if I catch him correctly, George Orwell is saying: always, when you see the report of some committee or commission, ask: who recruited these people? Why are they there? There are many well-documented instances of governments appointing committees with a view to producing the answer they first thought of. Sometimes, as with the one which Margaret Thatcher appointed to look at the future of broadcasting, the facts make a hole in the dogma and the politicians do not get the outcome they want. But quite often they do. I know nothing of the commissioners who serve at ISAH and of course accept the organisation's assurance that none comes from a hunting body. Even so, I think the list of the organisations which make up the ISAH underline the wise words of the Daily Telegraph's environment correspondent when this organisation was set up. The commissioners, he wrote, would be chosen by a panel consisting of five people connected to land management and veterinary and welfare organisations - but these were "unlikely to include the League Against Cruel Sports, the RSPCA, or the International Fund for Animal Welfare". You bet. david.mckie@theguardian.com

webTitle: Foot and mouth: controversy over limit to vaccination

fields.headline: Limit on vaccination 'a slap in the face'
fields.standfirst:
We have been left to rot, say sheep farmers

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Britain was given EU permission yesterday to vaccinate 180,000 valuable dairy cattle against foot and mouth in Cumbria and Devon but did not seek to do the same to safeguard other farm animals - a decision described as a slap in the face by desperate pedigree sheep owners.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, Ian Black and  Kirsty Scott
fields.body:
Britain was given EU permission yesterday to vaccinate 180,000 valuable dairy cattle against foot and mouth in Cumbria and Devon but did not seek to do the same to safeguard other farm animals - a decision described as a slap in the face by desperate pedigree sheep owners.

With the disease spreading yesterday to Swaledale sheep on the moors in Northumberland, putting more than a million animals on the Pennines in jeopardy, David Brown, chairman of the National Sheep Association, said farmers were in despair.

"This thing is growing like a cancer. No firebreak on earth seems capable of stopping it. We went to London a week ago and pleaded with the chief vet, Jim Scudamore, for the right to vaccinate and have heard nothing. If we delay any further it will be too late.

"We faxed another urgent letter today but got no response. To hear they have not even applied is a slap in the face. We have been left to rot. What do we have to do to get an audience? The anger is rising here; the time for talking will soon be over."

The new outbreak that dismayed farmers in the the area was on Hexhamshire Common, the first Pennine moor to get the disease. They had no contact with other infected sheep, and there are more than 100,000 roaming in the area.

Last night the Ministry of Agriculture said it did not consider sheep worth vaccinating because it was not sure the vaccine worked. Even with cattle - 100,000 in Cumbria and 80,000 in Devon - no final decision to vaccinate had been taken.

The Pennine sheep, like Herdwick sheep in the Lake District, are impossible to replace. The flocks are "hefted", meaning territorial, sticking to the same patch of hill or moor - something that takes generations to develop. Farmers want to vaccinate and bring sheep off the moors to preserve the blood lines, but the ministry has set its face against vaccinating hefted sheep.

In Brussels, Richard Cawthorne, deputy chief veterinary officer, joined fellow EU vets to discuss the request to vaccinate only cattle, granted specifically for cattle in Cumbria and Devon that are being infected by sheep on the same farms. Around outbreaks, all healthy sheep would be slaughtered and the cows vaccinated.

The target cattle are now in sheds but in May would normally be moved to pasture now being used by sheep. Vaccination would allow them to graze safely.

Before the go-ahead was announced, the European commission said movements of any vaccinated cattle would have to be severely restricted for many months.

The request for a limited emergency exemption from the EU's decade-long vaccination ban was intended to create a barrier around Britain's worst-hit areas, said the EC health spokeswoman, Beate Gminder.

Cattle are worth around £1,000 each, 10 times more than a sheep, and have a far longer production lifespan. Cattle are tagged and carefully monitored because of BSE, which means they cannot be exported. Sheep, as the foot and mouth outbreak has proved, are more difficult to keep track of.

Vaccination is said to have disastrous consequences for livestock exporters. They would lose their disease-free status on world markets, since vaccinated animals carry similar antibodies to those infected with the disease. That status is restored three months after the last vaccinated animal is slaughtered, but the EU fears it could take years before its exporters would fully recover from a long-term ban.

Senior ministers have decided to ignore a damning report on the government's handling of the crisis by Keith Sumption, a veterinary expert from Edinburgh university. It condemns the mass slaughter policy as ineffective and liable to worsen infection. It recommends emergency inoculation as the only viable means of containing the disease.

The report was commissioned from Dr Sumption, a renowned specialist in molecular virology at the university's department of tropical veterinary medicine, by Peter Kindersley, the former publisher who is now an organic farmer in Berkshire. Mr Kindersley is seeking a judicial review to declare the slaughter policy illegal.

Dr Sumption said vaccination was also seen as ethically and publicly acceptable, "a rational response to an exceptionally infective condition and which has a very rapid response".

He contested the ministry's claim that vaccinated animals would still have to be slaughtered. He said that even if every animal in the country were vaccinated, exports could resume in only 12 months.

He could not be reached for comment yesterday.

webTitle: Analysis: Consumer confidence not down despite falls

fields.headline: Stock shock
fields.standfirst: Although investors have suffered from falls in the markets in the past year, consumer confidence has not cracked - yet
fields.trailText: Although investors have suffered from falls in the markets in the past year, consumer confidence has not cracked - yet.
fields.body:
Despite the recent rally in global stock markets - down in London and New York again yesterday - investors have suffered huge losses during the past year. ING Barings estimates that $7.6 trillion has been wiped off share values in the past year.

These sorts of figures breed scepticism. Stock markets go up and stock markets go down and the paper losses that have been suffered since the bursting of the technology bubble merely eradicated the paper gains that preceded the crash. The question is whether the ebb and flow of fortunes in the high-powered gambling dens of the City or Wall Street have anything to do with the real economy.

Most economists think it does, especially in the US, where more than half the population directly own shares and have a considerable personal fortune in the fate of the stock market. Interest in equity markets is far more pronounced in the United States than in Europe, with dedicated business channels providing a minute by minute account of the health of the Dow Jones index, the Nasdaq index and the 500 shares that make up the S&P index.

Historically, individuals have tended to heed the wise words of Mr Micawber and organised their finances so that income exceeds spending, with the remainder saved. In the US, this has not been happening. Households have been spending above their incomes, with the result that the savings ratio has been negative.

All was well so long as share prices were going up. The idea that they were sitting on a nest egg that was growing bigger made individuals confident enough to go out and spend more. Companies responded to higher spending by investing more. Over the past 10 years, the level of consumption in the US has tended to lag behind the movement in the Wilshire 5000 - the broadest measure of the American stock market - with an increase in the value of equities prompting a rise in spending.

Over the past year, however, the situation has changed. The Wilshire 5000 has fallen sharply, making the financial position of American households much more precarious. Half the $7.6 trillion wiped off share values has been accounted for by the US. According to Graham Turner, of the consultancy GFC Economics, the ratio of financial assets to debt, a measure of net wealth, hit a record 510.6% when the stock market peaked a year ago. But within 12 months it has fallen to 419.3%, its lowest level since 1995, as a result of falling share prices, higher borrowing, and a continued running down of savings. "In short, the correction in share prices over the past 12 months has wiped out the rise in net wealth seen during the more than four years of the bull market."

It is this sharp decline in the financial position of American households that has prompted fears about a full-scale recession. Consumers may retrench, spending less and saving more, with knock-on effects on businesses which are also over-extended following ambitious expansion plans.

But while consumer confidence has been dented by the turmoil on the markets it has not cracked. Figures released earlier this week revealed a remarkably upbeat mood about the future. Consumer spending has remained fairly robust and there has been no attempt to rebuild savings.

There are three possible explanations for this. The first is that American consumers are so shell-shocked by the losses they have suffered that they are in denial, and simply cannot accept the gravity of what is happening to them.

A second, linked, theory is that consumers are worried by what has happened but retain total faith in the ability of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, to dig them out of a hole. Mr Greenspan has already cut interest rates three times since the start of the year in response to a big fall in industrial production at the end of last year and the be ginning of this, and the strength of optimism about future prospects may be a reflection of the Fed chairman's guru-like status.

Finally, it may be that share prices are only one factor affecting consumer behaviour, and that low US levels of unemployment are keeping confidence and spending underpinned. There has yet to be a full-blooded shake-out in the labour market, although there have been signs in recent weeks from the lay-offs announced by Motorola, Intel, Cisco and Procter & Gamble that one may be just around the corner.

In the UK, there is an additional factor to bear in mind. The Bank of England's latest inflation report said the overall wealth position of households had changed little since the end of 1999 because the decline in share prices had been offset by a rise in house prices. Although there are around 13m individual shareholders in the UK, 52% of them only have shares in one company, which is usually either the firm they work for or one of the privatisation stocks of the 1980s and 1990s. Consumer confidence - especially in the south of England - tends to be much more affected by what is happening to house prices than share prices, one reason why the fall in property values in the first half of the 1990s following the collapse of the Lawson boom was accompanied by a pronounced feel-bad factor.

That is not to say that falling share prices make no difference here. They do, not least because even those who don't own shares directly have a stake in the stock market through their pensions. But lopping 10% off house prices would have a far bigger impact than a 10% fall in equity values.

 Larry Elliott is the Guardian's economics editor.

fields.headline: Leave the Balkans to the big boys and forget about Vaz
fields.standfirst:
It's time to clear up some misconceptions about Labour's foreign policy

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It's time to clear up some misconceptions about Labour's foreign policy.
fields.body:
Protecting Keith Vaz is Robin Cook. Not just protecting, eclipsing. That is the point about Mr Vaz, a man of many guises. The smarmy politician, like the wheeler-dealer at the centre of squalor in the Labour party in Leicester East, momentarily becomes less significant than the junior minister at the Foreign Office, whose performance in his job is termed "deeply regrettable" by the Commons select committee on foreign affairs. But this time the charge is not justified. The Tories are calling it the most devastating attack ever made by a committee on a serving minister. It helpfully guides us, instead, towards three misperceptions about Labour's conduct of foreign policy. Let us get them out of the way, in ascending order of importance, before the election.

First, there does not need to be a junior minister with responsibility for the Balkans, and he does not need to go there. The job is as absurd as the committee's judgment is ritualistic. The MPs seared Vaz for his ignorance and his absence, as if there was anything he could do to affect a policy that is entirely out of his hands. The Balkans is big stuff, which Mr Cook has rightly taken under his personal control, with the prime minister close alongside. The whole of policy, moreover, is done collectively inside the European Union. For the committee to remark that the EU commissioner, Chris Patten, has been to the Balkans seven times while minister Vaz hasn't gone near the place is a reproach based on the premise that empty ceremonial remains at the heart of political accountability.

Which perhaps is a mirror of the committee's own role. To the over-stretched officials and military people trying to make a useful difference in Kosovo and the rest of the region, the only thing more irritating than a visit from a token British minister was surely the collective descent upon them, requiring to be watered and chaperoned, of a parliamentary committee whose subsequent report throws little more light on Balkans policy than many journalists have done before. The luckless Vaz, with his meaningless Balkan label, got caught up in the committee's own empty vanities.

Second, though, his proper role as minister for Europe has been misconceived in a different way. This is not his fault, nor parliament's, but the government's. Most countries have ministers with that title, and many of these make serious contributions to thinking about the EU. They are often politicians to be reckoned with. In both Germany and France, the Europe ministers have a standing that entitles them to be heard, with opinions that sometimes disagree with their superiors'.

Mr Blair has got through Europe ministers at the rate of one a year. Literally no job in the whole of government has come closer to being treated as a trash-can. The one occupant with the qualifications to fill it, Joyce Quin, was quickly moved on. The government thus accumulates little collective memory, or cultural affinity, for the kind of networking that is second nature to European politicians. Even harder than getting ministers to go to the Balkans is interesting them in the much more useful function of attending informal European get-togethers. Not long ago, at the annual Bertelsmann Foundation conference in Berlin, attended by Chancellor Schröder and President Prodi, and several foreign ministers, as well as a number of presidents from central Europe, the best Britain could field was a Conservative baroness. The government voice for the British interest simply wasn't heard.

This is a habitual British pattern, probably worse under Labour than the Tories. Since Peter Mandelson left office, there hasn't been a single leading Labour figure willing to do anything abroad which his department doesn't tell him he has to do. We need a Europe minister liberated to take the task of intelligent networking seriously, something Blair and Cook, in thrall to hierarchies of control, do not encourage. That person Keith Vaz will never be.

Third, though, Cook has become on the whole an excellent foreign secretary. His low reputation with his political enemies and several newspapers is the biggest misperception at the end of these four years, owing a lot to the kind of vicious, personalised triviality which can endure so much longer here than in more mature societies.

Apart from the major misfortune in his private life, Cook made one calamitous error at the start of his term, which was to promise an ethical dimension to his foreign policy in terms that have led to him being ethically faulted ever since. It was an honourable but half-baked claim, hoisting to prominence the false assumption that his predecessors had always been unethical and carrying the implication that he, a principled foreign secretary, would address the harshness of the world from a more elevated position. With the exception of a slight improvement in the European rules for arms sales, this he has naturally failed to do.

But he is now admired in quarters we seldom hear about. The Foreign Office itself, many of whose top people detested his posturing at the start, has succumbed to his intellectual swiftness. Some officials still reflect bitterly on the responsibility which, as they see it, he failed to take for the Sandline affair in Sierra Leone, instead dumping them in the dirt. But his thorough grasp of many issues now overshadows his notorious reluctance to carry half-a-dozen red boxes home at night.

He has likewise made friends in the European Union. For two years, he took no interest in the EU and made little impact on British policy there. Now he is an important player. When Mr Blair had to leave last week's Stockholm summit early, he could rely not only on Cook playing the British hand as he would have done but - a privilege not granted to many foreign ministers - on the Schröders and Chiracs accepting him at the table without demur. The friends of Mr Blair now say the leader cannot do without his foreign secretary. Of all top ministers, he has the closest, least troubled working relationship of any with the prime minister.

Though he, too, was tritely criticised by the select committee for not visiting the Balkans, it is there, in his own eyes, that he has earned the greatest credit. His role was less spectacular than Joschka Fischer's. He didn't, like the German foreign minister, put his political life on the line to persuade his party of the case for defending Kosovo against ethnic purging by the Serbs. But alongside Blair, from a different wing of old Labour, he can take some credit for the removal of Slobodan Milosevic from power. In the scales that measure ethical foreign policy with a political purpose, this weighs in as a not inconsiderable item.

After the election, I think Keith Vaz will no longer be minister for Europe, or the Balkans. A good thing too. But Robin Cook will still be foreign secretary, because nobody would do a better job.

The smarmy politician, like the wheeler-dealer at the centre of squalor in the Labour party in Leicester East, momentarily becomes less significant than the junior minister at the Foreign Office, whose performance in his job is termed "deeply regrettable" by the Commons select committee on foreign affairs. It helpfully guides us, instead, towards three misperceptions about Labour's conduct of foreign policy. Let us get them out of the way, in ascending order of importance, before the election. First, there does not need to be a junior minister with responsibility for the Balkans, and he does not need to go there. The job is as absurd as the committee's judgment is ritualistic. The MPs seared Vaz for his ignorance and his absence, as if there was anything he could do to affect a policy that is entirely out of his hands. The Balkans is big stuff, which Mr Cook has rightly taken under his personal control, with the prime minister close alongside. The whole of policy, moreover, is done collectively inside the European Union. For the committee to remark that the EU commissioner, Chris Patten, has been to the Balkans seven times while minister Vaz hasn't gone near the place is a reproach based on the premise that empty ceremonial remains at the heart of political accountability. Which perhaps is a mirror of the committee's own role. To the over-stretched officials and military people trying to make a useful difference in Kosovo and the rest of the region, the only thing more irritating than a visit from a token British minister was surely the collective descent upon them, requiring to be watered and chaperoned, of a parliamentary committee whose subsequent report throws little more light on Balkans policy than many journalists have done before. The luckless Vaz, with his meaningless Balkan label, got caught up in the committee's own empty vanities. Second, though, his proper role as minister for Europe has been misconceived in a different way. This is not his fault, nor parliament's, but the government's. Most countries have ministers with that title, and many of these make serious contributions to thinking about the EU. They are often politicians to be reckoned with. In both Germany and France, the Europe ministers have a standing that entitles them to be heard, with opinions that sometimes disagree with their superiors'. Mr Blair has got through Europe ministers at the rate of one a year. Literally no job in the whole of government has come closer to being treated as a trash-can. The one occupant with the qualifications to fill it, Joyce Quin, was quickly moved on. The government thus accumulates little collective memory, or cultural affinity, for the kind of networking that is second nature to European politicians. Even harder than getting ministers to go to the Balkans is interesting them in the much more useful function of attending informal European get-togethers. Not long ago, at the annual Bertelsmann Foundation conference in Berlin, attended by Chancellor Schröder and President Prodi, and several foreign ministers, as well as a number of presidents from central Europe, the best Britain could field was a Conservative baroness. The government voice for the British interest simply wasn't heard. This is a habitual British pattern, probably worse under Labour than the Tories. Since Peter Mandelson left office, there hasn't been a single leading Labour figure willing to do anything abroad which his department doesn't tell him he has to do. We need a Europe minister liberated to take the task of intelligent networking seriously, something Blair and Cook, in thrall to hierarchies of control, do not encourage. That person Keith Vaz will never be. Third, though, Cook has become on the whole an excellent foreign secretary. His low reputation with his political enemies and several newspapers is the biggest misperception at the end of these four years, owing a lot to the kind of vicious, personalised triviality which can endure so much longer here than in more mature societies. Apart from the major misfortune in his private life, Cook made one calamitous error at the start of his term, which was to promise an ethical dimension to his foreign policy in terms that have led to him being ethically faulted ever since. It was an honourable but half-baked claim, hoisting to prominence the false assumption that his predecessors had always been unethical and carrying the implication that he, a principled foreign secretary, would address the harshness of the world from a more elevated position. With the exception of a slight improvement in the European rules for arms sales, this he has naturally failed to do. But he is now admired in quarters we seldom hear about. The Foreign Office itself, many of whose top people detested his posturing at the start, has succumbed to his intellectual swiftness. Some officials still reflect bitterly on the responsibility which, as they see it, he failed to take for the Sandline affair in Sierra Leone, instead dumping them in the dirt. But his thorough grasp of many issues now overshadows his notorious reluctance to carry half-a-dozen red boxes home at night. He has likewise made friends in the European Union. For two years, he took no interest in the EU and made little impact on British policy there. Now he is an important player. When Mr Blair had to leave last week's Stockholm summit early, he could rely not only on Cook playing the British hand as he would have done but - a privilege not granted to many foreign ministers - on the Schröders and Chiracs accepting him at the table without demur. The friends of Mr Blair now say the leader cannot do without his foreign secretary. Of all top ministers, he has the closest, least troubled working relationship of any with the prime minister. Though he, too, was tritely criticised by the select committee for not visiting the Balkans, it is there, in his own eyes, that he has earned the greatest credit. His role was less spectacular than Joschka Fischer's. He didn't, like the German foreign minister, put his political life on the line to persuade his party of the case for defending Kosovo against ethnic purging by the Serbs. But alongside Blair, from a different wing of old Labour, he can take some credit for the removal of Slobodan Milosevic from power. In the scales that measure ethical foreign policy with a political purpose, this weighs in as a not inconsiderable item. After the election, I think Keith Vaz will no longer be minister for Europe, or the Balkans. A good thing too. But Robin Cook will still be foreign secretary, because nobody would do a better job. hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: Sketch: A baldy with a funny accent, speaking in code

fields.headline: A baldy with a funny accent, speaking in code
fields.standfirst: Special report: parliament
fields.trailText: Nobody wanted to mention the "E" word during prime minister's questions. In particular, William Hague can't appear to be running from an election.
fields.body:
Nobody wanted to mention the "E" word during prime minister's questions. In particular, William Hague can't appear to be running from an election.

Tony Blair wants it to seem that his choice of date will be made exclusively to benefit the national weal, and will have nothing whatever to do with cutting and running before the recession gets worse and before every animal in the country, including cute pet kittens and frolicsome puppies, has been shot, oh dear me, definitely not.

So Mr Hague had to employ a kind of code. After dancing around the prime minister, so to speak, trying to imply that the rampaging plague was in some way Mr Blair's fault without actually accusing him of feeding poisonous leftover number 37 with pak choi and egg fried rice to the pigs of Northumberland, he reached the point.

"The prime minister has promised to strain every sinew," he said. The present crisis required the use of all military resources "and every ounce of the prime minister's care and attention". In other words, this is no time for such frivolities as an election. Actually, "strain every sinew" is one of those dead metaphors you only ever hear politicians use. Brought back to life by a linguistic Frankenstein, it sounds to modern ears more like a cookery recipe. "Plunge the sinews into boiling salted water and simmer for five minutes. Then drain, being careful to strain every one."

Mr Blair, of course, was having none of it. "We are doing everything we can to bring it under control," and he was wise to say that, since if he had appeared to give way on the election, almost the entire parliamentary Labour party would have called for his removal to the nearest abattoir. They really want that election, now.

But nobody mentioned it. The tension in the chamber was almost unbearable. Most MPs are ready to snap. If they don't know about the poll, one way or the other, within 24 hours, some of them will be found naked under Westminster bridge, painted bright green, and claiming to hear messages from giant talking pigs.

So there was a happy moment of relief half way through. Tim Loughton, the Tory MP for Worthing East, had a question on the order paper. Unfortunately for him, it came the day after he had described his leader as "a baldy with a funny accent".

The public loves politicians who tell the truth, but politicians hate it. So even though Mr Loughton had gone on to say, "in spite of these drawbacks, he is a miracle worker who could cure foot and mouth if he only had time to lay hands on five million sheep" (or words to that effect), he was in big trouble.

Labour MPs had passed the word around, and greeted his question with cheers and cries of "more, more!", before he even started.

Mr Loughton had a choice. He could grin winsomely, chuckle, and make some self-deprecating remark, such as "...speaking as someone with far too much hair and a stuck-up accent..." Or he could be pompous.

He chose pompous.

"While Labour members cheer..." he said magnificently, rather like Sir Peter Tapsell waiting for the Hansard reporters to get out their stone and chisels so as to immortalise his words.

The cheering redoubled. The Speaker called for order. Mr Loughton sat down. The cheering ebbed. Then he rose again, pomposity coursing in his veins like steroids through an Olympic athlete.

"While Labour members cheer..." he went on, before reminding us of the state of play in the countryside.

A Labour MP I know was sitting diagonally opposite the Tory leader, and reported that, ever so slightly, he blushed.

fields.headline: 54-hour wait tops casualty survey
fields.trailText: A spot check of hospitals by community health watchdogs this week found at least 20 patients who were experiencing "unacceptable" waits of more than 24 hours in casualty departments.
fields.body:
A spot check of hospitals by community health watchdogs this week found at least 20 patients who were experiencing "unacceptable" waits of more than 24 hours in casualty departments.

They included a 93-year-old woman with hypothermia and leg ulcers who was kept for more than 30 hours in the accident and emergency unit at Maidstone hospital in Kent before being admitted to a ward.

The longest wait was by a 41-year-old woman with abdominal pains who spent more than 54 hours in casualty at Kent and Canterbury hospital in Canterbury where she was detained for investigation. Nine other patients at these hospitals had been waiting more than 24 hours at the time of the spot check on Monday.

The findings sparked anger between the Department of Health and the association of community health councils for England and Wales which organised the survey - the last annual exercise of this type before the councils are abolished by legislation going through parliament.

Donna Covey, director of the association, said: "For many people even a two-hour wait in accident and emergency can seem an eternity. Waits of over 24 hours are clearly unacceptable. Casualty waits of this length show that the system is now under year-round pressure."

But the department said 19 of the longest waits recorded were patients being cared for in beds in accident and emergency departments. Only one was on a trolley. "Many were not waiting," a department spokesman said. "They were under observation by doctors and nurses, or undergoing tests so they could diagnose what's wrong. This is a key part of what A&E departments have always done."

The government has set a target that by 2004 nobody is to wait more than four hours between arrival and admission, transfer or discharge. But ministers are considering how to define the goal to permit people to remain under observation in admission wards in accident and emergency if conditions are appropriate.

The annual casualty watch survey was carried out at 200 hospitals throughout the UK. Preliminary results showing the 20 longest waits were published yesterday.

Six were at Kent and Canterbury hospital, which came under fire last week when a report by independent experts said the accident and emergency department was "fundamentally unsafe".

Rupert Williamson, chief officer of Canterbury and Thanet CHC, said there was no serious incident at the time of the survey to explain the lengthy waits. The problem seemed to be that 74 beds in hospital wards were filled by patients ready for discharge who were unable to leave.

"As a result there were patients in A&E who should not have been there," he said. "It is not a ward. It does not have toilets or washing facilities. It is not ideal for feeding and patients do not have call bells."

David Astley, chief executive of the East Kent Hospitals NHS trust, said all the patients had been admitted to the hospital and were being nursed in beds, under the care of a named consultant, with a proper treatment plan. "Although they were not in ideal conditions .. their dignity and privacy was protected by screens."

The spot check also found a 30-year-old woman who had taken an overdose who waited 26 hours to be admitted to a ward at Newham general hospital, east London, and an 84-year-old man with stomach pains who waited in casualty at St Helier hospital in Surrey for 29 hours.

fields.headline: Bush kills global warming treaty
fields.standfirst:
Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The Bush administration yesterday appeared to end all hope of reviving the Kyoto treaty on global warming, declaring it had "no interest" in its implementation and taking the first steps towards withdrawing the US signature on the accord.
fields.body:
The Bush administration yesterday appeared to end all hope of reviving the Kyoto treaty on global warming, declaring it had "no interest" in its implementation and taking the first steps towards withdrawing the US signature on the accord.

Kyoto's death warrant, announced by Christine Todd Whitman, head of the environmental protection agency (EPA), represented a blunt rebuff to European hopes of establishing a global programme to slow down the emission of greenhouse gases, amid startling new evidence of rapid climate change. A UN panel of scientists assessing the threat recently reported that average temperatures could rise by up to 5.8 degrees celsius this century without a serious effort to curb emissions.

The former vice-president Al Gore signed the Kyoto accord on behalf of the US, but it was never ratified by the Senate. A state department official yesterday confirmed a report in the Washington Post that the new administration had asked the state department to explore ways of formally withdrawing the US signature from the document.

Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, privately told European ambassadors last week that the US considered the Kyoto accord "dead", but the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, had hoped to convince Mr Bush not to abandon the agreement altogether when the two leaders meet today in Washington.

"It is important that the US accepts its responsibility for the world climate. They are the biggest economy in the world and the heaviest energy consumers," Mr Schröder told the Los Angeles Times.

Ms Whitman's remarks represent a snub to the German chancellor on the eve of his arrival. Asked whether the Kyoto deal had any chance of survival, she told journalists: "No, we have no interest in implementing that treaty."

In a letter to Republican senators earlier this month, Mr Bush said he opposed the Kyoto deal - under which the US would have to reduce the emission of greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide and methane by 7% below 1990 levels by 2012 - because it exempted developing countries and would harm the US economy. He said he would not impose controls on emissions of carbon dioxide, despite an election pledge to do so.

A European diplomat called the hardline attitude depressing and marked a significant divergence between European and US views on how to deal with the problem. It cast a pall over an international meeting in Bonn in June, where a fresh attempt is to be made to establish a consensus.

European leaders had been hopeful that the 1997 treaty could be salvaged after Ms Whitman came to the G8 environment summit in Trieste and signed a joint statement on March 4 which said: "We commit ourselves to strive to reach agreement on outstanding political issues and to ensure in a cost-effective manner the environmental integrity of the Kyoto protocol."

Ms Whitman attempted to persuade Mr Bush to support an international agreement on global warming. In a memorandum to the White House obtained by the Guardian, her office said such a treaty would "begin to create some certainty that climate change is a lasting policy issue".

The White House's stance represents a serious defeat for Ms Whitman and the treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill. In a memo for Mr Bush on February 27, Mr O'Neill said that the accumulation of greenhouse gases was "a very big problem" and that the emissions controls laid down in the Kyoto treaty did not go far enough.

Amy Kreider, director of the global warming campaign at the US National Environmental Trust, said: "This is no way to conduct policy.

"It looks like amateur hour at the White House as regards foreign policy."

webTitle: Scheme targets vast area of uban decay

fields.headline: Scheme targets vast area of uban decay
fields.trailText: Plans for a new town within Manchester to help regenerate one of Britain's biggest areas of urban decay were unveiled by a business and council partnership yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans for a new town within Manchester to help regenerate one of Britain's biggest areas of urban decay were unveiled by a business and council partnership yesterday.

More than 1,000 hectares of land east of Manchester's city centre will be revived over 10 years in a scheme described as having "a scale and diversity almost unprecedented in an English city".

The scheme, which will be closely monitored by ministers, who regard it as a model project, is expected to attract £2bn in public and private funding. More than 15,000 jobs will be created as 12,500 homes are built, 7,500 existing homes are modernised, and the local population doubles to an expected 60,000.

The project will be managed by an urban regeneration company known as New East Manchester (NEM), a partnership between Manchester city council, English Partnerships and the north west development agency.

The scheme is closely linked to the new 48,000-seat stadium and other sports facilities that are under construction in the area for next year's Commonwealth Games. "The games are at the heart of this," said Sir Alan Cockshaw, NEM's chairman, at the launch yesterday. "We always intended that the development of the games area would be a catalyst for fundamental change."

The plan describes the area as "the epicentre of the world's first industrial revolution". It says: "In the last quarter of the 20th century, much of that industrial base, and the employment that accompanied it, was decimated by successive economic recession, and intensive competition from increasingly global markets."

It was announced yesterday that the redevelopment of the rundown Cardroom estate - described by a resident as like Beirut - will be led by Urban Splash, a company which has given new life to mills and other industrial buildings in Manchester and Liverpool.

In a recent Guardian debate, Urban Splash's chairman, Tom Bloxham, expressed concern that the wealth of booming Manchester was not trickling out from the centre to poorer neighbourhoods. The firm's managing director, Jonathan Falkingham, said yesterday the Cardroom estate was a challenge: "But it's also an opportunity. We have a vision for the estate which will create a 21st century residential community that is both inclusive and sustainable."

The NEM plan also includes a partnership with a private developer to construct, on a 160-hectare site, a business park forecast to create 9,000 jobs. Shops, restaurants, a market hall, hotel and homes are planned, and Asda Wal-Mart plans to build a superstore to be ready by 2002. The banks of the Ashton canal are being improved to create a walking and cycling route from the city centre to the stadium.

webTitle: Straw and minister clash on youth jails

fields.headline: Straw and minister clash on youth jails
fields.standfirst: Boateng's objections to early release of teenagers are overruled
fields.trailText: Boateng's objections to early release of teenagers are overruled.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, has overruled the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, in a Home Office clash over how to keep discipline inside youth jails, according to Whitehall papers leaked to the Guardian.

Mr Boateng objected to a more liberal approach now being introduced of releasing early those juveniles who behaved well, saying it would lead to suggestions that the prison service was rewarding them with reduced sentences as the only way to get them to behave.

The approach also brought a warning from the director-general of prisons, Martin Narey, about whether he could make it work.

But Mr Straw rejected Mr Boateng's criticism and backed demands from Lord Warner, head of the youth justice board, for a more liberal use of the carrot rather than the stick.

The options under the incentive scheme to enforce discipline among the more troublesome teenagers include rewarding good behaviour with early release, in-cell television and allowing them more trips home during their sentence.

The clash between liberal and hardline approaches at the highest levels of the Home Office took place after prison governors complained that the new juvenile detention and training orders did not give them the power to add extra days to a sentence for bad behaviour.

A leaked letter from Mr Narey to Mr Straw of February 12 makes clear that the home secretary rejected the option of new legislation to restore the punishment power of governors for juveniles under 18.

"In consideration of this I wanted to be open about how I will be encouraging governors to use the incentive of early release to encourage good order. You will remember that at a recent bilateral Paul Boateng expressed some concern about that," Mr Narey wrote, going on to make clear that he recognised some of the prison minister's concerns.

He said most young offenders' institutions were coping well, but there was a problem in three jails where the over 18s, who could be punished with extra days, were held alongside the under 18s, who could not.

Mr Narey also said the scheme was in danger of undermining the anti-drugs policy, which has so far proved successful because a positive drug test inevitably led to extra days on the sentence. "But a juvenile who tests positive for drugs can have no such sanction imposed."

He said nothing could be done about teenage offenders who smashed up their cells. webTitle: Ruling could free dozens of mentally ill offenders

fields.headline: Ruling could free dozens of mentally ill offenders
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: Key sections of the mental health laws of England and Wales are incompatible with human rights, the appeal court ruled yesterday. The landmark judgment could lead to the release of dozens of mentally disordered offenders from Broadmoor and other high security hospitals in the UK.
fields.body:
Key sections of the mental health laws of England and Wales are incompatible with human rights, the appeal court ruled yesterday. The landmark judgment could lead to the release of dozens of mentally disordered offenders from Broadmoor and other high security hospitals in the UK.

Three appeal court judges, led by the master of the rolls, Lord Phillips, declared that two sections of the Mental Health Act 1983 were incompatible with the European convention on human rights.

The ruling is the first "declaration of incompatibility" to be made by the appeal court since judges received the right last October, as the Human Rights Act came into force, to declare acts of parliament incompatible with the convention.

The only previous declaration, made by the high court in December, threw the planning laws into disarray. The law lords are now considering overturning the declaration.

In yesterday's case a person with paranoid schizophrenia, detained in Broadmoor for the manslaughter of a fellow hostel resident in 1988, successfully challenged procedures under which psychiatric patients detained against their will can gain release.

Lucy Scott-Moncrieff, the solicitor for the patient, who was named only as H, said: "This ruling will force the government to change the law. It means that all the patients who are now detained without strong evidence will be entitled to discharge."

The judges ruled that sections 72 and 73 of the Mental Health Act, which say how mental health review tribunals should decide on the release of patients, breached article five of the European convention - the right to liberty.

While patients could be admitted to hospital only if doctors decided they needed to be detained, when it came to their release the burden of proof was on the patients to prove they no longer needed to be detained. This "reverse burden of proof" breached the convention, the judges ruled.

A psychiatrist at Broadmoor told the tribunal that H was doing well on medication and might live in a specialised hostel. The majority of the clinical team on his ward favoured transfer to a medium secure unit. A second psychiatrist thought medium security was "unreasonably cautious". Both psychiatrists said H did not satisfy the conditions necessary for continued detention under the Mental Health Act.

But the tribunal concluded in December 1999 that H still exhibited symptoms of his illness (hearing voices), would not continue with his medication, and needed to be kept in hospital for his own safety.

A high court judge rejected H's application for judicial review of the tribunal's decision last September, and refused to hear arguments based on the Human Rights Act. But the appeal court granted permission in December for those points to be argued on appeal.

Lawyers for the health secretary, Alan Milburn, accepted that it would be incompatible with the human rights convention to put the burden of proof on the patient, but that the judges could interpret the Mental Health Act so as not to breach the convention.

The judges disagreed. They said the same test - whether it could be reliably shown that the patient suffered from a mental disorder serious enough to warrant detention - had to be applied to release as well as to the original detention. Since sections 72 and 73 did not require a tribunal to discharge a patient if this could not be shown, it was incompatible with the convention.

Lord Phillips said the circumstances of H's case were not uncommon. People in hospital with schizophrenia took their medication and went into remission; so long as they were treated they were no danger to themselves or others. But the professionals involved might be uncertain whether, if discharged into the community, patients would continue to take it their drugs.

Ms Scott-Moncrieff said she had up to 15 clients turned down in the past year who might now have grounds for release. H had another tribunal hearing pending, she said.

The Department of Health was refused permission to appeal to the Lords, but can still ask the lords to hear an appeal.
