webTitle: Comment: John Redwood: Labour's grim spring

fields.headline: Labour's grim spring
fields.standfirst:
To we Conservatives, Labour looks as if it's heading back to the old horrors of the winter of discontent

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: To we Conservatives, Labour looks as if it's heading back to the old horrors of the winter of discontent.
fields.body:
What a difference a month makes. Before the outbreak of foot and mouth, before the stock market crash, the government kept reciting, "No more boom and bust". Many believed it. Now people are not so sure.

This government of soothing soundbites is discovering that asinine spin when a crisis hits does not reassure. Farmers did not believe the government when they were told that the foot and mouth outbreak was under control. They were worried to death as the disease stalked ever closer to their farms. Steel workers at Llanwern do not believe that the government has created economic stability, as they line up to collect their P45s. Lorry drivers are not convinced that the government is on their side, seeing their businesses taxed and regulated to death.

This cold, hard, wet, sometimes snow ridden, grey, miserable spring is proving to be Labour's spring of discontent. You could see it in the faces of the Cumbrian protesters when Tony Blair swept in by Jaguar four weeks after the foot and mouth disaster struck. You can see it in the faces of the hoteliers and leisure operators looking at blank booking diaries, ringing their bank managers anxiously to see how long they will tide them over. You can see it in the crushed looks of the dot.com brigade, whose year of fun is well and truly over.

The government still tells us that the economy is fine. It has after all abolished boom and bust. When I warned that it could not abolish the trade cycle, I was told I was wrong. Now the trade cycle, like an unfriendly boomerang, is coming back to haunt them. Soon the government will solemnly tell us that Britain is fine, but unfortunately the US under Mr Clinton (they will probably blame Mr Bush) did not succeed in abolishing boom and bust, so there will be some collateral damage over here.

The truth is that this government has ensured that the bust will be bigger for more people in Britain than it need have been. It will be worse in the countryside. As we watch the funeral pyres mount on our TV screens, we are sickened and saddened by the slaughter. We see a way of life going up in smoke. No one can say how much animal husbandry there will be after this. No one in authority wants to tell us how many sheep and cattle will have to die before it is all over. People might be able to accept the slaughter if it was working, but so far it isn't. What we do know is that many farming businesses will go under.

We also see that the government's unsuccessful attempts to contain the disease are threatening countless other rural businesses with bankruptcy. The message has got out that much of the countryside is closed to tourists.

No amount of expensive advertising can restore the position, if footpaths are closed, if all contact with animals of any kind is banned, if the government gives out a message that you can go to the countryside but cannot walk on the grass. Pity the poor hotelier, tour operator or employee at a rural attraction.

Meanwhile, back in the City there has been a dramatic collapse in confidence. This week's rally has not restored the fortunes of investment banks and brokers. Wall Street started it, but now home grown problems are making it worse. Telecoms stocks have fallen around the world. One of the main reasons is the greed of the British government in designing an auction to charge them £22bn to stay in the business - followed by a similar auction in Germany, which charged them another £50bn. European governments decided to smash the telecoms industry, and they succeeded. They should not be surprised if such a massive hit causes cash problems and leads to redundancies and cancelled investment programmes. What did they expect?

Much of British manufacturing is suffering from high taxes and regulations at home, and a weak euro abroad. The government turns a deaf ear to them, as the factory closures and sackings mount. The dot.coms are largely history. Many middle of the road businesses are tearing up their plans for 2001 based on rosy government forecasts and battening down the hatches to prepare for the economic storm.

The government now faces not one crisis, but a series of intersecting ones. Its efforts to save farming will bring down much of the rural tourist industry. Its efforts to tax success will help bring down the dot.com and telecom sectors which led the growth of the 1990s. Its belief that business can pay more and accept more regulation will destroy jobs in manufacturing. Its belief that motoring is evil leaves us dependent on a railway system which has got worse.

Governments need to control events, or tell the public honestly they cannot and keep out. This government has said it can control the foot and mouth epidemic, but failed so far. It has said it can control the transport system and make it better, and has failed so far. It has said it has abolished boom and bust. What is it going to say and do now, when so many are staring bankruptcy or job loss in the face? Now is truly our spring of discontent. It is back to the 1970s with a vengeance.

 John Redwood is Conservative member of parliament for Wokingham

fields.headline: Tube strike causes severe disruption
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: London traffic is expected to grind to a halt this morning as the capital's underground system goes through its second strike in two months.
fields.body:
London traffic is expected to grind to a halt this morning as the capital's underground system goes through its second strike in two months.

The walkout by members of the Nation Union of Rail, Maritime and Transport workers, which began at 8pm last night, caused severe disruption on all lines and closed stations. The strike is due to continue until 8pm tonight and services are not expected to return to normal until tomorrow morning.

London Underground advised the capital's 1m commuters to walk home, not wait for crowded buses. The AA said there could be up to 70,000 extra vehicles on the roads today.

Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, said he was "trying to remove the cause of the dispute, which is the PPP".

Action by the RMT union whose members include 7,500 signal workers, station and maintenance staff and 38% of drivers on the tube, is in protest at the government's proposed public-private partnership for the underground. The union says the plans will compromise safety and affect jobs.

Jimmy Knapp, RMT's general secretary, has complained to the health and safety executive that London Underground issued safety licences this week to staff who had not received the normal training.

 Updated information for passengers from London Travel Information: 020-7222 1234. Or at www.thetube.com and www.transportforlondon.co.uk

webTitle: Blair in row over job for aide

fields.headline: Blair in row over job for aide
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, are at loggerheads over a proposal to offer a top political aide a new job as political secretary at £120,000 a year, if Labour wins the next election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his cabinet secretary, Sir Richard Wilson, are at loggerheads over a proposal to offer a top political aide a new job as political secretary at £120,000 a year, if Labour wins the next election.

Sir Richard has threatened to block the appointment of Anji Hunter because the prime minister wants to use £70,000 of taxpayers' cash to fund the post. The Labour party would pay the other £50,000.

The offer would make Ms Hunter, 45, now Mr Blair's social secretary, the highest paid political adviser in the government. She would earn £20,000 a year more than his press secretary, Alastair Campbell, and chief of staff, Jonathan Powell.

Mr Blair has known Ms Hunter since she was 15. She has worked for him since 1983 and has been described as his "fixer, charmer and tactician".

The Guardian has learnt that Sir Richard is against further use of taxpayers' funds for people in a political role, and objects to a proposal that Ms Hunter should have executive powers over civil servants.

Mr Blair's present political secretary is Sally Morgan. Her post has no executive power and she gets half the salary proposed for the revised post. She would have to become an assistant to Ms Hunter or leave.

A Cabinet Office spokeswoman said: "We cannot comment on speculation, especially about individuals." Ms Hunter said last night: "I am not speaking to you. As you know, I do not speak to journalists."

webTitle: Scheme targets vast area of urban decay

fields.headline: Scheme targets vast area of urban decay
fields.trailText: Plans for a new town within Manchester to help regenerate one of Britain's biggest areas of urban decay were unveiled by a business and council partnership yesterday.
fields.body:
Plans for a new town within Manchester to help regenerate one of Britain's biggest areas of urban decay were unveiled by a business and council partnership yesterday.

More than 1,000 hectares of land east of Manchester's city centre will be revived over 10 years in a scheme described as having "a scale and diversity almost unprecedented in an English city".

The scheme, which will be closely monitored by ministers, who regard it as a model project, is expected to attract £2bn in public and private funding. More than 15,000 jobs will be created as 12,500 homes are built, 7,500 existing homes are modernised, and the local population doubles to an expected 60,000.

The project will be managed by an urban regeneration company known as New East Manchester (NEM), a partnership between Manchester city council, English Partnerships and the north west development agency.

The scheme is closely linked to the new 48,000-seat stadium and other sports facilities that are under construction in the area for next year's Commonwealth Games. "The games are at the heart of this," said Sir Alan Cockshaw, NEM's chairman, at the launch yesterday. "We always intended that the development of the games area would be a catalyst for fundamental change."

The plan describes the area as "the epicentre of the world's first industrial revolution". It says: "In the last quarter of the 20th century, much of that industrial base, and the employment that accompanied it, was decimated by successive economic recession, and intensive competition from increasingly global markets."

It was announced yesterday that the redevelopment of the rundown Cardroom estate - described by a resident as like Beirut - will be led by Urban Splash, a company that has given new life to mills and other industrial buildings in Manchester and Liverpool.

In a recent Guardian debate, Urban Splash's chairman, Tom Bloxham, expressed concern that the wealth of booming Manchester was not trickling out from the centre to poorer neighbourhoods. The firm's managing director, Jonathan Falkingham, said yesterday the Cardroom estate was a challenge: "But it's also an opportunity. We have a vision for the estate which will create a 21st century residential community that is both inclusive and sustainable."

The NEM plan also includes a partnership with a private developer to construct, on a 160-hectare site, a business park forecast to create 9,000 jobs. Shops, restaurants, a market hall, hotel and homes are planned, and Asda Wal-Mart plans to build a superstore to be ready by 2002. The banks of the Ashton canal are being improved to create a walking and cycling route from the city centre to the stadium.

webTitle: Ruling could free dozens of mentally ill offenders

fields.headline: Ruling could free dozens of mentally ill offenders
fields.trailText: Key sections of the mental health laws of England and Wales are incompatible with human rights, the appeal court ruled yesterday. The landmark judgment could lead to the release of dozens of mentally disordered offenders from Broadmoor and other high security hospitals in the UK.
fields.body:
Key sections of the mental health laws of England and Wales are incompatible with human rights, the appeal court ruled yesterday. The landmark judgment could lead to the release of dozens of mentally disordered offenders from Broadmoor and other high security hospitals in the UK.

Three appeal court judges, led by the master of the rolls, Lord Phillips, declared that two sections of the Mental Health Act 1983 were incompatible with the European convention on human rights.

The ruling is the first "declaration of incompatibility" to be made by the appeal court since judges received the right last October, as the Human Rights Act came into force, to declare acts of parliament incompatible with the convention.

The only previous declaration, made by the high court in December, threw the planning laws into disarray. The law lords are now considering overturning the declaration.

In yesterday's case a person with paranoid schizophrenia, detained in Broadmoor for the manslaughter of a fellow hostel resident in 1988, successfully challenged procedures under which psychiatric patients detained against their will can gain release.

Lucy Scott-Moncrieff, the solicitor for the patient, who was named only as H, said: "This ruling will force the government to change the law. It means that all the patients who are now detained without strong evidence will be entitled to discharge."

The judges ruled that sections 72 and 73 of the Mental Health Act, which say how mental health review tribunals should decide on the release of patients, breached article five of the European convention - the right to liberty.

While patients could be admitted to hospital only if doctors decided they needed to be detained, when it came to their release the burden of proof was on the patients to prove they no longer needed to be detained. This "reverse burden of proof" breached the convention, the judges ruled.

A psychiatrist at Broadmoor told the tribunal that H was doing well on medication and might live in a specialised hostel. The majority of the clinical team on his ward favoured transfer to a medium secure unit. A second psychiatrist thought medium security was "unreasonably cautious". Both psychiatrists said H did not satisfy the conditions necessary for continued detention under the Mental Health Act.

But the tribunal concluded in December 1999 that H still exhibited symptoms of his illness (hearing voices), would not continue with his medication, and needed to be kept in hospital for his own safety.

A high court judge rejected H's application for judicial review of the tribunal's decision last September, and refused to hear arguments based on the Human Rights Act. But the appeal court granted permission in December for those points to be argued on appeal.

Lawyers for the health secretary, Alan Milburn, accepted that it would be incompatible with the human rights convention to put the burden of proof on the patient, but that the judges could interpret the Mental Health Act so as not to breach the convention.

The judges disagreed. They said the same test - whether it could be reliably shown that the patient suffered from a mental disorder serious enough to warrant detention - had to be applied to release as well as to the original detention. Since sections 72 and 73 did not require a tribunal to discharge a patient if this could not be shown, it was incompatible with the convention.

Lord Phillips said the circumstances of H's case were not uncommon. People in hospital with schizophrenia took their medication and went into remission; so long as they were treated they were no danger to themselves or others. But the professionals involved might be uncertain whether, if discharged into the community, patients would continue to take it their drugs.

Ms Scott-Moncrieff said she had up to 15 clients turned down in the past year who might now have grounds for release. H had another tribunal hearing pending, she said.

The Department of Health was refused permission to appeal to the Lords, but can still ask the lords to hear an appeal.

webTitle: Regular ecstasy users risking loss of memory

fields.headline: Regular ecstasy users risking loss of memory
fields.trailText: Regular users of the drug ecstasy are inflicting so much damage to their memory they frequently forget simple tasks and routinely lose their train of thought while talking, according to UK research.
fields.body:
Regular users of the drug ecstasy are inflicting so much damage to their memory they frequently forget simple tasks and routinely lose their train of thought while talking, according to UK research.

People who use the recreational drug regularly suffer significant impairment to all aspects of their everyday memory, finds the research, which will add to concerns over the worrying side effects of ecstasy. The drug is reported to be used by between 200,000 and 500,000 people in Britain, each weekend.

The research is among few studies of this subject, but previous work has revealed the detrimental effects the drug has on recall and working memory. This is the first time a danger to "prospective memory" - the planning centre of the brain which keeps most people's lives in order - has been revealed.

A team of psychologists, led by Tom Heffernan of the University of Northumbria, looked at how ecstasy use affected the memories of clubbers in the north-east. They found that people who took ecstasy regularly, between eight and 10 times a month, had significant memory problems; they would forget such things as setting their alarm clocks, and they had difficulty with long-term episodic memory, forgetting to pass on messages.

The drug users also had problems with internally "queued memory", failing to remember what they were saying half way through a sentence. "The research adds to the growing body of evidence which suggests there are psychological dangers associated with taking ecstasy. For example, people have found it can contribute to depression, that it can make users more irritable, and this study suggests it can impair your everyday memory," said Dr Heffernan.

The research, made public at the British Psychological Society's centenary conference in Glasgow yesterday, was carried out by comparing the memories of 40 adults, aged 23 on average, who took ecstasy regularly. Thirty-nine others were included who did not take the drug. Allowances were made for the tendency of ecstasy users to use more than one drug. The results were replicated in a second study by one of Dr Heffernan's students.

Dr Heffernan is not sure why ecstasy impairs the memory of regular users, but research in associated areas points to a biological explanation.

It is feared that regular use may cause damage to the frontal and pre-frontal cortex of the brain, which are used in planning and strategy.

If the explanation lies in biology, Dr Heffernan said, it could have particularly worrying consequences for young ecstasy users.

"There is some evidence that the frontal cortex is still developing in teenagers and adolescents," he said. "If your brain is still developing in parts, there is a strong possibility you could be seriously damaging this development with ecstasy use."

The researchers plan to expand their study to see if the damage to memory is permanent or whether the brain can be rehabilitated.

webTitle: Napster battle goes back to court

fields.headline: Napster battle goes back to court
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The legal fight between Napster and the music industry is to return to court next month, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
The legal fight between online song-swapping service Napster and the music industry is to return to court next month with both sides making increasingly acrimonious accusations.

In the latest round of the fight, the Recording Industry Association of America, which represents the leading record labels, has accused Napster of deliberately failing to comply with a court order to block access to copyrighted music.

Hilary Rosen, president of the association, said Napster was using outdated and ineffective technology to stop users downloading outlawed recordings. Tests by association members found that Napster was only stopping access to music if both the title and artist were searched for. So, for example, users could download Sting's Fields of Gold by searching for just the artist or the title of the song.

"Calling this type of filter effective is like calling an umbrella full of holes a hurricane shelter," said Ms Rosen. "It's not working, it never will work and Napster should be ordered to implement an effective filter or to change its filtering method."

The association, which filed its complaint three weeks after Napster was ordered to block access to copyrighted music, said there was a marked difference between the effectiveness of the company's technology for legal and illegal access.

"While Napster's filter works by blocking the precise artist and title, Napster's search engine intentionally finds and returns inexact matches."

After the latest court filing, Napster hit back by accusing the industry of acting in bad faith and failing to cooperate. Hank Barry, the company's chief executive, said Napster was "aggressively" complying with the injunction and had already blocked access to more than 275,000 songs and 1.6m unique file names.

"While we have gone forward to block this multitude of files, it is important to note that not a single record company has provided us with one variant of any song name," he said. "The RIAA's call for a fundamental change in Napster's technology is unsurprising. It is an attempt to change subject rather than cooperate with Napster as the injunction specifies."

He added that Napster had included more than 10,000 variations in artists' names and more than 40,000 variations in song titles in an attempt to block access. The number of files available through the Napster index has fallen by 57% from 370mto 160m. The average number of files being shared at the service has also dropped by almost two-thirds after the injunction on March 6.

The recording industry denied Napster's accusations and said that it had handed over details of 675,000 copyrighted works to be blocked. It called on the company either to use new fingerprint methodology to identify tracks or to use a "filter-in" service.

The latter would significantly change Napster's service as it would allow the company to offer only music it had certified as legal.

webTitle: Australia's patriotic painkiller taken to court

fields.headline: Australia's patriotic painkiller taken to court
fields.standfirst: Ads for Panadol replacement 'mislead public'
fields.trailText: GlaxoSmithKline will try to get an injunction today banning a TV campaign by a Brisbane-based company promoting its rival brand of painkillers. By Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
The global pharmaceutical giant GlaxoSmithKline will try to get an injunction today banning a television campaign by a Brisbane-based company promoting its rival brand of painkillers as Australian-owned.

The controversial but highly successful advert for Herron Pharmaceuticals has led some critics to brand patriotic marketing, which appeals to growing anti-globalisation sentiments in Australia, as "corporate racism".

Herron's campaign, first broadcast last month, claims that its brand of paracetamol tablets is identical to GlaxoSmithKline's market-leading product, Panadol, except that Herron is an Australian firm.

GlaxoSmithKline wants the federal court in Sydney to ban the advert, claiming that it misleads consumers into believing that Herron's products are made in Australia, when its Capseals brand is imported from the US.

GlaxoSmithKline has also launched legal action against Herron for allegedly flouting trade description laws.

Sales of Herron products have increased by 40% in the past year, while Panadol's market share has fallen by 8%.

GlaxoSmithKline blames its slump on Herron's nationalistic advertising campaign.

Euan Murdoch, founder and chief executive of Herron Pharmaceuticals, said that appealing to Australian patriotism has boosted his company's growth.

"The critical thing to survive in the global marketplace is to be able to differentiate yourself. We believe that our ownership is a differentiating factor. We're proud of it," Mr Murdoch said.

"This is a David and Goliath case," he said.

"It is also an attempt to use the litigious process to commercially frustrate private enterprise, and I think that's inappropriate."

The market for goods branded as Australian-made is booming, with the popular mood increasingly against globalisation and the foreign takeover of well-known Australian firms.

The Australian entrepreneur Dick Smith launched a range of Australian-made products last year, appealing to consumers' patriotism with the Australian flag spread across the products' labels and an aggressive marketing campaign against rival, foreign-owned brands.

Offering supermarkets Australian versions of popular foreign-owned brands, including Vegemite, Redhead matches and peanut butter, Mr Smith's company achieved a turnover of A$69m (£24m) in its first year. But like Herron, Mr Smith has caused controversy with some of his claims.

The Swedish owners of Redhead matches, for instance, have launched legal action to stop him marketing a parody of their brand, called Dickheads.

Pauline Hanson, the leader of the rightwing, anti-globalisation One Nation party, has called Mr Smith the best thing since sliced bread.

Not all Australians have been quick to denigrate foreign multinationals, though.

Dennis Shanahan, a commentator for the newspaper the Australian, said: "Among the thumping of the jingoistic tub, there is no mention of the following facts: foreign companies use Australian produce; foreign companies pay tax in Australia; foreign companies return profits to Australian shareholders; they provide jobs for millions of Australians."

Lee Jabara, spokesperson for Advantage Australia, a non-profit group which offers a loyalty reward scheme for consumers who buy Australian products, applauded Mr Smith for promoting Australian-made products, but he condemned the "churlish grandstanding" of many patriotic marketers.

"There are a lot of multinationals who are fantastic corporate citizens in this country but are vilified because they are foreign," Mr Jabara said. "I call it business racism."

fields.headline: Daniel Counihan
fields.standfirst: A familiar voice during radio's golden age, his dispatches for the BBC ranged from war reporting to coverage of royal visits
fields.trailText: Daniel Counihan, familiar to BBC listeners during the golden age of radio reporting from the 1940s to the 1970s, has died aged 83, writes Peter Clark.
fields.body:
The voice of Daniel Counihan, grave, mellifluous and authoritative, was familiar to BBC listeners during the golden age of radio reporting from the 1940s to the 1970s, when he worked for the BBC as a foreign correspondent and latterly as court correspondent. But Counihan, who has died aged 83, was a man of many talents and wide interests, who in his retirement from the BBC became editor of the Catholic Herald.

Born in north London, he went to school at St Ignatius' College. His father, a senior executive with London Transport, wanted him to have a "sensible" career, but Dan wanted to be an artist. He went to Hornsey Art School, paying his way by designing fireplaces for a company - a job he hated. During the second world war he was employed by the Ministry of Information and served with the army in Italy, rising to the rank of major. He was present at the Anzio landings and at the liberation of Rome. His last job was as head of the news division for Venezia-Giulia, based at Trieste. His tasks included the investigation of Axis atrocities and the editing of an army newspaper.

Such appropriate wartime experience led him to being recruited into the BBC as a foreign correspondent. For most of his broadcasting career, he was based in London with the title of diplomatic correspondent. He flew out to cover trouble spots and reported from all parts of the world. From the Congo and Vietnam, he sent despatches on atrocities that combined detachment with controlled passion. Three of his reports were published in the BBC's 1995 anthology, From Our Own Correspondent: the first 40 years.

He was the BBC's Moscow correspondent until expulsion as part of a diplomatic tit-for-tat in 1971. He then became first Commonwealth correspondent and lastly court correspondent. In the latter role he accompanied the Queen on overseas visits. His previous BBC assignments gave his reporting a width and a depth, and an appreciation of the Queen as head of the Commonwealth.

He had married, in 1939, Joan, the daughter of W Douglas Newton, the Catholic writer and journalist, who had also been a court correspondent, accompanying the then Prince of Wales on a tour of the US and Canada in the 1920s. A growing family - eight children in all - obliged Dan to supplement his income from the BBC with other jobs. He wrote regularly for John O'London's Weekly and The Tablet.

A lifelong interest was children's literature, and he reviewed children's books for the Times Literary Supplement. In spite of frequent absences, he cherished his home life, thought the world of his children and saw life through their eyes. One daughter recalls how, when a hamper of children's books arrived before Christmas, Dan would distribute these to his children and tell them to read them critically. He based his reviews on their insights.

He himself wrote a children's story, Unicorn Magic, published by Chatto and Windus in 1953. In this tale, children are able to step into an artist's canvas and become part of the world of the painter's imagination. Recent critics have seen this story of charm and magic as a precursor of the Harry Potter books. But he wrote also for adults. His Royal Progress was published to mark the Silver Jubilee in 1977.

Dan retired from the BBC in 1975 and was, in the early 1980s, editor of the Catholic Herald. By then, he was in his 60s and played a paternal role in encouraging and developing the talents of younger writers and journalists such as Christopher Howse, Jonathan Petre and Declan Donnellan. He brought a rigour and an experience to this paper, and strengthened its reporting of arts and literature. He also changed the colour of the paper's masthead to blue, the colour symbolising the Virgin Mary.

As a journalist, Dan Counihan combined a hard-nosed professionalism with a persuasive charm and a gentle humour. His writing was crafted, written to be heard as much as to be read - a consequence of his BBC career. His wide interests - political, artistic, literary - made him an amusing companion. With his deep rich voice he was a superb raconteur - even casual conversation sounded as if it was From Our Own Correspondent.

In retirement he continued to write a column, Charterhouse Chronicle, for the Catholic Herald, and to do work for the BBC World Service. He spent his last years enjoying his magnificent library of children's literature, of books on Italy and of 20th-century English literature.

He is survived by his wife and six of his eight children.

 Daniel John Patrick Counihan, journalist, born December 14 1917; died March 25 2001

fields.headline: Corley poised to take helm at GMTV
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Paul Corley, once one ITV's most powerful execs, could be set for a Lazurus-style return to the heart of commercial television, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Paul Corley, once one of the most powerful executives at ITV, could be set for a Lazurus-style return to the heart of commercial television.

It is understood Mr Corley is one of just two candidates shortlisted to take over as managing director of GMTV.

The other is David Bergg, the former ITV director of planning and Sky One general manager.

A decision on the appointment is expected from the GMTV board next week.

Sources say four candidates were interviewed last week - the other two who were seen were Carlton Central managing director Ian Squires and GMTV sales and marketing director Clive Crouch.

The job fell vacant following Christopher Stoddart's appointment as chief executive of the Channel 4/BSkyB/Arena Leisure horse racing broadcasting and gambling consortium, Go Racing.

The move could mark a remarkable return to a senior TV post for Mr Corley, who is currently on the board of the smallest ITV company, Channel TV, as well as working as a consultant.

He left his last job as Border TV chief executive in July last year after the ITV franchise was bought by Capital Radio.

Prior to his two-and-a-half year stint at Border, Mr Corley was controller of factual programming at the ITV Network Centre.

At the time ITV was lagging behind the BBC, which was wooing millions of viewers with the then innovative genre of docu-soaps.

Many blamed Mr Corley's network centre bosses at ITV for refusing to recognise that factual programming could be popular if planned and scheduled properly.

He quit the post at the end of 1997 after the then new ITV director of programmes David Liddiment restructured the Network Centre commissioning team.

Before joining the Network Centre Mr Corley was Carlton Television's controller of factual programmes for four years.

fields.headline: Muriel Young
fields.standfirst: Attending the wrong audition led to a career as a children's television presenter
fields.trailText: Muriel Young, who has died at the age of 72, was a children's television presenter in the early days of ITV, writes Philip Purser.
fields.body:
Muriel Young, who has died at the age of 72, was a children's television presenter in the early days of ITV as the lively Aunty Mu, who appeared with her disreputable owl accomplice, Ollie Beak.

Born in County Durham, and always keeping a hint of its accent, Muriel aspired originally to be an actress, and thanks to an uncle in the profession made a start in repertory at Henley-on-Thames, followed by roles at the little Gateway Theatre in London. Later, she had parts in two Sidney Gilliat movies of the early 1950s, The Story of Gilbert and Sullivan and The Constant Husband. Between whiles she worked as a photographer's model, tried her hand as a glass-painter, and even trained as a dental nurse, just in case.

It was in pursuit of her acting career that, in 1955, she applied to one of the pioneer commercial television contractors, Associated-Rediffusion, who had eight months in which to organise themselves, find studios, devise programmes and hire staff before the launch in September. By mistake, Muriel went along to an audition for announcers instead of the one for actors. She was hired on the spot, and was the announcer on opening night, when there weren't enough commercials to fill the commercial breaks and a good deal of improvisation was called for.

As ITV expanded into the regions, she worked as presenter and interviewer on Granada's People and Places in the north and Southern TV's Day by Day from Southampton; but it was in children's television for her original employers in London, Associated-Rediffusion, that she found her special niche. Under the relaxed leadership of its first head of children's TV, Peter Willes, a strand of light-hearted, inventive miscellany programmes evolved around the many talents of Wally Whyton, up till then a pop musician with the Vipers skiffle band.

It began in 1959 when Small Time, originally a midday programme for under-fives hosted by Susan Spear, was invited to spin off a five o'clock version which might also cater for an older and smarter audience. Muriel Young came in as presenter, Bert Weedon brought along his guitar and Whyton his love of folk music. Small Time already had an endearing glove-puppet character in Pussy Cat Willum, devised and animated by Janet Nicholls. Whyton, who had been to art school, created the truculent Scouse owl Ollie Beak and the dogged dog Fred Barker. Muriel did her best to keep order.

Under various titles - Lucky Dip, Tuesday Rendezvous, Five O'Clock Club, Ollie and Fred's Five O'Clock Club and Five O'Clock Funfair - the formula lasted until the re-allotment of ITV contracts in 1968, when Associated-Rediffusion was merged into Thames Television. Muriel Young, who in this period had also been a disc-jockey for Radio Luxembourg, was lured to Granada in an off-screen capacity, to head a new children's department.

She devised Clapperboard, a popular cinema programme for younger viewers, and a number of pop music series, including Lift Off (latterly Lift Off with Ayshea) and Get It Together. In the early 1980s, after leaving Granada, she made music programmes for Channel 4.

She had married, in 1954, Cyril Coke, a television drama director who also worked for Associated-Rediffusion, and in 1963 gave them a notable critical success with his own adaptation of Arthur Koestler's Darkness at Noon. He was still going strong in the 1980s with Malice Aforethought, Pride And Prejudice and other major serials, but in 1986 the couple decided to retire to Muriel's homeland and settled into an apartment in Stanhope Castle. She took up painting, and exhibited both locally and in London. Cyril Coke died in 1993. They had no children.

And with Wally Whyton's death four years ago, there can be few survivors from the great Five O'Clock days, unless it is the indestructible Ollie Beak, who once wrote to me after what he thought was a bad review and advised me not to walk down Fleet Street bare-headed.

Iris Warne writes: In 1943, Muriel Young was among many young women who joined the ATS and were trained to be special wireless operators. She was posted to Shenley in Hertfordshire after training and became a member of A-Watch. We all worked shifts, taking all the Morse messages sent by SS units in Europe for subsequent decoding at Bletchley.

After the war, we members of hut 15 kept close contact: Mu visited my flat and we visited her in Covent Garden, where she lived with her husband, Cyril Coke.

She was always pretty, cheerful and good-natured and is fondly remembered by all of us. Mu took her first steps to show business in Shenley, close to the Elstree Studios and subsequently joined ENSA when our operating days were over. We followed her career with interest and mourn her passing.

 Muriel Young, television presenter and producer, born June 19 1928; died March 24 2001

webTitle: Take risks with drama to stop flops, film-maker tells BBC

fields.headline: Take risks with drama to stop flops, film-maker tells BBC
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The film-maker Stephen Poliakoff yesterday blamed the crisis in BBC drama on "recycled ideas" and an overreliance on focus groups. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The film-maker Stephen Poliakoff yesterday blamed the crisis in BBC drama on "recycled ideas" and an overreliance on focus groups.

Poliakoff said BBC drama chiefs were not taking enough risks, and claimed that many top actors were effectively barred from BBC1 because they were not on the "list" of names regarded as bankers. "If you become more predictable than the audience then you are in real trouble," he said at the launch of BBC2's new programme season.

BBC1 has suffered from a succession of Sunday night drama failures. Executives are rethinking the whole policy of scheduling big-budget drama on that night, when ITV shows like Heartbeat and London's Burning are dominant.

The controller of BBC1, Lorraine Heggessey, said this week that landmark factual programming - such as Robert Winston's Superhuman and the John Cleese series The Human Face - had worked well on Sunday nights.

Drama had not fared so well: the adaptation of Kingsley Amis's Take a Girl Like You, Ronan Bennett's Rebel Heart, the dramatisation of Nancy Mitford's Love in a Cold Climate, and, most recently, Paul Abbott's original series Best of Both Worlds were all received poorly by critics and viewers.

The concern was such that Clocking Off, the acclaimed series starring Ricky Tomlinson and also written by Abbott, has been moved out of its usual Sunday night home to Mondays, scheduled against Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

ITV executives believe that the BBC has panicked. Recently Nick Elliott, the commercial network's drama controller, said: "What they ought to do is have the courage of their convictions and go ahead with good Sunday night stuff like Clocking Off."

Poliakoff, who is following his award-winning BBC2 series Shooting the Past with Perfect Strangers, another ambitious drama for the channel this summer, said the BBC had to think seriously about taking more risks.

"Irish history has never been big box office in Britain," he said, referring to Rebel Heart, which dramatised the Easter uprising of 1916. "And the same goes for Nancy Mitford. These were quite remote. I firmly believe that original drama, as Clocking Off has shown, has to be fresh.

"The way forward for all the main channels is to take a punt on something that they are really excited about. When you recycle old ideas, it's not surprising when some of these don't work. Things like Mitford have been done before."

BBC in particular had been too reliant on focus groups - "obsessed" with them on BBC1. "Trying to second-guess the audience is wrong," Poliakoff said. "I heard recently that ITV do hardly any focus groups, and they are the main commercial channel. It has led the BBC into a rivulet, trying to work out what is going to be popular."

He criticised the BBC's reliance upon a number of big-name actors - he did not name them, but BBC favourites include Nick Berry, Stephen Tomkinson and Amanda Burton. "Some of the finest actors in Britain are not seen on BBC1 because they are not seen as 'BBC1 actors'," he said.

Mark Thompson, the BBC's director of television, praised Poliakoff's new BBC2 series, Perfect Strangers, as "one of the finest television dramas" commissioned by the corporation, and said the channel would continue to programme ambitious drama projects.

Spring season

 Drama

Stephen Poliakoff's series Perfect Strangers is the centrepiece of BBC2's spring and summer season, starring Matthew MacFadyen, Lindsay Duncan, Michael Gambon and Timothy Spall in a tale of an only child's discovery of his unknown extended family.

Two films from Trainspotting director Danny Boyle - Strumpet and Vacuuming Completely Nude in Paradise - will also get TV premieres on BBC2.

The channel has bought a hit US show, Malcolm in the Middle, a comedy of family life seen through the eyes of a boy.

 Leisure

The Chelsea Flower Show comes back to BBC2 after three years on Channel 4, fronted by Alan Titchmarsh, who announced yesterday he was quitting the BBC1 series Ground Force. Another garden show presenter, Diarmud Gavin, will front Planet Patio, a series on patio improvement.

Masterchef, formerly presented by Lloyd Grossman on BBC1, transfers to BBC2 with Gary Rhodes as presenter.

 Entertainment

The 11 O'Clock Show's Ricky Gervais stars in a comedy series The Office, set in a struggling Slough paper merchant's firm.

Velvet Soup, a comedy sketch series from BBC Scotland, gets a full run after a pilot last year.

A potential cult series is God, the Devil and Bob, an animation series axed in the US after being seen as too controversial. God decides to destroy the world, but allows the Devil (Alan Cumming) to choose a man who could save it - the task falls to Bob, a porn-loving factory worker.

 Factual

In Ancient Apocalypse, computer graphics are used to recreate civilisations cut down by natural forces, including Egypt and the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. There will be a documentary on the life of Versace.

Art That Shook the World will examine works such as James Joyce's Ulysses and the Psalms of David.

Drama had not fared so well: the adaptation of Kingsley Amis's Take a Girl Like You, Ronan Bennett's Rebel Heart, the dramatisation of Nancy Mitford's Love in a Cold Climate, and, most recently, Paul Abbott's original series Best of Both Worlds were all received poorly by critics and viewers. The concern was such that Clocking Off, the acclaimed series starring Ricky Tomlinson and also written by Abbott, has been moved out of its usual Sunday night home to Mondays, scheduled against Who Wants to be a Millionaire? ITV executives believe that the BBC has panicked. Recently Nick Elliott, the commercial network's drama controller, said: "What they ought to do is have the courage of their convictions and go ahead with good Sunday night stuff like Clocking Off." Poliakoff, who is following his award-winning BBC2 series Shooting the Past with Perfect Strangers, another ambitious drama for the channel this summer, said the BBC had to think seriously about taking more risks. "Irish history has never been big box office in Britain," he said, referring to Rebel Heart, which dramatised the Easter uprising of 1916. "And the same goes for Nancy Mitford. These were quite remote. I firmly believe that original drama, as Clocking Off has shown, has to be fresh. "The way forward for all the main channels is to take a punt on something that they are really excited about. When you recycle old ideas, it's not surprising when some of these don't work. "I heard recently that ITV do hardly any focus groups, and they are the main commercial channel. It has led the BBC into a rivulet, trying to work out what is going to be popular." He criticised the BBC's reliance upon a number of big-name actors - he did not name them, but BBC favourites include Nick Berry, Stephen Tomkinson and Amanda Burton. "Some of the finest actors in Britain are not seen on BBC1 because they are not seen as 'BBC1 actors'," he said. Mark Thompson, the BBC's director of television, praised Poliakoff's new BBC2 series, Perfect Strangers, as "one of the finest television dramas" commissioned by the corporation, and said the channel would continue to programme ambitious drama projects. Spring season  Drama Stephen Poliakoff's series Perfect Strangers is the centrepiece of BBC2's spring and summer season, starring Matthew MacFadyen, Lindsay Duncan, Michael Gambon and Timothy Spall in a tale of an only child's discovery of his unknown extended family. Two films from Trainspotting director Danny Boyle - Strumpet and Vacuuming Completely Nude in Paradise - will also get TV premieres on BBC2. The channel has bought a hit US show, Malcolm in the Middle, a comedy of family life seen through the eyes of a boy.  Leisure The Chelsea Flower Show comes back to BBC2 after three years on Channel 4, fronted by Alan Titchmarsh, who announced yesterday he was quitting the BBC1 series Ground Force. Another garden show presenter, Diarmud Gavin, will front Planet Patio, a series on patio improvement. Masterchef, formerly presented by Lloyd Grossman on BBC1, transfers to BBC2 with Gary Rhodes as presenter.  Entertainment The 11 O'Clock Show's Ricky Gervais stars in a comedy series The Office, set in a struggling Slough paper merchant's firm. Velvet Soup, a comedy sketch series from BBC Scotland, gets a full run after a pilot last year. A potential cult series is God, the Devil and Bob, an animation series axed in the US after being seen as too controversial. God decides to destroy the world, but allows the Devil (Alan Cumming) to choose a man who could save it - the task falls to Bob, a porn-loving factory worker.  Factual In Ancient Apocalypse, computer graphics are used to recreate civilisations cut down by natural forces, including Egypt and the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah. There will be a documentary on the life of Versace. Art That Shook the World will examine works such as James Joyce's Ulysses and the Psalms of David.

webTitle: TV Corp seals £10m three-year Sky deal

fields.headline: TV Corp seals £10m three-year Sky deal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Television Corporation, the sport and entertainment production business, has secured a three-year contract to provide facilities for Sky Sports' live football broadcasts. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Television Corporation, the sport and entertainment production business, has secured a three-year contract to provide facilities for Sky Sports' live football broadcasts.

The £10m contract, which runs from the start of next season, more than makes up for the loss of the outside broadcast work for the Nationwide League which will move to ITV and ONdigital from August.

TV Corp subsidiary, Visions, will be employed on more than 100 live matches a year from the Premiership, FA Cup and England home internationals. It will supply facilities including trucks, cameras and production areas. The company snatched the contract from the production business of Carlton Communications.

Chris Rowlands, TV Corp chief executive, described the deal as "the best contract in football" and said the growth in multi-channel TV was playing into the company's hands. TV Corp already supplies hardware for the transmission of Scottish matches on Sky Sports.

Shares in the business climbed 4p to 418p.

TV Corp also produces programmes including Channel 4's highly regarded cricket coverage and recently paid £15m for Offshore Sport Promotions, the powerboat race promoter. It aims to develop the sport into a TV sporting event along the lines of formula one.

Last year, TV Corp took full control of Mentorn, the company which produces Robot Wars, Star for a Night, which drew big audiences in prime time for BBC1, and factual programmes including Question Time. The aim is to move the group up the value chain by investing in content as well as production services. About two-thirds of the company's revenues are now from content generation, up from one-third two years ago.

Its post-production studios have worked on ITV's police drama, The Bill, and the hit comedy series, The Royle Family.

The next season of the Premiership will be the first in the three-year agreement BSkyB signed last summer for continued live coverage of the competition. The company is paying a record breaking £1.1bn for the rights.

 Simply Money, the digital television channel broadcasting 24 hours of news and features about personal finance is to close. The channel, which is fronted by former newsreader Angela Rippon has been on air for little more than a year. Around 50 staff are expected to lose their jobs.

The channel's owner, Invest TV, will join the growing number broadcasting TV shopping channels with the introduction of Simply Shopping.

webTitle: Blair clears way for May 3 poll

fields.headline: Blair clears way for May 3 poll
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday paved the way for a general election on May 3 by agreeing to start a vaccination programme of 200,000 cattle as early as this week and by demanding that local councils reopen swaths of the countryside closed at the start of the foot and mouth epidemic.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Michael White  and Paul Brown
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday paved the way for a general election on May 3 by agreeing to start a vaccination programme of 200,000 cattle as early as this week and by demanding that local councils reopen swaths of the countryside closed at the start of the foot and mouth epidemic.

Mr Blair, determined to give the impression that the government will soon have the crisis under control, hopes to see more than 700,000 animals slaughtered by the weekend, with 50 burial sites identified.

Labour MPs expect him to go to Buckingham Palace next week after officials told them at a private meeting that the party's polling showed it had a 16-point lead over the Tories. Labour's poll, taken at the weekend, showed it ahead on every policy except immigration and asylum. The party's already rock-solid lead on economic competence had risen.

Election strategists who met in Downing Street yesterday believe that Mr Blair will face charges of insensitivity for the first two or three days of the campaign, but can ride out the charge.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, also gave the first public clue of how Labour will simultaneously fight an election and the spread of foot and mouth. He told MPs the 26-strong rural task force would continue to meet during the election and promised that any largesse to farmers would "not be done in a political way".

The main block to the election juggernaut was advice from some senior Labour MPs that William Hague now privately favours a May 3 election in the belief that the crisis has knocked the sheen off Mr Blair.

Despite the Tories' formal opposition to a May 3 poll, shadow cabinet members now believe that it provides the best chance to trim Labour's Commons majority to well below 100. One Tory MP said: "At last we've got an issue to hang our hat on: competence and opportunism."

The move to inoculate cattle, inititally in Devon and Cumbria, is expected to be announced today.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, who has in effect been sidelined by the prime minister this week, last night met the National Farmers Union leader, Ben Gill, to tell him that the vaccination programme must go ahead. Government sources said farmers' leaders increasingly recognised there was now no alternative to what was once described as the last resort.

A European Union veterinary surgeons' meeting in Brussels yesterday gave approval for the vaccinations to start. No fresh domestic legislation is required. Adequate supplies of vaccination are said already to be available in Britain. Once vaccinated the cattle will eventually be slaughtered, but the move buys ministers time and helps create firebreaks.

General Sir Mike Jackson, commander of British land forces and a Kosovo war veteran, personally oversaw the start of the mass slaughter in Cumbria. The animals were being buried in a mass grave. But the backlog of sheep waiting to be slaughtered in the county had risen to 140,000, leaving the government far off its target of reducing the wait from identification to slaughter to 24 hours. A total of 41 new cases were announced yesterday, taking the total nationwide to at least 716.

The Ministry of Agriculture has now authorised 764,319 animals for slaughter, including 552,550 sheep. So far 481,909 of the total have been slaughtered with 282,410 animals still be culled.

The prime minister admitted that it could not be said with certainty when the disease would end. Pressed by Mr Hague in the Commons, he conceded: "When you say how can we be sure when the disease is going to end, the answer is we cannot be sure at the present time."

In an attempt to reopen the countryside and save the ravaged rural tourist industry, ministers yesterday agreed revised guidelines for the opening of footpaths. Organisations such as the National Trust were pressed to reopen.

webTitle: Highest paid woman in Britain quits the City

fields.headline: City legend goes with a fortune: will she return?
fields.standfirst:
Carol Galley to exchange boardroom battles for a 'more balanced life'

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Carol Galley, the highest paid woman in Britain who built a £400bn investment empire controlling a large chunk of the London stockmarket, is quitting the City.
fields.body:
Carol Galley, the highest paid woman in Britain who built a £400bn investment empire controlling a large chunk of the London stockmarket, is quitting the City. She announced her departure yesterday. Her payoff is rumoured to run into tens of millions of pounds.

Ms Galley became a legend among City power brokers after delivering the Forte hotel group and London Weekend Television to Granada in some of the most fiercely fought takeovers the square mile has seen.

Her last officially reported earnings were £16m in 1997, when she had £6m in salary and £10m in shares at the time the company she controlled, Mercury Asset Management, was sold to the New York-based investment giant Merrill Lynch for £3.1bn. Since then her remuneration has not been revealed, but some estimates run as high as £20m a year.

She refused yesterday to disclose her final payoff when she leaves Merrill Lynch in December, but said that share options would make up a "significant element". These were awarded at the time of the Merrill Lynch takeover and are believed to run into millions of pounds.

But she denied that her departure was linked to the chance to cash in on options. "I have been free to retire from Merrill Lynch for the past 12 months. This is not a story about money and not a story about leaving just because the handcuffs are off. It was a personal decision first and foremost.

"I have had a huge amount of enjoyment and fulfilment being with Mercury and Merrill Lynch and feel the time is right now to retire. It has been my life for the last 30 years and the business has absorbed 100% of my time. I've not really been able to think about anything else," she said yesterday.

A ruthless guardian of her privacy, Ms Galley has no entry in Who's Who and lives in low-profile luxury in a flat in Eaton Square. Her husband Reinhard Winkler, a German stockbroker, collected £2m from the sale of his business last year. The two regularly spend weekends at their second home in the south of France.

But her departure immediately sparked speculation in the City that, aged just 52, she may return either by joining a rival City operation or by setting up her own boutique firm. Her former high-flying colleague, Nicola Horlick, set up a new operation after quitting Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, but Ms Galley insisted yesterday that she would never compete against her old firm. Even after her departure she will continue to hold a significant number of share options in Merrill Lynch which she will lose if she goes head-to-head against the company.

She also insisted that the decision to leave is not due to burn-out, and at Merrill Lynch yesterday there were few signs of a boardroom battle. "It has been a very demanding role and I am looking forward to having a more balanced lifestyle. I wanted to depart in an elegant way," she said.

Unlike Nicola Horlick, who was happy to use the press in her battle with her former employer, Ms Galley has consistently refused to give interviews, and until four years ago there was only one photograph of her available for publication. Her remoteness earned her the tag "ice maiden", but it is not a description her colleagues recognise today.

At one point she had a fearsome reputation for silent control over colleagues; it was not uncommon for her to break into meetings unannounced, spread the Financial Times over the table and read it while the meeting continued, then leave as suddenly as she appeared.

At Mercury's doughnut-shaped offices on the corner of London Bridge, something like a Mexican wave would follow her as staff - most earning well above £100,000 a year - almost stood to attention as she passed.

But people meeting her today find a mellower, charming figure; much of the remoteness apparently stemmed from shyness about making public presentations and speeches.

Edward Bonham Carter, brother of actress Helena and chief executive of a rival investment management company, Jupiter, said yesterday that Ms Galley was best known as a deal maker who worked behind closed doors.

"She has never been the extrovert and she was very much behind the scenes. She created a highly successful business and I guess she now wants to enjoy her time more. Since Concorde went down it has been very knackering for chief executives to fly back and forth across the Atlantic."The silver spoon tag does not apply. Raised in Newcastle, Carol Galley went to Gosforth Grammar School and read modern languages at Leicester university before joining Mercury Asset Management, then part of merchant bank Warburg, as a librarian.

Her golden period was in the 1980s through to the mid-1990s, when Mercury grabbed deal after deal to manage billions of pounds in pension fund money, testament to its investment performance.

The firm's returns temporarily fell back in the late 1990s, and because of this Unilever began legal action against it in 1999. At the time it was said that the action was also due to irritation at the multi-million pound pay packets awarded to Ms Galley and other Mercury staff.

Others see her departure as a sign of waning London influence in the money markets.

One senior investment consultant who advises big pension funds on Merrill Lynch said: "The fact is that Merrill Lynch is a global operator and that has to mean that its investment management arm will have less and less of a focus on the UK. Carol Galley going cements the takeover by the Americans and draws a line under the Mercury days."

Also announcing his departure yesterday was Stephen Zimmerman, joint chief operating officer at Merrill Lynch, who has worked alongside Ms Galley for the past 30 years.

Few in the City believe he will be spending much time gardening. "I'm going to take some time off and then I'll see how I feel," he said.

Deals that struck gold

 Galley first hit the headlines in 1994 during Granada's hostile £750m takeover bid for the London TV station LWT, when she was at Mercury Asset Management. She gained a reputation as one of a handful of investment experts whose judgments decide the fate of companies.

Despite the fact that LWT was one of Mercury's best performing investments, Galley controversially decided to hand control of the company to Granada's Gerry Robinson. Her actions led Greg Dyke, then chief executive of LWT and now director general of the BBC, to issue a harsh warning about the behaviour of investors.

In 1999 Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the BBC and another former LWT man, couldn't resist having a go at Galley. Asked by Management Today whether she was a close personal friend, Bland replied: "She is neither close, nor personal, nor a friend."

 As head of investment at Mercury in 1996, she played a key part in delivering control of the Forte hotel group to Granada when she voted Mercury's 14% stake in Forte in favour of Granada, enabling the media group to succeed in its takeover bid.

Control of what was Britain's leading hotel group had been hanging by a thread because Mercury owned around 14% of Granada as well. By steadily acquiring shares in both companies she succeeded in keeping everyone guessing until the last minute.

 Galley made around £10m when Mercury was taken over by the American investment bank Merrill Lynch in a £3.1bn deal in 1997. That was how much she collected for her shares, and was in addition to her earnings that year of around £5.5m.

Rupert Jones

In 1999 Sir Christopher Bland, chairman of the BBC and another former LWT man, couldn't resist having a go at Galley. Asked by Management Today whether she was a close personal friend, Bland replied: "She is neither close, nor personal, nor a friend."  As head of investment at Mercury in 1996, she played a key part in delivering control of the Forte hotel group to Granada when she voted Mercury's 14% stake in Forte in favour of Granada, enabling the media group to succeed in its takeover bid. Control of what was Britain's leading hotel group had been hanging by a thread because Mercury owned around 14% of Granada as well. By steadily acquiring shares in both companies she succeeded in keeping everyone guessing until the last minute.  Galley made around £10m when Mercury was taken over by the American investment bank Merrill Lynch in a £3.1bn deal in 1997. That was how much she collected for her shares, and was in addition to her earnings that year of around £5.5m. Rupert Jones

fields.headline: Mutual Friend pair team up for BBC1's Revenge
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The writer and producer team behind Our Mutual Friend are reuniting to make a two-parter for BBC1.
fields.body:
Producer Catherine Wearing and writer Sandy Welch, the pair behind the most critically acclaimed BBC drama of recent years, Our Mutual Friend, are reuniting to make a two-parter for BBC1.

Called Sweet Revenge, the bittersweet fantasy will centre on a fictional school for revenge in London.

Filming is due to begin in April and transmission is likely to be in the sought-after autumn/winter season line-up.

Casting has not yet begun, although actress Sarah Smart, who played the lesbian Virginia in ITV show At Home with the Braithwaites, said she had been given a role in the show.

"I'm a mousy student who is very downtrodden," she said of her role.

However, the BBC has confirmed that actor David Morrissey will make his large-scale directing debut with the project.

Morrissey was also one of the stars of Our Mutual Friend, playing the jealous schoolteacher Bradley Headstone.

The Charles Dickens adaptation won a string of top awards including the Royal Television Society, Bafta nd Broadcasting Press Guild prizes for best drama.

In addition, BBC2 has commissioned Tony GarnettÕs company World Productions to make Table 12, a series of films centred around restaurant conversations.

Four new writers and five young directors are involved in the project alongside established acting talent.

Performers include Daniela Nardini, Phyllida Law, Paul Nicholls and Gwen Taylor.

The commission follows the success of a similar format of dramas from World, the Black Cab 10-parter.

webTitle: Ford launches eco-series on satellite TV

fields.headline: Ford launches eco-series on satellite TV
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Ford is hoping to win over eco-warriors by launching a TV series about environmental issues, writes Julia Day.

Mar 20: Friends of the Earth joins Ford for traffic initiative
Mar 28: Sir Martin Sorrell's online interview
fields.body:
Ford is hoping to win over eco-warriors the world over by launching a TV series about environmental issues.

The move comes as Sir Martin Sorrell, chief executive of Ford's advertising agency WPP, warned that everyone should take the anti-consumerist movement seriously.

At the beginning of this year Ford teamed up with the National Geographic Society to launch a public awareness campaign called Earthpulse, focusing on conservation issues.

Now the partners are launching a 26-episode, half-hour TV series called Earthpulse to explore the ideas of people Ford calls "environmental heroes" in 20 countries around the world.

Earthpulse will be broadcast on the satellite service National Geographic Channel from April 9.

"Environmental responsibility is a key component of Ford's strategy in becoming a leading consumer-focused company," said Jacques Nasser, president and chief executive of Ford.

"At Ford we are fortunate to be in a position to lead the way in global environmental awareness and conservation."

The company's advertising is handled by WPP, which has also expressed the need to take heed of the environmentalists.

Asked about the anti-consumerist movement in Naomi Klein's book No Logo, Sir Martin Sorrell was clear.

"I have not read the book but believe the movement is a serious and important one, not a passing fad, and one that our clients have to take notice of.

"They will ignore it at their peril - the same is true of other movements of a similar nature," he told MediaGuardian.co.uk in an online interview yesterday.

Earlier this month the car manufacturer joined forces with Friends of the Earth to launch a fleet of electric cars in London as part of a sustainable motoring project.

Related stories

Mar 28: Sir Martin Sorrell's online interview

fields.headline: Nestle joins Emap for cross-media promotion
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Nestle is targeting music-loving teenagers with an extensive cross-media deal with Emap to promote Smarties, writes Julia Day.

Mar 27: Nestle blasts 'inflated' TV prices

Mar 13: KitKat games on mobile phones
fields.body:
Nestle's move away from TV advertising is set to continue as the food giant plans an extensive cross-media deal with Emap to promote Smarties to music-loving teenagers.

The company is in negotiations with the media owner to promote Smarties through Smash Hits magazine, the Smash Hits programme on The Box TV channel and on its Big City radio network.

Nestle is currently piloting advertising over mobile phones and has launched Kit Kat interactive games for mobile phones in Germany.

Nestle UK marketing director Andrew Harrison said the company will continue to explore new advertising channels for its 28 brands.

Mr Harrison has called on the TV industry to lower its prices and also offer innovative cross-media deals with their own assets or in joint venture agreements, or risk brands pulling out of TV altogether.

"Some smaller brands can't afford TV and bigger brands now have more options than TV alone," said Mr Harrison.

Related stories

Mar 27: Nestle blasts 'inflated' TV prices

Mar 13: KitKat games on mobile phones

fields.headline: Ask Jack
fields.standfirst: Send your questions and comments to Jack.Schofield@guardian.co.uk. Published letters will be edited for brevity but please include full details with your original query
fields.trailText: Dis contents | Word hunter
fields.body:
Dis contents
I can't get onto the web with Windows 98 because there seems to be a bug in Internet Explorer's Content Advisor. Every time I reboot I get an error message saying that information is missing, but when I change the settings, they default to zero, barring me from almost every website. This happens even when I disable the settings. Douglas Rome
douglas@rome47.freeserve.co.uk

Jack Schofield replies: Computer error messages are sometimes worse than useless. In this case, Microsoft almost admits as much. The Knowledge Base article http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/articles/Q242/0/37.asp for Internet Explorer 5 says: "If you follow the instructions in the error message, you may not be able to disable Content Advisor, or the changes may appear to work but do not work when you restart the computer".

Microsoft's solution is to delete a file called Ratings.pol in the Windows directory (see http://support.microsoft.com/support/kb/articles/Q154/9/99.asp.

I think it is better to disable Content Advisor altogether. Microsoft does not explain how - well, you might be a child researching satanic gynaecology. However, the information is widely available. Unfortunately it means editing the Registry, so it is a good idea to back it up first.

To disable Content Advisor in IE5, go to Start|Run, type regedit and press OK. Find the entry for H_KEY_ LOCAL_MACHINE and press the little plus sign to its left. Keep going down the tree until you get to HKEY_ LOCAL_MACHINE|Software|Microsoft|Windows| Current Version|Policies and click on Ratings. In the right hand pane, look for an icon called Key. Highlight that then press the delete key to delete the Content Advisor password.

Go to Registry (on the menu bar) and select Exit.

Restart your PC, and delete the Ratings.pol file.

Run Internet Explorer, select Tools|Internet Options (or View|Options, in earlier versions), and click the tab marked Content. The button for Content Advisor should say Enable, which is what you want. If it says Disable, click on it. If asked for a password, do not enter one: just press OK.

Word hunter
I want to research words in English so I thought a spell-checking dictionary would provide me with a plain list of words. However, looking into a dictionary file, it is obviously all coded. Any suggestions? I would also like a list of all English/ British place names. Brian Russ
bjruss@beeb.net

JS: Have a look at Kevin's Word Lists Page http://wordlist.sourceforge.net and Bryson's Wordlists http://www.bryson.demon.co.uk/wordlist.html. The latter includes the UK Advanced Cryptics Dictionary, aimed at crossword puzzle solvers, the Enhanced North American Benchmark Lexicon (Enable), for Scrabble players, and word lists for Shakespeare and the King James Bible.

You could also try the Online Plain Text English Dictionary, known as Opted. It has one line definitions with minimal mark-up added.

The Association of British Counties has a Gazetteer of British Placenames, but it would be hard to extract a list. Try searching from the Open Directory at http://dmoz.org/Science/Social_ Sciences/Geography/Place_ Names/ or the place name guide at www.asu.edu/lib/hayden/govdocs/maps/geogname.htm.

Time tracker
Is there some software that will keep a log of how long you have been online, preferably with a calculation of the costs of that call? Roy Pennington
Roypen@btinternet.com

JS: There are dozens for Windows: Dave Central has seven pages of them. JoJo Software's NetTimer 2000 looks useful and has nice graphs, while Rat Software's Internet Timer v4.5 is well regarded. Both are available in trial versions. However, TimeUP v4.5 will probably do what you want, and it is free.

Mac users could try PPPremier Timer 2.0.4.

Filling in
Is there any way of programming keys in Windows 98 and/or Internet Explorer 5 so that one or two keystrokes insert a short line of text? For instance, could you program a key to put the first line of your address into an address box on an online form? Steve Morris
steven@morriss54.fsnet.co.uk

JS: Internet Explorer is supposed to do this for you. Go to Tools|Internet Options and click the tab for Content, then press the AutoComplete button. Put a tick in the box to select AutoComplete for Forms. It is not perfect but it is fairly painless.

Naming parts
Can you tell me why Windows Explorer displays file and folder names in a variety of formats, eg upper case, lower case, sentence case? Is it possible to make the names look the same? Bob Hawkes
postmaster@hawkesfamily.demon.co.uk

JS: Not as far as I know. The problems arise from the fact that, in 1981, the Microsoft Disk Operating System (MS-DOS) had eight character file names (actually 8.3) that were assumed to be all in capital letters. Long file names were added with difficulty in 1995. For maximum control over the appearance of folder names, either make them longer than eight characters or include a space. It is still a good idea to make the first six non-space characters of file names unique. For backwards compatibility, the operating system uses these to generate short (8.3) names from the long ones.

Clean desking
When I load software, the set-up icons remain on my desktop. I have tried deleting them but the message "if this is deleted you may no longer be able to run the program" appears. Any suggestions, as they clutter my desktop up? David Miles
david.miles@djmiles.freeserve.co.uk

JS: If the software runs from the Start|Programs menu then you can throw any unwanted non-Microsoft icons into the Recycle Bin. That includes program icons. However, it is best not to save files on the desktop in the first place. The File Save dialogue box lets you choose where to put them. Create a new directory called Downloads and use that instead.

Hotmail spam
I was interested to read the piece about email using the web. However, I've found that with all the Hotmail accounts I've had, the addresses very quickly find themselves on spam address lists and they fill up with all sorts of rubbish. Why is this? Is the system's security that poor? Elliot Herman
elliot@n15.org

JS: When you sign up to Hotmail, the form you fill in has a section for Services which includes Hotmail Member Directory and Internet White Pages. Both are ticked by default. If you don't notice and untick them, you may well get lots of spam (junk email). This applies to some other services, too.

Since you are too cagey to fall for that one, I am at a loss for an explanation. However, I have opened a fresh, unlisted and unused Hotmail account and am waiting for the spam to turn up.
