webTitle: If this woman phones you be sure to answer - politely

fields.headline: If this woman phones you be sure to answer - politely
fields.standfirst: Headhunters make a killing as search for top corporate talent becomes more intense
fields.trailText: Headhunters make a killing as search for top corporate talent becomes more intense.
fields.body:
Miles Broadbent does not make many telephone calls. So when you receive one from him you know you are wanted. Mr Broadbent, 64-year-old chairman of the Miles Partnership, is the doyen of headhunters, discreetly searching out the most promising executive talent for Britain's top companies, and reaping handsome fees in return.

Over the past 20 years he has recruited more than 80 chief executives.

Notable successes include putting David Jones and Sir Brian Pitman into retailer Next as chief executive and chairman respectively. He plucked a relatively unknown Colin Marshall out of Avis and sent him to the top of British Airways, and to a peerage. He later found Sir Richard Sykes for Glaxo Wellcome and Sir Clive Thompson for Rentokil. "I suppose you could say I've had some decent hits," Mr Broadbent says.

As a business, corporate recruitment - and headhunting in particular - is booming. Executive salaries are higher than ever before, job markets are increasingly fluid, non-executive directors are nervous about appointing the wrong person and shareholders are becoming more intolerant of under-performing bosses.

These factors are contributing to a growing volume of lucrative business for recruitment firms.

Biggest new issue

In Britain there are estimated to be 2,500 executive recruitment consultancies and 150 headhunting firms. Investment bank CSFB reckons their combined turnover in 1999 was £18.4bn and that the sector is growing at 25% a year.

Yesterday's flotation of recruitment firm Michael Page, although at a lower price than was expected due to the turbulence of the stock markets, was still the biggest new issue of the year.

This morning the industry's movers and shakers will gather in Le Meridien Hotel in London for a conference on the future of executive recruitment, organised by the magazine Executive Grapevine.

In attendance will be senior figures from Allied Domecq, the BBC, Arthur Andersen, Imperial Tobacco, Tesco and Reuters. They know as well as anyone that the real talent does not flick to the situations vacant pages or pop down to the jobcentre.

Those that really matter do not apply for jobs, they wait for the flattering phone call from the likes of Mr Broadbent who will promise to smooth any appointment with the utmost discretion and minimal fuss.

Keeping in with these aristocrats of recruitment is important if you want to able to tell shareholders that you made the maximum effort to hire the very best to run their company.

The headhunting market is dominated by a small number of supremely well connected firms with networks extending across the world. When Saxon Bampfylde was asked by media group Pearson to find it a new chief executive, the headhunter eventually plumped for a relatively unknown American, Marjorie Scardino.

When it was commissioned to find a new chief executive for Sunderland football club it ferreted out Hugh Roberts from the Suffolk-based brewer Adnams after a nine-month search.

Mr Broadbent says the key to becoming a successful headhunter is maintaining good contacts and a strong reputation for finding successful recruits. "It's all about people. The name over the door to this business may have changed three times but the clients are the same."

A regular at the Ritz, Mr Broadbent says he tries to have lunch with every chief executive that he has placed at least once each year and that many of his commissions are referrals from firms where he has previously placed staff.

"You are pretty much dependent on the performance of the bloke or bloke-ess that you find. If they do well the firm will use you again, if you get a failure you don't tend to get invited back."

The only place he advertises is in Royal Opera House programmes. "It's pretty much our target audience."

Michael Byrne, chief operating officer at The Rose Partnership which specialises in finding staff for investment banks, says: "The secret is absolute closeness to your client and understanding better than them what they want, the type of person they need. We'll spend days inside a bank learning absolutely everything about it before we go recruiting on its behalf."

The fee headhunters typically charge for each person placed is usually equivalent to a third of the individual's first-year salary. It is not uncommon for the bill for finding a top chief executive to top £500,000.

An increasing number of big companies are bemoaning the fees and some complain about the quality of service they get.

Spencer Stuart, the recruitment agency where shadow chancellor Michael Portillo's wife, Carolyn Eadie, is one of the senior executives, is reported to have billed Barclays £500,000 for finding the bank a successor to chief executive Martin Taylor.

The problem was that the man they found, former US marine Mike O'Neil, signed a £10m, three-year deal, then developed a heart complaint and had to quit on the first day. Spencer Stuart had to find someone else for free, eventually plumping for Canadian Matt Barrett.

No one at the notoriously low-profile firm is prepared to speak about the incident, or the other 800 senior-level searches it conducts each year in 20 countries.

"I have to say that Spencer Stuart does not speak to the press," sniffs a receptionist.

Women top pay league

The growth in trade has catapulted the headhunters themselves into the list of Britain's top earners. Last year a survey by research firm Heywood Associates found that the most successful can earn up to £1.6m a year. Principals ask for a basic salary of £250,000 plus benefits and bonus, as the recruitment market for the recruiters becomes ever more competitive.

Women are among the biggest earners. Anna Mann of stock market-listed agency Whitehead Mann is said to have placed more chief executives than anyone else in the country. Ffion Jenkins, Conservative leader William Hague's wife, is reputed to earn more than £100,000 per year at Leonard Hull, an agency set up by former journalist Carol Leonard.

Philippa Rose, 41-year-old founder of the Rose Partnership, has been one of the leading specialists in the banking and finance sector since quitting Kleinwort Benson 20 years ago at the age of 22.

With business booming, the headhunters are unlikely to be spending any time pondering whether they should seek a change of career.

webTitle: Job fixers miraculously find their own niche

fields.headline: Job fixers miraculously find their own niche
fields.trailText: As far as everyone at Michael Page was concerned yesterday's £650m stock market flotation of the recruitment firm was a resounding success, writes John Cassy.
fields.body:
As far as everyone at Michael Page was concerned yesterday's £650m stock market flotation of the recruitment firm was a resounding success, writes John Cassy.

The valuation may have been significantly below the £900m bankers had originally hoped to achieve and early trading in the shares was hardly spectacular, but bankers close to the deal were claiming that any flotation of size at a time of such turbulent market conditions was close to miraculous.

The shares, which were placed at 175p, closed up 1p at 176p.

Michael Page company is one of the most widely recognised brands in the professional recruitment industry with 2,666 employees spread across 91 offices in 14 countries. Chief executive Terry Benson, who joined the firm in 1979, earned £2.4m last year and has options over shares worth more than £9m.

"This is a truly blue chip company doing business with every FTSE-100 firm which is why investors were prepared to back it in even these conditions," said Konrad Zomer, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, which was the investment bank behind the flotation.

In the wider recruitment market Michael Page sits below the executive focused headhunting firms and specialises in recruiting staff whose salaries range between £25,000 and £100,000.

Its main competitors are Hayes, Harvey Nash, Robert Walkers, TMP Worldwide, Robert Half and PSD.

Analysts say that the spread of Michael Page's business was also a comforting factor for investors. Only about 10% of its revenues come from the City of London where firms are expected to lay-off people rather than take them on if the economic downturn continues.

Accountancy, general finance, sales, marketing and legal are its other key areas. Last year it made more than 21,000 temporary job place ments as it reported revenues of £239.7m.

But it was the 26,000 permanent placements that it made that contributed the lion's share to an operating profit of £82.5m because the one-off commissions are much larger and higher margin.

The lower strata of the market are dominated by players such as Adecco and Manpower, which specialise in employing people earning £25,000 or less, particularly in the clerical area.

fields.headline: Iberia's plunging float yields BA £50m
fields.trailText: British Airways is to receive a rebate of more than £50m on its stake in Spanish flag carrier Iberia.
fields.body:
British Airways is to receive a rebate of more than £50m on its stake in Spanish flag carrier Iberia.

BA paid £155m for a 9% stake in Iberia in late 1999 but the deal included a clause under which the British airline is entitled to compensation if Iberia were privatised at a lower price.

Yesterday the Spanish government announced that the maximum price for the sale of its remaining 54% stake in Iberia would be 1.97 euros a share. At that price BA's stake is worth around £103m.

The compensation payment could rise if Iberia's advisers are forced to trim the offer-for-sale price further in order to ensure the shares are sold.

The exact price will be decided on April 1 and trading in the shares begins on April 3.

A spokesman for BA confirmed yesterday that the airline was entitled to compensation based on the price at which Iberia shares are offered to investors at the weekend.

BA bought the stake in Iberia, having identified "substantial areas of opportunity for cooperation" with the Spanish airline, according to the 1999/2000 annual report.

"We have a healthy commercial relationship which we are looking to make stronger," a BA spokesman said yesterday.

Analysts believe that the Spanish government holding company that owns the Iberia stake might have to consider a steep cut in the offer price if demand proves as weak as some indications suggest and there is a risk the issue could prove a flop.

The turmoil in the financial markets that has hit share prices around the world has made public offerings a risky business. A number of companies have delayed stock market flotations in the belief that their shares would have to be sold too cheaply to attract sufficient demand.

Iberia has already been forced to increase the proportion of shares being offered to retail investors because of weak demand from international institutions.

"There is institutional demand at prices around 1.55 euros," according to one fund manager. "The maximum price is not good."

Although there have been suggestions that Iberia could be forced to delay the sale, such a move at this late stage could prove as expensive as pressing ahead.

webTitle: Notebook: Very little British about the City

fields.headline: Very little British about the City
fields.standfirst: Galley and Zimerman go
fields.trailText: Notebook: Galley and Zimerman go.
fields.body:
So now we know why Merrill Lynch Investment Management has signed up as inaugural sponsor of the Chelsea flower show in May: the future is horticultural for that dynamic fund management duo, Carol Galley and Stephen Zimmerman.

The pair are retiring three and a bit years after selling what was widely regarded as the City's finest fund management operation, Mercury Asset Management, to the Americans. The timing back then looked perfect. Contagion was spreading through Asia, but Russia had yet to default. Taking £3bn for the business looked like the ultimate bear trade and there was an assumption that Ms Galley and Mr Zimmerman would soon depart.

The pair always thrived on their utter independence, taking aggressive investment stances, shaking down underperforming boards and swinging takeover battles with little regard for external sensitivities. Merrill, it was assumed, would suffocate them.

In the event, despite the constant flow of rumours, a ruthless Americanisation of the old Mercury business and a patchy performance record, the pair stayed on to run the entire Merrill asset allocation ranch - which, at the last count, was not insubstantial, with £400bn under management.

All the while, the City's big institutional investors have continued to follow their investment banking colleagues on the path to Wimbledoni sation (the tournament is still played here, but all the top seeds are foreign.)

Losing individuals such as Galley and Zimmerman makes the trend feel irreversible.

Happy pills

A little bit of chit-chat can work wonders. Just 18 months ago, the drugs industry and the government were at loggerheads - Sir Richard Sykes even threatened to shift Glaxo Wellcome overseas to escape the "hostile environment" in Britain.

He was upset that Glaxo's flu drug, Relenza, had been turned down by the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice), which vets national health service medicines. There was wider anger over the NHS's refusal to pay more for drugs, and a lack of action in clamping down on cheap continental imports.

Tony Blair responded by setting up a taskforce on competitiveness - effectively, a group hug between his ministers and top drugs barons. The results are startling - the taskforce's report yesterday contains pages of gush on the "spirit of goodwill" and the "unique relationship" established by the two sides. The government, it seems, has told the pharmaceuticals industry it is a "jewel in the crown" of the British economy.

This all seems to have been achieved with remarkably little horse-trading. A list of perfectly sensible measures have emerged - drugs companies will be able to access more NHS data, doctors will get more flexibility in prescribing and the industry's views will be considered when Nice is "reviewed", this summer.

The only vague passage relates to patents - the two sides will "work together" to ensure that drugs are available in developing countries. It will be intriguing to see whether Mr Blair is prepared to stand up to his new best friends as charities demand more help for patients in Aids-stricken Africa.

Marconi mess

George Simpson, Marconi's chief executive, has often dreamed aloud of turning the telecoms equipment maker into a genuine rival to the likes of Cisco, Lucent, and Nortel. Well, it is now, its shares dragged down by a series of profits warnings from its bigger north American cousins. Yesterday, Nortel's warning sliced another 9% off Marconi, knocking it back to 369p after last autumn's £12.76 peak.

The market and lots of commentators assume Marconi will be jolted into issuing its own warning in the closed period between this Friday and May 17, when the full figures are due. Yet there's still radio silence from the lord of Dunkeld and his chosen successor, John Mayo.

The noisy herd could well end up disappointed. Marconi has not issued a profits warning because it does not think the data warrant it. The consensus is for operating profits in the range £790m to £850m, some 5% down from the peak estimate of £900m, after £750m last year. Hardly reason to panic.

The group says it is less exposed to the US downturn, more to Euro-growth; operators still need to invest in broadband, while it is not involved in narrowband like Cisco and the rest. Profits warnings, moreover, can be self-fulfilling.

It's certainly true that everyone gets swept up in the overall malaise. It may also be true that Marconi is bucking the trend, but it needs more market visibility. A trading update would settle the nerves.

webTitle: Dow Chemical close to acquiring Ascot

fields.headline: Dow Chemical close to acquiring Ascot
fields.trailText: Dow Chemical of the US is believed to be close to an agreed takeover of Ascot, one of the country's few remaining independent speciality chemicals companies, for around £320m.
fields.body:
Dow Chemical of the US is believed to be close to an agreed takeover of Ascot, one of the country's few remaining independent speciality chemicals companies, for around £320m.

A statement could be released as early as today.

The deal is the latest example of consolidation within the chemical sector which has seen rivals such as Ellis & Everard and Laporte acquired by foreign rivals

With Dow ready to pay upwards of 400p a share, the size of premium is expected to surprise many.

Last night Ascot shares closed at 344p, up 5.5p, having moved steadily higher since the company announced it was in takeover talks with an unnamed suitor a week ago.

The acquisition of Ascot would bring to a close the turnaround story which began in 1992 when executive chairman Howard Dyer was brought in to rescue Control Securities, a bankrupt property company.

Mr Dyer renamed the company Ascot and started to dispose of its property and brewing assets, later deciding to focus on chemicals and engineering through the acquisition of Suter.

The transformation of the company was completed last year when Ascot decided to sell its four engineering businesses to a management buyout team for £45.6m and concentrate on chemicals.

In the past few years it has been expanding its printing inks and pharmaceutical intermediates business.

The acquisition of two pharma-technology companies, ChiroTech and Haltermann, were well received in the City.

Dow Chemical is thought to have been primarily interested in Ascot's expertise in the pharma-technology sector

ChiroTech is developing a technique that will allow it to make more powerful drugs.

fields.headline: Drugs reforms sought
fields.trailText: The government is to "streamline" the process of granting licences to test drugs on animals, amid fears that animal rights activists could drive research abroad.
fields.body:
The government is to "streamline" the process of granting licences to test drugs on animals, amid fears that animal rights activists could drive research abroad.

A report to the prime minister on competitiveness in the pharmaceuticals industry yesterday recommended reducing the "administration" involved in the procedure. It suggested this would free resources to devote to animal welfare.

The suggestion came from a task force co-chaired by AstraZeneca chief executive Tom McKillop and health minister Lord Hunt. It was established 18 months ago following a series of clashes between the government and the drugs industry.

Its recommendations include allowing drugs companies to look at NHS data on the efficacy of drugs.

The task force requested an easing of immigration laws to bring more scientific experts into the country and for doctors to be allowed to issue private prescriptions of medicines turned down for NHS use.

Mr McKillop said: "It's a good basis for working together in future."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: £600m loss for Pacific Century
fields.body:
£600m loss for Pacific Century

Pacific Century CyberWorks has posted a net loss of $886m (£602m), far worse than expected, as the telecoms and internet firm was weighed-down by merger costs and the plunging value of investment holdings.

The company, led by 34-year-old tycoon Richard Li, son of Hong Kong's richest man Li Ka-shing, last year pulled off Asia's largest-ever corporate takeover but has since seen its share price savaged.

Pacific's stock has fallen some 88% since February last year, PCCW shares fell 0.71% to close at HK$3.475 (31p) after hitting a post-takeover low of HK$3.30.

Gucci appeals against inquiry

Italian fashion house Gucci is to appeal against a Dutch court ruling ordering an investigation into its alliance with French retailer Pinault-Printemps-Redoute. This month the Amsterdam Enterprise Court launched an investigation into a white knight deal through which PPR bought a 42% Gucci stake.

Gucci said it would cooperate with the inquiry, but added in a statement: "The facts have not changed and the law has not changed since 1999 when the court did not find it necessary to order an inquiry."

LVMH, which was furious over the PPR deal that diluted its own Gucci stake from 34.4% to 20%.

Budvar takes on Bud

Czech brewer Budejovicky Budvar, locked in trademark disputes worldwide with its American rival Anheuser-Busch, has introduced Czechvar beer to go head-to-head with Budweiser in the US.

State-owned Budvar's general director Jiri Bocek said the firm has been forced to drop its brand name, Budweiser, and adopt Czechvar as it looks to gain a foothold in the lucrative American market.

Budvar has for years fought legal battles around the world over rights to the "Budweiser", "Bud" and "Budweis" trademarks.

BNFL decision deferred

The government yesterday put off a decision on BNFL's £460m mixed oxide (MOX) plant in Sellafield, Cumbria - centre of the foot and mouth outbreak - until after the likely date of the election.

Michael Meacher, environment minister, and Alan Milburn, health secretary, ordered a 10-week consultation process over BNFL's plans to produce MOX fuel for power stations from uranium and plutonium derived from reprocessing.

fields.headline: Elementis gets heated
fields.trailText: Sometimes sharp price movements are not always what they seem.
fields.body:
Sometimes sharp price movements are not always what they seem.

Yesterday, for instance, an early gain for the speciality chemicals group Elementis - it eventually closed up 11.5p, or 15%, to 89p - was interpreted by certain sectors of the market as a sign that a takeover offer was finally on the way.

This was not surprising. Elementis, which supplies chromium to the aerospace industry, said in December it had received an approach. But well informed market sources insist speculation of a deal is premature. They say Elementis started circulating an information memorandum to interested parties only at the start of the month.

The most likely explanation for the initial buying, traders said, is that the stock slipped back (about 24p) since the approach was revealed, plus the recent premiums that bidders have been paying for chemicals companies.

fields.headline: At this price?  Barratt
fields.trailText: Barratt Developments, Britain's second largest housebuilder, has constructed a strong market position through organic growth.
fields.body:
Barratt Developments, Britain's second largest housebuilder, has constructed a strong market position through organic growth.

While the rest of the construction sector has looked to consolidation, Barratt has bucked the trend and concentrated on volume growth.

It has doubled the size of its business over the past eight years at a time when critics said margins would be destroyed in the process.

But interim pretax profit figures at £63.1m, up 25%, showed the growth bandwagon continues to roll along successfully despite a tightening of the market.

Turnover rose from £516m to £629m on the back of 5,000 home completions, up 7% compared with an industry decrease of 3%. Barratt margins remained steady.

Earnings per share rose 28.5% to 19.4p while Barratt has proposed an interim dividend of 4.16p, a rise of 8% on last time.

Chairman Frank Eaton said forward sales were, like its profits, at record levels and he anticipated "another highly successful year".

Shares rose 10% in early trading and finished the day at 309p, up 25.5p as analysts increased their full-year forecasts.

Barratt remains happy to keep its independence even after the Persimmon takeover of Beazer which created the country's number one housebuilder. "Our growth has developed organically. We haven't the need to make acquisitions," said Eaton. With falling interest rates, low price-to-earnings ratios and reasonable dividend yields, the housebuilding sector looks attractive to investors.

Kevin Cammack, construction analyst at Merrill Lynch points out, however, that Persimmon can look to cost-cutting as "reinsurance" which is denied to its rival. But Barratt is on a price-earning of 6, well below the rest of the sector and its management track record is impressive. Hold.

webTitle: Market forces: Moss Bros finds new crease

fields.headline: Moss Bros finds new crease
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
The demise of the pinstripe suit has hurt menswear retailer Moss Bros. Profits have fallen sharply and the company has been forced to take radical action. Chains such as Savoy Taylors Guild, The Suit Company and Blazer are disappearing, being replaced by more contemporary formats that appeal to the man who wears chinos and open necked shirts to work.

But just recently the Moss Bros share price has started to tick higher on chatter that a mysterious investor is building a stake.

Yesterday, the shares continued the advance, rising 4.5p, or 16.6%, to 31.5p, as the investor added to his position. This, traders said, followed heavy buying by the same investor on Tuesday.

According to well informed sources, the mystery man believes current trading at Moss Bros has turned the corner. It is said that gross margins and like-for-like sales in the first eight weeks of the current fiscal year have improved, while Code, the new contemporary format, is achieving sales in line with expectations.

Moss Bros will reveal all on Monday, when it delivers figures for the year to January 31.

The day's other hot tales centred on Carphone Warehouse and aircraft seat maker Britax.

Carphone shares lost 5.5p to 125p on speculation that joint broker CSFB had lowered its 2002 profits forecast by 8% to take account of slowing handset sales. Carphone shares floated at 195p in July.

Meanwhile, Britax gained 5.5p to 120.5p on speculation that takeover talks, first revealed in January, are close to fruition. The gossips claim to have heard that an offer of around 130p has been accepted.

Fears that FTSE-100's recent recovery had been nothing more than a "dead cat bounce" were partly realised yesterday as the blue chip index fell sharply, closing down 114.1 points at 5,614.

Profits warnings from media company Disney, telecoms equipment maker Nortel, and handheld computer specialist Palm, which cast a shadow over Wall Street, were responsible for driving the index down.

Traders were not surprised by the performance. "We need signs of a turnaround from corporate America before this market recovers," one senior trader said. "You get big rallies in bear markets."

Elsewhere, the FTSE Tech mark 100 fell back 53.98 points to 1,980.16, with optical components maker Bookham tumbling 31.5p to 328.5p on the back of the Nortel profits warning. Dealers noted that 50% of Bookham's revenue comes from the Canadian company. FTSE 100 company Marconi, which competes with Nortel, was also suffering, losing 37p to 373p.

Unsettled by the profits alert from Palm, rival Psion dropped 13p to 117.5p. Analysts said the fall was overdone because Psion had negligible exposure to North America.

Back among the blue chips, semiconductor designer ARM Holdings ended 32.25p weaker at 315.75p with HSBC Securities said to have told its clients it sees downside risk to forecasts. HSBC's call followed a visit to ARM's customer base in North America. Vodafone eased 9p to 204p as Schroder Salomon Smith Barney lowered its target price to 220p.

ITV company Carlton Communications shed 34p to 415p as short sellers targeted the stock on rumours that it has been hurt by the slowdown in advertising spending. Apparently a profits warning could be on the way.

Among smaller companies, Britain's biggest owner of nursing homes, NHP, remained unchanged at 29.25p, although dealers think it is about to transfer the leases over 39 of its homes, worth £130m, from its struggling tenant Ultima to Southern Cross, the privately owned operator.

On Aim, Lady in Leisure, the women-only fitness club operator, ticked up 5.5p to 11.5p on word that its advisers have finally lined up a buyer.

webTitle: Arts: Arthur Smith on favourite sitcoms

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: With the proliferation of TV channels, magazines and newspaper supplements, it is inevitable that everyone will at some point be interviewed.
fields.body:
With the proliferation of TV channels, magazines and newspaper supplements, it is inevitable that everyone will at some point be interviewed. The interviewer will probably ask that most painful of questions: "Where do you get your ideas from?" The only response to this is John Cleese's: "I get mine from a retired colonel in Hampshire and he gets them from a lady who runs a post office in north Devon. Where she gets them from I don't know ..."

Another uninspired question is: "What is your favourite sitcom?" A popular answer, particularly among British football managers, is Only Fools and Horses. But the character of Del Boy always struck me as an out-and-out stereotype - Private Walker's son, or a less interesting version of Arthur Daley in Minder.

Dad's Army had wonderful characters but now looks creaky; Fawlty Towers was hilarious but Manuel now grates and there weren't enough episodes to judge properly; Hancock, Steptoe and Till Death Us Do Part are of their time; and though The Royle Family is sublime and iconoclastic, I don't make a date with it.

So I turn to America, where sitcoms have the opposite problem from Fawlty Towers in that there are too many episodes. Everyone in Friends has been out with everyone else and I hate their cuteness. Seinfeld had some great characters but, alas, the main character was not one. I want to give Jerry a slap and tell him to stop ironing his jeans or come out of the closet.

By far the best American sitcom still being made is Frasier. It is remarkable that the two principal laughter-getters should be effete, pretentious dandies and that the best episodes are thrillingly literate, but I think they may have written themselves into a corner with the pairing of Niles and Daphne.

There is only one candidate for best ever sitcom but I have run out of space for the appropriate eulogy so I'll save it. Can you guess what the programme is, children?

webTitle: Artists fascinated by the low life

fields.headline: Where there's muck ...
fields.standfirst: London's artists have long been fascinated by the low life - terrified they would end up in the gutter yet endlessly inspired by crime and squalor.  Jonathan Jones reports
fields.trailText: London's artists have long been fascinated by the low life - terrified they would end up in the gutter yet endlessly inspired by crime and squalor. Jonathan Jones reports.
fields.body:
In 1858 the painter Augustus Egg portrayed himself in the character of David Fallen, a starving writer from a play by his friend Edward Bulwer-Lytton. Egg, in reality a successful bourgeois with a nice house in Kensington, imagined himself as a failure, dark-eyed and sallow-cheeked, scribbling desperately in a garret with his laundry hanging behind him. He envisaged the ultimate nightmare: that he himself lived the life of a Romantic artist, outside respectable society, without middle-class comforts - even anyone to wash his clothes.

This is an unusual example from the many portraits of artists in the Museum of London's exhibition Creative Quarters: The Art World in London 1700-2000. Egg had a taste for morbid narrative and an overheated sense of the thinness of the line between the respectability he had achieved and what lay outside the parlour door. In the same year as he painted this self-portrait (commissioned by another painter, Patrick Allan, who escaped poverty only by marrying an heiress) Egg created the series of pictures for which he is best-known today. Past and Present I, II and III (1858), in Tate Britain, tell the story of a woman caught in adultery. Her sin leads, with melodramatic inevitability, to her ending up half-dead under a bridge by the Thames.

Egg's vision of what happens when you step outside the parameters of middle-class morality is comic today, but it's interesting that he portrayed himself as Fallen at the same time as he painted the results of women's sexual transgression. This is the period in which two French artists were celebrating life outside middle-class constraints in their founding masterpieces of modernism: Courbet with The Painter's Studio (1855) and Manet with Olympia (1863). Egg imagines the avant-garde artist as a doomed figure and creativity itself as a moral temptation that he, for one, was prepared to resist.

Creative Quarters reveals how deeply rooted this attitude was among British artists. It is not a story of wild social outlaws setting up their studios among the prostitutes, nightclub dancers and anarchist bomb-throwers, as Parisian artists did in Montmartre. From the moment London began to have an art world in the early 18th century, the ambition of artists was not to challenge society but to become part of it. They craved respectability, and this is revealed in their patterns of settlement.

The first move artists made was out of the City of London, which smacked of their old, despised status as craftsmen belonging to the Paint-Stainers' guild. They wanted to redefine themselves as gentlemen who practised the liberal arts, so they moved west, where the gentlemen lived.

West London was opened up as a posh commercial and residential territory, and artists settled in Covent Garden, which in the early 18th century was an aristocratic, stylish address. This story continued throughout the centuries to come: artists moved further and further west, buying country residences in Chiswick and Twickenham.

Even the British version of bohemia was very comfortable, with Rossetti and Whistler opening up Chelsea as a chic district in the late 19th century. It wasn't until the 1950s that artists started to flirt with danger in the booze-sodden atmosphere of Francis Bacon's Soho - but even that was a piece of fantasy by artists who never thought of actually living amid the Soho sleaze. Instead, Bacon lived and worked in a very desirable mews house in Kensington.

The Museum of London reconstructs this story of respectability and affluence with archeological precision. Yet if artists wanted nothing more than to avoid the garret, and if they really could imagine nothing more interesting than bourgeois comforts, there wouldn't be much interest in looking at British art before 1950. But there is. And a lot of it is about the dark side of London life. If British artists aspired to live in the smartest parts of the capital, to mix with the best people, they were also transfixed by low life.

The fear and seduction of the gutter were there in the 18th century, in the work of William Hogarth. Hogarth was the defining spirit of London's art, central to the history of the city's "creative quarters". It was Hogarth who laid the foundations of art as a middle-class career. He was a self-made man whose pride in pulling himself up into the upper-middle class can be seen in his self-portrait The Painter with His Pug (1745), in Tate Britain. More than anyone, Hogarth established a market for British art. He found new ways to sell art not just to the aristocracy but to the new middle-class public, inventing a new genre - "comic history painting" - that had the same broad appeal as the contemporary novels of Defoe, Richardson and Fielding.

Hogarth's visual narratives, such as The Rake's Progress (1733) and Marriage à la Mode (before 1743), are novels told in a series of pictures. And just to make them even more exciting for a popular audience in 18th-century London, he set them all, in great topographical detail, in the city they knew and lived in. No costume dramas for this British film-maker before the invention of film. His art was available to almost all, thanks to cheap prints of his paintings.

In 1731 Hogarth came to live in Covent Garden with his well-to-do father-in-law, the court painter James Thornhill; by 1733 he was able to afford his own house on Leicester Square. These were snooty addresses. Hogarth was one of the first wave of upwardly mobile artists, even buying a country house in then-rural Chiswick. But if he was proud, he was also anxious. If he was respectable, he was also fascinated by dirt.

In fact, he engraved the definitive image of the starving creative artist in his London garret. Egg's Self-Portrait as David Fallen is a close reworking of Hogarth's print The Distressed Poet, published in 1737, with the same washing on the line. Hogarth's writer scratches his head under his askew wig, trying to think of some wonderful, saleable poem to get his family out of this attic room. It's the same nightmare that tormented Egg, but Hogarth had better reason to fear it. His own father, Richard Hogarth, was an impecunious, would-be literary man who never made a decent living and was for a time imprisoned for debt. At the age of 12 Hogarth himself saw the inside of the Fleet prison.

In scene three of The Rake's Progress, we see the artist's anti-hero Tom Rakewell, having inherited his father's wealth and set up home in London, enjoying a night out at the Rose Tavern in Drury Lane. It's three in the morning, and the Rake has been out boozing and brawling - he wears a sword and rests a cudgel on the ground. The tavern is a prostitutes' hangout and two women are stealing his watch while he studies the entertainment. As one woman strips to her underwear, an employee brings in a candle and silver platter. This is for a performance in which the woman undressing will snuff out the candle during a simulated sex act.

Hogarth loved this dirty town. His visual novels are terrifying - the Rake ends up first in debtor's prison and then in Bedlam and, in the fifth scene of Marriage à la Mode, a man is murdered by his wife's lover after confronting them in a sex hotel or "bagnio". But they are also exuberantly comic. In Morning in Covent Garden, from his series The Four Times of The Day (1736) - painted not that long after he moved out of the square in 1733 - a thin old woman with her starveling servant boy walk across the square in front of the market at five minutes to eight, about to enter the classically porticoed St Paul's Church, still there today. Instead of today's tourists and buskers, the church-going representative of propriety is jeered at by a bunch of lowlifes who didn't go to bed at all last night - young bloods who make love to prostitutes right there in the middle of the square.

In this confrontation of the church-going middle class and the city's dirty denizens there's no ambiguity about which side Hogarth is on. The woman resembles Lent, as personified as a thin old woman in prints by Brueghel and his imitators. The carousing, screwing lowlifes represent her antithesis: carnival. For Hogarth, London is a city of frolics where there are no rules. In the bagnio scene from Marriage à la Mode, there is a crudely drawn graffito on the wall, representing the savagery underlying civilisation, but also associating art with low life. Again and again in Hogarth the instinct to make art is shown to be low, primitive and irrational. People draw caricatures on their hands when they are drunk and, in Bedlam, a maniac draws on the wall.

British artists after Hogarth tried to imitate his economic success and, if they were any good, also turned to the filthy inspiration of the city. Some of them lived the life of the distressed poet in all its seedy details. In the early 19th century Benjamin Haydon tried to establish himself as a great history painter on a continental model, but in Britain there just wasn't the market or patronage for it, and he ended up in debtors' prison. There he turned to painting comic narrative scenes in the manner of Hogarth, although he never got out of debt and eventually killed himself. It was not until the second half of the 20th century that the spirit of avant-garde social dissidence finally found a market in Britain. Yet the great art of London since Hogarth belongs in the gutter, the brothel and the asylum.

fields.bodyText: In 1858 the painter Augustus Egg portrayed himself in the character of David Fallen, a starving writer from a play by his friend Edward Bulwer-Lytton. Egg, in reality a successful bourgeois with a nice house in Kensington, imagined himself as a failure, dark-eyed and sallow-cheeked, scribbling desperately in a garret with his laundry hanging behind him. He envisaged the ultimate nightmare: that he himself lived the life of a Romantic artist, outside respectable society, without middle-class comforts - even anyone to wash his clothes. This is an unusual example from the many portraits of artists in the Museum of London's exhibition Creative Quarters: The Art World in London 1700-2000. Egg had a taste for morbid narrative and an overheated sense of the thinness of the line between the respectability he had achieved and what lay outside the parlour door. In the same year as he painted this self-portrait (commissioned by another painter, Patrick Allan, who escaped poverty only by marrying an heiress) Egg created the series of pictures for which he is best-known today. Past and Present I, II and III (1858), in Tate Britain, tell the story of a woman caught in adultery. Her sin leads, with melodramatic inevitability, to her ending up half-dead under a bridge by the Thames. Egg's vision of what happens when you step outside the parameters of middle-class morality is comic today, but it's interesting that he portrayed himself as Fallen at the same time as he painted the results of women's sexual transgression. This is the period in which two French artists were celebrating life outside middle-class constraints in their founding masterpieces of modernism: Courbet with The Painter's Studio (1855) and Manet with Olympia (1863). Egg imagines the avant-garde artist as a doomed figure and creativity itself as a moral temptation that he, for one, was prepared to resist. Creative Quarters reveals how deeply rooted this attitude was among British artists. It is not a story of wild social outlaws setting up their studios among the prostitutes, nightclub dancers and anarchist bomb-throwers, as Parisian artists did in Montmartre. From the moment London began to have an art world in the early 18th century, the ambition of artists was not to challenge society but to become part of it. They craved respectability, and this is revealed in their patterns of settlement. The first move artists made was out of the City of London, which smacked of their old, despised status as craftsmen belonging to the Paint-Stainers' guild. They wanted to redefine themselves as gentlemen who practised the liberal arts, so they moved west, where the gentlemen lived. West London was opened up as a posh commercial and residential territory, and artists settled in Covent Garden, which in the early 18th century was an aristocratic, stylish address. This story continued throughout the centuries to come: artists moved further and further west, buying country residences in Chiswick and Twickenham. Even the British version of bohemia was very comfortable, with Rossetti and Whistler opening up Chelsea as a chic district in the late 19th century. It wasn't until the 1950s that artists started to flirt with danger in the booze-sodden atmosphere of Francis Bacon's Soho - but even that was a piece of fantasy by artists who never thought of actually living amid the Soho sleaze. Instead, Bacon lived and worked in a very desirable mews house in Kensington. The Museum of London reconstructs this story of respectability and affluence with archeological precision. Yet if artists wanted nothing more than to avoid the garret, and if they really could imagine nothing more interesting than bourgeois comforts, there wouldn't be much interest in looking at British art before 1950. But there is. And a lot of it is about the dark side of London life. If British artists aspired to live in the smartest parts of the capital, to mix with the best people, they were also transfixed by low life. The fear and seduction of the gutter were there in the 18th century, in the work of William Hogarth. Hogarth was the defining spirit of London's art, central to the history of the city's "creative quarters". It was Hogarth who laid the foundations of art as a middle-class career. He was a self-made man whose pride in pulling himself up into the upper-middle class can be seen in his self-portrait The Painter with His Pug (1745), in Tate Britain. More than anyone, Hogarth established a market for British art. He found new ways to sell art not just to the aristocracy but to the new middle-class public, inventing a new genre - "comic history painting" - that had the same broad appeal as the contemporary novels of Defoe, Richardson and Fielding. If he was respectable, he was also fascinated by dirt. In fact, he engraved the definitive image of the starving creative artist in his London garret. fields.headline: Wahid impeachment wagon keeps rolling
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: The embattled Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday failed to win over an increasingly hostile parliament with his formal response to a censure motion. His defiant reply denied any wrongdoing and questioned the legality and constitutionality of the efforts to oust him.
fields.body:
The embattled Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, yesterday failed to win over an increasingly hostile parliament with his formal response to a censure motion. His defiant reply denied any wrongdoing and questioned the legality and constitutionality of the efforts to oust him.

Opposition party leaders' initial reaction was that even though Mr Wahid's response included a vague apology for "inappropriate behaviour", it was not enough to derail calls for a second warning to be issued next month.

If the president fails to satisfy legislators within one month of the second memorandum being issued, they are entitled to start impeachment proceedings.

In his 15-page address, delivered by the justice minister, Baharuddin Lopa, Mr Wahid, who was censured for his alleged role in two financial scandals in which £4.25m disappeared, repeatedly stressed that the censure was "baseless", "unobjective" and "completely out of proportion" because the parliamentary investigating committee had found no proof linking him to the scams.

"It is hard not to see the censure as the result of a dislike of the president or aimed at toppling the president," Mr Wahid's reply said. "The censure does not stand on the principle of justice."

Most analysts agree that the opposition is using the scandals as an excuse to force Mr Wahid from office.

The real source of discontent is Mr Wahid's erratic and ineffective governing style which has failed to end a three-year economic crisis, curb rampant corruption and prevent communal violence spreading across the archipelago.

"We heard nothing new today whatsoever," said Alvin Lie, one of Mr Wahid's harshest critics. "He was just trying to defend himself. What we wanted to hear was how he plans to improve the state of the country."

He added that it would now take "a very big miracle" to prevent the second censure from being issued.

Mr Wahid's party controls only 10% of parliament.

webTitle: Zapatistas, minus Marcos, have their day in parliament

fields.headline: Zapatistas, minus Marcos, have their day in parliament
fields.standfirst: More about the Mexican presidential election
fields.trailText: The Zapatista leadership addressed an extraordinary session of Mexico's parliament called to hear their demands for constitutional recognition of the country's 10m indigenous people yesterday, without their iconic leader, Subcomandante Marcos.
fields.body:
The Zapatista leadership addressed an extraordinary session of Mexico's parliament called to hear their demands for constitutional recognition of the country's 10m indigenous people yesterday, without their iconic leader, Subcomandante Marcos.

The rebel leadership filed into the huge chamber of deputies masked but unarmed. "The subcomandante is just that, a sub, and we gave him the mission to bring us here. Now it's our hour," said Comandante Esther in the main Zapatista speech, which received a standing ovation.

"My name is Esther, but that's not important. I'm a Zapatista, but that's not important either. What is important is that I am indigenous and I am a woman and I am speaking in this symbolic place," she said.

The Zapatista delegation was allowed 220 special guests in the parliamentary front row, many of whom wore traditional costume.

Last night's session was due to last five hours, with the Zapatista leaders' speeches in favour of an indigenous rights bill granting autonomy to indigenous communities to be followed by questions.

The bill's approval has been the rebels' key remaining condition for accepting President Vicente Fox's often repeated offer of peace talks anytime, anywhere. But last night Esther said initial contact with the government peace commission could start before that was achieved.

Most parliamentarians from Mr Fox's conservative National Action party (Pan) had said they would boycott the session to display their distaste for the presence of masked rebels officially at war with the state, and their objection to what they view as the president's capitulation.

The bill stems from a peace accord signed in February 1996 but blocked by the then president Ernesto Zedillo, prompting the Zapatistas to abandon negotiations.

It was dusted off by Mr Fox who, despite the tensions within his own party, has made his search for peace in Chiapas a pillar of his claims to be dismantling the authoritarian structures of 71 years of one-party rule by the Institutional Revolutionary party.

Marcos seized the opportunities presented by Mr Fox to break years of isolation in jungle strongholds and politically relaunch the militarily weak guerrilla faction.

"They no longer existed on the political agenda but now they have recouped an important place not only on the national agenda, but also internationally," said a political analyst, Carlos Elizondo.

But since they arrived in Mexico City the going has got tougher for the Zapatistas, with Pan insisting that the rebels should only talk to small groups of deputies in back rooms.

Other parties invited the Zapatistas to speak after Marcos had threatened to take his rebels home and was holding a "goodbye" rally in the city.

In an interview given to the Colombian-born writer Gabriel Garcia Marques, Marcos said the Zapatistas were "condemned to failure if we continue with an armed structure".

But before last night's session, Miguel Alvarez, who was a peace mediator in the early years of the conflict, had warned that even the approval of the bill, which is expected to be put to the vote next month, is no guarantee of a peace deal.

"It would be a further step, but Fox wants a quick peace deal while the Zapatistas want a more profound negotiation, and they are not in that much of a hurry," he said.

webTitle: One Briton freed, two held hostage by Somali gunmen

fields.headline: One Briton freed, two held hostage by Somali gunmen
fields.trailText: A British aid worker was one of five foreign hostages freed yesterday by Somali militiamen who were reported to have abducted them during fierce fighting in Mogadishu on Tuesday. Two other Britons remained hostage during a tense standoff between rival factions in the Somali capital.
fields.body:
A British aid worker was one of five foreign hostages freed yesterday by Somali militiamen who were reported to have abducted them during fierce fighting in Mogadishu on Tuesday. Two other Britons remained hostage during a tense standoff between rival factions in the Somali capital.

In Nairobi, in neighbouring Kenya, a UN spokeswoman, Sonya Green, said Jonathan Veitch, a Briton with the UN children's fund, Unicef, had been handed over to Somalia's transitional government along with an American colleague and three Europeans from French aid agency Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF).

Last night Mr Veitch, 32, said: "There's little I can say until my friends are released, but the two Britons there are two of the most experienced people we have in Somalia. We know where they are, and we know they're OK."

The two Britons who remained hostage were yesterday named as Bill Condie and Roger Carter.

MSF's Nairobi spokeswoman, Samantha Bolton, denied that the agency's workers had ever been held captive. "Our staff were never hostages, they were just keeping out of the way at a local businessman's house," she said. "The UN seems to have been sending out some conflicting signals."

The aid workers spent the day at the Hotel Ramadan, which serves as the base for President Abdiqassim Salad Hassan in the absence of any government buildings left standing in the wartorn city.

The UN and MSF both sent planes to bring the aid workers to Nairobi yesterday evening.

UN sources said that four remaining UN hostages, two Britons, a Frenchman and a Belgian, were being held by fighters loyal to the warlord Musa Sude Yalahow. Mr Yalahow's men sparked Tuesday's conflict by attacking a rival militia employed as MSF's security guards.

The UN and MSF staff, who had joined up to visit an MSF cholera vaccination project, became separated as Mr Yalahow's men ransacked the MSF compound.

Ms Green said: "The UN is in discussion about the four with faction leader Musa Sude Yalahow, who controls the area. We are not calling them hostages or kidnapped and we are not blaming Musa Sude. We are just talking to him because he controls the area."

According to local reports, the captives were being held in two groups, with the British pair under guard in a garage in north Mogadishu, and the other two in Mr Yalahow's compound.

On Tuesday, an aide to Mr Yalahow, who opposes Mogadishu's UN-sponsored transitional government, claimed that all nine aid workers had been taken hostage to show the world that President Hassan did not control Mogadishu. They would all be released soon, he said.

The interior minister, Dahir Dayah, said: "The local elders are working hard to secure the release of the remaining ones [hostages]. If they don't release them unconditionally, of course we will use force for their release."

The prime minister, Ali Khalid Gallaydh, criticised UN security officers for allowing a meeting of aid workers to take place so close to one of Yalahow's militias, but apologised for the incident.

"You can see what such people can do to aid workers and they even could do a lot worse," he said. "We used all of our means and will continue using it for the safe release of those still missing."

Fourteen Somalis were reported killed in Tuesday's fighting.

fields.headline: Nuclear waste faces last leg
fields.standfirst: Delayed train ready to transfer its cargo to lorries
fields.trailText: The nuclear-waste train harried for two days as it crossed Germany finally arrived at its destination yesterday after police officers and medical crews worked through the night to dislodge four protesters chained to the tracks.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Dannenberg and  Kate Connolly  in Berlin
fields.body:
The nuclear-waste train harried for two days as it crossed Germany finally arrived at its destination yesterday after police officers and medical crews worked through the night to dislodge four protesters chained to the tracks.

It was met in Dannenberg by more protesters and riot police with armoured vehicles and water cannon posted at crossings in and around the town.

The delay was achieved by the courageous, if foolhardy, action of four young activists - one a teenage girl - from a group known as Robin Wood, who attached themselves so securely to the line on Tuesday that it was not until yesterday that they were cut free.

By then they had spent 16 hours between the rails, chained to each other and with their arms in cement blocks fastened to the bed of the track.

The temperature fell to -7C during the night and the police brought in hot-air blowers to save the four from hypothermia. Even so, all four were taken to hospital on stretchers with suspected frostbite.

"I don't think that even these people expected it to last so long," a police spokesman said.

The Robin Wood group has its origins in the fight to save German forests but has broadened its campaign to take in other issues.

After the four were removed a crowd of several hundred gathered at the site and began to sit on the track for the best part of a quarter of a mile. They were removed by the police during raucous and sometimes violent scuffles.

Protesters at the top of the embankment chanted "We are peaceful. What are you?" as the police cleared the single track line.

The police then pursued them across an open wheat field, away from the route due to be taken by the 60-tonne shipment.

But within 20 minutes, knots of demonstrators had regrouped a few miles away in the hamlet of Eichdorf to stage another fleeting occupation of the line.

At the Dannenberg railway terminus, which is sealed off with barbed wire, the six containers of waste produced by reprocessing spent fuel from German power plants will be loaded on flatbed trucks for the last leg of the from a French reprocessing plant.

The journey is expected to be undertaken today.

The final 12 miles through a thickly wooded area to the nuclear waste dump at Gorleben was the scene of clashes between the police and protesters during the last shipment four years ago.

There is increasing political fallout from the protests, and the protesters were beginning to scent a kind of victory: one with potentially damaging consequences for Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's red-green coalition government.

He already faces an uncomfortable parliamentary debate today when the Christian Democratic opposition will accuse his cabinet of bungling the resumption of shipments - suspended by the previous government in 1998 - and call on the Greens, the junior partners in the coalition, to distance themselves from the violent demonstrators.

The Green environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, who authorised the resumption, faces a separate motion which could end his career in office.

The underlying question is whether the authorities will press on with the shipments in the face of the determined opposition demonstrated this week.

If the answer is no, the entire agreement to phase out nuclear power in Germany, of which this is an integral part, will be thrown into doubt. Though moderate Greens defend the agreement, radical opponents of nuclear power of the kind engaged in this week's protests regard it as a political sham.

The Green party, which was divided even before this week's demonstrations, appears more split than ever on the issue. After members in Lower Saxony, the region where the demonstrations are taking place, called for the agreement to be rethought, the joint national leaders cancelled a visit to the area. Several Green MPs say they will vote against Mr Trittin today

If Mr Trittin loses the vote Mr Schröder may be prompted to sack him. But government sources insisted yesterday that there would be no change in the policy towards nuclear energy and that the shipments would go ahead.

webTitle: Warring parties pull back troops from front lines in Congo

fields.headline: Warring parties pull back troops from front lines in Congo
fields.standfirst: UN to deploy peacekeepers as African troops start disengagement
fields.trailText: UN to deploy peacekeepers as African troops start disengagement.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Harare  and Victoria Brittain  in Kigali
fields.body:
UN peacekeepers are due to start deploying in the Democratic Republic of Congo today as the international momentum for peace builds up following the pull-back of Rwandan troops and the withdrawal of contingents from Rwanda and Uganda last week.

The UN says Rwanda, Uganda, Zimbabwe, Angola and Namibia have all met commitments to pull back nearly 10 miles at about 100 key locations along the 1,500- mile front line in Congo.

The Rwandan president, Paul Kagame, said his troops have pulled back much further, "showing we are really serious and trying to end the war and our presence in Congo".

The war in Congo, which began in August 1998, involves a number of foreign countries and several rebel groups. Zimbabwe, Angola and Namibia support the government of President Joseph Kabila, while Rwanda and Uganda back rebels. All sides signed a ceasefire and disengagement agreement in Lusaka, Zambia, in 1999, but it was never observed.

General Moutaga Diallo, the UN's military chief, said yesterday that forces backing the Kinshasa regime had not moved at Kananga in central Kasai province.

"Something's not right," the Senegalese general said. "We hope the disengagement will take place rapidly."

"The commander of the [government] Congolese armed forces (FAC) in Kananga says he has received no order to withdraw, [while] the high command has told us and told us again that the order was given," he added.

Sceptics question whether, in a country more than twice the size of western Europe, an initial contingent of 3,000 UN peacekeepers can monitor events, let alone have a real impact on the situation.

The key question remains Mr Kabila's commitment to honour the Lusaka agreement's pledge to disarm the three or four brigades of his army composed of Rwandans from the Interahamwe militia and former soldiers responsible for the 1994 genocide. The agreement did not make clear how the disarmament would take effect.

"If Joseph [Kabila] turned over those 6,000 men, some of whom should be facing an international tribunal, I would not be having troops in Kasai and Katanga," said Major-General Nyamwasa Kayumba, Rwanda's army chief of staff.

"The ball is in his court, we have done everything possible to create an atmosphere of goodwill," he said.

Mr Kabila has just returned from a successful international tour which took in the US, where he and Mr Kagame met, and the EU.

Western optimism about the young president's willingness to negotiate a speedy end to Africa's worst war is not matched by those close to it.

Behind the scenes, it is likely to be the Zimbabwean leader, Robert Mugabe, Mr Kabila's key military ally, who is setting conditions for ending the war. "Zimbabwe has been crucial in creating difficulties," said Mr Kagame.

Zimbabwean troops took a heavy beating in an offensive against Rwandan troops late last year, shortly before the murder of Mr Kabila's father.

"The amount of equipment we captured indicated the Zimbabweans were planning a major move, probably into Burundi, using both Burundian and Interahamwe troops which they had newly trained," said Gen Kayumba.

Mr Mugabe has committed about 15,000 troops to fight in Congo, one third of his army, even though the war is unpopular in Zimbabwe. It has cost his depleted national treasury at least £150m in the midst of an economic crisis. But senior army officers and businessmen close to the ruling party have been making large amounts of money through contracts and mining concessions.

Under Mr Mugabe's guidance, Mr Kabila publicly insists that Rwanda and Uganda must withdraw their forces from Congo before his allies pull out.

But neither Kigali nor Kampala will leave until their security is assured by Mr Kabila's taking action against the former Interahamwe.

fields.headline: Croatian soldiers mutiny in Bosnia
fields.trailText: Hardline Croat separatists in Bosnia yesterday set up their own defence headquarters as a mutiny spread among Croat soldiers serving in the Muslim-Croat federation army.
fields.body:
Hardline Croat separatists in Bosnia yesterday set up their own defence headquarters as a mutiny spread among Croat soldiers serving in the Muslim-Croat federation army.

Reports from barracks across the federation in Bosnia suggested that the majority of the 7,500 Croat soldiers in the 22,500 strong common army were joining the mutiny. On Monday, 1,900 Croat soldiers from the central town of Vitez had abandoned their posts.

The mutiny follows the establishment of a Croat national congress three weeks ago, which has called on all Croats to leave their jobs in the federation army, police and other public offices. The aim of the congress is to establish a "third entity" or Croat statelet in Bosnia, leaving the Muslims stranded in a small enclave between Serbs and Croats.

Officials representing the international community in Bosnia have described the events as the most serious threat to the unity of Bosnia since the 1995 Dayton accords which ended the war.

"This is an extremely worrying development. We are trying to outstare them, but at the moment, we are not staring hard enough," said one western diplomat in Sarajevo.

Under Dayton, Bosnia was divided into two halves, the Muslim-Croat Federation and the Serbian Republic, each with considerable decisionmaking powers but the skeleton of a central state holding them together.

Muslims and Croats began the war together in 1992, fighting the attempt by Serb extremists to destroy the newly recognised country. But following Serb successes, and assuming the partition of the country was inevitable, Croats turned on their Muslim allies in 1993.

Following intense international pressure, in particular from the US, an alliance between Muslims and Croats was eventually patched up in 1994, and the two armies finished the war together.

But hardline Croats, especially in Herzegovina, have never abandoned their dream of forming their own separate state called Herzeg-Bosna.

"Any attempt to establish parallel structures is illegal, and anti-Dayton," Chris Bird, the spokesman for the High Representative in Sarajevo, said yesterday.

"We call on all members of the federation army to remain loyal to their legally appointed commanders."

But that appeal seemed to be falling on deaf ears. Most Croat generals are said to have walked out with their men.

In the police force, officers in largely Croat areas have for years ignored a law requiring them to wear Bosnian insignia alongside the chequer-board Croat badge on their uniforms.

But western officials yesterday drew some comfort from the fact that an estimated 250 Croats working in the federation interior ministry in Sarajevo have not responded to the nationalist call to abandon their posts.

Police and soldiers have been warned that anyone who joins the illegal Croat structures will lose their jobs, pay and pension rights in the federation.

The key question is whether the Croat soldiers have left to set up a new army, with access to weapons, or whether they are simply going to "run around the woods in blue jeans", as a diplomatic source put it.

"We don't have any information about soldiers leaving barracks with their weapons," Colonel Alain Ollivier, the deputy chief press officer for S-For, the Nato-led peacekeeping force in Bosnia, said yesterday.

"This is a political issue which needs a political response."

webTitle: Chirac refuses to talk to judges about sleaze

fields.headline: Chirac refuses to talk to judges about sleaze
fields.trailText: Jacques Chirac yesterday refused to be questioned as a witness by a magistrate investigating a massive kickback scandal allegedly run from Paris town hall while he was mayor, sparking a furious row over France's laws on presidential immunity.
fields.body:
Jacques Chirac yesterday refused to be questioned as a witness by a magistrate investigating a massive kickback scandal allegedly run from Paris town hall while he was mayor, sparking a furious row over France's laws on presidential immunity.

The summons, the first sent to a head of state during the Fifth Republic, was posted to the Elysée Palace last week by Eric Halphen, a judge investigating claims that the town hall under Mr Chirac creamed some £60m off public building and maintenance contracts in the 1980s and early 1990s - the vast majority of it going straight into the coffers of the president's conservative RPR party.

In an unprecedented pre-dawn statement, Mr Chirac's office responded to news of the summons by insisting that "in view of the constitutional rules, he cannot answer this summons, which is contrary to the principle of the separation of powers and to the demands of the continuity of the state".

It added that Mr Chirac, mayor of Paris from 1977 until his election as president in 1995, would have spoken to judges about the case already if he had any information on it.

Mr Chirac later fired off an angry letter to the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, denouncing the publication of the news as a violation of judicial secrecy and calling on him to "take all useful measures within his powers to ensure the constitution is respected".

The summons is a severe embarrassment in the week after the RPR lost control of Paris in local elections that were dominated by mounting evidence of corruption at the town hall during Mr Chirac's tenure.

A formal judicial request for the president to present himself for questioning became almost inevitable after last year's publication of an extraordinary beyond-the-grave confession by a former property developer and prominent RPR fundraiser, Jean-Claude Méry.

Mr Méry, who died in 1999, accused Mr Chirac in a videotape recorded in 1996 of setting up the covert fund-raising system. "We worked only on orders from Mr Chirac," he said, adding that on one occasion he personally handed £500,000 to a top town hall aide in the presence of Mr Chirac.

The president has repeatedly denied any part in half a dozen town hall sleaze scandals currently under investigation, using a television appearance in December to dismiss out of hand all the charges made against him.

But the scandal may prove damaging to his re-election hopes in next year's presidential poll: surveys suggest 80% of the French think Mr Chirac "should testify" if asked to, while 71% feel it is "not right" that the former mayor of Paris should be immune from prosecution as president.

A 1999 ruling by the constitutional council stated that a president could not be placed under formal investigation as long as he was in office, although experts disagree over whether the ruling applies to a summons to appear as a witness.

The president's RPR defenders accused judge Halphen of politically-motivated and illegal behaviour. "He knows very well that this kind of summons is unlawful and unconstitutional," said the party spokesman, Patrick Devedjian.

But a leading Green politician, Yves Contassot, said everybody knew that Mr Chirac would have to talk to the judges sooner or later, "so it's good news that a judge dared to challenge his refusal to testify. By refusing to talk, he looks like someone who's afraid to talk".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Summit ends without accord
fields.body:
Summit ends without accord

The Arab summit wrapped up yesterday without its leaders reaching a formal agreement on how to resolve the conflict between Iraq and Kuwait over the lifting of sanctions and the no-fly zones. They did, however, express discontent with the last-minute US veto of a resolution backing a UN observer force to help protect Palestinians.

AP, Amman

28 Algerians die in two attacks

Suspected Algerian rebels killed 15 people in a shantytown on Tuesday near Blida, 40 miles south-west of Algiers. The attack came two days after a family of 13 was killed near the same town.

Reuters, Blida

Asylum sought for lone wolf

Animal conservation groups in Norway have filed a political asylum request with Sweden on behalf of a wolf that Norwegian hunters are trying to kill. Norway ordered the 10 wolves in its pack killed because they were threatening livestock. The wolf is the only survivor.

AP, Oslo

fields.headline: 'I saw my friends blown apart'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A group of Israeli schoolchildren were drawn into a tragedy at a roadside stop called Peace Rendezvous yesterday when a suicide bomber sidled into their midst and blew himself up, killing two of the children and injuring four.
fields.body:
A group of Israeli schoolchildren were drawn into a tragedy at a roadside stop called Peace Rendezvous yesterday when a suicide bomber sidled into their midst and blew himself up, killing two of the children and injuring four.

After six months of the Palestinian uprising many people are numb in the face of almost daily casualties - but yesterday's attack stands out because the victims were children.

So were the victims on the other side of the confrontation yesterday.

In Rafah, on the border between the Gaza Strip and Egypt, a Palestinian child of nine was killed and three others - all under 12 - were injured when they played too close to an unexploded Israeli shell lying in one of the few bits of open ground in the squalid town of open sewers and refugee shanties.

People in Rafah said such injuries were becoming common, with soldiers from the adjoining Israeli army base regularly shelling houses that back on to the concrete blocks marking the border.

For the seven Israeli schoolboys yesterday there was no indication of danger when they assembled in a car park in central Israel just before 8am.

The Peace Rendezvous is a grand name for a petrol station and transport cafe flanked by palm trees, lying between the central Israeli city of Kfar Sava and the West Bank town of Qalqilya. The boys waited there every day for their school bus - an armoured vehicle in this case - because they leave their homes inside Israel to study at a religious seminary in Kedumim, a hardline Jewish settlement.

Moments before the explosion at least one of the pupils noticed a man in his late 20s, with black hair and a moustache, drawing near, his black leather jacket zipped up to the neck despite the heat wave.

"Suddenly an Arab came up to my friends. He looked suspicious. Then I heard an explosion," Rafael Zomer, 15, told Israel Radio. "I saw my friends blown apart."

The bomb, strapped to the extremist's body under his jacket, spewed nails and metal into the group, killing Naftali Landskoren, 14, and Eliran Rosenberg, 16. Doctors operated for several hours on one of the four wounded. Another boy was pierced in the eye.

The one boy unscathed was standing away from the others. "My friends were gathering at a corner of the gas station when the explosion happened. When I opened my eyes, I saw the ground was strewn with bodies and injured people," he said.

Within hours the armed wing of the Islamist militant group Hamas claimed responsibility for the bombing and said there were more horrors to come.

"The elite unit 103 returned to base safely after moving the martyr [bomber] to the place of the operation," said a caller to Reuters news agency. "There are still seven martyrs ready to strike."

This bombing - the third in 24 hours - brought a deepening sense of dread among Israelis that they and their children can never be safe while the Palestinian uprising goes on.

There was an inevitability about Israel's first response: to surround Qalqilya with soldiers and tanks and mount a helicopter search for a suspicious van seen speeding from the car park around the time of the explosion.

Meanwhile, the Palestinians had new sources of grievance against Israel's continued occupation of parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

In the Jenin area, at the northern reaches of the West Bank, an elderly Palestinian woman suffocated after inhaling tear gas from a cannister thrown into her home.

In Hebron extremist Jewish settlers from the 400-member enclave that festers in the heart of the Palestinian city of 120,000 went on the rampage for a second day, burning shops, homes and vehicles.

This bombing - the third in 24 hours - brought a deepening sense of dread among Israelis that they and their children can never be safe while the Palestinian uprising goes on. There was an inevitability about Israel's first response: to surround Qalqilya with soldiers and tanks and mount a helicopter search for a suspicious van seen speeding from the car park around the time of the explosion. In the Jenin area, at the northern reaches of the West Bank, an elderly Palestinian woman suffocated after inhaling tear gas from a cannister thrown into her home.
