fields.headline: Israelis blast Arafat's HQ
fields.standfirst:
'Last chance of peace gone' after two killed in attack by helicopter gunships as Sharon retaliates

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: 'Last chance of peace gone' after two killed in attack by helicopter gunships as Sharon retaliates.
fields.body:
Israeli army helicopters attacked the headquarters of Yasser Arafat's elite forces last night after a day when another suicide bomber claimed the lives of two teenagers.

Witnesses said helicopter gunships fired missiles on Gaza and the West Bank city of Ramallah, setting buildings and cars on fire, knocking out electricity and killing at least two Palestinians in Ramallah. Dozens were wounded.

One of the dead was a bodyguard to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. The other a civilian woman.

An adviser to Mr Arafat said the retaliatory strikes had destroyed the last chances of peace. "This is a dangerous escalation," Nabil Abu Rdainah, who was with Mr Arafat in the Jordanian capital, Amman, said. "We hold the Israeli government fully responsible."

A military spokesman told Israeli television that the helicopters had fired on six targets in the Gaza Strip, including installations of Mr Arafat's Force 17 in the Jabaliya refugee camp and a police installation in Deir al-Baleh in the south. In Ramallah, tanks and helicopters struck a single target, again a building of Force 17.

"Our task is to hit directly at the sources of fire," the spokesman said. Palestinian officials said the Israeli army had warned them to evacuate the headquarters of Mr Arafat's administration in Ramallah, signalling an imminent attack.

Last night's hour-long attacks were the physical expression of Mr Sharon's regular accusations against Force 17. He has repeatedly blamed the unit, and by implication Mr Arafat, for drive-by shootings of Jewish settlers, and the firing on their enclaves by Palestinian militants.

He also blamed Mr Arafat for the suicide mission that killed two schoolboys yesterday morning - which the armed wing of the Islamist militant organisation Hamas said it carried out - because his administration had freed many jailed bombers.

"To my sorrow, despite the fact that many in the world thought a new leader had arisen here, to my sorrow he [Arafat] has remained a leader of terror," Mr Sharon said yesterday in parliament, hours before ordering the attacks.

Last night's reprisal raids had been anticipated. Since a sniper's bullet killed a baby girl on Monday in the extremist Jewish enclave inside the West Bank city of Hebron, Mr Sharon has faced a growing clamour to retaliate swiftly and harshly against commanders of the Palestinian uprising.

The pressure increased with two bombings in Jerusalem on Tuesday, and yesterday morning's suicide attack in central Israel. The cry for revenge put Mr Sharon in a peculiar position: the hardliner with a 50-year history of dealing harshly with Israel's Arab neighbours was being accused of going soft since his installation as prime minister three weeks ago.

It also showed up his own helplessness in soothing Israelis' anxieties on security, the same fears that saw the former prime minister Ehud Barak trounced at the polls last month.

"Everyone who sees these things that have occurred over the course of 36 hours understands exactly what kind of situation we are in," Mr Sharon told Israel Radio earlier yesterday. Then he promised: "If our deterrence has been slightly eroded it will soon be fully restored."

Most analysts - and Mr Sharon's advisers, who claimed he could not be provoked into intemperate action - had predicted that he would hold off for the duration of an Arab summit in Jordan.

The meeting in Amman, at which the Palestinians sought to solidify regional support behind their six-month uprising, ended yesterday afternoon, and Mr Sharon wasted no time in exacting punishment. The helicopter gunships began clattering over Ramallah within minutes of the convening of an emergency meeting of his security cabinet, which was expected to chart Israel's next course of action in response to a surge in Palestinian attacks.

Mr Sharon is now expected to consider further measures. In opposition, he repeatedly opposed Mr Barak's policy of bombing raids on Palestinian police installations, denouncing them as ineffective.

But Mr Sharon will have to weigh his next steps carefully. For all of his efforts to implicate Mr Arafat directly in the bombing attacks inside the borders of the Jewish state, and the drive-by shootings that have terrified Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza, last night's missions remain extremely controversial in the international community, and Mr Sharon knows it.

In the morning, he held a telephone conversation with President George Bush, part of a broader strategy in which Israel is seeking diplomatic sanction for a resort to greater military might to try to end the uprising.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Rosie Millard

fields.headline: No 1849
fields.standfirst: Rosie Millard
fields.trailText: Rosie Millard.
fields.body:
Cor! Who's that fit bird, then? About time the Guardian introduced page 3 girls. Busty Rosie, 35, loves glamorous parties and mixing with celebs. In her spare time she's the arts correspondent for the BBC.

BBC correspondent? Things have certainly changed since the days of Richard Baker. Does Ms Millard often wear such revealing outfits? Only on very important occasions. Aside from this daring £800 Vivienne Westwood number she wore to the Oscars this week, she has previously appeared on our screens in a daring little bustier.

Have her fellow Auntie co-workers encouraged Ms Millard's fashion statements? They've been a little less supportive than her dress was. Michael Buerk, conservative man that he is, smirked on the 10 o'clock news after Rosie's report, "That was Rosie Millard in the best-supporting dress." Rosie, good sport that she is, laughed off the remark: "He's always teasing me."

Those BBC correspondents, what wags they are. I hope others have been more appreciative. They certainly have. Elizabeth Hurley, no stranger to a bit of cleavage herself, once commented on Rosie's embonpoint, "I couldn't help noticing that woman ... doesn't she have wonderful breasts?" Millard is also the subject of a devoted website, extolling her as "curvaceous, demure and ultimately very sexy".

Any other admirers? Actually, it was thanks to that dress that Rosie got her report done at all. Elton John doesn't normally allow press into the party but, Rosie recounted: "They looked at me in that striking dress and just waved me through." And who can blame them?

So you see, it was all in the name of duty. And rather timely to. After all, it is National Cleavage Day tomorrow.

Mind you, I've never seen Barry Norman in a revealing little number at the Oscars ... Let's not even think about it.

Not to be confused with: Jordan.

Who's Jordan? Never mind.

fields.headline: Season's greetings
fields.standfirst: Crook, Weardale
fields.trailText: Crook, Weardale.
fields.body:
Once the fuse of spring has been lit by the gradual lengthening of the days, the outcome is inevitable. Little by little winter's grip is slipping. There's a tinge of green in the hawthorn hedges. Bluebells are spearing through last year's dead leaves. Frogs have produced spawn, although on most mornings recently it's been covered by a film of ice.

Somewhere close by - I'm not sure where - our local pair of mistle thrushes must already be nesting. Every morning they visit the holly to feed on the remains of last year's berry crop, defending it against redwings trying to fuel up for their migration back to Scandinavia. This much can be seen without venturing out into the countryside, but there is a terrible frustration in being unable to follow footpaths, to visit those places where familiar totems of spring appear. They have a visceral significance, way beyond any calendar date that might announce an arbitrary first day of spring. At this time of year we would follow a sunken lane in Weardale that leads to pastures on the edge of a wood, where hares chase across the skyline as the light fades.

Or we might follow the footpath along the River Wear, hunting for the first yellow Star of Bethlehem flowers amongst the celandines. Or perhaps head out across pastures in upper Weardale to take a look at this year's display of green hellebores.

Usually the most difficult decision is where to go first. I suppose you could call it territorial behaviour, checking the boundaries of the home patch, to see if everything is as it should be at this time of the year. Which, of course, it isn't. We can only keep away, watch from a distance, wait until next year for those reassuring signs of renewal.

webTitle: G2: Portrait of the real Cracker

fields.headline: The real Cracker
fields.standfirst: Dr Richard Badcock delves into the details of the nastiest, most violent crimes and comes up with psychological profiles of the offenders.  Stephen Cook  asks, does he remind you of someone?
fields.trailText: Dr Richard Badcock delves into the details of the nastiest, most violent crimes and comes up with psychological profiles of the offenders. Stephen Cook asks, does he remind you of someone?
fields.body:
The scene is St Aidan's church hall on the outskirts of Doncaster: strip lighting, yellowing pillars, frightful curtains. But there's a beautiful sprung wooden floor, and on it 25 men and women in dancing pumps are shaping up for a Strathspey. "You're going to set twice, then dance half rights and lefts," calls the instructor.

An accordion lurches into a tune called Hame Came Our Good Man, and the dancers smile and bow and launch themselves into the complex, elegant formations. Their ages range from 30 to more than 70, their figures from lean to frankly tubby. Three of the men wear kilts and sporrans, the most splendid of which belongs to Dr Richard Badcock, clinical psychiatrist and offender profiler.

"I do my best for an unfit middle-aged man," he says afterwards, panting slightly. "The whole purpose is to mix and mingle socially and to get the kind of physical exertion which clears the mind completely."

To understand why he needs to clear his mind we must rewind to a normal working day. Badcock is standing outside a high-security prison talking into a mobile phone after a visit to a dangerous remand prisoner. He is reporting back to one of England's three special hospitals, where he helps to treat some of the country's most violent and dangerous patients. For a moment, untypically, he slips into street language. "I've just seen this guy and he's a total whacko," he shouts above the traffic. "He scares the shit out of me, I can tell you."

Back at the hospital, the more characteristic side of Badcock comes to the fore as he sits with a young man whose problem is that he keeps getting into fights. Badcock talks to him in an easy, neutral voice: "Now, we've had some treatments focusing on that psychologically, and I want to talk through a lot of issues with you and to put you on some different tablets. Do you feel mentally prepared to cope with that, and with life on a different ward?" The patient mumbles a reply, hands clasped between his knees and head bowed.

That is the day job. By night, Badcock is often busy on something related, but more extreme: he goes up to his study, settles at his desk, and pores over documents from the latest cases with which he is helping police - cases in which aggression has spilled over into murder, rape and unspeakable deeds. The documents include photographs of the kind sometimes shown to juries at the start of criminal trials. Photos which make them wince and turn away.

As one of the country's foremost offender profilers, Badcock is a real life version of Fitz, the character played by Robbie Coltrane in the television drama Cracker. But while Fitz was a testy genius flawed by gambling and alcohol, Badcock is a mild-mannered, almost Dickensian figure with a ready laugh and a surprisingly cherubic smile. He often wears a bow tie and a flower in his buttonhole, and his penchant for quotations from Socrates or William of Occam has been known to leave policemen looking a little blank.

Cracker was broadcast just after Badcock began profiling work, and he enjoyed it. But he says it gave a misleading impression of profiling work to police officers as well as the public, and he and his colleagues have been trying to correct it ever since. "It was right, though, in saying that intuition plays an important part in developing knowledge of a case," he says. "The only thing is that it must be trained intuition."

As well as studying the documents and photographs, he has briefings with police officers, visits the scene of the crime, and usually re-enacts the crime in the attempt to get inside the mind of the offender: policemen tend to get embarrassed as he lies down in a field or rehearses the swing of the arm which held the murder weapon. He then offers the police his insights about what kind of person might have done it: his age, job, family situation, psychosexual makeup, likely history of offending, and probable future behaviour.

But it's an article of faith with him that the senior officers on any case can take or leave any information he offers them and all decisions must be made by police officers. And he is adamant that a profile should never be treated as evidence: "If they say to me, 'Well, Joe Bloggs fits this profile exactly, surely that means he's it?' I say 'No, it doesn't, because you don't know whether Fred Smith two doors down the road isn't exactly the same - and totally innocent as well.'

"Profiling is not about identifying individuals. It's about identifying characteristics of the offenders from the offences. If you've got a list of suspects, then the profile is quite useful in prioritising the investigation, but there has to be real evidence as well."

His approach to profiling is hard to define, because it treats each case as unique and draws on reasoning, experience and intuition: "It's a bit like intelligence - everybody knows what you mean, but if you try and define it, it's actually quite difficult."

Just how useful his insights are is a moot point. The limited research into offender profiling indicates that there are very few cases where the profiler produces the kind of blinding, Crackeresque insights which lead straight to the criminal. But it also shows that investigating officers like to have an intelligent outsider to share ideas with, and that a profile can reduce the suspect list and help with arrest and interviewing strategy. Nowadays profilers are used in most serious crimes where there's no obvious suspect within 48 hours.

Among cases Badcock has dealt with are the rape and murder of a young legal assistant, Yvonne Killian, in south London in 1998, and the murder of Dr Joan Francisco in 1994. Currently he is working on a murder, an attempted murder and a suspicious death.

Such a life means constant exposure to destruction and depravity for Badcock and the 20 other profilers used regularly by English police forces. Badcock has been doing it for eight years, and it has turned him into a vegetarian: "The last thing I want is more destruction on my plate." It has also made him very conscious of the need to leaven his life with other activities. "It' s a bit like what Nietzsche said about looking into the abyss," he says. "It has an effect on you - not so much depressing as isolating, because it somehow separates you from your own humanity."

So if you ring him at the weekend he is likely to be up on the roof repairing the slates or at his woodworking bench. His greatest achievement so far is building and glazing a conservatory made of African mahogany. Try him on a Monday evening and he won't be at home: that's when he and his wife, Christine, are out doing jigs and reels in Doncaster.

It plays a big part in the cheerfulness and good nature Badcock exudes. The shadows are still there, however: back at the church hall, his forehead sprouting sweat after a vigorous jig, he reaches into his sporran, a propos of nothing, and brings out a silver Greek coin. It is part of his collection of items of religious and philosophical significance and he fingers it meditatively: "This was minted at the time Socrates was about to drink his hemlock - makes you think, doesn't it?"

 Richard Badcock is featured in The Real Cracker on Channel 4 at 9pm tonight. The Real Cracker, by Stephen Cook, is published by Channel 4 Books, £14.99.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week to the address below. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

D1 Norman Wisdom films were once the only Western movies allowed in

(a) Albania.

(b) Iran.

(c) Pakistan.

(d) Morecambe.

D2 Who was once called "the Norman Wisdom of Western democracy"?

(a) Ronald Reagan.

(b) John Major.

(c) Norman Wisdom.

(d) George Dubbya Bush.

D3 Wisdom's catchphrase is

(a) Oops! I've fallen over... Again!

(b) Mr Grimsdale!

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Changing Places | In Conversation With... | Old Harry's Game
fields.body:
If you are searching for the cluster of houses recently built near the Nottinghamshire village of Hockerton you're likely to see no more than a hummock in a field. As Howard Stableford discovers in Changing Places (4.0pm, Radio 4), Nick White and his neighbours have put the greater part of their homes underground. This lets them maintain a comfortable inside temperature without artificial heating. Getting their hot water through solar power has also saved them another £1,000 a year.

Ray Galton was given six weeks to live when he was admitted as a priority case to a tuberculosis sanatorium. Alan Simpson arrived 18 months later, and their joint boredom led them to write comedy scripts for the hospital's internal radio. Paul Jackson helps them recall the story for In Conversation With... (6.30pm, Radio 4). Inspiration vanished after four episodes, so they wrote to Frank Muir and Denis Norden asking for tips. The professionals' response led them into a script-writing career which generated 600 radio and television shows, including Hancock's Half Hour and Steptoe And Son.

Andy Hamilton, playing the Devil, launches a new series of his patchy sitcom Old Harry's Game (11.0pm, Radio 4). This first episode is lively enough, with plenty of neat one-liners about life in Hell. But will the standard decline as quickly and disappointingly as it did in earlier series?

fields.headline: Family fortunes
fields.trailText: The Sound Of Music Children | The Hunt |
fields.body:
I wonder if The Sound Of Music Children (ITV) know the Harrow school song. Probably not, poor loves, being American.

Forty years on when afar and
asunder
Parted are those who are singing today
When we look back and
regretfully wonder
What we were like in our work
and our play.

Thirty-five years on, to be precise, an ingenious producer, Judith Holder, rounded up the seven people who played the Von Trapp children in The Sound Of Music and took them back to Salzburg. (Incidentally, the most successful movie of all time only ran for three days in Salzburg. Austria did not like its politics. Fancy.)

The articulate Nicholas Hammond, who played Friedrich, retold the extraordinary story of how The Sound Of Music saved the day when the grossly overweight Cleopatra bankrupted Twentieth Century Fox. "The sheriffs had locked the front gates and the studio was in receivership. Darryl Zanuck went to the courts and said 'Give me six months!'" It must have been, you feel, a palpitating performance. They gave him six months, and he raised enough money for three cheap movies or one big one.

Now Zanuck, like all movie moguls and, indeed, like the present owner of Twentieth Century Fox, Rupert Murdoch, was a riverboat gambler at heart. He risked everything on one throw. It was the 60s, a time of kitchen-sink realism, but he put his shirt on an apple-strudel musical about whiskers on kittens and won. Zanuck was a man, as Wodehouse once put it, at whose name even the blood-sucking leeches of the Inland Revenue were accustomed to raise their filthy hats.

The moment The Sound Of Music strikes up, you feel your intestines being pulled out in handfuls and hurled high in the air. It seems to appeal to the bowels. One way or another.

Future viewers of the film, probably on television, can now watch with informed interest as Friedrich grows six inches, monitor the precarious state of Marta's milk teeth and cheer as Liesl dances "I am sixteen going on seventeen" with a sprained ankle. (Wardrobe having failed to put rubber on her shoes, she shot straight though the plate glass of the gazebo.) The children were paid very little. Julie Andrews advised Charmian Carr, who played Liesl, "Buy a mink coat. It's the best investment you can make." She should have talked to Zanuck instead.

It does not surprise you in the least that The Sound Of Music is Michael Jackson's favourite film. He chose Charmian to decorate his houses, specifying 17 mannequins for his bedroom, 11 of them children of various ages. This part of her interview did not make it into the film. That does not surprise you either.

The Sound Of Music is essentially Snow White And The Seven Dwarfs. Both Nicholas and Charmian, who are discreetly devoted to each other, feel they were somehow fooled by the fairy story. She said, "I thought I would be married forever. I thought I would always be happy. At times it's upsetting to know that the ideal family doesn't exist. I wish I would have been more prepared for the bad times."

And so, in a touching double exposure, seven shouting carefree children rushed at the camera while their real selves stood stilly by.

As The Hunt (ITV) galloped haphazardly off into the sunset, I was poignantly reminded of an old Hancock's Half Hour, lightly based on The Archers, that went something like this. "Look, the whole village be coming across the field. The Honourable Hugh doing up 'is zip, a flock of his floozies, that mad old bat, Lady Diana, the gay vet, the fat German banker and assorted yokels from the locals." "They'd better watch out for they old mine workings." (Startled cries, then silence) "Oh, dear they've all fallen down an 'ole. Never mind."

Anyone care to say a few words over the departed? No? Right, let's get down the pub then.

"He was a scumbag. He's always been a scumbag. His brother was a scumbag. He probably comes from a long line of scumbags. One scumbag shoots another scumbag. What you got? One less scumbag." Is this

(a) Ian Beale on Who Shot Phil Mitchell (BBC 1)

(b) Almost anybody on Reggie Kray - The Final Word (BBC 1)?

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Guilty By Suspicion | Peggy Sue Got Married | Soapdish
fields.body:
Films

Guilty By Suspicion
(Irwin Winkler, 1991)
12midnight, Sky Cinema

Winkler was better known as a producer, with Robert Chartoff, of hefty films from Point Blank to Raging Bull. His directorial debut is a decently crafted story of Hollywood witchhunts in the 50s, when the HUAC suspected a red under every bed. Good on the feel and fear of the times, with Robert De Niro a director blacklisted after admitting having attended a few Communist meetings in his youth, Annette Bening outstanding as the ex-wife he can lean on.

Peggy Sue Got Married
(Francis Coppola, 1986)
1am, Carlton Cinema

Kathleen Turner is captivating in this testing dual role: first as a fortyish wife unhappy with her lot in general, and dud spouse Nicolas Cage in particular; then, having fainted at a high-school reunion, returning to the fresh-faced picture of near innocence she was, circa 1960. Given the opportunity of a second time around, she makes out with the lad she admired from afar, helps Dad out of financial trouble, and addresses the problem of the slick-haired teenage rebel who will become her husband: a charming, wistful comedy.

Dangerous Beauty
(Marshall Herskovitz, 1998)
1.50am, Sky Premier

This tale of a 16th-century Venetian courtesan is handsomely staged and engrossing, if a less assured US shot at costume drama than Michael Hoffman's Restoration. It stars Catherine McCormack - Mel Gibson's love in Braveheart - as Veronica Franco who, too lowly to marry her aristocratic love Marco (Rufus Sewell), instead learns the wiles of the courtesan from her mother (Jacqueline Bisset) and takes Venice by storm. Pestilence and the arrival of the Catholic inquisitors sharpen up the action.

Soapdish
(Michael Hoffman, 1991)
3.45am, Sky Premier

This farcical tale of the inner workings of a TV soap series is done with rampant good humour. Sally Fields plays the ageing star of The Sun Also Sets; jealous co-star Cathy Moriarty and producer Robert Downey Jr hatch a plot to drive her out by reinstating her hated ex-lover (Kevin Kline), who was written out years before, decapitated in a car crash. How to bring him back to life is only one of head writer Whoopi Goldberg's problems, as the actors' real-life squabbles start to take over the soap's script. Good anarchic fun, and, when Kline as the poor woman's matinee idol is around, hilarious.

Documentary

Grey Gardens
9pm, BBC Knowledge

The sad, funny, disturbing story of Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter Edie, the downwardly mobile aunt and first cousin of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Mother and daughter live like a couple of ageing bag ladies in a world of their own in a filthy, decaying 28-room East Hampton mansion. They bicker about suitors from 30 years earlier, sing half-remembered songs and flirt with handymen like characters out of Tennessee Williams. Old Edie is an ill-tempered battleaxe reliving injustices inflicted years ago, while young Edie clings to fading hopes that her big chance and big romance are just around the corner.

fields.headline: Bones of a theory
fields.standfirst: Does thes the variety of salamanders add to our knowledge of evolution? Henry Gee says that fossils are adding to the pool
fields.trailText: Does thes the variety of salamanders add to our knowledge of evolution? Henry Gee says that fossils are adding to the pool
fields.body:
Spring is sprung, believe it or not, and the thoughts of those interested in the mysteries of generation turn to their garden ponds, where frogs court, spawn and produce tadpoles - their remarkable, gill-breathing larval stages. For centuries, scientists have sought to unlock the secrets of generation from pondlife.

The great 18th century microscopist Spallanzani studied tadpoles to learn about evolution, in the strict sense of "unfolding" or "development". Like many scientists of his day, Spallanzani thought that all features of the embryo arrived preformed, either in the sperm or the egg - there was great debate between the opposing schools of "animalculists" (who supported sperm) and "ovists" (the league of egg men.) Some preformationists thought that the "germs" of animals nested one inside the other, each waiting its turn to be born, like an infinite regression of Russian dolls.

A confirmed egg man himself, Spallanzani declared in 1768 that he had seen the form of a tadpole inside the egg of a frog even before the male arrived to fertilise it. It took a few more decades, and the arrival of "nature philosophers" such as Goethe, to put the idea of preformation to a deserved death, and for the word "evolution" to acquire the meaning it has today. Although Charles Darwin, did not use the word "evolution" in this sense in the Origin of Species, preferring the less ambiguous term "descent with modification", he accorded ponds a special place as perhaps the primary habitat of all life.

He speculated that the ultimate ancestor of all living creatures received the vital spark in some "warm little pond". Such warm ponds can still have things to say about evolution. In a corner of what is now China, one pond, no bigger than an average garden ornamentation, squirmed with at least two sorts of salamander, both adults and larvae, when around 150 million years ago it was suddenly filled with hot ash from the eruption of a nearby volcano.

The animals, far from living up to their alchemical reputations as creatures sustained by fire, perished in a salamandrine Pompeii. Excavated today, the pond has produced more than 500 of the oldest known salaman der skeletons found anywhere in the world. Ke-Qin Gao of the American Museum of Natural History, New York, and Neil Shubin of the University of Chicago describe the fossils in today's Nature. The first lesson to be learned from the Chinese salamanders is that, unlike frogs, they have changed very little in their general form for hundreds of millions of years.

Also preserved in the Chinese fossil assemblage is their tendency towards neoteny. That is, some species of salamander become sexually mature while still in the aquatic, larval state. A good example of this is the axolotl salamander from Mexico that can breed quite happily without ever becoming fully adult (Spallanzani would have gone into transports of preformational delight). Other salamanders, however, such as the our own native newts, turn into fully air-breathing adults and shed their gills. Gao and Shubin reveal both kinds of salamander in their fossil pond.

One kind, Sinerpeton fengshanensis, was like an axolotl in that it had the fully-formed bones of an adult as well as bony supports for external gills - there are even faint traces of the delicate, feathery gills themselves. Another salamander, Laccotriton subsolanus, seems to have developed fully into the adult state. The sheer number of specimens in the Chinese pond will give scope for researchers to study another peculiarity of salamanders - their capacity for variation.

Shubin is one of a band of researchers interested in the question of whether variation between individuals in the same species can reveal anything about the evolutionary process as a whole. The Chinese fossils could add the important extra dimension of time. Shubin and others have shown that salamanders can vary hugely in the numbers of bones individual animals have in their limbs - even when the salamanders concerned belong to the same or closely related species. This line of study is important because variation is the essential substrate for evolution.

Without variation, natural selection would have nothing to select and evolution would stop. This begs the question of what generates variation. Darwin died before a mechanism for the generation of variation had been discovered - as a result, natural selection fell from favour in the years immediately following his death. It reached its nadir in the 1890s when English biologist William Bateson penned a huge and, at the time, quixotic tome called Materials for the Study of Variation , whose aim was to enumerate and classify all the different kinds of natural variation in the hope of shedding light on its source. A few years later, however, the answer came in the form of genetics - a word coined by Bateson.

In a sense, the possession of genes, collected into an entity called the genome, suggests that preformationists such as Spallanzani were at least partly right. The black spot in the centre of a frog's egg, before the sperm arrives, is not a preformed tadpole waiting for the spark of maleness to set it in motion. It does, however, contain the genome of the mother frog, inherited from her mother, and in turn from a heritage of frogs, frog ancestors, fish ancestors and vertebrate ancestors, all the way back to that warm little pond of which Darwin dreamed. It also realised - if only poetically - the slogan attributed to the great 16th century physician William Harvey: "Ex Ovo, Omnia": Everything comes from the egg.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature. His book Deep Time: Cladistics, the Revolution in Evolution is out in paperback, from Fourth Estate.

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: The cat that walks by itself | Polly wants a backpacker
fields.body:
Caught in the web of intrigue
Spider silk is a viscoelastic construction material evolved over 400 million years to arrest aerial missiles. Cocoon silk evolved to keep insects cosy. So the first has highly specialised properties that the second has not. Weight for weight, spider dragline silk is far stronger than high tensile engineering steel, say Fritz Vollrath and David Knight of Oxford in today's Nature. Strictly speaking, manmade Kevlar - used for bulletproof vests - is three times stronger, but spider silk is eight times more extendible and therefore, they say, five times tougher. This means tomorrow's GM silk will owe something to an eight-legged factory that spins at ambient temperatures, low pressures and with water as a solvent. And the output can all be recycled.

The cat that walks by itself
Cheetahs are solitary animals living at a density of one per six square kilometres, according to Roger Santer in the April issue of The Biologist. There are two populations in Africa and a few Asian cats in Iran and Afghanistan. But things look bad: 70% of captive cheetah spermatazoa are abnormal, and South African cheetah DNA shows up to 100 times less variation than other mammalian species - as if the species all but perished once before, leaving a few survivors to found the present population. Captive breeding has not been a success, although reintroduction has. Even so, the world's swiftest predator could still lose the race to survive.

Polly wants a backpacker
Forced into the southern Alps, New Zealand's thuggish mountain-dwelling parrot, the kea (Nestor notabilis) has evolved "a very humanlike flexibility and intelligence," say National Geographic Society researchers. Only about 3,000 of the birds remain. The kea is the only psittacine with a known appetite for sheep, and one of the few animal species that continues to investigate new food possibilities into adulthood - by chewing at cars and even bicycles.
fields.bodyText: Caught in the web of intrigue Spider silk is a viscoelastic construction material evolved over 400 million years to arrest aerial missiles. Cocoon silk evolved to keep insects cosy. So the first has highly specialised properties that the second has not. Weight for weight, spider dragline silk is far stronger than high tensile engineering steel, say Fritz Vollrath and David Knight of Oxford in today's Nature. Strictly speaking, manmade Kevlar - used for bulletproof vests - is three times stronger, but spider silk is eight times more extendible and therefore, they say, five times tougher. This means tomorrow's GM silk will owe something to an eight-legged factory that spins at ambient temperatures, low pressures and with water as a solvent. And the output can all be recycled. The cat that walks by itself Cheetahs are solitary animals living at a density of one per six square kilometres, according to Roger Santer in the April issue of The Biologist. There are two populations in Africa and a few Asian cats in Iran and Afghanistan. But things look bad: 70% of captive cheetah spermatazoa are abnormal, and South African cheetah DNA shows up to 100 times less variation than other mammalian species - as if the species all but perished once before, leaving a few survivors to found the present population. Captive breeding has not been a success, although reintroduction has. Even so, the world's swiftest predator could still lose the race to survive. Only about 3,000 of the birds remain. The kea is the only psittacine with a known appetite for sheep, and one of the few animal species that continues to investigate new food possibilities into adulthood - by chewing at cars and even bicycles.

fields.headline: Fruit fly genetics
fields.standfirst: Martin Brookes on how a Russian-born biologist took the ordinary fruit fly, fused Darwin with genetics and created history
fields.trailText: Martin Brookes on how a Russian-born biologist took the ordinary fruit fly, fused Darwin with genetics and created history
fields.body:
B iologists, like belly buttons, tend to fall into one of two categories, "innies" or "outies". Innies spend their entire working lives indoors. They are most comfortable sitting at the computer or laboratory bench and develop acute migraines when exposed to direct sunlight. To this group belong the biochemists, molecular biologists, geneticists and mathematical modellers.

By contrast, outies are laboratory illiterate. They understand how to open the fridge door but that is as far as their indoor knowledge extends. None of this matters to an outie, of course. Outies are more interested in devoting all their energy to prodigious beard growth and memorising the Latin names of a thousand different bird species.

Occasionally, however, you come across a third category of biologist, someone who is neither an innie, nor an outie, but an "in-betweenie". These are the rare individuals who feel equally at home in both artificial and natural light, people who can distinguish Petri dishes from pelicans, and can somehow manage to incorporate both into a single experiment.

Perhaps the first and certainly the greatest example of an in-betweenie was Russian-born biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky. He showed what could be achieved when white coats were combined with wellingtons. Back in the 1930s, he began dusting down Darwinian evolution to leave it looking modern, shiny and new.

In the early decades of the 20th century, with Darwin dead and Mendel on their minds, scientists were creating an entirely new way of looking at evolution. Instead of thinking about populations of plants and animals as collections of individuals, biologists like Dobzhansky began thinking exclusively in terms of genes and gene pools. As good as Darwin's evolutionary argument was, it had always lacked direct experimental evidence. By combining the fledgling science of genetics with Darwinian evolution, Dobzhansky gave Darwin's ideas the empirical kick up the backside they had been crying out for.

But Dobzhansky's success was no solo affair. He would have got nowhere without his insect comrade, the fruit fly, Drosophila pseudoobscura. His choice of experimental organism may have seemed unusual. After all, Dobzhansky's tiny fruit flies were hardly a match for Darwin's finches, or so it seemed. But Dobzhansky chose wisely. By the 1930s, fruit flies had already proved themselves as pioneers in genetics research. They were cheap, prolific and easy to breed. They also had the biggest chromosomes that anyone had ever seen.

Fruit flies, like footballers, produce immense quantities of saliva. The chromosomes inside the fruit fly's salivary glands are huge - a thousand times thicker than normal. Each chromosome is like a packet of spaghetti, made up of many parallel strands of DNA that have failed to separate. Chemical staining of these super-sized chromosomes reveals dark horizontal bands along their length, distinct landmarks corresponding to the positions of specific genes. When these chromosomes were first discovered in the 1930s, it was as revolutionary as the discovery of genetic fingerprints fifty years later. These super-sized chromosomes were like biological barcodes that gave biologists the first direct glimpse of genetic differences between individuals and populations.

To Dobzhansky, the fruit fly chromosomes were a godsend and he spent years in the Californian wilderness collecting flies for analysis in the laboratory. His first discovery was that populations of flies living in different areas could be distinguished by the banding patterns of their chromosomes. In other words, populations were not genetically uniform, but differed from place to place. This may sound like common sense today and, even back then, it was what many biologists had suspected but it was the first time that anyone had provided the experimental proof. Yet more amazing was the discovery that these genetic differences were not static, but could change over remarkably short time scales. In the struggle for existence, natural selection favoured different chromosome types at different times of the year. These results were epoch-making for evolutionary biology. Because Darwinian natural selection had traditionally been considered a slow paced affair that was difficult - if not impossible - to test experimentally, critics had often dismissed the subject as unscientific. But here was a perfect demonstration of evolution in action. This was no million-year wait for a two millimetre increase in the length of a leg bone. This was evolutionary change in front of your very eyes.

In accumulating genetic differences, Dobzhansky saw how two populations might also accumulate differences in body size, colour, genital architecture, behavioural idiosyncrasies, and a thousand other characteristics that could eventually make them reluctant or unable to mate with one another. In these distinct genetic profiles, Dobzhansky believed he was seeing the origin of species in its infancy.

Dobzhansky had shown what was possible when scientists were willing to abandon their prejudices and break with tradition. His experiments with the fly brought about a sea change in evolutionary attitudes. Fruit fly genetics made evolution and the origin of species more credible to a once sceptical scientific community. Genetics not only tightened up Darwin's theory, it also turned evolutionary biology into a rigorous experimental science. Darwin would have given anything for a share of Dobzhansky's experimental spoils. Serves him right for looking at finches rather than flies.

 Fly: An Experimental Life, by Martin Brookes, is published by Weidenfeld & Nicholson, £16.99.

fields.headline: Computing made easy
fields.standfirst: Stelios Haji-Ioannou is founder of EasyGroup, which includes the EasyEverything chain of worldwide internet cafes
fields.trailText: Stelios Haji-Ioannou is founder of EasyGroup, which includes the EasyEverything chain of worldwide internet cafes
fields.body:
What made you think that internet cafes would be a sustainable business model? My experience from EasyJet was if you take a product or service and make it significantly cheaper than the competitors a lot more people will use it. In the case of internet cafes, there were a series of owner-managed, small and nerdy cafes that were charging a high price but not offering a good service. I thought if I could scale up the business, instead of keeping it a cottage industry, then we could charge less and offer a better service. Most business people make the mistake of assuming that everyone in the world has a computer and internet access, whereas I found out that there are plenty of people who don't.

What's the general demographic of EasyEverything users? In London, half the users are travellers, although not necessarily tourists. The other half are locals who either don't have internet access or, interestingly, already have access but come into the shops for social reasons.

What was your first encounter with computers? At the London School of Economics in the mid-80s I took my first lesson in computing. I then bought my first Amstrad, which was non-IBM compatible. I realised fairly quickly what a powerful tool it was. I moved on to an 8086 machine with floppy disk only - if you pulled the plug out then you lost all your work! All my companies now are highly reliant on computers. I've moved all the email systems of my companies on to the web. I don't need any hardware or paper and I can log in and access my email from anywhere. I actually use our shops for that too. The one thing I've moved away from is using a laptop.

What technology do visitors to your net cafes have? We use flat-panel screens and each shop has about 8MB of fibre-optic line which gives you an experience that is unaffordable from home. We're fitting shops in London with webcams, phones and Microsoft Office 2001.

Can the dot.com world still make money? There's no substitute for a good business plan, strong management and good execution. The internet is only a tool and if the business is not good enough then the net won't help you. For a while, anyone who claimed to use the net seemed able to raise money, but now the emphasis is back where it should be on the business itself. For a year the normal rules of business were suspended and everybody thought you could keep on losing money indefinitely. The internet is an amazingly powerful tool, though. My airline is using it for 85% of its sales and my car rental company uses it 100%.

Any favourite websites? I book my air-travel and buy CDs online. Other than my own companies' sites I tend to end up on Yahoo Finance for stocks etc. I also visit the BBC and Financial Times sites often.

Visit: www.easyeverything.com/

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
US backward?
Online reported last week: "Sweden scores highly in the Information Society Index (ISI) because of the number of telephone lines and mobile phones in use".

Why is mobile phone use taken as such a yardstick given that the US, especially, is a spectacular exception to such "rules"?

Mobile phone use in the US is less than that in other advanced countries because the regulatory authority decided that a call from a fixed line to a mobile should be paid for by the mobile user. In Europe, it is the person initiating the call who pays. In other words, initially at least, in Europe fixed line users subsidised the mobile phone industry but Americans made a conscious decision for that not to happen. You can argue the pros and cons of that but to condemn the Americans as less advanced for doing what they did is simply ridiculous.

The implication is that people "must" have mobiles to be considered advanced. The use of such criteria at least calls into question the entire basis of the ISI and at worst invalidates it entirely.

Declaration of interest: I have never had a mobile phone and hope it will be a long time indeed before I do.
Frank Desmond
frank.d@ireland.com

Go slow
Living in an ADSL trial area since 1998, I expected that it would be easy for me to move to Openworld. BT was happy to accept my order, but for four months "administrative procedures" have prevented its execution. The trial failed a couple of months ago and as far as BT is concerned that's that. Far from making my business go 40 times faster, (see the ad on page 6 of last week's Online), this is more likely to bring it to a halt. Stephen Cole
ascott.allotments@ btinternet.com

Missing credit
The supplement in this week's Online was interesting for more than just its content - though its devotion to NTL was obvious. "Get the web you want" - but with NTL. However, there were no credits other than for the photographs, so who wrote it? I think we should be told... Christine Findlay
robanddinah@btinternet.com

Online replies: The NTL supplement was paid for by NTL and produced without any input from the Online team. This, with hindsight, should have been made clearer. Apologies for any confusion.

Still swapping
With reference to Napster alternatives (Online, March 22), my experience has been the complete opposite to the author's.

Napster is still usable, but I now use Bearshare and File Navigator instead as I have found them to be better.

To get the best out of Bearshare, you really do need to read the instructions. With Bearshare, it is necessary to wait until you have connected to a few stable hosts before searches can be effective.

It is possible to select more than one file for download at the same time. Files can be selected in the same way as with Windows Explorer, by pressing the CTRL key and then selecting as many files for download as you want.

The alternative is to use the shift key and select a whole block, then click the right mouse button and select "download". All of your selections will be sent to the download page at the same time. Just wait until one of these files starts to download and delete the rest. You will find that this tip vastly improves effectiveness.
Jeff Heslop
jeff.heslop@lineone.net

Robo taxed
So, if I plug a keyboard into RoboDog, I can do my tax returns on it (Online, March 22)? Excellent! Now, into which orifice is the keyboard plug inserted? Antony Hawkins
a.d.hawkins@shef.ac.uk

fields.headline: Outlook Express mail
fields.trailText: Start here...
fields.body:
Today, many people start using electronic mail through their web browser (Start here, March 14). However, email is much older than the web. Tens of millions of people still use proprietary mail services that do not follow internet standards, such as America Online's AOL Mail. Many more millions use dedicated email software such as Eudora, though by far the most common system now is Microsoft's Outlook Express.

The disadvantage with web-based mail services such as Microsoft's Hotmail is that users tend to stay online while they read and reply to letters. This can take hours. It can also result in high telephone charges for time online. Of course, you can write mail offline, in a word processor, then copy and paste it into a message window, but not many people do.

Dedicated email software works in a different way: it collects letters in batches from a mailbox.

The mailbox is an electronic pigeonhole on a central computer called a server. When someone sends you email, that is where it is stored. Your email software connects to the mail server, downloads messages to your personal computer, and puts them into an inbox.

You can either trigger a mail collection manually, or set your mail software to dial up at regular intervals. When mail arrives, you can read and reply to it offline (while not connected to the internet). Because your mail is on your computer, you can keep as much as you like, and take back-up copies for security.

Email software provides other features that allow you to take control of your mail. For example, you should be able to set up "filters" or "rules" that treat certain types of mail in different ways. You could have mail from your boss downloaded into a separate folder, for example. You could also have any email that includes an attachment above a certain size (500K is reasonable) deleted automatically.

Mail servers use two standard internet protocols: POP3 and SMTP. POP3 (Post Office Protocol) is used for storing email and enabling you to collect it. The server uses SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) to send email to other servers. You need to know the addresses for both. Your ISP (internet service provider) usually tells you what they are, but they are often easy to guess.

Examples of POP3 addresses include pop3. btclick.com , pop.freeserve. net , and pop.mail.yahoo.com .

To set up a service in Outlook Express 5, go to the Tools menu, select Accounts, and click on the tab marked Mail. Next click the button at the top right, marked Add, and select Mail from the pop-up menu. After that, the wizard will take you through the process.

Step one: type in the name you want shown, and click Next. Step two: type or paste in your email address on the service you want to use (joe.bloggs@btclick. com) and click Next. Step three: type or paste in the POP3 and SMTP addresses for incoming ( pop3.btclick.com ) and outgoing ( smtp.btclick. com ) mail and click Next. Step four: type in your account name and password, and click Next.

If you have done everything right, you have now set up a POP3 account, so click Finish and close the tabbed dialogue box. You can now send and receive messages.

To write a letter, click on the New Mail icon, or press Ctrl-N.

If you already have other email services installed, such as Hotmail, you can select the new one from the drop-down menu at the right hand end of the From: line.

When you have finished, press Alt-S to save the message in your Outbox, ready for sending.

To send and receive mail, simply click the Send and Receive icon. Your letter will be sent, and the copy moved to the Sent folder. If you have more than one mail service, select Tools | Send and Receive then choose the one you want from the drop-down list, or click the small arrow next to the Send and Receive icon. By default, Outlook Express puts all mail from different POP3 services (not Hotmail) into the same Inbox.

The layout in Outlook Express 5 is controlled from the View | Layout menu. This is important. If you get a lot of "spam" (unwanted commercial email) you may want to delete it quickly, without the message being displayed in the "preview pane". You can do this by unticking the box next to "Show preview pane". This will also enable you to delete some mail messages that may otherwise try to dial out.

The Layout box also lets you decide whether or not to show contacts from the address book, which toolbars to display, and so on.

Most other settings are stored under Tools | Options, including Mail sending format. This lets you select either HTML or Plain Text as the default. HTML or "rich text" means you can use web-style formatting with different sizes, types and colours for text; you can also include images.

Unfortunately, it also means your messages will be larger and more complicated, and may arrive as an attachment the recipient cannot read.

"Netiquette" demands that you should never reply to a plain text message in HTML, or send attachments without asking first.

If you get a lot of "spam" (unwanted commercial email) you may want to delete it quickly, without the message being displayed in the "preview pane". You can do this by unticking the box next to "Show preview pane". This will also enable you to delete some mail messages that may otherwise try to dial out. The Layout box also lets you decide whether or not to show contacts from the address book, which toolbars to display, and so on. Most other settings are stored under Tools | Options, including Mail sending format. This lets you select either HTML or Plain Text as the default. HTML or "rich text" means you can use web-style formatting with different sizes, types and colours for text; you can also include images. Unfortunately, it also means your messages will be larger and more complicated, and may arrive as an attachment the recipient cannot read. "Netiquette" demands that you should never reply to a plain text message in HTML, or send attachments without asking first.

fields.headline: Reviews
fields.trailText: Webmaster | Two Fat Ladies
fields.body:
Webmaster
PC/MacIntosh £19.99 Ijsfontein/Tivola

The American journalist JC Herz cheekily claimed in her book Joystick Nation that video games were the perfect education for a generation likely to spend much of its adult life interacting in virtual spaces on the net.

At first sight, Webmaster seems a rather literal response, in that its gameplay supposedly revolves around the basics of net surfing.

Players take on the role of heroic webmaster, saving the "dream wide web" from an evil hacker. And salvation comes through clicking from site to site looking for crucial bits of information. Players can bookmark useful sites and visit discussion groups to pick up hints on how to battle the hacker and his viruses.

So should parents be queuing up to buy Webmaster in the hope that it will help them get the net and have fun at the same time? In a word, no.

Webmaster doesn't really deliver on either count. All the stuff about the web bears little relation to the real internet, and is being used (bizarrely) to make a standard point and click adventure seem glamorous.

Perhaps it will work for the game's target audience, though you wonder whether 10-12 year olds will have the patience to master the klunky interface, getting a cursor-style glove to hop back and forth.

However, they might like the mix of gameplay styles. The "sites" players visit are Myst-like locations where they pick up the cards and clues to help them through the hacker's firewalls. And to get to the sites they cruise down the "information superhighway" (honestly), where the action is more arcade-like.

Webmaster looks nice, in a Dali-does-high-tech way, and it is not without clever touches. But, overall, it feels slow and worthy. And any 10 year-old with online experience will find the web imagery cheesy. (JM)

Two Fat Ladies

Windows 95/98/Me £17.99 Sierra Home
Computers and cookery have never joined forces with completely happy results. People cook, and they read about cooking, and they watch it on TV.

But attempts to marry all three activities in multimedia form have never cut the mustard, whether Dijon or Colmans.

Two Fat Ladies is the latest failure. In essence this offers 200 recipes (some illustrated) along with tips and a glossary, 23 QuickTime videoclips from the TV series, and the MasterCook recipe-writing system.

Sadly, the parts do not match together what they did separately, in their original formats. The recipes are easier to use in book form, and the visual information in the photographs comes across more strongly in print than in the images on this CD-Rom. The video content is more edifying and informative if you watch it on TV. And MasterCook, though a powerful tool, takes a lot of dedication.

Worse still, getting from one part of the package to another can be difficult.

What made the Paterson-Dixon Wright team so engaging was its irreverent approach to cooking and its eccentricity in general. The CD gives little more than a tantalising taste of those qualities. And I can't help thinking that both of them would sneer at the MasterCook nutritional analyses, which let you sniff out every microgram of sodium and saturated fat in the dish you're thinking of cooking.

The ladies may be fat - and long may they reign in televised repeats - but the attractions here are as slender as a supermodel's ankle. Buy the books, and the videos, and maybe even MasterCook if you're ready to work hard. But this CD is something you can safely leave on the shelf. (RE)

webTitle: Obituary letters:   Anthony Bevins | Ninette de Valois

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Obituary letters:  Anthony Bevins | Ninette de Valois
fields.body:
Ben Summers writes: Anthony Bevins (obituary, March 26) always wanted the truth. When I met him on my first day in the press gallery, I was subjected to a hail of questions about myself and my ambitions which pulled the truth from me in a way which should have been intimidating, but was actually inspiring.

He turned the same terrier instinct on written sources. I remember a senior journalist entering the room once and asking him simply: "How do you get all these exclusives?" Looking up momentarily from a ream of papers, he waved his arm at the shelves stacked with letters, bills and Hansards and said: "I read!"

He always kept an eye open for young reporters who worked with him, making sure they were happy, watching over the progress of their journalism, and taking a fatherly interest in their lives. How immensely refreshing it was to realise that you didn't have to be intimidated or rattled by Bevins - you just had to tell it like it was.

Richard Glasstone writes: There is one aspect about the life of Ninette de Valois (obituary, March 9) which deserves to be more widely known: her work in Turkey. I saw at first hand something of the miracle she brought about there: a Turkish national ballet academy (with full-time dance and education training); a professional national ballet company with an international repertoire; the nurturing of indigenous Turkish choreographers, composers and designers; and the creation of a ballet audience which now supports three full-time companies and several smaller groups. All this in a country with no previous interest in ballet - arguably an even more impressive achievement than her magnificent one in Britain.

webTitle: Leader: UN observer force might have helped Middle East

fields.headline: A journey to nowhere
fields.standfirst:
Vetoed: a mission that might have helped

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Since nothing else has worked, the plan to introduce a United Nations observer force into the Occupied Territories was worth trying.
fields.body:
Since nothing else has worked, the plan to introduce a United Nations observer force into the Occupied Territories was worth trying. Such a force could not, by itself, have prevented further Palestinian-Israeli violence. Nor could it have magically created conditions for a resumption of meaningful negotiations. But it might have helped stabilise a viciously volatile situation.

Young, militant Palestinians, over whom Yasser Arafat seems to have little or no control, could have seen its advent as an achievement of sorts, in the name of all their slain brethren. An unarmed UN mission, as proposed, would hardly have compromised the Israeli defence force's military grip nor the Israeli government's territorial concerns. A compromise version of the plan was supported by Britain and France and a UN security council majority. But it will not happen. The US, urged on by Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has vetoed the resolution. In the words of its UN ambassador, James Cunningham, it did not accord with "political reality".

To which political reality does Mr Cunningham refer? The reality of a dead Jewish baby and yet another slaughtered Arab child, perhaps. They are but two of the most recent victims of the mutually enslaving carnage that joins these two peoples, like death row prisoners handcuffed at the wrist. Perhaps it is the political reality that encourages the suicide bombers of Hamas and Islamic Jihad to commit daily atrocities with the aim of driving Israel into insupportable overreaction. Or perhaps it is the political reality of the Amman Arab summit which ended yesterday and which, seen from the Arab street, once again failed to provide a strong, united lead in defending Palestinian rights.

Syria's Bashar Assad, for example, of whom much has been hoped, continues to take the easy option. Israeli society, in his refined opinion, is "more racist than the Nazis". This sort of repugnant talk may go down well with the hardliners his father coddled. But in the scales of offensive rhetoric, it merely begins to bring Mr Assad into negative balance with the reviled Mr Sharon of old. Absent from the Amman communiqué were constructive ideas about a way forward and any sense that the Arab states will apply real leverage. They have the means. But they are, as ever, too divided and weak-willed to do so.

No, the political reality to which Mr Cunningham refers is that captured by official photographers at the White House last week when Mr Sharon turned the charm on George Bush. The US veto was one result of that unequal encounter. Another is continuing American acquiescence in what UN chief Kofi Annan decries as Israel's "collective punishment" of the Palestinians. Yet another, more fundamental still, is Washington's tacit consent to allowing Mr Sharon to dictate the terms and pace of Middle East peacemaking. The "reality" is that Mr Sharon is not ready, perhaps never will be, to talk about underlying causes and long-term solutions. In the meantime, he does not want outsiders interfering. When it comes to the UN, Mr Bush is sadly burdened with similar prejudices.

Thus for all these reasons, and to the detriment of all, vital hope of progress shrivels. This is no way to proceed. It surrenders the initiative to extremists on both sides. It victimises innocents. It courts disaster, especially if Mr Sharon, emboldened by US indulgence, is led to believe that he can launch with impunity some swingeing, inflammatory retaliation for the latest attacks inside Israel. This is not political reality. It is gross political irresponsibility.

webTitle: Katinka Blackford Newman on surrendered wives

fields.headline: He who must be obeyed
fields.standfirst: Laura Doyle shot to fame for telling wives to 'surrender' to their men. New bride  Katinka Blackford Newman went to find out what it's really all about
fields.trailText: Laura Doyle shot to fame for telling wives to 'surrender' to their men. New bride Katinka Blackford Newman went to find out what it's really all about.
fields.body:
I had been married for only three months when I read an article about Laura Doyle, a housewife in Orange County, California, who claimed to have saved her marriage by "surrendering" control to her husband, John. The article surprised, shocked and intrigued me, not because my marriage needed saving quite yet but because I am a film-maker.

Her story certainly seemed bizarre, not least because Doyle describes herself as a feminist and former shrew. She claims she ended years of loneliness and misery in her marriage by a simple process. She stopped treating John like a child and telling him what to wear and what to do. She stopped criticising and nagging, handed over the finances and made herself always available for sex. As a result: "The man who had wooed me was back."

More interesting than Doyle's own marital triumph is the size of her following. When we met last year, her homespun philosophy had already reached the international press. Surrendered support circles were springing up and New York publishers Simon & Schuster were to bring out her book. Why was the world suddenly so interested in a woman whose only qualification in the field of matrimony was the unexceptional fact that she claimed to have rescued an unhappy marriage? And who seemed to be telling women to relinquish everything they had fought for?

Doyle defends herself by explaining at the outset what surrendering is not. "It's not about submissive wives, or wives obeying their husbands, or women returning to the kitchen. A surrendered wife can earn as much as or more than her husband. Surrendering doesn't mean being a doormat, it means relinquishing inappropriate control. Control is the enemy of intimacy. If you try to control your husband, you end up emasculating him. He sees you as his mother and what man wants to have sex with his mother? Marriages work best when you let the man be the man and you let him take control."

But women have been fighting for years for greater control. How can Doyle advise them to give it away?

"By giving up control, you gain power," she says simply.

Doyle does not fit my mental picture of a "surrendered wife". Throughout our first meeting, her husband jumps up and down to the buffet, getting her whatever she tells him she wants. Sometimes she doesn't even have to tell him. His greatest wish seems to be to make her happy.

It was not always the case. Both agree their marriage was on the brink of collapse. John felt he could not do anything right, so why bother trying? He sulked, while Laura saw him as incompetent and unloving. Then she decided to try something different. Why not try trust, give him the reins of control, lavish a bit of praise?

"It's about reframing," she explains. "You have a choice as to how you view things. It's about concentrating on the haves, rather than the have-nots."

Critics have accused Doyle of creating a new breed of Stepford wives, but none of the women I met was remotely brainwashed. Take Connie, Tammy and Merilee, the women we filmed at Doyle's four-week workshop. For all of them, to coin a Californian phrase, "control was an issue".

To put it bluntly, they were "ball breakers", incapable of "obeying" anyone for a day, let alone a lifetime. And this is the interesting thing: while the coverage Doyle generates tends to take a hard line - "Wives surrender all to cult of obedience" was a recent headline in the Times - the women drawn to her philosophy are for the most part successful women who display considerable control over their lives, but who clearly feel their desire to control is screwing up their relationship.

Forty-year-old Tammy constantly nags husband Ben to lose weight. He is so dispirited by her criticism that their sex life has become nonexistent. Fifty-year-old Connie runs her own company and is a self-confessed control freak. She refuses to accept that her ex-navy boyfriend Ted likes guns while she hates them. Finally there is Merilee, who continually badgers her husband for material things, even though they cannot afford them.

It would be easy to paint all three as affluent Californians jumping on the latest self-improvement bandwagon, paying their $200 to take another step down the illusory road to human perfection. But they clearly recognise Doyle's diagnosis that too much control can destroy relationships and by the end of the course, all claim to have improved theirs.

Doyle is often accused of turning back the clock, but she is not turning it back to the 50s, as her critics have said; rather she is turning it back to the early days of a relationship, to the time when you were so in love that you chose to see only the best in your partner. Of course, this works only if both parties love each other. Doyle's caveat - ignored by her critics - is that if you are with somone who is violent, an addict or a serial adulterer, not only should you not surrender, you should get out quick. But how would you realise if you were simply in the wrong relationship? Surrendering seems to imply the problem is with the woman, not with the pairing.

I have now been married for a year and people often ask if my encounter with surrendering has influenced me. The answer is, undoubtedly, yes. As the gloss of newly wedded bliss wears off, I make a conscious effort to hold on to the "in love" me and not descend to the "you can't do a thing right" me that has been the hallmark of my past relationships. I have learnt that being opinionated, bossy and belligerent does not get me far in my marriage.

I tried a modest "surrendering" experiment. I always used to moan when my husband came back late from work. Then I tried substituting "You're always late" with "I love it when you come home early". Hey presto, favourable results.

"Don't sweat the small stuff" is one of Doyle's mantras. It's not worth having a row because your partner drops wet towels on the floor. Even on the larger issues, I have found a little generosity goes a long way. The biggest test was when my husband wanted to buy a car we couldn't afford. My natural instinct would have been to fight him. This time, I did a calculation: the price of a new car in return for matrimonial harmony. The choice was obvious. I gave it my blessing. He bought the car. We were broke, but he was deliriously happy and, in turn, exceptionally nice to me. A few months later, when the house was in darkness because we could no longer afford new light bulbs, he decided to sell the car. Things have a habit of turning out OK in the end.

Since I finished filming, Doyle has become a household name in America. Surrendering has struck a chord with those out of control of their desire to control and, as a result, her book is an international bestseller and her days are packed full of media interviews.

I have no doubt surrendering has worked for Doyle and her husband - but I have no doubt it is she who wields the power in the relationship. She has transformed herself from former shrew to queen bee, but this time around, she is far too clever to let John know who is really the boss.

Surrendering is probably no more than a clever conjuring trick, an optical illusion where you juggle the reins of power and end up with the same balance. Doyle weaves her homespun advice in deliberately provocative packaging. But behind the hype and hysteria, the main principle seems to be the rather prosaic one that if you are nice to your partner, he will be nice back. Not so revolutionary and surely a message for both sexes, not just for women.

 Surrendered Wives is on Channel 4 on Sunday at 8pm.

She has transformed herself from former shrew to queen bee, but this time around, she is far too clever to let John know who is really the boss. Surrendering is probably no more than a clever conjuring trick, an optical illusion where you juggle the reins of power and end up with the same balance. Doyle weaves her homespun advice in deliberately provocative packaging. But behind the hype and hysteria, the main principle seems to be the rather prosaic one that if you are nice to your partner, he will be nice back. Not so revolutionary and surely a message for both sexes, not just for women.  Surrendered Wives is on Channel 4 on Sunday at 8pm.

webTitle: Men with cancer still won't talk about it

fields.headline: Men with cancer still won't talk about it
fields.trailText: Men suffering from cancer should not be forced to talk about their disease or "open up to their families" about it, research suggests.
fields.body:
Men suffering from cancer should not be forced to talk about their disease or "open up to their families" about it, research suggests.

Despite the growing social trend towards encouraging British men to ditch their reserve and talk more candidly about their emotions, the researchers say that it is generally healthier for men with cancer not to depart from their "emotional stereotype".

Yesterday, Clare Moynihan, of the Institute of Cancer Research, told the conference that men generally felt that being open about their illness would endanger their relationships with male family members and friends. "They felt they would make their male friends and family members uncomfortable. They were far happier being private, keeping the illness to themselves."

Forcing people to talk about the disease could only be unhealthy, she said.

But Ms Moynihan found that because communication between male family members about the illness was often minimal, there were difficulties in educating men about cancers with a genetic base, such as prostate and testicular.

The study showed that male knowledge of these cancers was extremely limited, and Ms Moynihan said men needed to be enlightened: "We must find ways of getting the word out about these genetic cancers."

webTitle: Stanley J Seeger's art collection displayed

fields.headline: Reclusive millionaire's art collection may fetch £45m at auction
fields.standfirst: Security tight for display of magnificent modern works
fields.trailText: One of the greatest private collections of 20th century art went on display in London yesterday. It includes works by Francis Bacon, Braques, Miro, Egon Schiele and Jasper Johns, and no less than three Picassos.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
One of the greatest private collections of 20th century art went on display in London yesterday.

It includes works by Francis Bacon, Braques, Miro, Egon Schiele and Jasper Johns, and no less than three Picassos.

There was heavy security at Sotheby's yesterday for the display of 130 paintings and sculptures bought over 45 years by Stanley J Seeger, an American millionaire who is described as "a very private collector".

The collection will be sold at auction in New York in May, and is valued at up to £45m. Five years ago Mr Seeger sold a part of his collection, 88 paintings, etchings and drawings by Picasso, for $20m.

Tobias Meyer, Sotheby's director of contemporary art, said: "For Stanley Seeger collecting has always been a very private pleasure.

"Assembling this magnificent group of works has been for him an exercise in scholarship and connoisseurship."

The millionaire is noted as a patron of arts and educational charities, including endowing a chair of Hellenic studies at Princeton, but is never known to have given an interview.

Some of the pictures once hung in Sutton Place, a vast Tudor mansion set in 775 acres of Surrey countryside.

Mr Seeger bought it for £8m from the estate of oil tycoon John Paul Getty in 1976, redecorated it, and hung some of his finest paintings including a Bacon triptych.

Although Mr Seeger is said to have spent almost £1m a year on maintaining the house he rarely lived there.

After 10 years he sold it to another reclusive American, Frederick Koch, who in turn redecorated the house and hung his art collection, but is said never to have spent a night under its roof before selling it for £32m two years ago.

The Seeger collection is on display at Sotheby's until tonight. The auction takes place in New York on May 8 and 9.

A self portrait by Max Beckmann, described as "an icon of 20th century art," also went on display yesterday.

Self-Portrait with Horn, which is being sold by the estate of Beckmann's patron, Stephan Lackner, was painted in Amsterdam in 1938 when the artist was in exile after being named on a Nazi list of "degenerate art".

The work is estimated at up to £7m, and will be auctioned in New York the day after the Seeger sale.

Stephane Connery, vice president of Sotheby's impressionist and modern art department, said yesterday: "It is certainly the most important German painting to come up for auction in living memory."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Couple agreed suicide pact |  Identical twin sent for trial | Train driver fired on
fields.body:
Couple agreed suicide pact

An Oxford inquest was told by a friend of Open University professor Jack Lowy, 78, and his wife Ruth, 79, that they had made a pact before taking painkillers at their home in Oxford in October. Gerald Elliott told the hearing Mrs Lowy wanted to die at the same time as her husband, who had terminal leukaemia. Verdicts: suicide.

Identical twin sent for trial

Magistrates yesterday committed Paul Dane, 21, for trial accused of aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the suicide of his identical twin, Kevin, who was found hanged in October at the Dane family's home in Carlisle. Dane was bailed to the care of a psychiatric hospital.

Train driver fired on

A freight train driver was fired on from a house while going through Maidstone in Kent. Marks were found under the cab window, apparently from airgun pellets. The train firm EWS said the driver could have been killed, and appealed for help to find the culprit.

Springsteen CD ban contested

A ban won by Bruce Springsteen on a CD of early songs was challenged in the court of appeal by Masquerade Music of London and the man behind it, Ronald Winter. In 1998 "the Boss" was awarded costs and damages, to be assessed, for breach of copyright.

Capital DJ went too far

London's Capital FM has been criticised by the broadcasting standards commission after a complaint that DJ Steve Penk told bullying victims to "pull themselves together or get a damned good thump". The station said it had spoken to the DJ.
