fields.headline: Building social capital
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee is right to give schools and other children's services a central place in the strengthening of communities (Comment, March 28).
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee is right to give schools and other children's services a central place in the strengthening of communities (Comment, March 28). I would be surprised if Professor Robert Putnam did not agree with this, since his bold case for rebuilding social capital implies developing a web of mutually reinforcing relationships. Primary schools are particularly appropriate channels for this, where parents can get to know and help each other as school supporters and adult learners, as well as mothers and fathers.

All the studies - including Putnam's own - show that education has the strongest of links with social capital.
Prof Tom Schuller
Dean, faculty of continuing education, Birkbeck College t.schuller@cems.bbk.ac.uk

 Polly Toynbee's prescription of "children's palaces" must be the right starting point for reinventing communities. Offering a range of universal services at the heart of every neighbourhood, these centres could give every child a good start in life and support their families.

We could make it happen by building on the early excellence centres, neighbourhood nurseries and Sure Start programmes that already exist. At £10bn for 10,000 children's centres, it is a small price for investing in the future.
Stephen Burke
Director, Daycare Trust stephenburke@daycaretrust.org.uk

 Local sports clubs have long been the focus of community life. At their best they can bring together all sections of a neighbourhood. Sport appeals to young people and Peter Hall's study of social capital in Britain notes that the young are least likely to be part of the civic society.

Under the championship of the sports minister, Kate Hoey, the case for a fairer tax system to support these voluntary sports clubs has at last been heard by the Treasury. Tax breaks for community amateur sports clubs will help to promote community spirit whilst helping to create clear pathways for sporting excellence.
Nigel Hook
Central Council of Physical Recreation nhook@ccpr.org.uk

 I have lived in two deprived areas for over 25 years. From door knocking, public meetings and membership of community groups, my experience is that residents mostly opt for youth clubs and holidays.

But this is just two communities. If "empowerment" - to use a Blair word - means anything, it means giving locally controlled community groups the resources to develop what they want, be it cafes, food coops, credit unions, play schemes or whatever. It will entail residents doing it over a long period not a three-year fix by outsiders.
Bob Holman
Glasgow

 So, yet another government initiative to "push up pre-school standards" (Pre-school groups to get star ratings, March 27). When are the powers that be going to leave us to get on with the job? Over the past six years we have embraced, amongst other things, funding for three and four-year-olds, Ofsted inspections, and the European working directive with its huge financial implications for voluntary groups, revised qualification standards, early school entry and more, all in the name of standard raising.

The trouble is, most of us are so busy coping with the paperwork, that we have almost forgotten why we do the job for such paltry pay. Please, Mr Blair, just leave us alone for a couple of years; you might be surprised at the standards we achieve.
Margaret Collins
St John's Pre-school
Orpington, Kent
Margaret.Collins@care4free.net

fields.headline: Country matters
fields.trailText: The Lords' rejection of the "middle way" solution to the hunting issue may not be all it seems (Peers reject fox hunting ban, March 27). Peter Luff and others shouldn't treat this as defeat, rather their best chance yet of being the architects of a sensible conclusion.
fields.body:
The Lords' rejection of the "middle way" solution to the hunting issue may not be all it seems (Peers reject fox hunting ban, March 27). Peter Luff and others shouldn't treat this as defeat, rather their best chance yet of being the architects of a sensible conclusion. Most peers who voted for "supervision" did so on the proviso this was only a start. A framework upon which many of the sensible middle-way concepts can be attached. If allowed to run its course, the final outcome will reflect much of their work. They should be congratulated for introducing an air of sense to an often too emotional debate, for now the government has been presented with the best chance yet to show leadership and good sense.

There is now a middle ground between the two houses, free from party pressure, which the government should claim. The pro-hunt peers have hinted, wisely, that they could be moved towards it, whereas their opponents, thoughtlessly, will settle for nothing less than a total ban. The manifesto must not add insult to rural injury with talk of a ban. It should commit the next government to resolve this issue by way of completing the job the Lords started on Monday. Then and only then should those who wish to retain the right to hunt settle for what would then be a workable middle way.
Lindsay Hill
Union of Country Sports Workers

 Your call (Leaders, March 27) for a new ministry of food and rural affairs may be worth considering. But the priority right now must be to defeat this terrible disease. Generalised criticism of Maff will not help the morale of its hard-pressed staff, who have helped keep this country free of foot and mouth disease for over 30 years.
Mark Serwotka
General secretary-elect, Public and Commercial Services Union

webTitle: Letters:   Institute for Animal Health  gives its advice openly

fields.headline: Our institute gives its advice openly
fields.trailText: In your March 20 edition you ran a report concerning vaccination against foot and mouth disease. In it you quoted an anonymous source whom you described as "one of Britain's most prominent vets who has close association with the world foot and mouth centre in Pirbright", implying that he or she was writing with the authority of this institute's Pirbright laboratory.
fields.body:
In your March 20 edition you ran a report concerning vaccination against foot and mouth disease. In it you quoted an anonymous source whom you described as "one of Britain's most prominent vets who has close association with the world foot and mouth centre in Pirbright", implying that he or she was writing with the authority of this institute's Pirbright laboratory.

The Pirbright laboratory conducts internationally recognised research on foot and mouth disease, provides the statutory diagnostic service for the UK and Eire and hosts the world reference laboratory and international vaccine bank for foot and mouth disease. This institute has a long-standing policy of open and attributed publication of our work and openly provides advice to governments and the public around the world, based on the experience gained from working with the virus and the disease it causes. No member of this institute's staff would seek to hide behind the cloak of anonymity; all our publications would identify and credit our staff as an author.

It is essential that the public is properly informed about all sides of the debate on how to control foot and mouth disease effectively and vaccination is an important and accepted tool in this process.

In my view, the arguments in favour of vaccination put forward by your anonymous source would have carried greater authority had your readers been able to judge the credentials and interests of their originator.
Prof CJ Bostock
Institute for Animal Health

webTitle: Letters: There is no conspiracy against Israel

fields.headline: There is no conspiracy against Israel
fields.trailText: The fact that anti-semitism is wicked, pointless and self-defeating does not deter those such as Simon Sebag Montefiore (an author who has my great admiration as an historian) who claims that balanced coverage of Israel is seldom heard in Britain (Anti-semites really exist, March 28).
fields.body:
The fact that anti-semitism is wicked, pointless and self-defeating does not deter those such as Simon Sebag Montefiore (an author who has my great admiration as an historian) who claims that balanced coverage of Israel is seldom heard in Britain (Anti-semites really exist, March 28).

I have had business interests in the Middle East for many years, I often travel to Israel and the West Bank, and I am in contact with journalists, aid workers and UN officials there. I can state categorically that all those whom I have met, who have come to work on the West Bank with an open mind, or even, like me, with some prejudice in favour of Israel, leave with disgust and rage at Israeli brutality, racism and hypocrisy. Some are Jewish. It is experience on the spot that leads them to this perception. So while I cannot absolutely deny the existence of the anti-semitic conspiracy perceived by Sebag Montefiore, I can, I believe, absolutely refute that its influence is critical, or even perceptible.

What he calls "the fashionable menu of shameful lies" about Israel, seems to me truthful, but seldom to go far enough. He says the Guardian "leans towards the Israel-phobic"; but to me, it seems never to address adequately the justice (or the tragedy) of the Palestinian position, or the frightening racism that seems to me to be at the core of Israeli arguments and actions. Far from there being a conspiracy against Israel, I would suggest that Israel may be saved from pariah status in this country and economic boycott, only by reluctance to recognise that yesterday's victims may now be of quite another stripe.
Nicholas Vester
London nicholas@crewster.demon.co.uk

 Once again Jonathan Freedland's scrupulously liberal judgments cloud his opinions on Palestinian resistance (Comment, 28 March). To say that it is useless to resist a militaristic, imperial power that is illegally and immorally occupying your land is to give in to the "might is right" mentality. The Palestinian anti-colonial struggle is deeply flawed and often horribly violent, but one must focus on the root of injustice. "Terrorism" doesn't exist in a vacuum.
Sameer Rahim
Cambridge

fields.headline: Verdict on Sven's men
fields.trailText:
David Seaman 6/10
(Arsenal)
A bored spectator until Vata's shot, spilled across the goal-line, woke him up 10 minutes into the second half.
fields.body:
David Seaman 6/10
(Arsenal)
A bored spectator until Vata's shot, spilled across the goal-line, woke him up 10 minutes into the second half.

Gary Neville 8/10
(Manchester United)
Solid, dependable and a willing, mobile outlet down the flank while other England players were too static.

Rio Ferdinand 6/10
(Leeds United)
Looked more comfortable in the air, where he was utterly dominant, than when the ball was buzzing around his feet. Generally tidy.

Sol Campbell 6/10
(Tottenham)
A well-timed interception on Igli Tare and some booming headed clearances had set the tone before a twisted ankle ended his outing.

Ashley Cole 7/10
(Arsenal)
He may be defensively raw, but the debutant was always keen to tear forward, even if he provoked anxiety on the bench by dribbling past two attackers in his own area. Too often his final ball disappointed, but one long pass to McManaman smacked of pure quality.

David Beckham 7/10
(Manchester United)
As ever, his crossing created England's best chances and he saw two trademark free-kicks well saved.

Paul Scholes 8/10
(Manchester United)
One of his quieter performances in a congested midfield, although he flickered into life in the second half with a potent pass for Owen's goal and a well-taken second.

Nicky Butt 4/10
(Manchester United)
Some rugged challenges and a spirited early burst forward suggested much, but he slipped into the humdrum as the visitors lost all rhythm. His passing disintegrated, although he might have won a penalty on the hour.

Steve McManaman 4/10
(Real Madrid)
With so little possession down the left, he drifted in-field in search of the ball but remained peripheral and was withdrawn at half-time.

Michael Owen 7/10
(Liverpool)
Had such an anonymous start that it took a brace of runs from the deep, spurred by fleet-footed turns, to remind everyone he was playing. Latched on to Scholes's pass and took his chance well.

Andy Cole 6/10
(Manchester United)
Fluffed an early half-chance and was too static for much of the first half, but kept trying and in the end it turned out to be 13th cap lucky.

fields.headline: Scholes puts snap into England
fields.standfirst:
Rraklli 90 | Owen 73, Scholes 85, Cole 90
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText:
It wasn't pretty but England did what they had to last night courtesy of goals from Michael Owen, Paul Scholes and a relieved Andy Cole. David Lacey reports.
Verdict on Sven's men
World Cup round-up
fields.byline: David Lacey at the Qemal Stafa stadium
fields.body:
England may yet get to next year's World Cup in the Far East, but at the moment their journey is alternating dizzily between jumbo jet and Chinese junk.

Last night's victory over Albania means that in the space of five days Sven-Goran Eriksson has achieved maximum points from his two qualifiers to repair much of the damage caused by Germany's 1-0 win at Wembley last October.

Yet comfort was hardly a word which sprang readily to mind for much of the match as England consistently failed to produce the pace, accuracy and above all the imagination to break down a resolute and disciplined Albanian defence.

Not until the 73rd minute, by which time a check on the pre sent suicide rate among Swedes would not have gone amiss, did Paul Scholes and Michael Owen produce the element of surprise so badly lacking hitherto.

Owen scored his 10th goal for England, and Scholes netted his 11th soon afterwards. That seemed to be game over but in stoppage-time an Albania substitute, Altin Rraklli, exploited a mistake by Rio Ferdinand to get one back and less than a minute later had a second flagged offside.

As missiles began to rain down from the stands Emile Heskey, who had replaced Steve McManaman at half-time, set up a long-overdue landmark, namely Andy Cole's first goal for England in his 13th international.

"At least now no one will write that it was six years since he has scored," Eriksson said later. "Now the ice is broken, and he played very well."

The striker's moment, however, was immediately lost in confusion as Ashley Cole, joining in the celebrations, ended his first senior England appearance by being struck on the head by a lipstick. The Arsenal defender did not look seriously hurt but the incident gave the evening a sour, if cosmetic, ending and another complaint to Fifa, to add to that from the Under-21 game, will ensue.

England could not have complained had they been denied the win which had appeared beyond them for much of the game. Until Owen scored, the Albanian goalkeeper Foto Strakosha had been disturbed only by a couple of David Beckham free-kicks.

Albania, meanwhile, several times threatened to produce the sort of attacking pressure which might have produced a major upset if they had pressed home with greater conviction.

As it was, Eriksson's team sometimes experienced difficulty in tracking down Alban Bushi, whose angled runs with the ball several times threatened to expose England at the back. In addition the frequent interchanges of position by Bushi, Igli Tare and Bledar Kola confused a defence deprived of Sol Campbell when the centre-back limped off after 28 minutes.

For all that, Albania disturbed the equilibrium of David Seaman only once, and that was when Fatmir Vata awoke uncomfortable memories of Dietmer Hamann's winner for Germany by firing in a speculative shot from 30 yards which skidded in front of the goalkeeper. This time Seaman managed a fumbling save.

Eriksson's team is nowhere near to fruition. The coach is trying to leave the players alone as much as possible, making changes which are really adjustments. Last night, for example, Ashley Cole was preferred to Chris Powell because the Charlton defender had at times looked out of his depth in Saturday's 2-1 win over Finland at Anfield.

Eriksson's faith in Andy Cole was eventually repaid and the Manchester United striker again did much off the ball that was admirable. Yet his failure to cause Geri Cipi and the other defenders more problems still posed questions about his true international quality. As it is Eriksson will have to find an alternative for England's qualifier in Greece on June 6, as Cole collected his second World Cup booking and will miss the Athens game.

England had to win last night and no messing. Sir Norman Wisdom might have provided the comic relief at half-time but nobody was ever going to augh off failure to beat Albania. For a time, nevertheless, they were too inclined to give the ball away and final passes were poor.

Again Eriksson sacrificed McManaman, who early on had combined promisingly on the left with Ashley Cole, in order to introduce Heskey's weight and pace. Heskey spent most of the second half on the left but achieved little until he set up Andy Cole's goal.

Owen, who had played off Andy Cole against Finland, seemed less inclined to go deep last night. Maybe he was obeying instructions; either way it made life easier for Albania's defenders, though it eventually did get England off the hook.

A ball inside from Gary Neville, an exquisite touch by Scholes, and there was Owen haring to beat Strakosha. The next goal was equally astute, owing much to Andy Cole's surge on the left after which he smartly switched the ball back from the goalline for Scholes to thrust into the net.

Rraklli's goal punished an error by Ferdinand and Andy Cole scored while Albania were grumbling about the one they lost through offside. England might well have come away singing Lipstick on your Collar. Certainly their make-up is still a bit messy.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Albania (3-5-2): Strakosha; Fakaj, Cipi, Xhumba; Lala, Hasi, Kola, Bellai, F Vata; Bushi,Tare.

England (4-4-2): Seaman; G Neville, Ferdinand, Campbell (Brown, 29), Ashley Cole; Beckham, Butt, Scholes, McManaman (Heskey, h-t); Andy Cole, Owen (Sheringham, 84).

Referee : A Hamer (Luxembourg).

webTitle: Cole climbs out of deep hole

fields.headline: Cole climbs out of deep hole
fields.trailText: Richard Williams watches Ashley Cole receive a baptism of fire and runs the rule of England's performance.
fields.body:
The most emphatic advice given to a visitor to Tirana is to watch out for the manholes, which tend not to have covers and make the city's pavements something of a hazard for those who choose to wander after dark. Chris Powell, the fairytale hero of Sven-Goran Eriksson's first selection, was the first to disappear without trace last night, before the match had even kicked off.

It was probably Mika Nurmela, his direct opponent last Saturday, who did the most damage to Powell's immediate chances of adding to his two international caps. Having mastered the far more highly rated Gaizka Mendieta on his debut in the friendly against Spain, the Charlton left-back was rocked only three minutes into the match at Anfield when Nurmela dived in and dispossessed him. Powell won the ball back, but the incident seemed to have unsettled him, or perhaps merely reminded of his comparatively humble background, and he never looked like making the sort of adventurous overlapping runs that had been a feature of his performance at Villa Park.

So the sight of Ashley Cole in the No3 jersey represented another indication of Eriksson's ability to take the adventurous option, as long as one discounted the possibility that the inclusion of a second A Cole was designed to take the pressure off the first. Unlike Powell, whose honest astonishment at his original inclusion was a delight to everyone, the 20-year-old Arsenal defender clearly believes that a place in the England starting line-up is part of his destiny.

His introduction to life as a senior international showed him that nothing can be assumed at this level. The ball went straight to him from the kick-off, and he was in possession several times in the opening minutes, but the Albanians were of a mind to make it as hard as possible for him to forge a partnership with Steve McManaman, and there were several nervous moments.

A sinuous run past Cipi and Hasi across the edge of the Albanian penalty area was spoiled by an inaccurate pass, but an early ball into McManaman's path demonstrated the potential offered by his attacking instincts. His defensive uncertainties were more clearly to the fore, however, as the hosts began to exert sustained pressure on England.

Encouraged by their team's performance against Germany at the weekend, the 18,000 Albanian supporters were in full cry, cheering every success, great and small, and taking understandable delight in any sign of an error by their gilded visitors.

Albania is known to its inhabitants as Shqiperia, which means "land of eagles", and the crimson flag with the double-headed eagle was flying proudly as they approached half-time not only keeping England at bay but looking quite as likely to score as the representatives of one of the world's richest leagues.

Sol Campbell was the next to disappear down the manhole, leaving England with a back four featuring three young and inexperienced defenders, each of whom was facing the fiercest test in a match of such importance. Once again, Eriksson had to be complimented on his willingness to take the brave option by putting his trust in the untested flair of youth.

For the second match in succession Emile Heskey arrived in place of McManaman. Unlike the Finland match, in which he went to the right wing in a 4-3-3, this time he took up a station on the left side of a four-man midfield, perhaps with the idea of restricting the good work being done on that side of the field for Albania by Altin Lala and Fatmir Vata. But the danger persisted, Vata coming closer than anyone on either side to scoring in the first hour when he fastened on to a loose ball and saw his 30-yard drive bounce off David Seaman's chest.

England's moves had the greater silkiness and sophistication, but their inability to penetrate was becoming a source of frustration while Albania were gaining in confidence, with the combination of Alban Bushi and Igli Tare presenting the classic threat associated with the combination of a target man and a terrier.

Michael Owen and Andy Cole produced neat runs and touches, but for a long time all their best work was being done outside the Albanian penalty area.

As with Saturday's match, it was Owen who made the breakthrough, reacting with a familiar sureness of touch when Paul Scholes emerged from obscurity to produce a shrewd little pass which allowed the Liverpool man to spin off his marker and give England a lead that they scarcely deserved but which the Albanians seemed to accept.

Andy Cole deserved to break his duck particularly after the clever run and cutback with which he laid on the second goal for Scholes.

Eriksson would probably say that he doesn't care who scores as long as England win, but there is certainly some scope left for creative thinking before England resume their World Cup odyssey against the Greeks in June.
